Title: Exploring the Magic of Prague: 10 Must-Do Things on Your Trip

Prague, capital of the Czech Republic and home to 1.3 million people. A wonderful place, that offers tourists from all over the world the chance to discover. From cultinary adventures over historic sites to cultural exhibits, Prague is offering from a wide spectrum of activities. So most likely, the challenge will be what acitivity you will decide for during your stay. I went there this year in May 2023 for about a week. This guide is to help you make a more sophisticated choice. To get an overview of the city, we need to talk about the city layout first.
Prague, or Praha in Czech, consists of several zones, ranging from Zone 1 to 22. The city center is in Praha 1 and the surrounding zones. Most of the things that I did have been in Zone 1, 2, 5 and 6. You can easily travel through these zones with the metro system or walk. So I‚Äôd recommend to get an accomodation in one of these zones for convenience. If you haven‚Äôt any, I have one recommendation for you.
I recommend to stay with Vladimir, who offers a few rooms on AirBnB in zone 6. You will get the most bang for your buck. The room has access to a kitchen, laundry machine and is located right next to the metro station, which is just 5 minutes to the centre. A perfect headquarter to deal with all the high priority missions during your stay in Prague. If you fancy something more high-end like a hotel, there are plenty of locations to choose from. I suggest you look for a hotel in some of the zones close to the city center.
Great! You have a basic knowledge about the geographics of Prague and hopefully your accomodation is set. Next, let‚Äôs check out what we can do. I will introduce the most exciting activities I did during my stay in Prague, and I‚Äôm sure, at least one of them will catch your interest. You can get the location of all activities on the map below. The number corresponds to the number besides the activity in this blog. Activity 10 is secret till the end. So let‚Äôs not waste time and dive right into it!
If you didn‚Äôt go to Wenceslas Square, also called V√°clav√°k, then you haven‚Äôt been to Prague! It‚Äôs the city center and where you will see a huge crowd. It‚Äôs a great starting point for any tour, just get off the Metro station M≈Østek, and you can easily discover cultural sites by foot from Wenceslas Square. I definitely recommend to explore the alleys and site streets by foot, because you can discover all those hidden gems easily. For example the Slight Uncertainty by Czech Sculptor Michal Trpak is just a short walk from Wenceslas Square. It‚Äôs located right in front of the Mosaic House. It‚Äôs also a great place to exchange money, since you always want to have some cash on you, even though I have noticed that many locals like to pay with credit card.
One of the iconic sites of Prague is the Charles Bridge, spanning across the Vltava, the longest river in the whole country. There will be plenty of people testing the durability of the Charles Bridge, which has been finished in the year 1402, after 45 years of construction: a testimony to medieval construction skills. Walking across the Charles Bridge, you will meet many small souvenir vendors, sculptures and artists. If you find yourself in the lesser town, it brings us right to the next mission: walking up to the Castle.
Walking up from the Mal√° Strana (english: lesser Town), which starts on the west side of Charles Bridge, you can already see the famous Prague Castle. It‚Äôs a huge complex with many historical buildings on its premise. One that needs to be mentioned besides the castle itself is the St. Vitus Cathedral, which can be visited anytime, but it will be free during the official church service on Sundays.
One of my favorite restaurants in Prague has been the U Glaubic≈Ø. This restaurant has been there since the 16th century and offers some of the cheapest beers. You can get half liter of beer for around 1.5 $ in 2023. I even met Vladimir (my landlord) here, who is a local. And there was another tourist whom I talked to, that came here everyday to eat their roasted duck. Definitely a great sign. I went there with my dad, check out the image below. Can you see a crazy Person? That‚Äôs my dad.
You will have to wait though, since this place is very popular, so it might be best to make a booking or to avoid peak times. I recommend to try any of the local foods, but my favorites are the pork knuckle, the beef tartar and the radish-kraut-salad. After having tried some food in Czech Republic, the food to me feels like a mix of Italian, Barvarian and Austrian cuisine. Meatlovers will be on cloud nine.
Every hour on the hour, the Prague astronomical clock at the Old Town Hall in Prague starts moving. The mechanism is highly complex and has been first built in the 1400th. Figures will show up from the windows. There is also a small skeleton that is ringing a bell, besides other figures, that stand for the sins that humans fall for. Each figure stands for one of the following: narcissism, greed and hedony. The guy with the mirror stands for narcissim. The person with the money bag stands for greed. The person with the instrument stands for hedony. I wouldn‚Äôt know this if we didn‚Äôt get a tour by my friend Greg. So, if you are interested in some more background knowledge, it might be worthwile getting a tour guide. It is one of the most visited places in Prague and you will surely face a huge crowd.
If you want to see some cute furballs, you can head to Libe≈àsk√Ω and St≈ôeleck√Ω islands. These islands are home to Nutria, which belong to the family of mammals. However, as cute as they might be, they are rodents and have brought up the same problems as rats do. They transmit diseases and do damage the infrastructure. They have risen fast in their population count due to oversupply of food. Many tourists love to feed them, but I would highly advocate against it. Watching them and enjoying the view can be just as good.
I could recommend you to go to one of the biggest clubs in Europe, since there is this place in Prague that claims to be the biggest one. The place consists of multiple dance floors, where each floor comes with its own style of music. It‚Äôs called Karlovy l√°znƒõ (in case you want to go anyway). But sometimes, the best things are those that speak for themselves. Similar to a best-selling author, who is the best at marketing and selling his product. That doesn‚Äôt mean that the author‚Äôs style of writing is best. Same it is with this endeavor and I was lucky to run into it. If you walk in Letna Park during the night, you will find one place, where people set up a rave and come to dance. It‚Äôs a great vibe and you will have a great view over Prague.
What is great about Prague is the manifold of Parks that you can discover. There is Letna Park, Folimanka Park or Riegrovy Park. But my favorite park were the Petrin Gardens. You can go there and hike up all the way up to find something that looks like the Czech version of the Eiffeltower in Paris. And when you are up there, you will have a wonderful view down on Prague. You will be able to see most of the sites that I have described above.
The National Technical Museum of Prague is located right besides Letna Park. It‚Äôs home to a big collection of airplanes, bicycles and vehicles. It‚Äôs great for all tech-fans. There are english descriptions. I‚Äôll leave this to yourself to discover.
My last advice is to just explore the city and take in the great vibes. It‚Äôs always an adventure for me to discover a new place. Figure out how to get best from A to B, where to find the best food or discover those hidden gems, that haven‚Äôt received too much attention, but are special and interesting to you personally. For myself, I fell in love with those many street art and street sculptures, as e.g. the one below. With this last shot from Prague, I‚Äôll leave you hanging right here.
It‚Äôs time to say Ahoj(Czech for Goodbye) for now. I really enjoyed my trip to Prague and am happy to share my experience. Prague is a gem in the center of Europe and a great city to visit. Prague offers defty food, a fascinating historical culture and lots of arts for curious travelers. I hope, you found at least one thing that you want to do during your next trip to Prague. I‚Äôd appreciate a virtual hand for that! If you want to stay tuned and discover other travel gems around Europe and the world with me, follow me right here or connect with me on LinkedIn to not miss out on future blogs. I also write about tech, food and some of my other hobbies.

Title: 5 Reasons to Visit the City of Prague

When you think about your top ten places to visit in Europe, which cities come to mind? Maybe wandering around the streets of Paris sounds like a dream come true? Or perhaps sightseeing in the historical city of Rome? Why not enjoy the beautiful beaches Santorini has to offer?
Europe definitely has plenty of great travel destinations, but most people wouldn‚Äôt think to visit the city of Prague. Nestled in the Czech Republic, right smack in the middle of Europe, surrounded by Germany, Poland, and Austria, Prague is a city worth visiting at least once during your next trip to Europe, and here‚Äôs why:
If you didn‚Äôt know, Prague is an undeniably beautiful city. It‚Äôs an incredible city with so much culture and history. There is a bridge that connects the Old Town with the Lesser Town (not any less beautiful, however) and everywhere you look, whether it‚Äôs the cobblestone strees or the medieval architecture, it‚Äôs enough to make anyone fall in love with the city.
Are you a John Lennon fan? There‚Äôs a literal wall in Prague dedicated to him. Do you want to see the narrowest street of Prague? Vin√°rna ƒåertovka is so narrow it even requires a traffic light to prevent pedestrian traffic jams.
Or perhaps The Metamorphosis is one of your favorite novellas, and you‚Äôre a major fan of Franz Kafka? You‚Äôd be delighted to know there‚Äôs a moving statue of him right outside Quadrio Shopping Centre! If you‚Äôre more into chapels and Prague‚Äôs rich history, the stained glass of St. Vitus Cathedral is sure to leave you breathless.
I was a broke grad student when I visited Prague. I couldn‚Äôt afford to live in the finest hotels or dine at the best restaurants. I did, however, live in a more than sufficient Airbnb for a very reasonable price. Even though Prague is not only the capital, but also the largest city of Czech Republic, it is still affordable for those who don‚Äôt have that much to spend, or frankly want to spend that much. You‚Äôll get a lot of bang for your buck; it‚Äôll be enough for the Airbnb, food, and a lot of fun sightseeing, touristy things.
I‚Äôm using the term ‚Äòinteresting‚Äô because I‚Äôm aware that the food may not be for everyone. There‚Äôs meat, meat, and more meat. I, for one, enjoyed the food thoroughly, and ate until I was very full every meal. For carnivores, the food option is considered pretty diverse. In addition to chicken, beef, and pork, there‚Äôs boar, venison, and even rabbit. I‚Äôm personally a big fan of the Goulash, or Gul√°≈°, as the Czechs call it. The meat is tender, the potatoes are crispy, and the flavor is rich. To top it all off, there‚Äôs plenty of beer and delicious desserts to go along with it.
I remember people didn‚Äôt give me weird stares as I walked around the streets of Prague. As a POC, it is not uncommon to be looked at a certain way in Europe. Having traveled a bit in Europe, I‚Äôve had my fair share of strange stares because of my skin color. And trust me, it‚Äôs not something that goes unnoticed when you‚Äôre on the receiving end. In Prague, however, I felt that people were generally friendly. We were greeted in restaurants, just like our fair-skinned counterparts. It might also be worth mentioning that I had a roommate from Prague, and she was an absolute sweetheart.
There you have it. Five reasons to visit an absolute gem of a city. The next time you go to Europe, don‚Äôt sleep on Prague. Hopefully, you‚Äôve been convinced to visit this amazing city nestled right in the heart of Europe. I had a great time in Prague and would go back in a heartbeat. It‚Äôs definitely worth Czech-ing out!

Prague, in my opinion, is known by most people and has amazing sound even abroad. I don‚Äôt know about overseas, but when I‚Äôve talked to people from different parts of Europe on my travels, everyone knows Prague. But Prague is not only the historical center, but it also has many other amazing parts and that‚Äôs why today I would like to show you one cool place to relax after a hard day or to get away from the busy life in the capital of the Czech Republic.
The place is called the Wild Sarka Valley and is located in the north of Prague. It is a gorge between two rocks, with a trail along the Litovick√Ω Brook. For me, it is worth staying up there and going to a place called ‚ÄúNebusicka vyhlidka‚Äù. Hustopeƒçe and finally this year the calendar allowed me to go there.
This is the rock from which you can see the rest of the valley and it is the place for sunrise and sunset. It‚Äôs relatively quiet except for the planes flying by, as the site is close to the main airport.

Content:

This October was pretty awesome for me because I got to try out lots of new things.
The month began with a visit to a country known for its rich history and captivating beauty: the Czech Republic.
I spent four days in the capital city, Prague, and instantly fell in love with it. Prague charmed me with its historical significance, picturesque cobblestone streets, and the vibrant colors of autumn that painted the city.
The iconic Charles Bridge spanning the Vltava River stood as a testament to Prague‚Äôs beauty and heritage. Even in the crisp October weather, the city was teeming with tourists.
Let me tell you a little secret ‚Äî Prague has some of the best and most affordable food in Europe. I‚Äôve been living in Germany for nearly two years, but I‚Äôve never tasted food as good as what I had in the Czech Republic. They really know how to cook. They have this famous dessert called Chimneys, which is like the crunchiest cone you‚Äôve ever had, and they come in all sorts of flavors. And their colorful macarons are giving France a run for its money.
Few reasons that made Prague stand out for me:
1. English Everywhere: The best part? Everyone speaks English, so you don‚Äôt have to worry about translations. I know, many of you will think, is this even a criteria! Everyone speaks English nowadays. But trust me, it‚Äôs a huge criteriaspecially when you are travelling to non-English speaking countries in Europe.
2. Friendly People: The folks in Czech are super nice. No matter how beautiful a place is, if the people aren‚Äôt friendly, it can ruin your experience. But the Czechs have big hearts, helpful and a pinch of humor as well.
3. Rich History: Prague is a fantastic mix of culture, heritage, and history. Don‚Äôt forget to catch the military parade at Prague Castle before noon.
4. Food: Obviously, when you‚Äôre traveling, you walk a lot, get tired, and want some good food. Prague has you covered with loads of options. They even have healthy stuff like salads, juices, and green shakes for health conscious travellers. My favorite places for a quick bite were Bageterie Boulevard and Salatarie ‚Äî they have amazing bread.
5. Shopping: We all know how expensive touristy places can be. But in the center of Prague, there‚Äôs a shop called ‚ÄòThe Half Price‚Äô that‚Äôs pretty reasonable. You‚Äôll find all sorts of good brands, and even luxury items at affordable prices.
Hidden Gem ‚Äî Cesky Krumlov: If you‚Äôre up for a short journey from Prague, visit Cesky Krumlov. It‚Äôs like something out of a fairy tale, and it‚Äôs only a few hours away. The town is surrounded by a river in the shape of a ‚ÄòC,‚Äô and it has a beautiful castle and cute souvenir shops. You can easily spend 5‚Äì6 hours here, just taking in the magic and relaxing.
As a fun fact, Prague‚Äôs Astronomical Clock was named Europe‚Äôs fourth most hyped place in 2022/23. While it‚Äôs undeniably beautiful and impressive, it may be somewhat overhyped compared to its extraordinary popularity.
Tip: If you are visiting any historical places, I will always recommend to book a tour guide. All the sculptures, castles and churches has a great historical significance and a tourist guide can help you to know it and much more. While the famous company‚Äôs tours are very expensive, Prague has some local tour guides which are free (technically you have to pay them according to you wish) and very affordable and given by local people. So do check those out.
So, that‚Äôs my Prague adventure from a different perspective than your usual travel guide. If you plan to visit this lovely country, definitely check out these places and restaurants, and don‚Äôt forget to wear something colorful to match the picturesque surroundings. üåû
Happy travelling!!!üåª

Title: What to do in Prague, Czech Republic: a guide to must-Czech-out sights, bites & libations
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

Travel. Food. Photography.

--
Listen
Share
When I visited Prague in the summer of 2017 during my 35 day backpacking trip through Spain, Portugal, and central Europe, I was absolutely smitten.
72 hours in Prague gave me (and 2 of my dear friends) a taste of the city. And yes, by taste, I do mean we had a few bites to eat while meandering through the cobblestone streets‚Ä¶
Among all the historical charm, Prague is also a modern and vibrant city full of energy, music, and people who know a good time.
Read on to share in some of my Prague highlights.
Enjoy!
In every new city I visit, I personally love spending 1.5‚Äì2 hours of my first morning on a walking tour. It‚Äôs the perfect way to get a lay of the land and also learn more about the city‚Äôs rich history.
In Europe, Sandeman‚Äôs New Europe tours is typically my go-to, simply because they have a good reputation for knowledgable yet charming tour guides who know how to tell a great story. It‚Äôs super simple to register a few days before your preferred date and they‚Äôre donation-based, so you only tip if you think they did a good job. Which they always do.
The Prague tour started in the Old Town Square where we admired one of the oldest astronomical clocks in the world: Prague Astronomical Clock, Orlaj. This clock not only measure the minutes and hours with its distinctive hand in the shape of the sun, but also tracks the days of the week, month, year, and zodiacal ring showing the path of the sun and moon through the sky (i.e., ‚ÄúStar time‚Äù). It‚Äôs currently under major renovation, and is expected to complete by the end of October 2018.
During the tour, we also visited the Jewish Quarter and other historical landmarks.
Charles Bridge was completed in 1390, but only took Charles‚Äô name in the 19th century ‚Äî it was originally known simply as Kamenn√Ω most aka Stone Bridge (lol). You can take a walk on this bridge, or if you want a view OF the bridge itself, you can walk along the river or across any of the parallel bridges.
Because it‚Äôs at the top of every Prague visitor‚Äôs must-see list, if you want to have it all to yourself, you‚Äôll have to visit at night or very early in the morning (i.e., at sunrise). Hint: perhaps before or after your night out clubbing?
Pra≈æsk√Ω Hrad, Kajet√°nka, Hradƒçansk√© n√°m., 118 00 Mal√° Strana, Czechia
Of course, Prague Castle is a must visit while in Prague (as it‚Äôs a UNESCO World Heritage site and the largest coherent castle complex in the world ‚Äî more than 750,000 square feet).
However, after you trek up to visit the castle, be sure to swing by this Starbucks before winding your way back down the hill. You‚Äôll be rewarded with a veranda with the most beautiful views over the city of Prague.
Situated within the walls of the Strahov Monastery are two of the most magnificent library halls, dating back to the 17th century: Theological Hall and Philosophical Hall. If my college‚Äôs library looked like this, maybe I would have hit up the library more often. Just sayin‚Äô.
In addition to the entrance fee, you‚Äôll need to purchase a photo pass to take photos, but hey gotta support the cause, right?
After, we grabbed a few beers from the Strahov Monastic Brewery. I don‚Äôt typically drink beer, but even I conceded and gave them a thumbs up. This microbrewery serves up some delicious staples as well as a few seasonal beers. Super charming ambiance and a good time!
After John Lennon‚Äôs murder in 1980, he became a pacifist hero for many young Czechs. The wall first started with a painting of Lennon along with political graffiti and Beatles lyrics.
While authorities initially repeatedly tried whitewashing the walls, they have since bowed to the inevitable, and the wall is now a symbol of global ideals of love and peace. Quite romantic.
The late Anthony Bourdain went so far as to describe Czech Republic as ‚Äúthe land that vegetables forgot‚Äù. Meat lovers, rejoice!
What better place to grab lunch than at this old butcher shop, where they source meat directly from farms around Czech Republic who raise the animals, including Prestice pigs (an old Czech breed of pigs). Na≈°e Maso, I want mas.
If you‚Äôre not looking to buy a raw hunk of meat to cook on your own, you can order and eat there like we did. The menu consists mainly of burgers and sausages, with a beef tartare dish, meat loaf and some cold cuts for good measure. But you can also order anything on display and they‚Äôll cook it right up for you.
Prague‚Äôs classic lunchtime favorite is chleb√≠cky aka an ‚Äúopen-faced sandwich‚Äù
Bistro Sisters makes a very modernized, elevated version of it. The flavor combinations displayed in the beautiful case are so well thought out. They were almost too pretty to eat, but surprise, they taste good too! So I had every last bite.
Tbh I don‚Äôt remember what this place was called, but that pork knuckle was sow delicious. And alarmingly big. Who knows, this was probably a ‚Äútourist trap‚Äù, but I didn‚Äôt care. You know why? Because I felt like a barbarian and loved it.
Cafe Savoy serves famous Czech classics such as pork schnitzel, as well as some beautiful basic brunches (from what I could tell from IG). The restaurant was recently renovated, yet still has its Neo-Renaissance feel.
I went for after-dinner desserts. Among other goodies, we tried the Makov√Ω kol√°ƒçek aka poppy seed cake. Was pleasantly surprised to find that the sweets here are not as cloyingly sweet as the ones we have in the States.
In the blazing summer heat, identifying a good gelato shop is critical to survival.
When I had the first lick of my salty caramel and nocciola aka hazelnut cone, I certainly felt like angels were calling my name. It didn‚Äôt hurt that they claim to hand-churn this goodness out of local, natural ingredients.
Runner-up favorite for us was Puro Gelato.
BEWARE: there is a tourist trap called trdeln√≠ks aka a ‚Äúchimney cake‚Äù and this new trend where they fill them with soft-serve ice cream.
Everyone has lost their minds over it. While it‚Äôs super IG-friendly, don‚Äôt be fooled into thinking it‚Äôs a traditional Czech dessert. It‚Äôs a fairly new addition (<20 years) to Czech gastronomy, but given that it‚Äôs sweet, pretty, and different enough from your standard donuts and pastries to be interesting, this is a dessert that‚Äôs here to stay.
However to add insult to injury, they don‚Äôt even taste good. Given that A) I like desserts and B) I am basic and like pretty things, I tried not ONE, but TWO. And on both occasions, I can confirm, this is a tourist trap. Pretty to look at, kind of dry. Disappointing, really.
As you know, I‚Äôve never been a big fan of beer. But when the most talked about place in Prague is a beer garden, you better bet your keg I‚Äôll be there.
This was our only destination north of the river, and wow even the view alone was worth it. After a (mildly tiring) winding hike up a hill, we were rewarded with a gorgeous panorama view of the old town below. And my friend was rewarded with a beer. So cheers to that.
Have you heard of any famous Czech wines or wineries? No? Neither had I.
However this was one of my favorite stops during my time in Prague because the reason why we don‚Äôt get to taste (or hear) about Czech wines is because for the most part, their wine isn‚Äôt exported out of the country.
Not surprising since they only grow 20,000 hectares of vines. In comparison, France grows more than 800,000 hectares‚Ä¶ that‚Äôs 4,000% more than Czech Republic. And in Czech, the wine consumption per capita is nearly 23 liters per year. So it‚Äôs no wonder they don‚Äôt have the wine or time to ship it out here to the states.
So what wine varietal is the Czech Republic known for? Due to the continental climate in Marovia (the largest wine region in the country), the majority of grape varietals that do well are white grapes (and their principal varietal is Welschriesling) although that‚Äôs not to say you shouldn‚Äôt have them recommend a few to you.
You might learn a thing or two, or at the very least drink a glass or two, like I did.
Do as the locals do and just chill.
In addition to the grassy knoll where people watch the sun sett over Prague Castle, there‚Äôs actually also a beer garden nearby. But we opted to grab a bottle from a local store and hike up to the top of the hill to enjoy the sunset (fantastic view).
Peaceful, tranquil, allegro.
Due to the aggressive flooding Prague is prone to, much of the city was actually raised by a few meters in the 10th century.
And this turned many of the originally ground-level rooms into makeshift interconnected cellars. The cavern-like rooms are actually quite cozy and such fun exploring (because each wine cellar / room within has its own personality)
The two we visited were U Sudu and Vzorkovna. U Sudu felt pretty hip, and a good time overall. Vzorkovna was even more hip, issuing wristbands at the door that we had to preload minimum Czech Koruna to use once inside. Interesting concept, and a fun night overall (and there‚Äôs a resident dog I might add‚Ä¶) Great way to to socialize with locals and tourists alike.
This club is nuts. It‚Äôs 5 floors, making it the biggest night club in central Europe. And every floor has a different DJ spinning different tunes: mainstream, EDM, oldies, hip hop, and mellow tunes.
You know those nights where you and your friends go out, but you keep trying to go to different places because one of your girl friends will inadvertently want a different scene? Well that‚Äôs not a problem here. And that‚Äôs also probably why it‚Äôs crowded with both locals and tourists alike.
It‚Äôs situated right on the water, just East of the Charles Bridge. So the view at night is beautiful, as is the sunrise after you‚Äôve dance the night away (yes, I can confirm that they‚Äôre open until 5 AM)
Thanks for reading! Enjoy what you‚Äôve read so far? Feel free to Czech out more of my adventures in Europe below:

Title: Prague - the Storyteller
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

My experience around the world today which will become the history of tomorrow. Record keeping is important, especially by one without an agenda.

--
Listen
Share
It was the first week of December and temperature outside was -3 Celsius. The wish to see the German-European Christmas markets came with its weather implications, even more so in Prague. Balancing my walk on the icy, slippery cobbled streets and braving the extreme cold, I finally made my way via the Golden Lane to the viewpoint at the Prague Castle. There, warming my freezing palms and soul with a glass of mulled wine, I gazed upon the city.
With the snow and lights, Prague looked like a Southern Indian bride, draped in white and gold. Is there another city more beautiful than Prague? Not in my experience. Prague is a town plucked straight out of your fairytales. There are castles, cathedrals, stone bridges, opera houses, and a giant peculiar medieval clock, keeping track of time for 600 years. And if you decide to step outside the town to Bohemian Switzerland, you will find yourself in the magical world of the movie Narnia, where mountains are cloaked in silver trees and you hike amongst the petrified ogres.
Over the years, every person discovering my passion for history would advise me to visit Prague. ‚ÄúSo old and beautiful‚Ä¶so much history‚Äù. It surprised me a bit as Prague (or Czech in general) does not make its appearance in the accounts of antiquity which is my primary area of interest. So I brought a book on the history of Prague to enlighten myself. Between the text and my walking tours, here is what I learnt.
The tale of Prague (or Praha) begins with a beautiful myth of Libu≈°e and her Amazon like female forces laying its foundation. However, its emergence onto the stage of Western history occurs as late as 1333 with the reign of Charles IV. Born as heir of Luxembourg and raised by his uncle Charles in France, Charles IV is hailed as the icon that placed Prague on the map. He brought the seat of Holy Roman Empire to Prague for the first time after which the boundaries of Bohemia, Bavaria and Austria kept shifting, colliding the cultural tectonic plates of Jewish, French, Italian, German and Bohemian cultures.
Two hundred years before Martin Luther initiated Reformation of Christianity against the Catholic Church, a Czech priest named Jan Hus was burnt at stake by the Church for questioning practices like Simony and Eucharist. In 1600, Johannes Kepler questioned the perfection of the universe itself when he suggested the orbital trajectory of planets is elliptical and not a perfect circle. Mozart‚Äôs Don Giovanni considered too distasteful by the Holy royals of Vienna, was premiered in Estate Theater in Prague in 1787.
Maria Theresa introduced the compulsory schooling of children in Habsburg empire bringing universal literacy to Prague and giving birth to writers like Franz Kafka immortalizing the city in their works. After the First World War, Prague emerged as a strong democracy under the philosopher President Tom√°≈° Masaryk, a protestant who re-established Jan Hus as the symbol of Czech Nationalism. And after the Second World War, Prague fell under the Communist rule only to regain freedom and its culture in 1989.
So quite a lot happened in Prague but to be fair, its not very different from the story of any medieval European city ‚Äî A founding myth, a glorious Christian monarch, a monument inscribed in his glory, some Renaissance science followed by artwork in the age of Enlightenment, melancholy in the age of existentialism and atrocities in the age communism. If you are lucky, may be a Roman connection with its ruins of camps and baths.  Then what is so special about Prague that captures the aesthetic eye? The answer to this question came from a local tour guide while describing the only ugly thing in this gorgeous town ‚Äî the ≈Ωi≈ækov TV tower built by Communist. He said ‚ÄúI know its ugly and we hated communist but its there because its still our history. In Prague, we preserve everything.‚Äù
The answer to this question came from a local tour guide while describing the only ugly thing in this gorgeous town ‚Äî the ≈Ωi≈ækov TV tower built by Communist. He said ‚ÄúI know its ugly and we hated communist but its there because its still OUR history. In Prague, we preserve everything.‚Äù
Whether it‚Äôs the new world of America or the ancient land of India, people in all ages have decided to live in their selected view of history and constructed that obstructed view by destroying the representation of any other era. While in India, it‚Äôs the classic imposition of superiority of one group over another, America is unique in the sense that they just destroy the old for their love of new. The first Ferris wheel, the original Opera houses in New York are all long gone. But a lot around the world has also been lost because new rulers refuse to accept the old as their legacy. Talibans destroyed Buddhas of Bamiyan , Left wing Portland pulled down Abraham Lincoln‚Äôs statue and BJP in India abandoned the Edwin Lutyens Parliament building as the symbol of British Imperialism.
But nothing is lost in Prague. Somehow the rulers in all ages agreed to maintain the continuity and today, its entire story can be relived with physical representations of each era through out the city. You don‚Äôt have to imagine prosperity of the Carolines, the reforms of Habsburg, the curiosity of the Renaissance scholars or the lack of creativity of communism. You just need to open your eyes and see how the contradictions coexists in these 200 square miles.
World‚Äôs third largest atheist population walks across the Charles Bridge everyday surrounded by the statues of Catholic saints. Ladislav ≈†aloun decided to honor Jan Hus with a monument in Old Town without destroying the Catholic Church of our Lady before Tyn across the street. Kafka‚Äôs grim portrayal of Prague was celebrated even in the nationalist years of 1920s. And for the country known for its exports of engineering equipments, there is no desire to put a show of prosperity by replacing the stone bridge with steel structure or astronomical clock with a 3D Billboard.
These structures provide a complete picture of the history of Prague, against the backdrop of which, we can comprehend the city‚Äôs inhabitants and their present identities.
What makes Prague truly exceptional is this embracing of their legacy and the commitment to preserve it. The beauty of the city lies in its 1000 year old journey chronicled by its own nooks and corners.

Engineer, loves history and travels to relive it

Title: 3 Reasons to Visit Prague, The City of Alchemy
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
is an ancient city filled with a long history of mystery, with much more than meets the eye. I recently had the pleasure of visiting this amazing city in August 2023. It was a last minute trip, so I truly had zero expectations for what to expect. Soon after landing, I realized I had stumbled upon an alchemical city filled with intrigue and magic! You can feel a buzzing energy once you step into this uniquely built city. The buildings and streets all seem to be laid in some perfect, symmetrical grid. Prague Castle sits high up on the hill, giving off an almost invincible feeling as you look upon it. This was the home of the Roman Emperor Rudolph II, who was obsessed with Alchemy, and the pursuit of the Philospher‚Äôs Stone. King Charles built The Charles Bridge in 1357, built strategically with astronomers and numerologists, to align the bridge and towers with the rising and setting of the sun. Prague was the capital of the Holy Roman Empire in 1300‚Äôs, and is where King Charles oversaw The Golden Age of Bohemia.
There is an abundance of mysticism and symbolism throughout the city, which is filled with alchemical bars, fascinating museums, and the famous astrological clock that brings the city center to life. Visiting Prague is certainly a portal to the old world, which lead the way for modern pharmacy and medicines. Praha truly seems to be covered in magic, and I highly recommend you visit this mystic, legendary city. Here are my 3 reasons why Prague should be high up on your travel itinerary.
I am not the biggest fan of cities, but Prague was a city full of wonder and mystery. The roads told a story of a distant past, the aged buildings still etched with beautiful gargoyles, symbols and designs, still dimly shining their radiance. I was immediately in awe at how well preserved the historic buildings and statues were. It truly felt like I was in a medieval movie, moving forward on my own alchemical journey. The city seemed old, yet proud, with all of its traditions and secrets. I am fascinated by stories of alchemy and have enjoyed researching this field for years; and now I stumbled upon a whole alchemical city. Just my luck!
One of the most notable proponents of alchemy was the Roman Emperor Rudolph II, who ruled and lived in Prague until his death in 1612. He was a very curious leader, who encouraged alchemists, astronomers, philosophers to travel to Prague and share their teachings. This was technically their modern day medicine, so Rudolph naturally built his own laboratory at the castle. He was obsessed with find the Philosopher‚Äôs stone, which according to legend is the key to the Elixir for immortal life. He brought over Edward Kelley, a self proclaimed spirit medium, and John Dee, occultist and Mathematician. You can visit a recreation of the alchemical laboratory Rudolph had in the Prague Castle.
This museum houses real alchemical laboratories, only recently discovered in 2002 due to intense flooding and road erosion. Within the museum they found herbs, flasks, and more in an underground complex of labs and rooms. The underground labs still contain original glassworks, rooms, and kilns the alchemist‚Äôs used for transmuting lead to gold. It is an incredible experience to set foot where true alchemists have stepped foot, creating and experimenting with elixirs that have changed the face of medicine today. The underground is truly remarkable, and filled with different tunnels and passageways. They offer a guided tour of 30 minutes, which is actually packed with interesting information and sights, which I highly recommend!
This marvel within Prague is one of the main landmarks you will see in Prague. This bridge, which used to be a main crossing between East and West Europe, was built in 1357 by King Charles in accordance with the palindromic number 13579753. King Charles worked with astronomers and numerologists on how, where, and when to build this historic bridge. By working with the stars and numerology, Charles constructed the bridge to align with planetary energy, and to align with the rising and setting of the sun. Pretty advanced stuff for 700 years ago! Along the bridge there are several sculptures of historical figures that represent Prague‚Äôs long history. You can take a boat tour that take you around the bridge and gives you heaps of interesting information about the bridge, its past, and the Prague Castle.
There are rumors that Prague was laid out in a geometrical shape, adhering to symmetry and planetary grids. I truly feel like this is not far from the truth. I‚Äôve traveled to some amazing energy vortexes in my life, and it was quite surprising to find the energy still strong, even within this bigger city. There are also many underground tunnels, and small street that seem to go on forever. Get lost in these mystic streets, and who knows, maybe you‚Äôll find what you‚Äôre looking for!
This is a no-brainer! Prague Castle is the biggest castle complex in the world, and you can certainly tell when you visit. It stand watch high over Prague, a beautiful sight to see from almost anywhere in the city. The complex and intricate design of the roofs and towers of the castle are truly an ode to the complexities of life and nature. It is remarkable to see such a great feat done and still standing from so long ago. The original Prague Castle was built in the 9th century, yet you can still get a good idea of what the original felt like! It seems time skipped over this part of the world, still revealing clues to our distant past. The castle is filled with sculptures, angels, demons, and scars of its‚Äô past. Walk around the Castle and marvel in its wonder. It is a nice walk up a hill, so do be prepared! It‚Äôs all worth it once you get to the top, as the view from the city is truly amazing. It also holds the Guinness Book of World Record for largest Castle Complex!
I found one of my favorite bars in the world. I really enjoy Alchemy, and its rare to find a place that is Alchemically themed, and done well. I won‚Äôt give away the location, as you will need to find it yourself ( come on, alchemist!), but this is a must do here in Prague. Their bar will brew some mystic elixirs that may enhance Alchemical power and insight. The whole bar has really cool decorations (its very own Hermit), and the menu is filled with illustrations and sayings that will have you rethinking your life.
Prague is a short train ride away from Plzin, the official home of the Pilsner Beer. It actually got ripped off from a famous American brand, which isn‚Äôt totally surprising! Prague is actually the leader in the world for most beers consumed per capita. Prague is lined with traditional pubs and restaurants, ready for you to try some of their unique dishes. It is a charming place with lots of history, and people seem to gravitate to small pubs and places to eat, and just talk and observe the beauty. Get yourself a cold one and kick your feet up, buddy!
Czech goulash is a pretty unique, tasty traditional meal that should try. A Proper homemade Czech Goulash is prepared by first braising chunks of stewing beef with potatoes, tomato, onions, paprika and garlic. This serving is usually served with crusty bread, boiled dumplings or noodles. Wash it down with an ice cold glass of pilsner lager like an original Pilsner Urquell.
I am a big fan of shows like Vikings because I get to fantasize about how it was to live in earlier times. Times before electricity, before the internet and before mobile phones. I was able to really feel like I had stepped in the past in Prague. Being from the States, its rare to see such ancient feeling buildings, roads and infrastructure. You can go to so many museums, shops, cathedrals, and shop within just Prague alone. The city seems to be proud of its rich heritage, and they have preserved much of its history. There are many important historical events and figures that have traversed to the City of Alchemy, and have surely been amazed by its‚Äô charm. Enjoy the never ending wonders within the streets of this magical city.
There is a big bohemian energy in Czech, which makes sense, since it is originally the home of the Kingdom of Bohemia. There are many crystal shops, yoga places, and mystic shops sprinkled throughout. I was lucky enough to know a few friends out there, and was able to see another side of Czechia outside of the city. The forest truly seem to contain fairies within them; there is that mystic charm that I have heard so much about of the enchanting European forests. The soil is fertile and lush, the people content and beautiful in their own ways. There is a quiet and calm energy all throughout the countryside. If you are like me, you enjoy some solitude and retreat into nature and chance you may get. This was a welcome treat after traveling through other busy cities in Europe.
I was able to see some less travelled places in Czech, and the charm only grew from there. The people were very welcoming, and the natural beauty really held me in its arms. It feels a lot more simple in the countryside, where they are unburdened by the heaviness of the city. If you can, take a train outside of the city, take a walk through nature, and eat a mom and pop restaurant. Thank me later.
Get to Prague if you are traveling nearby in Europe! If the mystic, magical, and mysterious intrigues you, I guarantee you will have a great time if you travel to Prague. There is a treasure trove of secrets and history amongst the castles, museums and ancient river. The old cobblestone roads, mixed with goulash and Pilsners, will captivate your senses as you gaze upon historic marvels. Satisfy your craving for more alchemical tools along your hero‚Äôs journey! This geometrically aligned city has more secrets waiting to be revealed. I would take at least 3‚Äì5 days to explore most of Prague and the surrounding towns. Take the leap into the unknown and travel into this City of Alchemy.
Mark Jason

Title: Prague ‚Äî 5 great things to do on a budget
Content:

Share
Currently, in the middle of the corona pandemic crisis, it might not be the right time to travel unfortunately. Last year I was on a little eurotrip and one of the places I visited was Prague in the Czech Republic. If you‚Äôre sitting at home watching Triple X and dreaming about where to go next after all this is over then here are some budget tips on what to do in one of the most beautiful cities in central Europe.
Walk around in the old town
With documented settlements dating back over a thousand years and current buldings such as the Old Town Hall with the foundation being built in the 14th century, Prague‚Äôs old town called Star√© Mƒõsto in the Czech language will leave you with a magical feeling.
This is a must and quite frankly difficult to avoid since the medieval Star√© Mƒõsto is smack in the middle of the city center. Go see the astronomical clock which was installed in 1410, the old town square, the stands in the narrow streets and the Charles bridge. If you look around closely you might find some cosy hidden restaurants such as the Charles Bridge Restaurant which is basically a floating barge, sitting on the water by the base of the bridge on the Old town side. Pro tip: You might also wanna try the local Czech cuisine at some smaller place around the corner on a side street away from the tourist rush. That‚Äôs generally how I‚Äôve stumbled on some of the best food on my trips. The Czech cuisine resembles other central and east European dishes such as goulash, various soups and pancakes, bread dumplings, schnitzel and baked meat. For a drink you should try any Czech beer. It really doesn‚Äôt matter which one you choose, they all taste magnificient and much better than at home.
Prague is literally a city of bridges, it has over 300 hundred of them, so there are many more to see than just the Charles bridge. Each with their own history to tell. Some other famous ones are the Legion bridge, the M√°nes Bridge and the Palack√Ω Bridge.
Visit the St. Vitus Cathedral and the Castle complex
This huge breathtaking gothic style cathedral is the largest church in the Czech republic. The main tower is over 100 metres high (328+ feet) and the cathedral itself is situated on top of a large hill which is housing the Prague Castle complex. From the hill you are able to see most of Prague‚Äôs center and the nature around it. One of the slopes even has a vineyard.
The castle is very big and was originally built in the 9th century and went on being improved up until the mid 19th century. Because of all the different eras in which it was constructed it consists of different architectural styles. Inside the complex are several museums in which you can learn all about the history of the Czech republic and also the famous so called Golden Lane. There are also several art galleries, small cafe‚Äôs and shops, although it might be bit of a tourist trap. Be wary of the prices and unnecessary touristic small stuff.
Go up the Pet≈ô√≠n Hill
A large hill is situated just off the center on the other side of the Vltava river above the Mal√° Strana district. The top is higher than the castle hill and rises 130 metres above the river. From there you can get some amazing views over Prague. The Pet≈ô√≠n Hill is a popular rectreational area and almost the entire hill is covered in parks. The so called Hunger Wall was built in the 14th century on the hill and is still there to be visited.
There is also a tall Eiffel styled lookout tower which you can visit for a fee. Although for sure a nice view I would however say that it‚Äôs not worth its price, and if you walk past by over to the Strahov Stadium (one of the largest stadiums ever built) there is a nice view point there by the tunnel ventilation tower. Although still in use, the stadium is a remnant of the old communist era. The tunnel towers has an interesting modernism style and were built and designed in the 80‚Äôs and 90‚Äôs by an architect called Ji≈ô√≠ Trnka.
To get to the top of the hill you can either walk, take the bus or tram or the funicular rail. If you‚Äôre walking from the city center there is a restaurant on the way up called Pet≈ô√≠nsk√© terasy. It‚Äôs situated straight up to the west of the Kampa riverside. Grab a bite with Czech styled food and enjoy the view over the city and the castle if you‚Äôre hungry or just step by for a drink.
While not a super fancy place, they do offer weddings and it has a large outdoor terrace. Inside you can enjoy the lumberjack styled pub and restaurant. They also have a large open fireplace that you can watch while you‚Äôre sitting and relaxing reading Frommer‚Äôs.
Check out the V√≠tkov hill Monument
There‚Äôs another hill in the ≈Ωi≈ækov district on the opposite side of the city center which is called V√≠tkov. On top of it is a memorial monument that features a large granite stone plaza and a large grey bulding. A huge bronze statue is standing on a pedestal in front of the building resembling Jan ≈Ωi≈æka, who in 1420 in the Battle of V√≠tkov Hill defeated enemy forces.
The memorial monument was mainly built in the 1930‚Äôs but had to be paused when the WWII started and the Germans occupied the land. It was later finished and was for a while used to promote communism. In 2000‚Äì2009 a renovation work was made by the National Museum and was reopened for the public to enjoy. From this place you will have one of the best views over Prague. It‚Äôs especially extraordinary in the sunset and many people are coming there to watch it.
Bonus tip: Around the Seifertova street nearby are several cocktail bars for having a little preparty or a drink on the way into the Old Town districts. You should maybe not stay too late as it might get noisy in this area and filled with drunk people.
Also nearby, on the other side of the railroad is a beautiful church called the Church of Saints Cyril and Methodius, and just past it is a small asian place called Ng√¥ where they serve fantastic food. This is a convenient area to stay in and with walking distance from the Old Town so look for hotels here. I stayed at Hotel Alwyn which is a pretty good hotel.
Have a drink at a roof bar
Roof bars are getting more and more popular and Prague has them as well. There is for example a nice one on top of the Hotel U Prince, nearby the Old Town Hall, with 360¬∞ views over the city. There is a restaurant so you can enjoy a bite and they make their own signature cocktails. It‚Äôs possible to stumble upon higher priced places but this one is still fairly reasonably priced. Just enter the hotel at street level and look for a glassed elevator, it will take you up to the roof restaurant and terrace. Other roof bars worth a visit are Cloud 9 in the large Hilton hotel, CODA restaurant in the Mal√° Strana district, Duplex in the center and T-anker in the old town.
Generally you will find value for your money in Prague and in the Czech republic. They have their own currency, Czech crowns, but might accept euros in some places. In smaller restaurants they might be slightly reluctant to taking cards for some reason so be sure to bring some cash as well. Situated in central Europe you can get there by car from Germany and Poland, or Austria from the south. There is an international airport for which most European airlines operate to and from the US you can go with Delta or American Airlines.
About the author: Marcus Segerros is a freelance Writer, Content Creator, Designer, Engineer and Business owner with a double BS and University Diploma Degree in Design and technology. Travelling as often as he can, he has visited a numerous number of countries and places and shares travelling tips in his articles.

In full transparency, our Eastern European stint of Budapest ‚Äî Vienna ‚Äî Prague is starting to blur together. While each of these cities are of course different, there are a lot of commonalities in terms of architecture, cuisine, and atmosphere. We were in Budapest and Prague for just over a week each, with only three days in Vienna, but all three stops were also slightly limited by poor weather, travel fatigue, and/or illness making it fairly even across the board. We traveled between them by train which was efficient, comfortable, and a change from planes and cars. Overall, I think Prague was my favourite of these three, but by very slim margins. It had a great mix of everything you could want: it was lively, the architecture is unmatched, many buildings are actually original whereas several in the other cities were destroyed during wars and rebuilt in the same style. Many of the buildings here were also painted pastel colours making the neighborhoods feel unique and cheery.
Activity-wise, Prague (similarly to Budapest and Vienna), was filled with a lot of walking and exploring the area. We did two walking tours, and visited a museum, and aside from that our activities were wandering, eating, and people-watching ‚Äî our favourites! We stayed in a hotel in Prague as well, which was a nice change from our Air BnBs. While very basic, we did have breakfast included. I did miss having a kitchen, but overall it was nice to be in comfy beds with daily room services.
Our first walking tour was an introduction to the city, winding through the Jewish quarter, crossing the Charles Bridge, and finishing at the Lennon Wall. While walking past one of the oldest synagogues in the city we learned the legend of Golem, a clay man brought to life by Rabbi Loew to help protect the Jewish people. The Rabbi would deactivate the Golem on Shabbat, however one week he forgot and the Golem got loose, leaving a path of destruction in his path. After this, the Rabbi never brought Golem to life again, and the form is said to still be locked in the attic of the old-new Synagogue. While this is the most famous Golem legend, he is not the first man of clay as this idea is reflected in stories and Jewish folklore prior to the 16th century. I find legends and folklore very interesting, and both Budapest and Prague offered nighttime ghost and legends tours that we had planned to take but were rained out which was disappointing.
Our tour also took us past the astronomical clock, a famous symbol of Prague. It is an intricate clock with multiple displays dictating the time, positions of the sun and moon, and Zodiac constellations. Given it‚Äôs age (built in the 15th century), it‚Äôs incredible how accurate it is. On the hour each hour is the worlds first puppet show, as a few of the figurines around the clock nod or make similar small movements, leading the square to be packed with people.
Charles Bridge was once the only bridge across the Vltava River, with construction starting in 1357 and ending in the early 15th century. As we crossed we heard buskers playing tunes and passed small stands selling jewelry and paintings.
After crossing the bridge we made our way to the Lennon Wall, named after Jon Lennon from the Beatles. John is not from the Czech Republic, nor did he live there, however when he was shot in New York in 1980, young Prague residents decided to draw on a wall in Prague as a memorial to the musician. Artistic and personal expression was not allowed under the communist regime in power at the time, and so by the next day the officials had painted over the drawings. The artists came back and painted again, only to have it painted over the next day. And so they painted on it again, and this cycle continued. It quickly evolved into a silent protest against communism. The wall still stands, and people continue to add their own artwork and words to it as it has become a symbol of freedom of speech and self-expression.
Our second walking tour was of Prague Castle, timed to see the changing of the guard. the rain held off for 90% of the three hours, and there were gorgeous views from the castle of the city below.
We also visited the Narodni Museum, which is a natural history museum founded in 1818. The exhibitions themselves are what you would expect from this sort of museum, nothing spectacular or unique, but for me the star of the show is the building itself. The detailed tiles and architecture were truly stunning.
We were overdue for a night out and decided to go on a pub crawl as Prague is known to have awesome nightlife that goes all night long. Overall, this was a fun night, but I would say it was not the best pub crawl we‚Äôve gone on. It was a very large group, many coming together from a hostel where a lot of pre-drinking had clearly happened and also meant that it was quite a young crowd. The first couple of places we went to were fairly empty, but our group was large and the pubs were small so we filled them up and it was a fun time. This pub crawl justifies its price by providing a free drink at each stop (typical of European pub crawls), as well as free entry into the largest club in Prague. We went on a Thursday, which we thought would be fine given Prague‚Äôs reputation and that we‚Äôre entering peak tourism season. We were wrong. The final club was not only a twenty-minute walk from the last bar, but it also was completely empty. The club is five floors with different music on each, and it would take a lot of people to fill it up‚Ä¶ but it was really disappointing, with maybe five people in each of the large spaces. We left almost as soon as we got there, waited for twenty minutes in the cold night for the tram which didn‚Äôt come (turns out we were on the wrong street), and wandered through the area until we picked up a free wifi network to call an Uber and make our way home. A bit of an unfortunate end, but a fun evening for the first 3‚Äì4 hours!
After about five days of amazing exploration and soaking in everything the city had to offer, I got my third cold of the trip. David and I both went to bed with throats that felt scratchy. In typical fashion, David‚Äôs immune system won and he woke up feeling ok, mine did not, and I woke up with a full-blown head cold and raw throat that stuck with me for several days, and now a week later is still clinging on with a hoarse cough in the evenings that I just can‚Äôt seem to kick. Our last couple of days were also pouring rain, so they were quiet days, we went out here and there, but mostly enjoyed the hotel and again took some recharge time before heading to our final destination of the entire trip: southern Portugal.
--
--
A Canadian couple on a five month trip around the world sharing our adventures as we go

Title: How is visiting Prague as a business traveller different from a tourist?
Content:

In my Previous work at GoodData, I had a chance to have two business trips to Prague, Czech Republic. Before joining GoodData, I have never been to any European counties east of Germany or Austria. In 2022, our team had trouble finding sales engineers in the Czech Republic, so everyone in our team was taking turns working in Prague to cover the European business timezone. Therefore, I went to Prague to help out the sales representatives in Prague as a temporary sales engineer in May 2022 and September 2022.
First time to ‚ÄúThis Part of Europe‚ÄùThis is my first time visiting the Czech Republic, and also the first time visiting a former Warsaw Pact country. I was very curious about how the country transformed after the Berlin Wall broke 30 years later, and how much does the Czech Republic different from the European countries I have been to. Most of my colleagues asked me whether this is the first time I visit Europe, I told them: ‚ÄúThis is the first time I have been to ‚ÄòThis Part of Europe‚Äô‚Äù.
My first impression of the Czech Republic is Soviet architecture in the suburban, Pre-Modern Austro-Hungarian city-style Downtown, Modern Western European office buildings in the business area. When I arrived in Prague airport, the airport is obviously built during the former Warsaw Pact era the building is very rectangular and lack of decoration, which creates a contradiction when modern Boeing or Airbus aircraft were parked against it. Although the highways looked new and well-maintained, I can still see some poor-maintained Soviet-style buildings in the suburban area. Once the taxi enters Prague‚Äôs city limit, the city's appearance changed to the beautiful 19th-century Austro-Hungarian city-style Downtown, mixed with newly built Western European office buildings. I am able to see the overview memories of the Czechs in the form of Prague architecture.
No One Calls it CzechiaDuring my stay in Prague, I have more opportunities to talk with the locals since I was working with them for a couple of weeks. I literally hear none of the Czech call their country Czechia. They mostly call their country by their full name ‚Äî the Czech Republic, or the country abbreviation ‚Äî CZ (American Zee) or CZ (British Zat). It appears that Czechs in general really don‚Äôt like the new name for their country (I personally call it the Czech Republic too).
Another interesting thing I learnt in Prague is that the relationship between Czechs and Slovakians is not as close as I thought. I learnt from an American YouTuber that Czechs and Slovakians are culturally close so their relationship is as intimate as siblings, but one of my Prague colleagues disagreed.
The City AppearanceDowntown Prague is a very beautiful city where the beauty came from the late Middle Ages and pre-Modern style buildings next to tram routes. The iconic Soviet-style Prague trams ran between those buildings are the only confusion that you think you are visiting a Warsaw Pact country in the latter half of the 20th century, but you realize there are newly built Austrian trams replacing the aging iconic trams when they pass by occasionally.
Sadly, most of my time in Prague was spent at the GoodData headquarter and I did not have a lot of chance to go around the city, besides Prague Castle, Charles Bridge, and Petrin Tower.
Office Culture is a Mixture of American and Continent EuropeAlthough GoodData originated from the Czech Republic, the company culture was relatively Americanized. Besides the office appearance looks very no different from a Tech company in the San Francisco Bay Area, the work culture is basically the same! The atmosphere in the GoodData headquarter embraces creativity, work-life balance, and the work-hard-play-hard mentality. During my stay in Prague, I feel the work environment in the Prague office is the same as in the San Francisco office.
Czechs are very easy to work with: They are not as serious as German, nor lazy. They will deliver what you need on time, as long as they have a proper summer break (3‚Äì4 weeks off), which does not exist in the Anglophone countries. Their impression of American work culture is a hard work culture with an insufficient amount of holidays ‚Äî One of my colleagues mentioned he was impressed (negatively) that American mothers can only take 10 weeks of paid maternity time off that he does not wish to live in the US if his wife and he are planning to have kids.
Czech FoodBesides Pilnser, anyone who visits the Czech Republic should try any duck dish since Czech ducks taste very taste! One of the common duck dishes in the Czech Republic is duck confit (Which is also common in Slovakia, Austria, and maybe Poland?), although my Czech colleagues always laugh at me eating what they eat on Sunday prepared by their grandmas. This grandma's dish usually serves with Czech dumplings and pickles to ease the duck grease.
On my second trip to Prague, half of my team was actually visiting Prague. Therefore, my manager decided to bring us to a team lunch. Although my manager is a Czech who lived in San Francisco, he acts very differently when he is in Prague. When he was bringing us to lunch in San Francisco, he brought us to cafes with health choices; in contrast, he would have brought us to a cafe close to our Prague office too, but the first thing to order is wine. I bet Europeans are very flexible in switching their culture mode wherever they are at.
Prague has quite a big portion of the Vietnamese population (They have mostly immigrated to the Czech Republic in the 70‚Äôs and 80‚Äôs), so there are a lot of Vietnamese restaurants or shops serve pho and Vietnamese sandwiches. Not surprisingly, there are a lot of Chinese restaurants; however, most of those Chinese restaurants not only serve Chinese dishes, but also Japanese, Korean, and Thai dishes as well‚Ä¶
Czechs in General Hates the Communist EraWorking in a company with Czech heritage allows me to understand the Czechs. I thought the Czechs have some degree of good memories from the Communist Era, but I was wrong! The upper managers in GoodData sent memos to us during the pandemic to make up the communication supposed to be done on-site, I remember one of the memos was sent during the week of the celebration of the Velvet Revolution for embracing freedom gained after the end of communist-ruled Czechoslovakia.
During the last week of my first Prague visit, I was planning to watch an opera in the State Opera House. While I was discussing with my colleagues how to get to the opera house from the office, one of my colleagues started to complain about the city planning policy during the Communist Era (Out of nowhere too‚Ä¶but he has a point). He was complaining about the fact that a highway was built next to the opera house, which made complicated and inconvenient pedestrian access and prevented the highway to build straight to avoid the road cutting through the building (If a highway is not straight enough, then it is not fast). Although I tried not to give any opinion on this topic as an outsider, I can see the reputation of the previous era has left a bruise on the Czechs.
Prague Castle and Charles BridgeMy colleagues were nice to bring me to visit Prague Castle and Charles Bridge after Wednesday work and had dinner together next to Prague Castle.
My impression of Prague Castle is not a castle! To me, a castle is a walled building built in the Middle Age or before for the landlord to live; Prague Castle looks like a pre-Modern era palace, which is a couple of hundred years ahead of its time.
We had dinner and beer afterward. And of course, my colleagues ordered something that I never had. One of those is Chicken liver pat√©.
After dinner, we walk from Prague Castle and across Charles Bridge to take the metro. During the walk, my colleagues explained Prague Castle and Charles Bridge. I really enjoyed visiting the sightseeing spots with the locals rather than guides because the locals know what the sightseeing spots are, but they can‚Äôt remember hard fact details like the year when built and historical figures, it makes them more authentic rather than a guide who tries to impress you.
Petrin TowerIf I have to pick one must-see sightseeing spot it has to be Petrin Tower, over Prague Castle or Charles Bridge. I personally am attracted by the architecture of Prague, therefore, Petrin Tower is the best place to view Prague from a bird's view.
BeerI save this topic to the last ‚Äî Beer! Basically: Czech Republic = Beer. So that you can understand how important beer is to the Czechs. Among all the national brands, Pilsner is the best for me. Pilsner is a lager that has a very light body with some pine finish, it is a very refreshing beverage, especially for summer! One good reason to visit Prague: Pilsner is significantly taster when serve in draft beer than in cans!
During my second visit to Prague, my company had an offsite in a local theater in Prague. Interestingly, beer was served between breaks for the whole afternoon, but no one was drunk by the end of all presentations at 6 pm. Czechs simply cannot get drunk on beer (Not sure whether that is a good thing or not). I am not a person who is crazy for nightlife so I don‚Äôt consider myself a good dancer, one of my male colleagues was impressed with my dance move. He asked me how he can dance as well as me, I told him the key is to get drunk since I don‚Äôt have a good answer for him so I joked with him. He was quite a humour to say: ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs the problem! We Czechs are hard to get drunk.‚Äù Quite an answer!
ConclusionI really love Prague, and so does the Czech Republic. I really like the architecture of Prague, the city vibe, the city, and the people! They gave me a good time when I was visiting Prague. It is a very nice place to visit as you would learn a lot from the people and the city. It is also very affordable to visit. A 3-star hotel night (May or October) is less than 100 Euros in the city center, and a decent dine-in meal cost you about 20 Euros with beer and coffee. It is worth your money, not only on seeing Charles Bridge and Prague Castle but also I am pretty sure both Prague and the Czech Republic can give you a Central European vibe that you can enjoy. I am not sure when next time, but next time I got to visit as a tourist! And I really miss Pilsner too!

Title: The Doors of Prague
Content:

Sign up
Sign in

1
Listen
Share
Prague is the capital of the Czech Republic with a long history as the central city of the region and the first capitol city of Bohemia. Bohemia dates back to 870 where by 1198 the Kingdom of Bohemia was established as part of the Holy Roman Empire. Prague has served as the center of life for the region through trade technology language and culture where much of the art and architecture over the centuries has been thoughtfully preserved. Prague suffered no major damage during the great wars except that many synagogues were robbed and their Jewish community targeted for deportation and execution by the Nazis during World War II.
On a recent visit to Prague my wife and I toured Old Town, the Jewish Quarter, Mal√° Strana, Prague Castle, and Wenceslas Square in New Town primarily on foot and with some assistance from the public tram system. One of the interesting and amazing discoveries on this visit were the Doors of Prague which I am sharing in this article.
Our room for the week was at the Grand Hotel Praha where we had this wonderful view of the Old Town Hall and the Astronomical Clock. The Old Town Hall building is primarily Gothic in design with some elements of Romanesque and other styles.
In addition to the main entrance there were these doors with a pointed arch of Gothic design a round arch of Romanesque design and a rectangular door with elaborate metalwork similar to that of the Romanesque door.
The interior featured many historical meeting rooms reflecting early forms of developing democracies, including the meeting hall for the people, a governing suite, and Senate chambers.
A unique feature of the Old City Hall and the Old Town area are the underground tunnels that connect the basements of many buildings in the area. The city was raised about 2 to 4 meters beginning in the 13th century to protect the city from flooding and to accommodate the construction of dams and locks on the Vitava River. So the original first floor of many buildings are now underground forming a network of connected basements.
Our first full day in Prague was spent exploring the Old Town Square and some of the surrounding streets to the North and East of the square. Old Town Square has a wide variety of beautiful entrance doors. These feature Romanesque designs with transom lights above the doors providing daylighting to the interior even when the doors are closed. Note the center door below featuring a door within a door.
These entrance doors with Baroque design influences feature bars and gates over the windows and doors with intricate design.
Saint Nicholas Church at Old Town Square features a Baroque architectural style with elaborate doors and this elegant window in the center below with intricate metalwork over the glass.
Art Nouveau influences were found too in these Romanesque entrance near Old Town Square with transom lights that have more free-form patterns integrated into the door designs.
Another elaborate gated entrance on Par√≠zsk√° street, and the blend of Gothic and Romanesque features in the Church of Our Lady at Tyn on Tynsk√° street. These were found on our venture up to the Jewish Quarter and back where we toured the Spanish Synagogue completed in 1868 and its Museum on Jewish history and the holocaust.
Dozens of Jewish Synagogues were destroyed in Czechia and tens of thousands of its citizens were deported and murdered by the Nazis during World War II. Fortunately most of the Synagogues in Prague including the Spanish Synagogue we visited were not destroyed. An example of the architectural loss in other parts of the Czech Republic is this beautiful Baroque Synagogue at Holesov with Moorish design elements.
Holesov was designed by the architect Jakob Gartner and completed in 1893 with elaborate Baroque decorative features on the facade and in its doors and windows. It was burned down and demolished by the Nazis in 1941. An excellent display of the facts can be found at the Spanish Synagogue and Museum just minutes north of Old Town Square.
On our second day we ventured across the Vitava River to Petrin Tower, down to Mal√° Strana, and back across the Charles Bridge. We took a tram from Old Town to the base of Petrin Hill Park and then another tram up the hill to Petrin Tower. I highly recommend this route as the hill would have been quite a climb and the trams are free for seniors.
Along the way back we found this collection of entrance doors including Baroque style double doors with Moorish influences at the Strahov Monastery and Romanesque style facades at Mosteck√° street and near the Charles Bridge.
Crossing the Charles Bridge was special because you could see the many statues on the bridge and the spires all around in Old Town, Mal√° Strana, and the Prague Castle. Here is an interpretation of that experience from my wife Ana Mari.
As we wandered back to Old Town on Mari√°nsk√© N√°mest√≠ you can find these new glass doors with transom and side lights, the Art Nouveau facade of the New City Hall which is not that new since it was built in 1911, and around the corner on Linhartsk√° street this gated entrance to the courtyard of a residential complex that can open wide for vehicular traffic or for pedestrians through the door within a door. It actually looked 21st century new.
In the rooms above many of these beautiful buildings are residential quarters. I noticed this early in the mornings when the locals were coming out and leaving for work, some slipping through their door within doors.
Venturing on, these entrances have Romanesque influences found on the doors at Lingartsk√° and Karlova streets. Note again the door within a door in the center image below.
Continuing on Karlova street are more entrances with Baroque and Moorish influences. Note the doors on the right with the large stone bumpers at the base. These were common on many entrances and designed to protect the doors from carts moving in and out from the interior courtyards to the street. Many are still in place and some have been cut or chiseled back as the building use has changed over the years.
Our third day was spent at Prague Castle where we took another tram from Old Town to the top of the hill entering the castle complex from the North. You can walk west from Old Town to the east Castle entrance but it turns into quite a climb by the time you get to Saint Vitus Cathedral.
Saint Vitus Cathedral has Gothic style features as noted by the pointed arches on all of these doors. The front entrance doors have elaborate facades, an interior side door features a door within a door, and one of the back service doors features beautiful stone and metal work.
To the east of the cathedral is St. George‚Äôs Basilica which displays many Romanesque features with its doors sunk deep into the thick stone walls.
Our fourth day included an outing south to Wenceslas Square which led to these finds along the way. A Romanesque style door within a door, a Baroque style entrance with some Moorish influences, and an Art Nouveau styled entrance.
Approaching Wenceslas Square there is a transition from Old Town to New Town where here Romanesque influences can be seen in the entrances on Ryt√≠rsk√° street and Wenceslas Square.
Our last day was a free day for wandering which included a round about route to the southeast to see the Franz Kafka Head by sculptor David Cerny. Along the way we made these discoveries on Jalovcov√° and Husova streets. Note the elaborate designs and textures and another door within a door.
At this entrance on Husova street below, note the door within a door to what looks like private residences on the two floors above. Most of the buildings in Old Town have been limited to about three floors in height except for those churches and public buildings with spires and towers.
In New Town and the Wenceslas Square area there is a change to building heights in the five to seven story range. New Town is what the Wenceslas Square area is called which is not that new given that many of the buildings date back to the early 1900s.
Along the way back we found these Baroque style influences on N√°rodn√≠ and Michalsk√° streets. Note here another door within a door leading to an interior courtyard.
In Closing I‚Äôll share that we found time to relax on a few evenings, me with a good book, and my wife painting. We spent five full days in Prague walking several miles a day to tour Old Town and the surrounding areas. With a redeye flight on the way over we found that the jet-lag is real when it finally hit requiring about 10 hours sleep the first night and making up the rest with an extra hour or two a night through the week.
Prague is a beautiful and historic city and well worth exploring in person. If you have not been there then be sure to put it on your list of future adventures.
Notes and References:
Story, photographs, and slides, by David Smitherman with site visits made in March 2023.
Historical data collected from brochures, onsite inscriptions, Wikipedia, Google Maps, and I-Maps.
Ana Mari Cadilla‚Äôs art can be seen on Instagram at @arte_anita11.
‚ÄúArchitecture of Prague, Czech Republic‚Äù at https://architectureofcities.com/prague#elements
Images from the Spanish Synagogue Museum displays, www.judalco.cz and Mestske muzeum a galerie Holesov.
Architectural Style designations are the authors visual interpretation and do not necessarily represent the official designation or time period of construction.

Immersed in history, overflowing with charm, and speckled with orange-topped roofs lies the city of Prague in the Czech Republic. Whether you love castles, architecture, or are just in need of a good beer, Czech Republic‚Äôs most popular city is one of the most interesting in Europe.
Prague has tonnes to offer with regards to culture, architecture, food, and drink; it has been on the tourist map for decades, and the crowds show no signs of dwindling down.
The Czech have a wonderful spirit. You really do get a feeling that they are not just putting up with all the tourists but instead embracing it, and want to show off their beautiful city. One of the most mind-blowing facts is their beer consumption; which may have something to do with their positivity. According to a local citizen there, the average Czech citizen consumes 300 litres of beer a year. They are serious about their beer and I am all for it! They know how to have and show you a good time. Prague is the perfect place to relax, explore, and get a feel for the history of Europe.
