Title: Top 10 Vegan Restaurants & Caf√©s in Prague: A Local‚Äôs Guide to Plant-Based Dining
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

A travel guide to Prague, Czech Republic. Uncover the best tips and insights about the city.

--
Listen
Share
Traditional Czech food might be very meaty, but that doesn‚Äôt mean that vegans have it tough here. In fact, there are many vegan-friendly places in Prague that even my staunchest meat-eater friends can‚Äôt resist.
What are those? Here‚Äôs a local‚Äôs perspective on some of the plant-based food in Prague in 2025.
Whether you‚Äôre looking for Czech classics with a vegan twist, international cuisine, or budget-friendly options, this guide has you covered.
Eaternia is a popular vegan diner in Prague and genuinely one of my favorite places to eat ever. The first time I had their burger? I almost cried. That‚Äôs how good their food is! It‚Äôs been two years, but my sister and I still talk about that incredible culinary experience to this day.
Menu highlights: The burger menu, obviously. But they also always have traditional Czech desserts and cakes (all 100% vegan) that I would recommend trying.
Location: Prague 5 ‚Äî Sm√≠chov. About 7 minutes away from the Sm√≠chov Train Station.
For the cool diner vibes, including a classic jukebox and funky wallpaper in the restrooms. And the burgers! Have I mentioned the burgers?
St≈ôecha is the place for everyone and anyone wanting to experience traditional Czech food with a vegan twist. It‚Äôs a cooperative restaurant run by formerly homeless people and ex-convicts, supporting their reintegration into society.
Basically, if you eat here, you‚Äôll get to:
Menu highlights: Sv√≠ƒçkov√°, aka soy sirloin in creamy vegetable sauce with traditional Czech dumplings. Personally, I‚Äôm also a big fan of the Budvard goulash.
Location: Nov√© mƒõsto. You can get here by metro (line B, station N√°rodn√≠ t≈ô√≠da) or tram (station Lazarsk√°).
St≈ôecha is affordable, welcoming, and one of the most famous vegan restaurants in Prague.
Safe Space Bookstore & Caf√© is a relatively new spot in Prague (it only recently celebrated its first birthday), but it‚Äôs quickly become one of my favorites. This place is a unique vegan caf√© and queer-friendly bookshop all in one.
There are always fun and inclusive events on, too, so if you‚Äôre looking for a quick vegan lunch, snack, or cocktail alongside some entertainment, why not check out Safe Space?
Menu highlights: Traditional Czech spreads and snacks, including the strange ‚ÄúCzech hot dog.‚Äù
Location: ≈Ωi≈ækov. Get here by bus, tram, or walk from Florenc Bus Station (about 12 minutes).
If you‚Äôre looking for some LGBTQ+ friends or just want an affordable place that has both delicious food and interesting books for you to peruse, Safe Space is the spot for you.
If you like your dining on the bougier side, you have to go to Palo Verde. This Prague vegan bistro is perfect for fancy brunches and celebratory dinners. My sister took a group of her friends here for her birthday, and it was honestly the perfect spot for the occasion!
Menu highlights: Personally, I really enjoyed their kimchi omelette and have heard great things about the red pesto lasagna.
Location: Palo Verde is located in Nov√© Mƒõsto, close to the Muzeum metro station (line C).
Cozy spot. Friendly staff. Fancy vibes. Also, they have board games you can borrow and play!
Let‚Äôs stick with the brunch theme! CHUTNEJ is a spot I kept getting recommended over and over again, until I finally gave in. And it‚Äôs a good thing that I did. This spot is amazing, and it‚Äôs no wonder it has such a great reputation among other Prague vegans.
It‚Äôs not just a brunch spot, either. You can get dinner here, too, as well as some delicious coffee.
Menu highlights: The above-pictured traditional Czech ‚Äúloup√°k.‚Äù I used to eat these a lot as a kid, and it was amazing to see them again in a fully vegan caf√©.
Location: Hole≈°ovice. Take the tram to Letensk√© n√°mƒõst√≠.
The way people rave about this place, why would you not want to visit CHUTNEJ?
Imagin√°rn√≠ zmrzlina is the only place that‚Äôs managed to get me excited about ice cream in recent years. And there‚Äôs a reason for that. This place genuinely has some of the best ice cream ever. Whether you‚Äôre a fan of traditional flavors or prefer more adventurous options, this tiny caf√© has it all.
Menu highlights: The poppy ice cream. Just trust me on this.
Location: Karl√≠n, near the Florenc bus and metro stations.
This is the best ice cream I‚Äôve had in years. And I mean that.
Loving Hut isn‚Äôt exactly for those of you looking for a fine-dining experience, but it is a staple in Prague‚Äôs vegan restaurant scene. It‚Äôs an affordable vegan buffet chain that offers a variety of Asian-inspired dishes.
Here, you serve yourself. Just pick up a box or a plate and load it with whatever you fancy. You pay by weight here, which makes it perfect for those of you on a budget.
Menu highlights: Noodles, curries, dumplings, sushi, and more.
Location: There‚Äôs a bunch of these all over Prague, including N√°rodn√≠ t≈ô√≠da and Karl√≠n.
If you‚Äôre on a budget or in a rush but still want to eat out, try one of these buffets!
Pastva is a small vegan restaurant in Prague that I can wholeheartedly recommend. I took my friend from the UK here, and we had some delicious ‚Äúlango≈°e‚Äù here (as pictured above). We were stuffed by the end of the meal, but I‚Äôm fully planning to come back and try some of their tasty-looking desserts.
Menu highlights: Lango≈°, which is a beloved dish in Czechia. Their risottos look incredible, too!
Location: Andƒõl, Prague 5. Close to the Andƒõl metro station (line B).
For the stylish atmosphere, comfort food, and craft cocktails, of course.
Similar to Loving Hut, Dhaba Beas is an affordable chain of vegetarian and vegan buffets that you can find all over Prague. Most of the meals are India-style, and while I wouldn‚Äôt exactly call them authentic, many of them really do hit the spot if you‚Äôre looking for someone quick and easy.
Menu highlights: They have these little soy pieces in peanut sauce that are to die for.
Location: Trust me, Dhaba Beas is everywhere. If you walk around Prague city center for 15 minutes, you‚Äôre bound to find at least one. But just in case, here‚Äôs a map of all the different locations.
It‚Äôs super affordable, and you pay per weight here, too, so there‚Äôs less danger of unnecessary food waste.
Last but not least, we have Linh‚Äôs Vegan Corner, a place that I just can‚Äôt resist. This Asian-style restaurant has a super comprehensive menu. As vegans, we‚Äôre often used to not having too many options. But not here. This place has a lot on offer, and it‚Äôs honestly a struggle to just pick one or two things each visit.
(Maybe that‚Äôs why I always end up ordering from this restaurant above most others.)
Menu highlights: I‚Äôm obsessed with the Black Magic Udon. Also, the traditional vegan honey cake here is a must!
Location: Vinohrady, aka one of the coolest parts of Prague.
Their Instagram says that this place is just like a fairy tale, and I have to agree. It‚Äôs that good.
Got some questions? Here are some answers.
A: Yes! As this guide shows, Prague has a blossoming vegan scene where you can find everything from casual buffets to cool brunch spots and bougie restaurants (perfect for those Instagram travel pics).
A: Go to St≈ôecha for amazing vegan versions of Czech classic dishes like sv√≠ƒçkov√° (sirloin with creamy sauce), bread and potato dumplings, and beer goulash.
A: Yes! Try Loving Hut and Dhaba Beas for quick vegan meals under ‚Ç¨10.
A: Palo Verde and CHUTNEJ are definitely up there. Or, if you‚Äôre a member of the LGBTQ+ community (or an ally), head to Safe Space for books and brunch!
A: Definitely! Most of the popular, big grocery stores like Albert, Lidl, Billa, and Tesco have all you could possibly need, including plant-based milk, meat alternatives, tofu, tempeh, and vegan snacks. Albert has vegan pastries, too, which are great if you‚Äôre looking for a quick snack. Other than that, DM Drogerie is also a good place if you‚Äôre looking for some fancier vegan products.
A: No! Most restaurant staff in Prague‚Äôs vegan restaurants and caf√©s speak English. In fact, most Czechs speak English, especially those who live in Prague. They‚Äôll probably be happy they get to practice their language skills with you.
Whether you‚Äôre looking for traditional Czech dishes or international cuisine, Prague has a ton of vegan options available to you. This list featured some of my and my friends‚Äô favorite spots, but there are many more. So feel free to explore the city and enjoy the best of vegan food that Prague has to offer.
And please, do let me know if you try any of these spots ‚Äî or if you have other favorites that I forgot to mention.

Some cool historical stuff to know about Prague before you go
Defiant. Resilient. Betrayed. Those are the words that come to mind as I walk through the streets of Prague for the first time and learn about this historic city on the Vltava River.
It is hard not to experience Prague and feel the weight of history that bears down of the city and the Czech people, who over the course of the last nearly 700 years, have been ruled for a majority of that time by other states, nations and empires.
Prague got off to a really strong start in the 14th Century under King Charles IV, who strengthened the economy, started the first university in Central Europe and expanded the Prague Castle, including starting construction of St. Vitus Cathedral. He also commissioned the famous bridge across the Vltava, which was started on July 9, 1357, at 5:31 a.m. when he laid the first stone. This is well known because the date and time create a numerical palindrome (1‚Äì3‚Äì5‚Äì7‚Äì9‚Äì7‚Äì5‚Äì3‚Äì1), which meant something to Medieval numerologists, who must have been on to something because the original bridge is still standing strong, 668 years later.
Despite its promising start as the capital of the Kingdom of Bohemia, Prague fell into the hands the Hapsburgs, when Ferdinand I was elected by the Bohemian nobility as king after their ruler, King‚Ä¶

Title: My 2‚Äìday Trip to Prague
Content:
Sign up

Sign up

As a Master‚Äôs student living in Munich for almost a year, I hadn‚Äôt ventured outside of Germany much, except for a brief visit to Maastricht. After finishing my exams two weeks ago, my friends and I decided to take a weekend trip to Prague. Being students, we couldn‚Äôt afford a longer trip without stretching our finances, and we all had commitments the following week. So, we planned a straightforward two-day trip, determined to make the most of our limited time.
Our plan was simple: catch a Flixbus from Munich to Prague at 7 a.m. on Saturday, arriving at noon, and return by 8 p.m. on Sunday. We booked a hostel near the city center so we could explore Prague on foot without worrying about public transportation. It seemed foolproof ‚Äî what could go wrong?
Well, things didn‚Äôt go quite as planned. We all made it to the bus on time, only to discover that the seats we had booked together in row 20 didn‚Äôt exist. The bus wasn‚Äôt configured as expected, and when we asked the Flixbus employee, he simply shrugged, saying there wasn‚Äôt much they could do. So, we reluctantly sat in random seats, separated from each other.
The journey was supposed to be straightforward, but when we made a stop in Regensburg, things took a turn. The bus, already nearly full when we left Munich, was supposed to be a two-story vehicle, but instead, it was a single-story bus. At Regensburg, there were many passengers waiting to board, but not enough seats. It quickly became clear that there had been a mix-up. The employees informed the waiting passengers that they‚Äôd have to wait for the next bus, which would arrive in two hours. This didn‚Äôt sit well with two elderly Ukrainian women who boarded the bus and refused to get off until the next bus arrived. As a result, we were all forced to wait for two hours.
Frustrated by the delay, we decided to grab some coffee to stay awake, as we were all pretty tired from the early start. While waiting outside the bus, a young Canadian couple approached us, asking for directions to the bakery where we had bought our coffee. The guy went to get their drinks, while the girl stayed and joined our conversation. We learned that they were from Quebec and had been exploring Europe for a week, also heading to Prague. When the guy returned, we chatted for about an hour, discussing everything from European culture to the situation with the two Ukrainian women holding up our trip.
About 20 minutes before the other bus was due to arrive, a shy teenage girl slowly joined our conversation. We found out she was from Prague and had been taking a German course in Regensburg. Her local knowledge came in handy, and we asked her for recommendations on what to see and do in Prague.
Finally, after what felt like an eternity, the second bus arrived, and the extra passengers boarded. We resumed our journey, but by the time we reached Prague, I was in desperate need of a bathroom. After handling that situation, we checked in at our hostel, which was conveniently located near the city center. The hostel was basic, a small room on the 5th floor with four beds and no windows, but thankfully it had air conditioning, as the weather was quite warm.
We took quick showers and headed out to explore the city. By then, it was already 3 p.m., so we started with a checking out the exterior of the National Czech Museum, right next to our hostel. Prague‚Äôs architecture immediately captivated us ‚Äî vibrant colors, tiled streets, and historic buildings at every turn.
Feeling hungry, we went to a Czech restaurant recommended by the girl we met on the bus and tried traditional dishes like Sv√≠ƒçkov√° and Czech goulash, accompanied by the famous Czech beer. Fun fact: the Czech Republic has the highest beer consumption per capita in the world, which was surprising to learn, given that I live in Bavaria.
After our meal, we made our way to the Old Town Square, passing the quirky Dancing House and numerous tourists along the way. We couldn‚Äôt resist trying Trdeln√≠k, a sweet treat made of a cinnamon roll-like cone filled with ice cream and fruits. Delicious as it was, it attracted a lot of bees ‚Äî something to keep in mind if you ever try it!
At the Old Town Hall, we met up with the Canadian couple again to see the Prague Astronomical Clock. Afterward, we walked through the city, crossing the beautiful Charles Bridge over the Vltava River, surrounded by stunning views and people enjoying boat rides. We decided to save the boat ride for the next day and continued towards Prague Castle. The hike up to the castle was challenging, but the view was worth it. Although the ticket booth for the castle interior was closed, we explored the castle grounds and admired the colorful, doll-like houses on Golden Lane.
By this point, we had walked nearly 15 kilometers and were ready for dinner. After trying several places that were either full or had closed kitchens, we found a laid-back burger place where we ate and drank until 11 p.m. Exhausted, we finally called it a day and returned to our hostel.
The next day, we started with breakfast at a local caf√©, then headed to the Czech National Museum. This museum was incredible, with rooms dedicated to everything from minerals and history to World War II and various species of animals. We spent four hours there, completely absorbed in the exhibits.
After the museum, we met up with the Canadian couple again for a planned boat ride on the Vltava River. However, the boat operator warned us of an impending storm, which we didn‚Äôt believe at first because the weather seemed fine. Fast forward a little, and we were running through the rain to the nearest restaurant. The storm dashed our hopes for the boat ride, but we found a fantastic Italian restaurant where we spent the next two hours waiting for the rain to subside, enjoying great pizza, beer, and conversation.
As the rain eased, we reluctantly made our way back to the bus station, still a bit wet and tired. Despite a half-hour delay, the return bus ride was uneventful, and we finally arrived in Munich at 3 a.m., facing long routes home via public transport.
Despite the challenges and setbacks, the trip to Prague was incredibly satisfying. The city left a lasting impression, and I‚Äôm already eager to return to explore more ‚Äî like the Jewish Cemetery, beer bath, Sex Machine Museum, Beer Museum, Ice Bar, Torture Museum, and many more fascinating places.
I‚Äôm writing this recollection of my trip to Prague in order to preserve the beautiful memories I had. I hope you enjoy it as much as I did!

Title: 6 Things you Must Do in Prague
Content:

The Charles bridge is one of the busiest spots in Prague because of its beautiful gothic structure and central location. If you wanna avoid the crowds, head over later in the day as it gets dark. But if you‚Äôre looking for a souvenir or a performance make sure you get there before 4 to see the street performers work their magic or buy a painted picture of the city‚Äôs scenery. For the best views on the Charles Bridge, take in a sunset view or climb the tower at the foot of the bridge for just 100 Czech crowns (around 5 U.S. dollars) for some beautiful views at the top.
The Prague castle is one of the most visited spots in Prague and it boasts incredible architecture at the top of a hill offering spectacular views. Head there on a weekday for less crowds. If you‚Äôre traveling on a budget you can get inside the back area for free, or pay a small fee to get closer up to the front and see the whole thing. To avoid walking up the big hill, take the tram up the hill and walk back down for the beautiful views.
This monastery has been named the most beautiful library in the world. Go just two tram stops beyond the Prague Castle for a chance to see the beautiful painted ceilings. The monastery does have a charge to go inside, as well as a small fee to be able to take pictures of the inside. Also note that you cannot go fully inside the rooms but can get a view beyond a roped off area.
The dancing house is a marvel of Czech modern cubist architecture along the Vlatva river. Take a tour of the museum and gallery or ride the elevator to the top floor for a restaurant and outdoor deck. Just order a drink or some food and get access to the outdoor viewing area with a 360 view. Fun fact: you can see 9 different bridges in the distance from the top of Dancing House!
For one of the most iconic Prague sights, head to Old Town Square and the astronomical clock tower. A huge crowd gathers as the time reaches the hour and people wait for the clock to change. Get there 15‚Äì20 minutes early for the best views. The clock also has an inside museum that gives you its history and lets you see the other side of the characters that pop out of the clock.
Wenceslas Square has been called the Times Square of Prague. It‚Äôs just a short walk from Old Town and named after the Czech Saint Wenceslas. It has a combo of shops and restaurants, with several traditional Czech restaurants as well as street food. Right in the heart of Wenceslas Square is also a bustling nightlife with a variety of clubs and bars that stay open late and attract large crowds. You can also hope to catch an outdoor food festival, held seasonally and offering street food like sausages and hot wine and beer.

Vienna, Slovakia, Budapest and Prague are very common tourist stops in the central Europe vacation circuit. The architecture has similar trends (some cities survived the World Wars better than others), their history is tied together by royal families, common wars and the development of governments as they stand today.
We really enjoyed our guide and the history lesson she shared on our walking tour in Prague. She explained they had three massive invasions in the last few decades: first, by the Germans who stripped their culture and language and replaced it with German. Second by the Soviets who drew the iron curtain for many years. And then most recently by tourists‚Ä¶ who have come to explore this relatively new country (it separated from Slovakia in 1993) and is still trying to solidify its routines for decades before.
We also learned a few shocking pieces of history‚Ä¶ Prague is actually one of the best preserved cities in Europe. Why you ask? Because Hitler wanted to retire in Prague. So he didn‚Äôt bomb it.
It was only bombed twice: once by the Americans by mistake (funny right?), who thought they were bombing Dresden in Germany. Both cities are super close, and I guess they just made the mistake. And then by the Nazis, two days before the end of the war. But not much was destroyed.
Another one that is even more grim ‚Äî Prague has the best preserved Jewish quarter in Europe. And that is because Hitler wanted to keep it as a museum of the extinct Jewish race. Yeah, pretty dark stuff.
Lots was absorbed here. We met some great people and hung out a few times during our stay as well as had the chance to watch the most crazy football match‚Ä¶ England vs. Croatia with a bar that had hundreds of UK fans!! A few thousand people in a biergarden outside, mostly intoxicated. Whenever a team would score a goal, beers were flying in the air. Full beers, I should mention. A 0.5L beer in Prague costs about 2$, so people are not too careful when they challenge gravity with it. We went back home covered in ale.

Sigmund Freud likes to hang around. üòâ Fun fact: this was a statue in memory of his crazy experiments, and caused a high call volume of 911 calls in the city as locals and tourists assumed it was a real person.
‚ÄúWhy don‚Äôt you Taj Mahal the shit out of it?‚Äù is what the Rolling Stones said when they decided to paid for the lights on the Prague Castle since at night in the 1990‚Äôs, since it had no lights on it until then.
The Summer Palace, and the astronomer who made discoveries from this location was killed by a blater infection‚Ä¶ as he was too nervous to go to the bathroom and leave his meal with the king‚Ä¶
England vs. Croatia semi-final game at a beer garden in Prague. All I can say is that UK fans are crazy‚Ä¶and a few beer showers were had.

Title: 7 Reasons You Need to Add Prague to Your Bucket List
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Ah Prague,
Forget Paris being the city of love. Prague, in my opinion, takes the prize! It‚Äôs one of the most well-preserved and beautiful cities in the world. I‚Äôve had the pleasure of visiting several times and I never seem to get bored! There is always something new to discover or somewhere new to explore. Despite the cobblestones causing me to stumble every few steps or almost being hit by a tram, I have fallen in love with this charming medieval city.
Since my first trip there at sixteen, which was a bazillion years ago, I have been back 5 times. And no matter how many times I visit, I never seem to shake off the feeling that I am walking through a fairytale. I still haven‚Äôt found prince charming, but the hunt isn‚Äôt over!
Everything from the historical bridges to the hidden cobblestoned alleyways to the vibrant buildings, Prague really is a place that should be on everyone‚Äôs bucket list.
To inspire your inner wanderlust, and hopefully get you to start planning your trip to Prague, these are the things that made me fall in love with the city. If this list doesn‚Äôt convince you, I don‚Äôt know what will!
Walking through Prague feels like visiting a neverending history museum. It‚Äôs one of the very few European cities not destroyed by the World War II bombings, so most of the architectural beauty is original and more than eight centuries old. Each building has a distinct style and color, and to me, that is one of the things that makes this city so special. I love walking around and imagining who lived in them right after they were built or what they were used for.
A few of my favorite architectural gems are Charles Bridge, National Theater, and Municipal House. Prague is best explored by ditching the map and just getting lost. You never know what you might find.
Prague has a reputation for being one of the most beautiful cities in Europe and there is no better way to experience that beauty than from an elevated vantage point. There are so many places to get spectacular views, you really can‚Äôt go wrong. My personal favorite is the Letna Park Beer Garden. On a warm day, it‚Äôs the perfect spot to grab a cold beer and gaze out at the picturesque city below or better yet, watch the sunset. There is no better way to end your day.
One of my favorite aspects of Prague is the vibrancy. It‚Äôs a city with so much going on day in and day out and can be overwhelming to pick and choose where to go and what to do, but being in a city with too much choice has never been a bad thing in my book. Let‚Äôs just hope indecisiveness isn‚Äôt your weakness because then you might have a problem.
Prague‚Äôs mystery is one I have yet to crack, and I hope to keep it that way. With a history dating back over 2000 years and the fact that all the buildings are original and intact, makes it one of the most interesting, spellbinding and mysterious cities in Europe. I always seem to discover a new part of the city every time I visit.
These days, finding cheap destinations in Europe has become more difficult. Unfortunately, Prague isn‚Äôt as cheap as some of it‚Äôs Eastern European neighbors, but that doesn‚Äôt mean that it‚Äôs not one of the more affordable places to visit. You can easily find budget-friendly activities and restaurants scattered all over the city.
One of my favorite resources for finding budget-friendly things to do is Like a Local. Locals will give you tips on restaurants, attractions, shopping and nightlife and a lot of times they will recommend places that tourists don‚Äôt normally know about. You can save quite a bit of money if you are willing to venture out of the city center.
Smazeny Syr is a delicious traditional Czech food you can‚Äôt leave Prague without trying. This fried cheese dish is found pretty much everywhere from the simplest food cart to the classiest restaurant. Fast food places will usually serve it as a sandwich, which makes for a pretty amazing snack after a night out, but most commonly it is served on its own with a side salad or potatoes. Don‚Äôt order it on your first day because you might not want to try anything else.
Is there anything like watching a sunset after a busy day of sightseeing? I personally think it‚Äôs the best way to finish off a day. Ohhh, that rhymes! Prague has several vantage points where you can witness mother natures phenomenon. Many of the places will have cafes where you can grab a drink, find a seat as you watch the sun slowly sinking below the horizon.
A few of my favorite spots to watch the sunset are, Letna Park, Stefanikuv Most (a bridge with less foot traffic than Charles Bridge), Vy≈°ehrad, and Prague Castle. Although watching the sunset with Prague Castle in the background is pretty incredible.

My Guide in the Czech Republic (main part Prague)
In this article, I am going to answer the FAQ about Prague and give you some tips about the city.
I have been living in the city for 4 years and whenever I go for a walk in the old town, I feel like it is my first time visiting the city. That‚Äôs why I decided to work as a tour guide for a while. I don‚Äôt do it anymore, except private tours from time to time.
So, let Is go through the things that you want to know before coming to the Magical City.
*I will recommend videos to watch or website(s) to visit in each section, some of the videos may don‚Äôt have accurate information such as exchange rate but the information is useful no matter when you come to Prague ;)
The Czech Republic is not in the eurozone, the official currency of the Czech Republic is the Czech crown (Kƒç/ in English CZK). 1 euro is around 25CZK. You will find a link to the Czech National Bank and to a website with the best exchange point in Prague in the end of this section.
Coins: 1, 2, 5, 10, 20 and 50 CZK * All the coins are useful (not the case with euros ‚Äî 1cent, 2cent, 5cent) Banknotes: 100, 200, 500, 1000, 2000 and 5000 CZK
*You should avoid the 2000 and 5000 banknotes for small purchases.
Although CZK is the official currency in the Czech Republic, you still can pay by Euro almost everywhere specially in Prague. However, you will not get the best exchange rate except in the international chains (supermarkets, coffee chains, fast-food chains, ‚Ä¶).
Czech National Bank
How to exchange money by (Honest Guide)
Prague without cash by (Honest Guide)
Public transport is efficient in Prague in a way that you don‚Äôt need a rental car or taxis. Actually, it is cheaper and faster xD. There are 3 lines of Metro, 10s of tramways, and 100s of buses.
The tickets for a single trip are for 30 minutes (for 24czk) or 90 minutes (for 32czk). The daily ticket (24h) is for 110czk and if you are here for 3 days (72h) your ticket costs 310czk.
*If you are willing to stay more than 5 days, I recommend buying a monthly ticket for 570czk
For more details check these videos:
How to buy a ticket (Honest Guide)
Travelling around the city (Honest Guide)
Prague Public Transport at Night (Honest Guide)
How to get from Prague‚Äôs airport to the city center (Honest Guide)
GOING TO PRAGUE BY TRAIN OR BUS (Honest Guide)
To find transport connection, check out this website (they have also mobile app) www.idos.cz
To rent bikes use Rekola, but you will need a credit card to use the app.
You can use Uber and yeah it is possible to pay by cash or taxi companies like Tick Tack, Nejlevnƒõj≈°√≠ Taxi or MODR√ù ANDƒöL (if you went out with your car and end up drinking beers with your friends, they can give you a ride for you and your car xD at night).
*Ride for the airport to the city center should cost you around 500czk (20 euro), be careful from scams.
You have many options such as Hotels, Hostels, Airbnb, apartments, etc. I am going to describe the different areas by character so that it helps you choosing the right place.
Old town : you won‚Äôt need transportation since everything is close to you. However, a lot of going on around and there is a big possibility that you won‚Äôt have a calm night.
Lesser town (mal√° strana) : It is near the castle, Charles Bridge and many beautiful parks. You will need transportation and there are almost no supermarkets nearby (most of the prices are for tourists).
New Town : A great neighborhood, restaurants and caf√©s are excellent in the area. Most of your neighbors are tourists, those who hurry up are called the locals. You will need transportation and fortunately there are two metro stations in the area and many tramways pass by that zone.
The rest of the areas are cheaper, calmer (exception: ≈Ωi≈ækov) and most of the residents are locals, so you won‚Äôt be scammed.
During my work as a tour guide, I met tens of people who planned their stay in Prague just one day or two days and double of that period in Budapest (sometimes more time for Bratislava than Prague :D). I think you know what I am going to say by now. Minimum days to spend in Prague should be 3 or 4 days. If you want to enjoy the city and yourself, one week to 10 days.
Plan A ‚Äî 3 days:
You should not enter every monument/museum in your way. Consider taking transportation so that you won‚Äôt be tired by the end of the day.
Plan B ‚Äî royal stay:
Life is good, you have enough time to visit the main monuments, party, enjoy the traditional Czech cuisine and save energy for the next city/country.
Plan Z ‚Äî Underestimated city / just 1 night or even less
You can start by Prague Castle (don‚Äôt spend more than 60 -90 minutes in that area)than follow the Royal way (Coronation route). Next stop will be Charles Bridge that will lead you to the old Town Square. You should be tired by now from walking, so reward yourself by a hot coffee in Skautsk√Ω Institut or another place (avoid the coffees in the square if you don‚Äôt want to be scammed) .
You should have enough time to enjoy a traditional dish. Later on, go to Wenceslas Square.
*This can be done the other way around (from Wenceslas Square to the Castle, but I recommend the first direction because Prague Castle in on the top of the Hill).
COOLEST DISTRICT in PRAGUE (Honest Guide)
1000czk without accommodation is fair enough. I will tell you why :
Transport: 110czk for 24h
Food: 600czk (150‚Äì200 per meal)
Coffee&cake: 150czk (coffee for 50czk, cake for 100czk)
The rest can be used for entrance to museum (sometimes it will cost you 250 czk, but generally around 150czk or less)
The list is so long, you should make your priorities. If you like museums, Prague offers museum for any kind of thing (Torture, toys, chocolate, Lego, Apple Inc.,). You love outdoors?.. well Prague offers that too, but if you can‚Äôt stand cold weather, you should visit the City during Spring or Summer Season.
The must visit list that I recommend is the following:
Charles Bridge, Prague Castle, Old Town Square, Prague Zoo, Wenceslas square, National museum, etc.
However, those are the typical ones, there are other monuments and places to visit. Check out the following videos:
PRAGUE CASTLE (Honest Guide)
10 BEST INSTAGRAM SPOTS IN PRAGUE (Honest Guide)
MUST SEE HIDDEN GEM IN THE HEART OF PRAGUE (Honest Guide)
SECRET PLACES IN PRAGUE (Honest Guide)
The traditional Czech cuisine is so authentic. The food is heavy, tasty and not healthy :D Main ingredients are meat (mainly pork), potatoes, cabbage and flour. So, don‚Äôt expect salads or vegetarian food.
The best thing that you will enjoy, in the Czech Republic, are snacks and cakes.
I recommend reading this article:
https://www.tasteofprague.com/pragueblog/traditional-czech-food-in-prague-what-to-have-and-where-to-have-it
Here is also a playlist of videos from Honest Guide that I recommend to watch (included vegetarian restaurants):
Restaurants in Prague (Honest Guide)
Safety:
The City is safe and secure, but be careful in the crowded areas. There are no ghettos or not recommended areas. The Czech Republic is one of the safest countries in the world üòä.
Halal food:
There are some restaurants that offer halal food. Most of them are near to the city center. Here is a list of the restaurants, I will try to cover all the areas in Prague:
Mangal Restaurant is located in the Wenceslas square. Address: V√°clavsk√© n√°mƒõst√≠ 64, Praha
Barakat is near the mosque of the center. Address: Opletalova 28, Praha
Istanbul Kebab is also near the mosque of the center, less than 100 meters from Barakat. Address: Politick√Ωch vƒõz≈à≈Ø, 17, Praha
Jordan Restaurant in the lesser town (mala strana). So, if you are hungry and you still near the castle this should be your destination. Address: Malostransk√© n√°mƒõst√≠ 36/22, Praha
Saf√≠r is a good Lebanese restaurant. You can find it in different malls (OC Nov√Ω Sm√≠chov, Ark√°dy Pankr√°c, OC DBK ‚Äî Budƒõjovick√° , OC Chodov) * OC stands for Commercial Center. Here is their website http://www.isafir.cz , but it is not updated.
*if you are so into halal things, you should go 100% vegan in this country or buy expensive food from bio supermarkets/restaurants.
Different products use pork gelatin or other extracted products from pork. These products can be yogurt, sweet bakery (even croissant), etc.
If you want to have bolognaise or burger with mashed beef meat, make sure that is not mixed with pork (in non halal places).
Mosques:
Mosque of the center: Opletalova 930/28, 110 00 Praha 1 (be advised, it is located inside a building)
Mosque Alfirdaus : Na Ko≈°ince 502/1, 180 00 Praha 8-Libe≈à
Mosque of ƒåern√Ω Most: Blatsk√° 1491, 198 00 Praha 9
Other tips:
Keep in mind that the Czech Republic is in the CENTER of Europe and not in the East. Also avoid saying Czechia, no one like it.

The first light of dawn slips through the curtains of our hotel room. I glance over at my girlfriend, already awake, her eyes tracing the soft glow filtering in. Neither of us know why we‚Äôre up so early. It‚Äôs not jet lag or the faint hum of the city outside. So maybe, it‚Äôs the anticipation of wanting to see a side of Prague that most visitors miss.
We step outside into the cool morning air. The cobblestones feel damp beneath our feet. Street lamps cast soft halos in the mist, and somewhere in the distance, a bird begins to sing. The city feels quiet, almost like it‚Äôs waiting for something to happen.
We turn the corner together and spot the Old Town Hall. Its underground played a pivotal role in the Prague Uprising against Nazism. Attached to it is the Astronomical Clock, a medieval wonder that shows the positions of the Sun, Moon, Earth, and Zodiac constellations.
Humanity has tried to measure time for millennia. From the Maya in Mesoamerica to Mesolithic hunter-gatherers in the UK‚Ä¶

Title: Czechia: Prancing Through Prague
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

Life by way of travel.

--
Listen
Share
Prague is a beautiful city. The river flows through the heart of it with the Disney-looking castle perched atop a hillside in the background. Its baroque and romanesque architecture give it an air of elegance that is incredibly unique.
The Old Town Square is the main area boasting beautiful buildings and the famous Orloj, an astronomical clock that sings at the top of every hour. It was teeming with tourists, so we didn‚Äôt stay too long in that area. And, unfortunately similar to Amsterdam, many of the streets were overflowing with trash and graffitied walls, which degraded the beauty of the city. In addition, overwhelming crowds and poor weather influenced our perception of Prague. It was obscenely hot the first few days, which gave us limited time to prance about before the sun scorched down on us and we had to take refuge inside shady cafes. But, the last few days cooled off and it even started raining out of the blue so we had to take cover again.
Despite an abundance of tourists and hot weather, we found that the best way to enjoy ourselves was by venturing out of the main town squares and finding solace along the side streets. Wandering along Old Town‚Äôs cobblestone streets was a great way to spend our time because we felt like this was more of an ideal way to experience this archetypal European city. I also had a chance to discover a specialty of Czech desserts: the trdeln√≠k chimney. It‚Äôs a funnel-cake filled with soft-serve ice cream and smells like a cinnamon roll. You can often find bakers on the streets baking the dough on a rotating spit then rolling it in cinnamon and sugar before filling it up with soft-serve. It was delicious confection for any sweet-tooth to enjoy!
In Vrtba garden, I got to see a photoshoot with a fashion model walking throughout the grounds. And I followed in her footsteps popping some poses myself.
We also got a great view walking up the steps of the Italian-style gardens and seeing the city beyond them. But, the best sights (and sounds) were yet to come‚Ä¶
The walk to Prague Castle was one of our favorite parts of the city. First, we started the walk from the Powder Tower, then up and over Charles Bridge. Charles Bridge is an attraction all by itself. Built in the 14th century, it‚Äôs lined with: sculptures of religious images and prolific Czech figures, street performers, artists and peddlers. It provides some of the most scenic views of the city over the Vltava River.
After crossing the bridge, we wound through cobblestone lanes and then climbed 200+ steps up to the castle entrance. Though the hike up to the castle is a bit of a workout, it‚Äôs worth it to get a spectacular view of Prague. In particular, the view at the top from the Starbucks (yep, you read that correctly; they pick the best locations!) situated in an outdoor patio setting overlooking the city was incomparable.
Once we arrived at Prague Castle, there‚Äôs no shortage of things to do. The compound includes a pretty expansive collection of eclectic buildings with museums, cafes, and archways connected by the internal castle roads. It‚Äôs a self-sufficient city unto itself similar to Windsor Castle. And, after the trek uphill we found a nice little offshoot area next to a cafe where we could sit, listen to a fountain, and cool off.
One of the best things we did was attend an organ concert in St. Vitus Cathedral, in the heart of the castle complex. St. Vitus is a 14th century Gothic church housing the tombs of many Bohemian kings and Holy Roman Emperors. It‚Äôs also the home to a great organ that‚Äôs about 3 stories tall! We got to hear the prodigious instrument in all of its glory at a special evening concert. The booming sound of the pipes reverberated through the gothic arches making the church come alive! I can only imagine how awesome it must have been to the Bohemians back in the day when this baby was first installed. The event was unbelievably special, and I savored the moment listening to the sweet tempo and the rich tones of the organ. It has inspired me to start tickling the ivories once again!

Title: Prague ‚Äî A Winter Wonderland
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

Listen
Share
A few days before Christmas, I received the Winter Holidays Edition of the Prague for Expats Newsletter. It began by saying:
‚Äúwe hope you are enjoying snowy Prague, as it really is the best time for long walks through the city and its surroundings‚Äù
I was a little taken aback by this, and my initial reaction was to question whether the author had ever visited Prague in the snow. Actually, TBH, that was my second reaction. My first wasn‚Äôt suitable for a family-oriented blog! Like many cities, Prague, in the snow, is far from being a good place for long walks. It‚Äôs not even a good place for short walks, especially in the city centre or ‚Äúhistoric Prague‚Äù as it‚Äôs called in the guidebooks. For several days that week before Christmas, I felt more locked down than during the official lockdowns during the pandemic. During the pandemic, we were just discouraged from going out, but the snow is a different matter, and like many locals, I dread snowfall in the deep midwinter. The cold I can handle, which is good because it can get mighty chilly! But, not the snow‚Ä¶
Sure, from the comfort of a room with a view, Prague is absolutely stunning under a shroud of pristine white snow. The hills surrounding the city take on a bleakness in the pale grey light, but the scenery becomes stunning when the skies turn blue. Be forewarned. Once you step outside, walking around Prague becomes a nightmare. In her 2011 song, ‚Äú50 Words for Snow‚Äù, Kate Bush got really close to the mark with ‚Äúanklebreaker‚Äù.
The problem is Prague's pavements combined with the huge footfall of thousands of tourists. It takes very little time for the white snow to turn into an ashy dirty wet sludge which on Prague‚Äôs mosaic pavements becomes a skating rink even before the wet sludge starts to refreeze. When it‚Äôs cold enough (as it was last week), the sludge quickly turns into invisible sheets of ice which are treacherous to both body and ego. Let‚Äôs face it; no one likes to look like a clown when they‚Äôre walking down a street full of people; it‚Äôs embarrassing enough when you can‚Äôt be seen!
But the problems don‚Äôt just come from under your feet. You‚Äôre constantly at risk of an attack from above as snow begins to melt on the rooftops, there‚Äôs a threat of baby avalanches, icicles spearing you and huge dollops of icy meltwater, which almost always seem to land on your glasses (or bald patches).
Prague city authorities are quick to get the gritting wagons and carts out, but this compounds the problem. Even after ten days, some of the more heavily gritted pavements are still covered in pin-sharp little stones which get stuck in the soles of your shoes and need to be picked out with that penknife attachment you never use for getting stones out of horse's shoes!
I have yet to find a single pair of shoes that can deal with Prague pavements regardless of the weather. Some are great in the summer; some work well in the rain, but none work well in any snow conditions ‚Äî not even proper mountain boots! I had a pair of ECCO Gore-tex shoes which were the best all-rounders, but sadly, these have been decimated by five years of constant usage walking around the city.
So, don‚Äôt be fooled by the tour guides, the glossy guidebooks and the slick videos showcasing our beautiful city under a fresh fall of snow. Call up an Uber to take you to Petrin Hill, up to Prague Castle, or over to Vitkov Hill, walk a few hundred yards, and marvel at the panoramas. Then get back in your taxi and get comfy in the hotel bar until the thaw has completed.
Unless, of course, you really want to put the Czech health system to the test or find out how good your insurance is!
I am a semi-retired independent management consultant specialising in organisational change management and better Ways of Working. I‚Äôm from the UK but based in Prague in the Czech Republic. I mainly write about developing better ways of working, working in the Apple ecosystem, and my adopted home in Prague. I‚Äôm still fairly new to Medium (so please be gentle with me!) but if you‚Äôve enjoyed this, please check out some of my other articles or even follow me if you‚Äôd like to be notified when I publish new material

Title: Why Prague Shines
Content:

Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

Bay Area Travel Writers tell stories through media, old and new‚Ää‚Äî‚Äänewspapers, magazines, broadcasts, blogs, videos, books, and online publications.

--
3
Listen
Share
I suspect that on a clear day, when seen from the moon, Prague glitters like a sparkler. It seems like every Old-World store window gleams with crystal: bowls, bottles, bells, boxes, baskets, trays, vases, ladles, plates, jugs, wine glasses, brandy snifters, beer steins, cups and saucers, napkin holders, atomizers, and assorted tchotchkes.
All that glitter sparked an idea: Buy a chandelier.
Did it matter that all I had to carry souvenirs in was a daypack? That crystal chandeliers are made of hundreds of pieces of fragile and weighty glass? That I was already carrying 18 traditional, hand-painted, blown Czech Easter eggs?
No, it didn‚Äôt matter because my husband and I had just bought a charming Victorian house in San Francisco. The showpiece dining room featured a 10-foot-high ceiling, embossed wainscoting, a bay window, a built-in Victorian hutch, an antique dining table, and, suspended down from the flowery ceiling-rose disk in the middle of the dining room: an out-of-place, two-foot-diameter, Japanese paper lantern that looked like a glowing, white beach ball.
We needed a crystal chandelier.
But we were house-poor.
At home I had checked big-box stores and boutique lighting ‚Äúshoppes,‚Äù but no chandeliers were less than $1,000, way out of our range.
Now I wandered in Prague, the Crystal Capital of the World.
My three-day trip was a personal reward after a rough week on a writing assignment in Bratislava, the capital of Slovakia. Blocky, gray, Soviet-era architecture matched blocky, gray sky and overwhelmed the tiny historic quarter. I needed picturesqueness. I needed pizzazz. I needed Prague.
Staromestsk√© n√°mest√≠ ‚Äî Prague‚Äôs medieval-to-Renaissance Old Town Square ‚Äî featured warm yellow, pastel blue, and soft peach baroque buildings with flat facades, pointed tops, and curving lines set in restful balance. Soulful violins and upbeat guitars from the lively music scene sent their melodies through the narrow alleys. Aromas of chicken paprikash, potato dumplings, and garlic soup from caf√©s and home kitchens comforted me.
Of course, I couldn‚Äôt possibly buy a chandelier. It was ridiculous enough that I imagined I could safely carry a dozen and a half hollowed eggs back to California, but their rich red and yellow colors, complex geometric patterns, and symbolism of protection seduced me.
In a shop up the hill toward Prazsky hrad ‚Äî Prague Castle ‚Äî crystal seduced me, too. I saw a chandelier for US$250 ‚Äî including sea-mail shipping. For a day I agonized about the money, but the fact that it could be shipped ‚Äî for free ‚Äî finally won me over. Late in the afternoon I was leaving Prague, I made the commitment and returned to buy it.
A different clerk was on duty.
‚ÄúOh, no, we cannot possibly ship this sea-mail. This must go airmail,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúThat will cost $100 more.‚Äù
In the rapid switch to capitalism, the Czechs were clicking ‚Äî but this development moved my chandelier out of reach.
Deeply saddened, I hurried down the hill because I needed to take the subway soon to catch the bus to the airport for the last flight to Bratislava. Across the Karluv most or Charles Bridge, which spans the River Vltava, I passed another lighting store.
A chandelier hanging in the window was perfect: hundreds of delicate crystals draped in rows ‚Äî not ostentatious, not gaudy. It was 4,440 koruna or about US$185. Even adding air-mail costs it was acceptable.
I went inside. The middle-aged saleswoman spoke no English and I no Czech so we muddled through with my pathetic German and gestures.
She had no more chandeliers of that model. Could I have the one in the window? Yes. She was so kind. We took it down together. She found a battered, yellow, cardboard box ‚Äî three feet square by two feet high. We stuffed it with newspaper and tied it with many swirls of string.
What were the costs for shipping? No shipping. No shipping? I would have to carry it.
I dashed to the money changer, checked my watch, waited in line, checked my watch again, and told the clerk how many koruna I needed. He told me how much that would be in U.S. travelers‚Äô checks.
I got the cash, dashed back to the store ‚Äî and the saleswoman pointed out that I was short by a few koruna.
Time was getting very tight now. I was glad I had already bought my subway pass.
I ran back to the money changer and explained the situation. He said, ‚ÄúOh, I did not realize you needed exact amount for purchase.‚Äù I gave him another travelers‚Äô check, he gave me more koruna, and I flew back to the store. Transaction finally complete, I checked my watch, waved a ‚ÄúThank you!‚Äù and skedaddled.
Carrying my daypack with the blown eggs and struggling with the awkward box and its heavy glass contents, I waddled around the corner to the subway station. I had seen the station many times so was comfortable that all would work out now.
Down the steps I wobbled. Stairs to the lower level were boarded up. I traipsed around in search of others. No luck. The cavernous station held delis and clothing stores, but no information booth. My heart rate increased, and sweaty palms made it harder to grip the clumsy box.
I lumbered to a magazine stand. I couldn‚Äôt afford to wait in the long line. ‚ÄúBitte, wo sind die Zuge?‚Äù I shouted in German. ‚ÄúPlease, where are the trains?‚Äù
‚ÄúGeschlossen,‚Äù said the harried clerk without looking my way.
‚ÄúGeschlossen?‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúClosed? You can‚Äôt ‚Äòclose‚Äô a train! I have to get to the bus for the airport!‚Äù You could take a train out of service, but this was a perfectly fine, obviously functioning subway station so you couldn‚Äôt just ‚Äúclose‚Äù a train.
‚ÄúThe station is closed,‚Äù said a tall, thin, dark-haired Czech man in his mid-30s standing next to me. The white plastic bag of vegetables he carried contrasted with his brown business suit. ‚ÄúThe nearest station is . . . ‚Äú and then he said something like ‚Äúup, left, right, street, around, under, right, blocks, down.‚Äù
Hyperventilation befuddled my brain. I stared at him.
He took the scruffy box and handed me the bag of vegetables. We hoofed up the stairs and dashed for several blocks through the streets of Prague, twisting left, turning right, ducking through breezeways, and finally ending up at the entrance to another subway station.
My benefactor then took his vegetables, handed me the box, and said something like ‚Äúin, right, up, along, left, over, behind, across, right.‚Äù
Again, I stared at him.
Again, he grabbed the box, gave me the veggies, led me through the dark subway maze, and deposited me on a platform. He pointed in the direction the train would go. He placed the box on the platform, and I handed him his vegetables. I bubbled over with ‚Äúthank you‚Äù and ‚Äúdanke schon‚Äù and ‚Äúb√Ωt zav√°z√°n tebe,‚Äù and he laughed as I got on the train.
So I made the bus and caught the flight but had to check the chandelier like a suitcase. The next morning before dawn I took another bus to Vienna and again had to check the chandelier as luggage on the flight home. I changed planes in New York; and when I arrived in San Francisco, the box was there ‚Äî a little battered, but upright and more-or-less the same size.
I opened it and checked the 1,392 crystals. Only one had broken. All 18 of the eggs survived, too.
The chandelier shone beautifully in our Victorian dining room. When we moved nine years later, we took it with us ‚Äî I couldn‚Äôt bear to leave it and all it represented.
As valuable and delicate as a crystal chandelier is, the more worthy ‚Äî and fragile ‚Äî factor is the kindness of human beings, and the memory I treasure most is of the smiling face and shining heart of the handsome Czech man with his suit and vegetables.
Find more of April Orcutt‚Äôs stories at Medium.com/BATW-Travel-Stories, Medium.com/Travel-Insights-And-Outtakes, AprilOrcutt.Medium.com, and AprilOrcutt.com.

Discovering Beautiful Prague Hacks
Ahoj!
Now,if you have visited the beloved continent Europe ,you already know what a gem it is for travelers.It‚Äôs almost safe to say that it is every traveler's dream destination. Not only does it have over 40 countries to be explored (most without any visa restrictions)it offers a chance to experience rich history and cultures given most European countries have different languages.This said I put myself on a challenge to explore the world a little bit more,to experience other cultures and appreciate the diversity it brings through travel and what better time to do so whilst living in Europe.This brings me to why am writing this article,I fell in love with the beautiful city Prague ever since I embarked on a 4 day trip to celebrate my birthday. It left a lasting impression because of its beauty and rich history and would like to share some hacks and tips for first time travelers based on my experience there.
1 . Pick an accommodation location that minimizes traveling
Even though Prague is a fairly affordable city in terms of cost of living ,i‚Äôd recommend finding accommodation around the namesti republiky . Here you‚Äôll find a vast amount of key monuments within its vicinity (Kotva Department Store, Municipal House, Powder Tower, Czech National Bank and Palladium shopping mall) . In addition all other key places e.g Prague castle,National Theater,Jewish Quarter are accessible by foot hence you save on the 32czk ticket that allows you 90 mins of travel using the buses/trams/metros. However should you choose an accommodation that requires you take the public transportation i‚Äôd highly recommend taking the 3 day pass ticket that costs 310 CZK.
This is not a sponsored article but am sharing the accommodation that I stayed and felt I really had value for money
emporio-prague-apartments.com
2. Be smart when it comes to currency conversion
If you are arriving from other country you should know that Czech doesn‚Äôt use Euros and instead uses Czech koruna(CZK). Hence prior to getting here I would recommend either have some loose cash around 5 euros to change at the airport exchange bureaus which give an awfully bad rate or pay your transportation by card. Please note the ticket machines only accept coins or card.Ticket cost from the airport to the Namesti republiky city center costs 32 CZK which is an equivalent of about 1.28 euros.
Recommended Exchange bureaus that had the most competitive rates eXchange, Kaprova 14/13, 110 00 Josefov, Czechia
Alfa Prague S.r.o., Na P≈ô√≠kopƒõ 957, 110 00 Star√© Mƒõsto, Czechia
Another important thing to be mindful about is the cash withdrawals or payments when using cards because of the bank conversions. Locals have recommended that its better to pay in czk than your bank currency when using a card for payments.
3.Maximize your itinerary (Use the free maps shared either in hotels or airport!)
Am sure if you google what to do in Prague in x number of days you‚Äôll find tonnes of information. Whilst this is nice as it gives you an idea of what is available I highly recommend that you pick up the free maps offered at the airports on your way out,they are really handy in giving you a visual of where the places you ought to visit are!! I got a really cool map at the airport that had listed all the key places to visit,metro line guide and Prague city tourism information. I found this to be truly useful as it enabled me make an optimized visit schedule since I could see the location of each place I wanted to visit and the proximity to other places.
4.Book a free tour prior to arriving
You‚Äôd be amazed at how much you learn about Czech through these free tours which at the end you give whatever amount you see best.
Fun fact : Did you know which music Neil Armstrong took to the moon? wait for it‚Ä¶Anton√≠n Dvo≈ô√°k‚Äôs New World Symphony is the answer! :) .He was a famous Czech composer. I didn‚Äôt know this until i had this tour :p.
Link to the free tour that i used
freewalkingtourprague.eu
5.Eat,Explore,Reflect and Repeat
Travelling is fun but even better when we can use that chance to learn about a new culture and people. Explore the local foods and experiences ,you must agree having Italian cuisine in Prague is probably a not so good idea. Also take time to reflect and appreciate the precious moments and memories made in the new place.
My short recommended list of top foods and things to do
Hidden gem I stumbled upon :Restaurace U Dvou Velbloud≈Ø, Ko≈æn√° 474, 110 00 Star√© Mƒõsto, Czechia
Hidden gem i stumbled upon :Na≈°e maso, Dlouh√° 727/39, 110 00 Star√© Mƒõsto, Czechia
There are two points at the Charles bridge that you can make a wish (Statue of St John Nepomuk and the statue in the picture below) :) i made my wish for ‚Ä¶
If you are a lover for animals this is totally worth it !. For (250 CZK) as entrance fee, I got to see so many amazing animals and reconnect with mother nature through the trail walks.
Accessing the Prague castle courtyards and gardens is free. The golden lane is free to access after closing hours (please note that the houses aren‚Äôt accessible however). Whilst you have plenty to do I highly recommend buying one of the tickets to access some Prague castle structures.Depending on which circuit you choose you either pay 350 CZK or 250 CZK. I chose to go with the circuit B ticket that gave me access to the Old Royal Palace,Basilica of St.George,Golden Lane and the St.Vitus‚Äôs Cathedral. There is so much history in these places and for a moment at the golden lane I felt as if I traveled back in time.
There‚Äôs so much to share and this is definitely not exhaustive . However I shared my top hacks I believe are handy for first time travelers to Prague. Thank you for taking time to read this article and don‚Äôt forget to share your Prague stories.
Dekuji!!

Title: Prague in the Movies
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

A personal tour guide of Prague and Czech Republic

--
Listen
Share
Prague is a hot destination for the movie production. And not only the city itself, but all Czech Republic. Especially in the last decades there are more and more foreign producers exploring the beauties of our country.
One of the main reasons why we are so popular are lower prices and tax incentives. Only in Prague you can find Barrandov movie studios, the largest film studio in the country and one of the largest in Europe, nicknamed ‚ÄúEuropean Hollywood.‚Äù And, the most important, is the architecture. It offers the new and old, romantic and scary places. You do not need to travel anywhere else to find Venice, Paris or Vienna on the same street! :-)
Many, many movies were filmed in Prague and here I‚Äôm bringing you a few of them, in this limited space. It might be also a nice idea what to watch them prior coming to Prague ;-)
Mission: Impossible 1 (1996) and 4: Ghost Protocol (2011)
Nothing is impossible for Tom Cruise. To run across the Charles Bridge just within a few seconds or stealing from the Russians atPrague Castle. Large parts of these movies were shot not only in the historical centre (Old Town Square, National Museum, Wenceslas Square, Kampa Island, Municipal House‚Ä¶) but also in wider Prague areas ‚Äî Vy≈°ehrad Castle or Strahov Stadium.
Btw, Mission: Impossible 1 was the very first foreign movie made in Prague after the fall of communist regime.
Amadeus (1984)
Probably the best and the most known movie ever made in Prague is Amadeus. Filmed in 1984, so when we still had communistic regime, by Czech director Milo≈° Forman (who had to leave the country because of the same regime). The plot of the movie is set in Vienna, telling the story of two rival composers ‚Äî Mozart and Salieri. It won eight Oscars including Best Picture, Best Actor and Best Director. That‚Äôs pretty good, isn‚Äôt it?
The best filming location to visit is the Estates Theatre, where the real Mozart premiered his opera Don Giovanni. Among others, try to stop in Wallenstein Garden, Strahov Monastery, St. Giles church or Colloredo ‚Äî Mansfred Palace.
Casino Royale (2006)
Agent 007 had to make it to Prague one day, no doubt about it. Some of the place where he is walking, running and shooting were filmed in Strahov Monastery, National Museum or Prague Airport that was supposed to be‚Ä¶ well, Miami Airport :)
Actually, most of the movie was shot in other towns, such as Loket and Karlovy Vary. Especially in Karlovy Vary, the movie makers decided to use again famous Grandhotel Pupp ‚Äî that you might know from another movie, The Last Holiday with Queen Latifah and G√©rard Depardieu.
Operation: Daybreak (1975) or Anthropoid (2016)
One of the most important moments in the history of WW2 is the arrival of the Butcher of Prague and his eventual assassination in 1942 by two Czechoslovakian paratroopers. There are several Czech movies dedicated to this operation. Speaking about those made in English language, you must watch Operation: Daybreak and the new Anthropoid movie, both filmed also on the authentic locations. They display the bravery of Czechs and how terrible price we had to pay.
To find out more about what really happened in 1942, join my Memorial Tour.
Child 44 (2015)
Movie based on a book that tells the story of the Russian military police (Tom Hardy and Gary Oldman) investigating a series of a child murders during the Stalin era in Russia. Movie makers decided to come to Prague especially because of the underground stations (dated back to communistic time) but also for the interiors. One of them is the National Museum. However, the director Ridley Scott did not like the facade of the National Museum and asked to repaint it. He was quite confused when the city did not allow him to do it. :)
Btw, did you know that for the filming, producers had to stop the operation of Prague‚Äôs underground? That happened for the first time in our history. You can imagine how locals were happy about it :)
Les Mis√©rables (1998)
Probably the best version of Victor Hugo‚Äôs story and made in Prague! The cast is perfect, starring Liam Neeson, Uma Thurman or Geoffrey Rush and the setting even more splendid. For many travellers Prague really look like a small Paris and if not, it is easy to make by using film effects. That‚Äôs how the movie makers replaced St.Vitus Cathedral for Notre Dame de Paris in one scene, but in the other one you can see our Cathedral back again :)
Yentl (1984)
Barbra Streisand and the song ‚ÄúPapa, Can You Hear Me?‚Äù, who would not know it? It comes from the movie called Yentl that tells a story of a Jewish girl disguises herself as a boy to enter religious training. It won also one Oscar, Golden Globe and the nomination for Grammy Awards.
xXx (2002)
An extreme sports athlete, Vin Diesel, is recruited by the government on a special mission. The movie itself is nothing special, but the scene on Vltava river is pretty amazing. Also several sights from historical centre appear in the movies, such as T√Ωn Church, Old Town Square, Municipal House or Charles Bridge.
And the winner for the Best Shot in Prague is‚Ä¶
The Best Offer (2013)
The story of an elderly man working in auctions, the collector or the painting, was mostly filmed in Italy. However, at the final of the movies, the main character (Geoffrey Rush) decides to come to Prague. He enters the room of the hotel, opens the window and the first thing he sees is the famous Astronomical Clock. What an amazing shot! Only afew seconds, but it makes you feel you need to come to this city. Watch and decide. :)
Btw, the restaurant mentioned in the movie. Night&Day, does not actually exist :)
Looking for more?
‚Ä¶and many more :)
Here you can see some photos from the streets of Prague, directly from the set. And try to guess what movies it is from :)

Title: Coming to Prague? I‚Äôm a local, and here‚Äôs what I love to do here
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
I‚Äôve lived in Prague for 25 years, and I get asked pretty frequently about good things to do, so I figured I‚Äôd put it into a list.
In terms of events calendars, I‚Äôd check the Expats.cz (www.expats.cz) calendar, the Prague TV (www.prague.tv) calendar, and the Czech Tourism site (which is good, but kinda basic ‚Äî http://www.czechtourism.com/home/).
Here‚Äôs something you might not know: Vietnamese culture is strong in Prague. Vietnamese are the third-largest ethnic minority in the Czech Republic (behind Slovaks and Ukrainians), and there are a number of places to get great Vietnamese food, including the sprawling SAPA marketplace (Anthony Bourdain visited there when he came to Prague a couple of years ago). SAPA is like a huge swap meet. It‚Äôs kind of hard to get to, but a really unexpected thing to find in Prague. (Map: https://goo.gl/maps/wKypyCh5AW32)
Barring that, I‚Äôd recommend visiting Banh Mi Makers on Dlouh√° t≈ôida in the Old Town for a great Banh Mi sandwich. In fact, the building that houses Banh Mi Makers is a gourmet shopping center that also hosts one of the must-visit restaurants in town, the stand-up Na≈°e Maso butcher shop Map: https://goo.gl/maps/XacKM4neyct. If you have enough lead time, I highly recommend reserving their ‚ÄòNoc s ≈ôezn√≠kem (Night With A Butcher)‚Äô an absolutely massive six-course
Just down Dlouh√°, you have Lokal, which is a retro-style pub that serves some of the freshest Pilsner Urquell outside of Pilsen. And next door you have the Roxy and NoD spaces, which are great for catching a DJ gig or maybe a performance (check the website at www.roxy.cz).
In terms of vegetarian fare, I like the Maitrea restaurant near the Old Town Square, and Radost FX Cafe, and I highly recommend the Eska restaurant in the up and coming Karlin neighborhood. It just got a Michelin Bib Gourmand, and while it isn‚Äôt a strictly vegan restaurant, it‚Äôs a place that focuses on bread and things made with yeast or fermentation. It‚Äôs excellent.
One place that‚Äôs kinda touristy but still excellent is the rooftop bar at the Hotel U Prince, just off the Old Town Square. Walk into the hotel, all the way to the back, and you‚Äôll find a glass elevator. Take that to the top and walk up some stairs, and you‚Äôll be rewarded with one of the most spectacular views of the city you could ever imagine. And it‚Äôs even heated in the winter. https://www.terasauprince.com/terrace
The Maurer Grand Restaurant list (and app) has a ton of great restaurant recommendations too. http://www.grandrestaurant.cz/home/?lng=en
Prague has some great design shops if you know where to look. I especially like Tuzeks (http://tuzeks.eu/), which is a play on words on the old Communist hard-currency shops. Tuzeks sells retro Czech design (the lamps and chairs are great). https://goo.gl/maps/L7u5hKYkTG62
In the last couple of years we‚Äôve seen a lot of design stores open up, and one of my favorites is the Chemistry Design Store (https://www.facebook.com/thechemistrydesignstore/), which has a lot of funky prints, glasswork, and some of the coolest turntables I‚Äôve ever seen (made by 440 Audio ‚Äî http://www.440audio.eu/). I also love the Modernista store in several locations, including the House of the Black Madonna. They specialize in faithful reproductions of Czech art deco, cubist and modernist pieces, and they‚Äôre gorgeous. http://www.modernista.cz/?lang=en
The Museum of Decorative Arts is also off the beaten path and is excellent, and has a wonderful museum shop, also run by Modernista (https://goo.gl/maps/1WdovwAG1Ro). Bonus: The windows, especially the ones in the stairways, overlook the Jewish Cemetery. I‚Äôm of two minds on whether the cemetery itself is worth going to. It‚Äôs usually mobbed, and it‚Äôs pretty pricey to get in. But the synagogues are beautiful. I‚Äôd instead recommend the small Jewish cemetery under the Zizkov TV tower. While there, you can check out the bar up on top of the TV tower, as well as checking out the Palac Akropolis, still my favorite concert venue in town, with two separate DJ bars.
I also like the scruffy ≈Ωi≈ækov neighborhood where the Akropolis is located, which, pound for pound, has the highest concentration of bars, restaurants and cafes in town. That and the more upscale Vinohrady neighborhood next to it are good.
Being an old fart, I don‚Äôt get out as much as I‚Äôd like to. But when I do, I like the Naplavka riverwalk (https://goo.gl/maps/66HK8PEoGEH2) and the Krymska street neighborhood (https://goo.gl/maps/3PfbNjZEM5r). Naplavka is not so great in the wintertime, but is the place to be in spring and summer. And Krymska is ground zero for Prague hipsters. Pretty great.
Clubwise, some of Prague‚Äôs must-visit places include the Palac Akropolis (www.akropolis.cz), Roxy, Rock Cafe, Radost FX, and definitely the Cross Club, which must be seen to be believed ‚Äî Atlas Obscura has a nice writeup here: http://www.atlasobscura.com/places/cross-club
I live close to the up-and-coming Letna neighborhood, which is anchored by the Bio Oko arthouse cinema and cafe (https://goo.gl/maps/rLkuMmDs9YF2). That neighborhood has the National Technical Museum, a must-see for geeks (https://goo.gl/maps/a9h6YqqUp6v) and Letna Park‚Äôs beer garden (https://goo.gl/maps/Dqvzyh8HNEs), which has one of the best views in town. In between are all kinds of great cafes and bars.
I‚Äôd strongly recommend getting a metro pass for the time you‚Äôre here. It‚Äôs cheap and so much less hassle. I‚Äôd also recommend (if you have mobile data) the Google Maps app, which also gives you timetables and nearest transit stops.
Prague taxis are a total ripoff, and I definitely do not recommend taking a taxi from the street. Use one of the services instead. I use Tick Tack Taxi (www.ticktack.cz), Taxi AAA (http://www.aaataxi.cz/en/), and Uber, which works well (although, like everywhere, surge pricing is something to watch for).
If you‚Äôre heading toward Vienna, I‚Äôd recommend either ƒåesk√Ω Krumlov or Mikulov. ƒåesk√Ω Krumlov is one of my favorite places on the planet and an amazing UNESCO World Heritage site ‚Äî it‚Äôs an entire town from the 14th century flawlessly preserved. Just gorgeous. Mikulov, in southern Moravia, is in the wine region, and is also a really nice place to be, moreso in summertime. Plus, there‚Äôs a nice waterpark just outside of town (http://www.aqualand-moravia.cz/en)/.
If you‚Äôre heading north toward Berlin, I‚Äôd recommend taking a day to check out Bad Schandau, a spa town with a kickass thermal bath (http://www.toskanaworld.net/web/en/therme_bad_schandau/home.asp), and the Czech and Saxon Switzerland national park, famous for its sandstone formations, including a couple of natural bridges.

Title: What & Where to Eat and Drink in Prague
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
We had explored many places before going to Prague because of our love to discover new places. Some of the places I list below are the places we had previously explored, and some of them we found by chance. PS: We tried to explore some concept places rather than the most popular places on this trip.
Cafefin is not a breakfast place where you can spend hours as we are used to. For example, you wake up so early, you‚Äôre in a hurry, you want to have a healthy and delicious breakfast. Then here is the right address! This busy and popular cafe is the first Vietnamese coffehouse in Prague. There are mini tables and the stools at the long bar that you can sit. The staff are incredibly friendly. The Vietnamese baguette category in the menu attracted our attention. Baguette varieties were not the kind we were used to, but I have to say that I liked it very much! The cafe is also known for its sweet chao rice and homemade yoghurt with black rice.
The weather was very cold in April. Therefore, when we were too cold, we would urgently sit in any caf√© we found by chance. That‚Äôs also how we discovered Tricafe. :) Tricafe was such a pleasant place that we have wanted to stay for 2 hours. We felt like we were at home with old-looking wooden tables, armchair seats in our grandmothers‚Äô house and rocking chairs. You could read books from their library or you could take a glance at drawings on the wall as a mini exhibition. By the way their coffee was pretty good.
Trdelnik has started to spread after Easter markets that were established in Czech Republic in 2002 and it has become one of the symbols of Prague. We have gone to Prague during Easter so we had the opportunity to experience it in the Easter markets. Trdelnik is made from rolled dough that is wrapped around a stick, then grilled and topped with sugar and walnut mix. I‚Äôve tried the Nutella version of it. You can find different versions of Trdelnik in various shapes and with different flavors. Especially in the summer, you can find Trdelnik with different kinds of ice cream in Prague.
Restaurant Bella Vista has the best view in the city. Its panoramic view stretches from the Petrin Tower all the way to Prague Castle Hillsides. It streches from the west to the north, it provides spectacular views of greenish copper cupolas, narrow cobblestone streets, bridges connecting both river banks and green gardens from red-roof tops of centuries-old houses. Actually, we had come here to visit the Strahov Monastery. After the visit to the monastery, this amazing view has made our day! We couldn‚Äôt leave there without drinking a green lager to the accompaniment of this view.
Kantyna is a restaurant where you can taste great meats in Prague. In the entrance part, you can choose the meats that you would like to eat in the butcher section or if you are in a hurry, you can prefer the meats that are already cooked. We chose to choose our meat from scratch and we started to wait at our table. Alcoholic and non-alcoholic beverages are also available, but we wanted to try local beer with our meats. This was the first place we stopped by after we got off the plane. We were very lucky because this place was so close to the hostel. Since I got back from Prague, I‚Äôve been telling everyone about this place. The meats were absolutely incredibly delicious.
Cafe Slavia was the place where Nazƒ±m Hikmet had written some poems in Prague. There is a portrait of Nazƒ±m Hikmet which is painted by one of the Czech artists. However, the place also inspired many important literary artists. Kafka also had been going to this cafe while writing his novels.
First of all, if you want to go this place, you have to make a reservation. That‚Äôs why we‚Äôve waited too long to sit, but the friendly staff was really helpful. I really like their food presentation. They served a meat with a kind of bread that they called ‚Äúknedliky‚Äù and cranberry marmalade. It was really delicious!
I‚Äôm a real John Lennon fan and that‚Äôs why I don‚Äôt recommend this place. We really wanted to have a drink at John Lennon Pub. However, we could not spend more than 10 minutes. Due to the fact that the waiters didn‚Äôt let us have a drink here. They said we could sit here if we ate something. If we only wanted to have a drink, we couldn‚Äôt sit even if there were available tables inside. There wasn‚Äôt anything there to connect with John Lennon except his photos. I would love to have waiters understand and embrace his spirit.
The Hemingway Bar is the most popular cocktail bar in Prague. This place deserves all highest points because of the friendly waitresses and the wide cocktail menu. The name of the cocktail in the photo is Snow Globe. I used to like to watch the snow globe when i was a kid. I felt the same feelings because of this cocktail. Watching the coconut particles brought me back to my childhood. If you travel to Prague, I‚Äôd say that you should go to Hemingway Bar.
Enjoy your trip!
