By Jacques Poitras
MATT WELCH WAS back in Prague for the Party at the End of the World. It was March 1, 1995, and the newspaper and the life he had created for himself were crumbling in the old cobblestone streets of the Czech capital. Prognosis, the English-language rag he had launched five years earlier with a few friends, had ceased publishing; tonight, a final, drunken bash would send it off into history.
Before heading to the party at Rock Club Bunkr, a bar housed in a former Communist nuclear bomb shelter, Welch, some of the other founders, and a few friends ducked into U Vejvod≈Ø, a traditional Czech pub. They reminisced about all the struggles going back to the beginning. Charlie Hornberger, the paper‚Äôs last editor-in-chief, described closing down the office. Welch shared anecdotes from the Budapest Business Journal, where he‚Äôd taken a job two months earlier. At their feet sat bundles of newspapers: the cover of the final issue of Prognosis showed a Communist-built apartment complex crumbling under the headline ‚ÄúThe End.‚Äù
That possibility had been looming for months, even years. Prognosis had never made a single koruna in profit. Then again, that had never been the point. ‚ÄúThough it misfired and miscued on more than one occasion,‚Äù Welch wrote in a goodbye essay, ‚ÄúPrognosis at its full bloom was one of the most ferociously good newspapers any part of the world has ever seen. There is no satisfaction that can compare to this essential fact, nor any disappointment that can diminish its luster. Prognosis was, for nearly four full years, the exact sum of what the editorial staff imagined a great newspaper should be.‚Äù
And now it was over. Along with those defiant superlatives, Welch‚Äôs essay dished out an equal helping of self-pity. The other founders of the paper had postponed promising careers to embark on this adventure with him; ‚ÄúI, as a college dropout with little experience at anything, had nothing except an exaggerated sense of self-worth,‚Äù he wrote. ‚ÄúI am acutely aware that my life, such as it is right now, exists because of this newspaper and this experience called Prognosis. ‚Ä¶ Fact is, I now have something akin to a viable life, and the tangible source of that life is now dead.‚Äù
Prague was no longer the dreamy, mystical city Welch and his friends had discovered in 1990 as it emerged from the Cold War. The looseness of those post-Velvet Revolution days was fading, and the city was completing its transition from Soviet bloc outpost to Western destination. The Czechs were cashing in, hustlers now outnumbered hipsters, and the market was swallowing those, like Prognosis, who didn‚Äôt cut it.
Back home in the United States, Ken Layne, a former Prognosis writer, read Welch‚Äôs farewell column. The piece, he told me in 1995, ‚Äújust shows Welch playing his favourite role: the bumbling can‚Äôt-get-my-shit-together-but-I-mean-well loser. ‚Ä¶ He refuses to take real responsibility for stuff falling apart. Prognosis failed because the founders had no interest or experience in running a successful business‚Äîand that‚Äôs what a newspaper is: a business. They thought business was bad and success was evil.‚Äù
ACROSS THE TABLE at U Vejvod≈Ø, Doug Arellanes, a former art director at the paper, pulled out an old letter. In 1990 Welch and two other founders ‚Äî campus paper colleagues from the University of California at Santa Barbara ‚Äî wrote to Arellanes from Prague. They shared the excitement of an idea: to launch an English-language newspaper in the Czech capital. ‚ÄúThe key to all this I think is tapping as many good people as we can,‚Äù Christopher Scheer wrote in that letter, ‚Äúnot running this like a business but like a movement.‚Äù He would later explain: ‚ÄúNo one starts a business with basically no money. We did. Lacking money, we damn well better have some love and elbow grease to carry us through. We were somewhat fatalistic, also, realizing that any outcome would be an adventure and therefore a success.‚Äù
Welch had arrived in Eastern Europe that August to write a novel. When the other Americans who made up the future core of Prognosis pulled into Prague at the end of disparate backpacking trips, he was away in pre-war Yugoslavia; his pals discovered he had already established a profile. ‚ÄúHe made quite an impression on this town,‚Äù Scheer wrote to Arellanes. ‚ÄúWomen strewn in his wake, fans rumour-mongering about his eternally imminent return ‚Ä¶ It‚Äôs like Jesus!‚Äù
Anyone who met Matt Welch understood why. His long, blond hair, piercing dark eyes and affable demeanour often made him the center of attention. In Prague, he took to playing guitar for passers-by and spare change on the city‚Äôs postcard-perfect 700-year-old Charles Bridge. Back home in California, he had worked alongside the other Prognosis founders at the Daily Nexus, the University of California at Santa Barbara student paper, composing its weather forecasts as beat poetry. ‚ÄúHe drank enormously, liked to wear dresses to work once a week and otherwise tried to create a mythos about himself,‚Äù Scheer would remember.
There was no shortage of talent among the founders of Prognosis, but Welch seemed to be the catalyst. He was ‚Äúincredibly skilled at assembling myriad people to make his daydreams come to life,‚Äù according to Ken Layne. ‚ÄúI once told Matt the reason he‚Äôd never finish [writing] a book of fiction is because he‚Äôs too goddamn busy living a book of fiction.‚Äù If his life was, as he told it, going nowhere until he reached Prague, then the city offered the ideal setting for his apotheosis.
BESIDES THE STUNNING architecture, a rich cultural tradition, and women with beautiful Slavic eyes, Prague had V√°clav Havel. Czechoslovakia‚Äôs president knew about rising from despair to an exalted position. Havel, a playwright, had been jailed as a dissident by the Communists before the Velvet Revolution of November 1989 transformed him into head of state. He remained an idealist who talked of ‚Äúliving in truth‚Äù and building a civic society; for young Americans disenchanted with the Republicanism of Ronald Reagan and George Bush, Havel added to Prague‚Äôs appeal. ‚ÄúMy God, this is what politics should be,‚Äù John Allison, an early expat arrival, would remember thinking after seeing Havel‚Äôs February 1990 speech to the U.S. Congress. ‚ÄúThis is my calling.‚Äù By the end of the year, Allison found himself working as the ‚ÄúAmerican advisor‚Äù to Prague‚Äôs mayor.
Havel ‚Äúdid sort of underline the uniqueness of the place and time,‚Äù Christopher Scheer remembered. ‚ÄúHe sort of encapsulated it. But he wasn‚Äôt the whole story, just a symptom, because every Czech we met seemed to have a wild story, to be oddly humble and intellectual at the same time. That‚Äôs why Havel could be president‚Äîbecause he represented a powerful strain in Czech culture.‚Äù
Welch came to idolize this rumpled philosopher-king who, indirectly, had made Prognosis possible. In his cramped apartment in an industrial section of Prague, a large poster of Havel occupied a place of honour on one wall. Someone had used a cigarette to burn out the eyes on another poster, of V√°clav Klaus, Czechoslovakia‚Äôs Thatcherite finance minister. You can deface anything on the walls, Welch once told a group of guests, except the Havel poster.
Besides Welch and Scheer, the other Americans who gathered at a pub in Prague in November 1990 to hash out the newspaper idea were Ben Sullivan, Laura Pitter, Jenny Ogar, and Lisa Frankenberg. They were all staying with Czech students Welch had befriended. ‚ÄúThe next morning, we woke up hungover and had to decide if it was all just a beery fantasy,‚Äù Scheer recalled. ‚ÄúWe decided tentatively that it wasn‚Äôt.‚Äù
The next evening, sober, they sat down and figured out how much money they could pool for the launch. Travellers‚Äô cheques, credit card advances and anything they could sell were all put on the table. Everyone anted up except Lisa Frankenberg.
IN WELCH‚ÄôS PROGNOSIS narrative, Lisa Frankenberg became the villain. Even in those early days, Scheer and others had doubts about Frankenberg, who had worked at the Nexus before leaving to get involved in the UCSB student government. Her unwillingness to put up money made them question her commitment to their Prague newspaper, but Welch, a friend, defended her. ‚ÄúShe was not at all like our vibe,‚Äù Welch says. ‚ÄúWe were pretty hippie and idealistic and journalism-based and easy to get along with. She was considerably more abrasive.‚Äù But he argued that ‚Äúwe need different types of personalities here, particularly on the business side, and maybe we can convert those negative characteristics into something we need.‚Äù
Today, the first few issues of the monthly Prognosis look amateurish, with unattractive fonts, awkward layout, and collegiate earnestness. But they were fresh and lively, and in the spring of 1991, with Prague‚Äôs expatriate population swelling, and thousands of English-speaking tourists on the way, they represented a triumph. The founders, their meager start-up funds supplemented with money from ‚Äúinvestors‚Äù ‚Äî a few well-heeled family friends back home ‚Äî had waded through layers of left-over Communist bureaucracy just to launch the paper. The first edition, ‚Äúzero issue,‚Äù was snapped up by expats and backpackers starved for something to read in English. The paper would go on to chronicle everything from the sweeping privatization of state institutions, to the growth of the drug trade and prostitution, to the establishment of an Andy Warhol Museum in the Slovak village where the artist‚Äôs mother was born. ‚ÄúWe wanted to create something that had never existed, in a place where it was impossible to imagine such a thing existing,‚Äù Welch says.
Frankenberg soon began to have doubts. In charge of distribution and advertising, she heard the same comments over and over when she tried to sell subscriptions and ad space to the growing foreign business community. Prognosis was fun, but her prospective clients wanted serious business news to help them understand this lucrative new market. They also wanted it fast: a monthly paper didn‚Äôt provide immediacy in a quickly changing economy. And the sometimes arch, collegiate tone of the paper turned them off.
In an interview in 1995, Frankenberg described how no one at Prognosis seemed concerned about what she was hearing. ‚ÄúThe attitude was, ‚ÄòWe‚Äôre having fun, we‚Äôre enjoying this, why should we change?‚Äô‚Äù she told me. There was no business plan for growth, and no budget forecasting revenues and expenses. ‚ÄúVery clearly, the response [from the others] was, ‚ÄòWe‚Äôre not a business, we‚Äôre a newspaper.‚Äô And I thought, ‚ÄòWait a minute, a newspaper is a business.‚Äô‚Äù
Frankenberg‚Äôs worries were compounded the day Alan Levy visited the Prognosis office to offer his services. Levy, a 59-year-old American journalist, had covered the Prague Spring, Alexander Dubƒçek‚Äôs 1968 attempt to democratize Communism from within. When Soviet tanks arrived to crush Dubƒçek‚Äôs experiment, Levy was expelled. He lived in Vienna for 21 years, moving back shortly after the Velvet Revolution, and his book about 1968, So Many Heroes, became a must-read for expats. He proposed writing a column for Prognosis, a series of profiles of interesting Czechs and expatriates.
The founders turned him down. ‚ÄúWe didn‚Äôt want to publish an archetypal expat-freelancer just because he had ‚Äòclips,‚Äô‚Äù Welch later wrote. ‚ÄúI wasn‚Äôt at that fateful meeting, but apparently he came on strong and condescending, and I‚Äôm sure we were more than just a little defensive about people questioning our credentials and telling us what we should cover. So with those prejudices, we read his stuff and thought it wouldn‚Äôt fit into our Mission-from-God approach.‚Äù
Welch came to see it as a defining moment for the young paper: ‚ÄúWe finally had confidence enough in what we were to reject an over-qualified representative of what we didn‚Äôt want to be,‚Äù Welch said. Frankenberg would later call her Prognosis colleagues ‚Äúcallow‚Äù for not hiring Levy. ‚ÄúI was flabbergasted that anyone would turn away such a gifted writer and I expressed my apologies to Alan,‚Äù she wrote years later. Frankenberg was now so frustrated that she considered packing it in and resuming her studies back in the States in the fall.
But in July 1991, a newspaper distributor working for Frankenberg had a chance meeting with a Texas businessman, Monroe Luther, who was in Prague inking deals. Luther told Frankenberg he might invest in Prognosis, but he wanted his money put to good use: he wanted a more business-oriented weekly, and suggested she come back with him in two days with a proposal to transform the paper.
According to Matt Welch and Christopher Scheer, Frankenberg and her philosophical soulmate in the Prognosis business office, Kent Hawryluk, demanded a radical change of editorial direction‚Äîmore serious and business-friendly‚Äîwithout mentioning Luther‚Äôs possible infusion of cash. (Frankenberg disputed this account when I interviewed her in 1995, saying she was upfront about Luther‚Äôs investment offer and that the desire for a revamp came from him.) Frankenberg and Hawryluk also wanted to be equal partners in the business, a status denied to them because they had invested no money. Otherwise, they said, they‚Äôd walk. ‚ÄúMan, were we agonized,‚Äù Welch says. ‚ÄúWe definitely needed them, and they did stuff we couldn‚Äôt imagine doing ourselves, but there was something pretty gross and not trustworthy about playing ultimatum games with an idealistic venture started by people of good faith. So ultimately, we said no.‚Äù
A few days later, Frankenberg and Hawryluk resigned from Prognosis and persuaded Luther to use his money to help them launch a business-oriented weekly called The Prague Post. It hit the streets in October, 1991, its early issues were hopelessly dull in design, style and content. But the paper knew how to sell itself: the Post played to the business community with credulous coverage of finance and investment, and bought prime space on billboards, branding itself a serious player in the marketplace and selling a lot of advertising. ‚ÄúTheir initial billboards cost more than we spent in the first nine months of our entire operation,‚Äù Scheer recalled.
Alan Levy was hired as titular editor-in-chief of The Prague Post. ‚ÄúWe are living in the Left Bank of the ‚Äô90s,‚Äù he declared in a column in the inaugural issue, alluding to Hemingway‚Äôs Paris. ‚ÄúFor some of us, Prague is Second Chance City; for others a new frontier where anything goes, everything goes, and, often enough, nothing works. Yesterday is long gone, today is nebulous, and who knows about tomorrow, but, somewhere within each of us, we all know that we are living in a historic place at a historic time.‚Äù
The Prognosis founders were hardly jealous of the Post‚Äôs content‚Äîthey rolled their eyes at Levy‚Äôs prose, and they wouldn‚Äôt miss Frankenberg and Hawryluk‚Äîbut the pair took their advertising and distribution contacts with them. Suddenly, Prognosis was without a business staff, and without the network the pair had assembled to sell the newspaper in an often-baffling post-Communist environment. ‚ÄúIt was like a jackhammer in the nuts,‚Äù Welch says. ‚ÄúIt totally drained the joy out of the situation.‚Äù
Welch, Scheer, and the others responded by taking Prognosis biweekly and working even harder. ‚ÄúWe did not, however, try to beat the Post at their own game,‚Äù Scheer said. ‚ÄúArrogant or not, we decided very consciously to keep trying to put out the newspaper that we wanted to put out and not just try to be a local version of The Wall Street Journal.‚Äù
THEY STILL HAD HYPE on their side. For foreign reporters dropping in on Prague to profile the growing expat community, the grimy, cluttered Prognosis office was an essential stop. The paper represented the kind of journalism they secretly wanted to practice: fun, smart, brashly principled. Any feature piece on the self-exiled, twentysomethings of Prague inevitably included the same tropes: the American-owned New York Pizza restaurant; the mayor‚Äôs ‚ÄúAmerican advisor,‚Äù John Allison, who had moved onto a job in Havel‚Äôs office in the majestic Castle overlooking the city; Laundry Kings, the American-owned, first-ever self-serve laundromat in Prague‚Äîand Prognosis. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs practically impossible to live here for any length of time and not be interviewed by some major paper or broadcast network, adding another level of absurdity to what is already a pretty ridiculous existence,‚Äù Welch would write. ‚ÄúAll this silliness has not exactly hurt our paper, my career or my swelling ego needs.‚Äù
In July 1992 Welch was the central character in a lengthy article in Details magazine that many expats credited with single-handedly spinning the Prague hype-meter into the stratosphere. Using Prognosis as a framing device, writer Henry Copeland portrayed Prague as a hedonistic haven for a new lost generation. Welch and others would mock the article, particularly a quotation uttered by one Prognosis writer: ‚ÄúIn Prague, everything is so open that you can re-invent yourself every day.‚Äù Yet a copy of that issue, preserved like new, was tucked away in Welch‚Äôs flat, where I discovered it during the two months I spent subletting his place.
In retrospect, that Details piece represented the high-water mark for expatriate Prague. The same summer it was published, reality began to intrude on the fairy tale: Czechoslovakia‚Äôs first full-scale elections, in June 1992 produced a political schism in the federation. V√°clav Klaus, leader of the Civic Democratic Party, triumphed in the Czech parliament, while the victory of a pro-independence party in Slovakia threatened to split the country. Klaus, a bottom-line man in favour of rapid privatization and economic restructuring, had no qualms about saying goodbye to the Slovaks: the poorer, slower-to-modernize, more rural part of the federation was a drag on his ideological plans. As president, V√°clav Havel sought to preserve the federation because of the multi-ethnic ideal it represented, but even Havel‚Äôs moral authority could not contain the forces that had been unleashed. On New Year‚Äôs Day, 1993, Czechoslovakia, the country that had survived Nazism and Communism, the two great totalitarian plagues of the twentieth century, ceased to exist.
Havel was soon chosen as president of the new Czech Republic and Klaus became its prime minister. Prognosis would call them ‚Äúthose wild and warring poster boys of the modern Czech soul.‚Äù Klaus, the no-nonsense, get-things-done manager in a hurry to downsize the machinery of government, was the efficient administrator, while Havel, the philosopher and moralist, was perfect for the role of symbolic head of state. They would clash repeatedly: Havel felt Klaus forgot the human element in governing; Klaus found Havel‚Äôs dreamy idealism impractical. ‚ÄúThe advocate of non-political politics met a consummate political animal,‚Äù Havel‚Äôs biographer later wrote.
The schism echoed Prague‚Äôs expat newspaper war: Prognosis, though struggling financially, continued to strive for a journalistic ideal akin to Havel‚Äôs ‚Äúliving in truth‚Äù as it chronicled the changes in Czech society. The Post, Klaus-like in its pragmatism, prospered by playing to the market, giving the big-spending expat business community what it wanted. Prognosis was still cooler, but like Havel, it was no longer invincible.
THE DETAILS STORY drew me to Prague as I fled a recession-wracked newspaper industry in Canada. But by the time I arrived in January 1993, the city was re-inventing itself so quickly that it was no longer the Capital of Dreams sketched by the magazine just six months earlier. The cost of two expat staples, beer and apartment rent, both ridiculously cheap by U.S. standards in early 1992, were creeping up as the market adjusted to the city‚Äôs destination status. The talk now was less about Havel, the playwright president, and more about Klaus, the economic guru whose reforms were seen as a textbook example of how to move from Communism to capitalism.
Visiting reporters had also discovered a new source of expat wisdom. They now often visited the offices of The Prague Post to interview Lisa Frankenberg. Across town at Prognosis, meanwhile, the founders, exhausted by the grind of publishing and the battle with the Post, turned over senior editorial positions to newcomers and moved into writing positions, or onto new adventures. Welch relocated to Bratislava, the capital of newly independent Slovakia, to run the paper‚Äôs bureau there, while the new managers grappled with how to give the operation some much-needed stability.
The new publisher, Erica Breth, discovered there was still no real budget, business plan, or bookkeeping. (Scheer, when I interviewed him in 1995, disputed the idea that the founders had ignored the business side; they ‚Äúworried enormously‚Äù about it, he said, but ‚Äúnone of it made our business sense any more acute, none of it made us more organized, none of it brought us big investors.‚Äù) More money from ‚Äúinvestors‚Äù back in the U.S., including wealthy liberal philanthropist Helen Bing, couldn‚Äôt erase the red ink. The journalism remained solid, and Breth and her fellow managers stayed one step ahead of invoices from printers, phone companies and other suppliers. But Prognosis was sputtering financially.
Several staff members left in the summer and fall of 1993. Some, like me, were lured by jobs back home; most feared the paper‚Äôs demise was a matter of time. On a fundraising trip to the United States, Breth made the rounds of foundations and other do-gooders who had endowed the paper in the early days. But the Czech Republic‚Äôs much-publicized economic success meant, perversely, that the novelty of a scrappy little paper in Prague was wearing off. The money Breth gathered in early 1994 was quickly used, all at once, to pay off the paper‚Äôs printers, who hadn‚Äôt collected for months and were refusing to roll the presses.
Matt Welch wouldn‚Äôt give in. He left the bureau in Bratislava and returned to Prague, where he and Ben Sullivan, another founder, stepped back into senior editorial jobs under John Allison, who became editor-in-chief. ‚ÄúI still recall that the engine that was the news desk was being fueled almost single-handedly by Matt and John Allison, who both toiled mightily to put out a newspaper,‚Äù reporter Logan Mabe would say.
Welch was still making myths: Prognosis could rise again. In May, 1994, a Dutch businessman, Harmen Smink, injected cash by buying 51 per cent of the paper. Welch contacted a handful of Prognosis alumni in California, among them Ken Layne, and appealed to them to return to Prague. ‚ÄúHe had these various godlike attributes attached to each of us,‚Äù Layne told me in 1995, ‚Äúand he figured he could just play God and assemble a new group of ‚Äòfounders‚Äô that would continue the legacy, as it were, and maybe put some fire and guts back into it.‚Äù Others were wary, but Layne accepted an offer to become editor-in-chief‚Äîuntil he learned at the last minute that he would not have the authority Welch had promised him. He was tempted, he said, to fly to Prague ‚Äújust to beat the shit out of Matt and leave him for dead with his fucking guitar rammed up his hippy ass.‚Äù In Layne‚Äôs place, Charlie Hornberger, a Nexus pal of Welch, took over.
Smink‚Äôs money allowed Prognosis to move into better offices and go weekly with full-colour covers. Newsstand sales jumped, but advertising did not. Within a few weeks the problems began anew: Smink‚Äôs hard currency seemed to be evaporating. It would later emerge that the paper‚Äôs business manager was defrauding the paper, funneling money into her own private ventures. By the time anyone noticed, it was too late.
The newspaper‚Äôs philosophical guru up in Prague Castle was in no better state. As his popularity plummeted, V√°clav Havel mused to one interviewer about how he looked forward to leaving the presidency and becoming a simple pensioner. The economy, not ethics and morals, drove the agenda in Prague, and Prime Minister V√°clav Klaus was the man of the moment. He had a budget surplus forecast for 1995, the lowest inflation rate in the former Soviet bloc, and a jobless rate below four per cent. At the end of 1994, Klaus mocked Havel‚Äôs idea of the president delivering a ‚ÄúState of the Nation‚Äù address to Parliament ‚Äî then delivered one himself. Poll after poll showed Czechs considered Havel the more principled of the two men, but they trusted Klaus to run the country.
On New Years‚Äô Day, 1995, Klaus gave a look-ahead interview to the country‚Äôs first private TV station, Nova. In a clear attempt to eclipse the president, it was broadcast at the same time as Havel‚Äôs New Year‚Äôs address on state television. Of Havel‚Äôs remarks, Prognosis reported: ‚ÄúFar from an optimist in his days of waning popularity and influence, Havel could apparently muster only the dark conclusion that ‚ÄòNot everything is lost yet.‚Äô‚Äù
The president might as well have been talking about the expat newspaper inspired by his idealism. As the financial situation worsened, Welch accepted a job at the Budapest Business Journal. Smink tried to buy out the remaining 49 per cent of the paper still owned by Welch and the founders; when they balked, he cut off salaries and shopped his controlling shares to potential buyers, including The Prague Post. A gossip column in the February 21 issue of Prognosis ended prophetically with a comment that ‚Äúall things come to an end sometime.‚Äù The following week, the founders decided to maintain their paper‚Äôs dignity. They closed it down.
MATT WELCH SAT down with a bottle of wine at his desk in Budapest at the end of February 1995 and wrote a piece for the final issue of Prognosis that would be headlined ‚ÄúA Long Goodbye to the Paper I Loved Best.‚Äù
‚ÄúWe were right all along,‚Äù Welch wrote, ‚Äúif excessively stupid and self-indulgent in the deployment.‚Äù He expressed pride in the legacy Prognosis would leave‚Äîin particular the journalism education it gave to many young Czechs and Slovak interpreters and translators who became talented reporters for local media organizations‚Äîbut he also mourned: this was the piece in which he declared that ‚Äúthe tangible source of [his] life is now dead,‚Äù tying his own fate to that of the daydream he would soon bury. ‚ÄúWhat I was expressing there,‚Äù he says now, ‚Äúwas a kind of gratitude for having been able to experience something that made me at least quasi-presentable to the world of journalism, and a melancholy for that beautiful and helpful thing being dead.‚Äù
Lisa Frankenberg told me she felt no sense of triumph at the demise of Prognosis, even though it gave her Prague Post a freer hand in Prague‚Äôs English-language media market. She claimed to be moved by Welch‚Äôs coda. ‚ÄúThere were probably only a handful of people who read that through to the end. I read it. I read it to the very end,‚Äù she said. Winning the expat newspaper war was ‚Äúvery weird and sad. It was a very weird day. We knew it was coming for a long time.‚Äù
One night in May 1995, as the spring air brought with it the promise of another beautiful summer in Prague, Frankenberg took a stroll on the Charles Bridge with Monroe Luther, the owner of the Post. They talked about the paper‚Äôs prospects: its circulation was rising, and a growing number of English-speaking Czechs read it. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a successful business,‚Äù Frankenberg told me at the time, though she refused to reveal if it was profitable.
Suddenly Frankenberg saw a familiar figure with a guitar, blond hair waving in the breeze as he strummed on the bridge. ‚ÄúHey, Matt!‚Äù she yelled. He smiled, answered, ‚ÄúHey, Frankenberg.‚Äù Matt Welch was back in town, and could still muster a smile for his former rival.
Frankenberg and Luther kept walking. ‚ÄúSomeday in the future, I‚Äôd like to sit down with him and have a coffee or a beer and talk things out,‚Äù she told me in 1995. ‚ÄúBut it takes time. It was probably like part of him dying when Prognosis died.‚Äù
They never had that coffee. Welch eventually returned to the United States, where, he says, he parlayed what he called the ‚Äúquasi-presentable‚Äù reputation he earned in Prague into a career in journalism. The Prague Post continues to publish digitally, though it shed its print edition in 2013. Welch says he holds no grudge against Frankenberg. ‚ÄúWhy? Competition‚Äôs good, man! It made both papers better. And because I, unlike her, can look at myself in the mirror every night before going to sleep without so much as a twinge of doubt of how I comported myself professionally in my early twenties. She won the battle, for which she deserves real credit. But history will not remember her paper nearly the same way, and that just makes me smile and smile.‚Äù
IN 1995, MANY Prognosis staffers and alumni were less sanguine. True, the city had become faster, harder, more expensive and less forgiving: the free market that had made Prognosis possible had killed it. But it was tempting to conclude Welch and the others had squandered what they had built‚Äîa newspaper that everyone who worked there had come to consider their own.
‚ÄúThese American kids start the first English-language newspaper. ‚Ä¶ It can‚Äôt help but thrive, right?‚Äù Welch‚Äôs friend, Ken Layne, told me in an e-mail in 1995. ‚ÄúIt sputters along for several years, getting a million dollars in free press, no business plan, no financial plan, no discipline, just bumbling along, just like all of Prague is doing. And just like the fucking Communists, Prognosis is living off subsidies,‚Äù a reference to the money from relatives and foundations in the United States. ‚ÄúMeanwhile, the Czechs figure it all out. They toss away a lifetime of anti-capitalist bullshit and turn Prague into a fucking money machine. Everybody figures out how to run a business, how to make cash, how to succeed ‚Äî everybody but these American kids who refuse to even acknowledge the need for money, for success.
‚ÄúIf Lisa Frankenberg is your villain,‚Äù Layne added, ‚Äúyou‚Äôve bought into the biggest piece of fabricated history ever. If they had figured out how to use Lisa‚Äôs smarts ‚Ä¶ Prognosis would be a thriving media empire today instead of a dead newspaper fondly remembered by fifty people. The results speak for themselves. Lisa is no monster. A hundred other people have felt the same way about the half-ass manner in which Prognosis was run.‚Äù
When I remind Layne of those comments almost two decades later, he explains that ‚Äúone of my habits of my youth was to get good and drunk and pissed off while typing. It was, I guess, my literary style of the era.‚Äù In 1995, he says, he was still bitter about his aborted return to Prague. ‚ÄúI was supposed to be editor of a paper I loved in the Czech Republic, and instead I was drifting around.‚Äù
Layne still doesn‚Äôt blame Frankenberg for the paper‚Äôs demise: she left in 1991, and the paper took another four years to fold, he points out, plenty of time to have turned things around. But he is more forgiving of Welch and company. ‚ÄúWhile I‚Äôve lost touch with all but a dozen or so of the Prognosis gang, those dozen people remain some of my best friends,‚Äù he says. ‚ÄúThe group of Californians and Czechs who started up that paper did a pretty good job with intolerable circumstances.‚Äù Even in 1995, at his most frustrated, Layne said of them, ‚Äúthey are good people, and that Prague experience remains incredibly significant. It reverberates through every part of my life.‚Äù
CHRISTOPHER SCHEER‚ÄôS FATHER, journalist Robert Scheer, urged the Prognosis founders in 1994 ‚Äúto just become an Internet newspaper,‚Äù Welch says, ‚Äúwhich would have been way ahead of the curve.‚Äù Instead, because the paper died at almost the precise moment the Internet became a mass phenomenon, there is no online archive or digital database of its five-year run. Former employees now speak of a complete set of printed issues the way one recounts an urban legend: the full run is always sitting in the basement of the friend of a friend, just out of reach. So Prognosis, as an iteration of young, earnest, idealistic journalism, cannot be considered in its entirety, but only in pieces. A virtual collection of yellowed issues lies scattered across the globe, a notional scrapbook of clippings, impressions, half-memories and fading photographs.
In the twenty years since its demise, my picture of Prognosis has evolved from a lost opportunity into something else. As a bit player, I too was frustrated to see it fold. Today, I no longer imagine an alternate history in which Prognosis survived the nineties: I just marvel at the audacity of its brief, improbable existence. During one gloomy period in 1993, Christopher Scheer wrote in a memo to the staff that the paper was not ‚Äúa normal institution. ‚Ä¶ Stability is not its primary, overriding goal. Those who seem to wish Prognosis was some great gleaming ship of stable corporate love ‚Äî including myself at many an exhausted moment ‚Äî would not want to work at such a place.‚Äù The founders of Prognosis gave us a life-changing experience; they didn‚Äôt owe us permanence.
Any outcome would be an adventure and therefore a success, Scheer had said. And so the sharp edges of the picture soften to something else: a moment, ephemeral but real, in the dusty swirl of post-1989 Central Europe. Lyle Zimskind, a managing editor of the Czech edition of Esquire, would remember Prognosis as ‚Äúchaotically managed‚Äù but ‚Äúlivelier‚Äù than the Post ‚Äî a victory by any measure, except that of for-profit survival.
In his 1990 letter, Scheer had advocated ‚Äúnot running this like a business but like a movement.‚Äù And every movement runs its course. Welch made not only his daydreams come to life, but those of every other expat who saw their work ‚Äî their words, their whimsy, their passion ‚Äî on those pages. ‚ÄúPrognosis was an expression of pure newspaper romanticism,‚Äù he says. ‚ÄúThe whole thing was an expression of love for the form.‚Äù
‚ÄúThe paper failed,‚Äù writer Logan Mabe would conclude, ‚Äúbut it wasn‚Äôt a failure.‚Äù
IN LATE 2011, Welch, now the editor-in-chief of Reason, a Washington libertarian magazine, returned to Prague to attend the funeral of his idol, V√°clav Havel. Havel‚Äôs English translator, Paul Wilson, had secured him a seat inside St. Vitus Cathedral, the imposing Gothic structure at Prague Castle that dominates the city skyline.
Outside the gates, hundreds of thousands normally taciturn Czechs were mourning their hero. They were part of the West now, part of the European Union and of NATO, and though Havel‚Äôs popularity had faded before he left the presidency in 2003, his reputation for principle was intact ‚Äî unlike that of his rival, Klaus, whose government was eventually tainted by corruption scandals. And so, though the end of Communism had produced many complications and disappointments, the citizens of Prague crowded the streets for Havel‚Äôs funeral procession, wrapping the city in the same atmosphere of possibility they created in 1989.
In a piece for Reason‚Äôs website, Welch reflected on what Havel had inspired, not in Welch himself, but in the Czech capital. ‚ÄúFrom the Velvet Revolution through at least 1991, and in many (though lesser) respects for years after, Prague was alive with rediscovery and experimentation in the exciting, difficult, anarchic interlude between Communism and its built-out replacement,‚Äù he wrote. ‚ÄúMore than mere nostalgia for a limited era of time (one I was fortunate enough to participate in), that same spirit of, well, love, or at least its handmaiden decency, has never really gone away.‚Äù
The newspaper was never far from Welch‚Äôs mind during his quick return to Prague. ‚ÄúThat forty-eight hours I spent there was a profound moment, one I absolutely lived up to by drinking until 5 a.m. the night before the funeral with a bunch of ex-Prognosis comrades, and then vomiting inside the castle after the religious ceremony, and also, again, under the Charles Bridge on the walk back,‚Äù he told me. ‚ÄúFriends from New York told me to do it right, in their honor, and so I did.‚Äù
‚ÄúPrague is beautiful like an insecure woman,‚Äù Prognosis staffer Kate Sullivan once wrote. ‚ÄúIt doesn‚Äôt seem to realize the crazy extent of its beauty; it doesn‚Äôt notice the effect it has on people.‚Äù But everyone who ever worked at the paper realized it. They still do.
‚ÄúTo this day,‚Äù Welch says, ‚ÄúI reject the term ‚Äòthe real world,‚Äô because my feeling is that we should all strive for the surrealism that we were able to enjoy in early-nineties Prague.‚Äù
--
--
2
Journalist and author of 5 books, including Pipe Dreams: The Fight for Canada‚Äôs Energy Future and national bestseller Irving vs. Irving.

Title: Being a Tourist in Empty Prague
Content:

Last summer, when the spring lockdown temporarily lifted, we engaged in a bit of an ‚Äòempty Prague tourism.‚Äô It‚Äôs surprising how little I get to see the city‚Äôs historical parts ‚Äî I mostly avoid them because they are full of tourists. Prague is wonderful (so I understand that people want to see it), and the distinctive landmarks like Charles Bridge or Old Town Square are usually packed. And so that‚Äôs where we decided to go.
We started our stroll at the beautiful Kampa island. With its maze of tiny streets and an old watermill, it‚Äôs one of my favorite places in Prague. We didn‚Äôt go as far as the famous Lennon wall, but we enjoyed the poetry booth on the edge of the park instead. This invention is one of the indigenous ideas of Ondrej Kobza, who is also behind the Prague street piano initiative and is always looking for ways to make the city more interesting. Needless to say, I am a fan.
From Kampa, we headed to the Charles Bridge. I was curious about how many people would be there ‚Äî after all, we were not the only ones on the empty city sightseeing bandwagon. As it turned out, it wasn‚Äôt completely devoid of explorers like us, but there were very few people.
The Charles Bridge is usually a bustling hub of activity with its sides lined by various stalls and the space between them filled by a mass of people. You can move only at a slow pace here ‚Äî together with the crowd. I have never seen it as empty as that day.
We crossed the Charles Bridge and got to the Old Town Square and its famous astronomical clock. When I was a little child, my parents sometimes took me there to see the renowned moving figurines of the twelves apostles, a display that plays out at the end of every hour. But we always had to stand on our tiptoes in the middle of the crowd to see them.
This time was different. We picked the restaurant directly across the astronomical clock, sat at an outside table, ordered lunch, and waited for the whole spectacle to begin.
I have never ever thought that I would be eating in one of the Old Town Square restaurants. Usually, they are full of tourists, and the prices are astronomical ‚Äî no pun intended. Today though, the restaurant was half-empty and the prices reasonable. And the food was delicious too! I was glad to find out they served a vegetarian burger, and I can definitely recommend it. If you are interested, the name of the restaurant is El Toro Negro.
We slowly ate our lunch, and then the astronomical clock awakened, and everything suddenly set to motion. The twelve apostles moved behind the little windows, a figure of a skeleton that represents death beckoned at us with its little scythe, and the cockerel that symbolizes life ended the spectacle with its crowing. It was pretty nostalgic because I haven‚Äôt been here for a long time.
At the end of our excursion, we decided to visit the main Prague library around the corner from Old Town Square. We had a particular reason for it ‚Äî in the lobby is a sculpture that I love, and Ben has never seen it before. It is a tower built from old books stretching from the floor to the ceiling. Inside of it are two mirrors that reflect the picture, so when you look inside, you see a book tunnel that stretches into eternity.
I never get tired of this sight. Ben was properly amazed. We are a pair of bookworms, so we can never pass on a sight like this. And it was a great conclusion to a well-spent day as tourists in our own city. It was a fun thing to do, and I think we will try to repeat it more often from now on, Covid or not. After all, Prague is a beautiful city, and I should realize more often how lucky I am to live here.

It‚Äôs a cold, sunny day in mid-January, and I‚Äôm sitting on a frosty barstool outside, sipping the hot mulled wine the Czechs call Sva≈ô√°k.
I can see the colorful Astronomical Clock about thirty feet away, built by Master Mikul√°≈° Kada≈à in the early 1400s, with the Church of Our Lady of T√Ωn looming above Old Town Square.
Across the narrow cobblestone street stands the ornate house, dubbed the Minute House, where the influential writer Franz Kafka spent his early childhood.
As always, there is a constant flow of people bustling about, wrapped in parkas and earmuffs, moving into and out of the beautiful square. Many people stop every hour to watch the Twelve Apostles appear at the top of the Astronomical Clock.
It‚Äôs busy but not too crowded, yet more proof that the best time to travel is in the winter, when prices are low, tourists scarce and you can appreciate what a place has to offer.
I‚Äôve come to Prague to escape the Covid madness still gripping much of the United States and the West ‚Äî and the increasingly aggressive propaganda of the corporate media.
My grandchildren needed someone to take them back to London after their annual Christmas visit, and I instantly volunteered.
With my American Express travel points, I could get a ticket almost for free ‚Äî and prices for a week-long visit in Prague were too good to pass up. My hotel right on the Old Town Square, with its large ornate bedrooms and funky statues of angels with swords, cost me just $83 per night, breakfast included. I couldn‚Äôt afford to stay home.
I did have to take not one but five separate Covid tests and demonstrate a near-professional knowledge of computers to clear the bureaucratic hurdles, but I sailed through Czech Immigration with hardly a glance.
After breakfast, I work in the mornings on my laptop and then spend the afternoons exploring the city ‚Äî Prague Castle and the magnificent St. Vitus Cathedral on the hill, the medieval Charles Street bridge, the Museum of Communism, the shape-shifting steel statue of Kafka‚Äôs head by the artist David ƒåern√Ω, the National Museum near Wenceslas Square, the Jewish Quarter.
I pay the obligatory visit to an Absentherie, tasting the once-forbidden Green Fairy, and take a cruise out on the Moldau River.
What strikes me the most is the upbeat, freer atmosphere in Prague.
As much as the US prides itself on its love of liberty, the truth is that there is more freedom now in Eastern Europe than in many countries in the West or in places like Australia.
Some tourists wear face masks but most of the Czechs do not. Life has returned to normal here in Central Europe, and the smiling faces and friendly greetings of dobr√Ω den on the street stand in marked contrast to what you see in locked-down Los Angeles, New York or Chicago.
After nearly a week, I have been asked only once for my digital Covid Passport, and, when the scanner couldn‚Äôt read the QR Code from the U.S., the waitress just shrugged her shoulders and let me in anyway.
The thing about the Czech Republic is that its people had more than 40 years‚Äô experience dealing with Communist governments and their insane bureaucratic demands, from 1948 up until the Velvet Revolution threw the dictators out of power in 1989. Once you‚Äôve dealt with Soviet tanks rolling down your streets, as happened in Prague in 1968, Covid insanity is small beer.
The other aspect to Prague that both delights and unsettles me is how safe and clean the city is. The streets are spotless, the centuries-old architecture magnificent and the buildings freshly painted.
There are no homeless visible on the streets at all, although you do occasionally see a beggar kneeling with his forehead touching the ground, hat or cup obsequiously raised upward for a donation. Young women walk the dark alleyways and cobblestone streets late at night, seemingly unafraid.
In contrast, on the car trip to Los Angeles for my flight here, there were entire tent cities tucked underneath the freeway overpasses, mounds of garbage piled ten feet high. Violent crime in American cities is skyrocketing, thanks to the ‚Äúdefund the police‚Äù movement and the election of ‚Äúdecriminalize everything‚Äù leftist prosecutors.
In other words: Prague shows you that cities don‚Äôt have to be cesspools of crime, violence and uncollected garbage. Instead, they can be havens of culture, beauty and neighborliness. The ethnic hatreds and identity politics that are tearing America and countries like the UK apart are absent here.
In the end, this trip is restoring my faith in humanity ‚Äî and in the possibility, at least, that big cities can be livable again.
If the relatively poor Czech Republic can afford cities of unparalleled beauty and serenity, surely the vastly more affluent United States can do the same.
The lesson I take from Prague, therefore, is that there is hope for the future.
If the Czech people were able to remove authoritarian, surveillance-obsessed bureaucrats from power in a peaceful, nonviolent revolution, so, too, can liberty-loving Americans. Hopefully, it won‚Äôt take us 40 years.
NOTE: This article originally appeared in Mercatornet.com here. If you would like to receive these articles via email, subscribe to my newsletter at Substack.

Title: Seattle vs Prague
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
I lived in the greater Seattle area for three years. I‚Äôve lived in Prague for five months. Here‚Äôs my take on the wins and losses in both countries.
1Topic: SmokingWinner: Seattle
As a lifelong non-smoker, I define a country‚Äôs smoking success as having less of a smoking culture. Compared to the US, Prague has a huge smoking culture. According to data from the Czech National Cancer Control Programme, about 25% of Czechs smoke, compared to approximately 15% of Americans.
Anecdotally, I‚Äôve noticed much more smoking on the sidewalks, in parks, and in the outdoor sections of restaurants in Prague than in the US. Every time I walk through a smoke cloud in Prague, I long for the US.
2Topic: DogsWinner: Prague
If you‚Äôre a dog-lover, Prague has two really awesome parts of dog culture that make it better than the US:
3Topic: Dog PoopWinner: Seattle
Czechs don‚Äôt pick up dog poop. :( I almost had to stop picking up my dog‚Äôs poop in Prague because I physically could not find anywhere to buy poop bags and could not consistently find publicly-provided ones. For months, I lived off the supply I brought from the US, then finally restocked when I was on vacation in Asia.
But don‚Äôt take my word for it. A reply on a TripAdvisor forum went as far as to encourage people to not pick up dog poop, as it labeled you as a foreigner. And this poignant excerpt from the Czech Expats page, titled ‚ÄúPoo Fighters‚Äù (the Seattlite in me approves of the title), explains the issue even better:
There‚Äôs the issue of doggy do-do. However positively disposed you are towards our four-legged friends, no-one enjoys stepping in a steaming pile of poop. Yet despite all those green disposal bins supplied with free brown, erm, doggy bags, some owners persistently fail to clear up after their pets‚Ä¶ Matters have become so serious that Prague 7‚Äôs district council is considering DNA testing feces at the scene of the crime in order to track down the responsible pooches.
I don‚Äôt think I‚Äôve ever stepped in dog poop in the US. In Prague, I‚Äôve stepped in it more than half a dozen times. Get your shit together, Prague. Literally.
4Topic: Public TransportWinner: Prague
If you want reliable, dependable, and affordable public transport, Prague is an easy choice. On a normal weekday, if you miss your metro, the next one is only two minutes away. Two. Minutes. From this list of best global public transportation, Prague ranks within the top 25:
In the US, conversely, public transport is a nightmare of inconsistent times on incomplete routes. I can personally speak to the abhorrent public transportation Pittsburgh offered during my college years; with the minor experience I‚Äôve accumulated, I can also briefly speak to Seattle‚Äôs public transport. That said, with the exception of New York, none of them compares with any of the public transport systems I‚Äôve used in Europe. For the curious, Now This News covered the historical reasons why the US is transportationally behind the rest of the world (summary: we chose highways).
5Topic: Health CareWinner: Prague
I caught a lung infection within my first two months in Prague. I went to the doctor but didn‚Äôt have my work-supplied insurance card yet. They charged me without insurance for an emergency, unscheduled visit with a nurse practitioner. I approached the checkout desk post-appointment, waiting for the immense sans-insurance bill. As I stood, cringing, watching the lips of the receptionist read out my balance, seemingly in slow motion, it was‚Ä¶ $35. Without insurance.
In the US, my boyfriend had some blood tests done in a scheduled appointment and was charged $1,500 post-insurance. Prague obviously wins here.
It‚Äôs not just cost, however. It‚Äôs also coverage. In the Czech Republic, every citizen is by-default insured. In the US, over 10% of adults do not have health insurance. Health insurance for all is definitely a win.
You go, Czech Republic.
6Topic: Automatic Sliding DoorsWinner: Seattle
Sliding doors in the Czech Republic have two major issues:
In the US, sliding doors open in such a way that you just keep walking, and the doors will move to not impede your pace. Czech doors, in contrast, will open after you‚Äôve been standing in front of them for a few seconds. On my first day in Prague I tried to enter a mall, but the sliding doors weren‚Äôt sliding. I figured the mall was still closed. It wasn‚Äôt. I just didn‚Äôt wait long enough for the sliding doors to engage. I texted my American friend living in Denmark about it. She confirmed that European sliding doors just suck.
I only have anecdotal and social evidence to back up my claims, however, I know I‚Äôm not the only one to have noticed this. I don‚Äôt know this person, but based on their rant, I can tell we‚Äôre soulmates in another life:
2. The doors have different opening widths depending on the season
Czech sliding doors open less in winter. I get it, they save energy. However, this algorithm has a ton of problems. First, you get used to one opening width and then have to acclimate to another. This wouldn‚Äôt be a problem, except that you‚Äôre usually not paying much attention to the doors when walking through them. Suddenly ‚Äî SURPRISE. They unexpectedly open narrower than they used to and you walk into the door. I wish I were kidding, but the sliding glass doors at my work cracked in the winter, I presume for this very reason.
And second, the narrow width is a huge bottleneck. Luckily, waiting outside doors in the winter is one of my favorite pastimes. Oh wait, it‚Äôs not.
Get with it Prague.
7Topic: Drinking CultureWinner: Prague
US drinking law: No open alcohol on the streets, absolutely no open containers in cars, and .08 BAC to drive. And that .08 BAC is something a drunk person has to self-gauge. Ne dobry (that means ‚Äúnot good‚Äù in Czech).
Prague drinking law: Open alcohol containers are mostly legal, open containers in the car are fine as long as the driver doesn‚Äôt partake, and drivers must have 0 BAC. There‚Äôs no tolerance for drunk driving, or even buzzed driving, in the Czech Republic. üëç
The Prague drinking laws make Czech drinking culture less restrictive for people enjoying responsibly. Additionally, they‚Äôre not so strict that they ironically encourage more drinking, like in the US, where paper-bagging alcohol or hiding alcohol in a bottle of Gatorade is a common sight. And finally, the zero-tolerance rule for drivers makes drunk driving less prevalent in Europe.
In the US, alcohol is involved in 23% of traffic-related deaths. In the Czech Republic, that same statistic is 4%. And the Czech Republic is one of the worst offenders in the EU.
8Topic: ShoppingWinner: Seattle
You know what I miss about the US? Target. Need to find some obscure household item? Target has it. Target doesn‚Äôt have it? Amazon surely does.
What happens in the Czech Republic? Well, if you want to find that same obscure household item‚Ä¶ well, you can go to‚Ä¶ fuck it, I don‚Äôt know. There are no major shopping centers like Target or Walmart. Think you can turn to Amazon next? Nope, there‚Äôs no Amazon in the Czech Republic. Your only options are to use Germany‚Äôs Amazon service, or the Czech Republic‚Äôs Amazon equivalent, Alza.cz.
I miss you, US shopping. ‚ù§
9Topic: TechnologyWinner: Seattle
One of Prague‚Äôs charms is its rustic, classic look. The streets are still cobblestone, the buildings are still original. Apparently, Prague is so beautiful that Hitler himself was inspired to spare it. Consequently, it‚Äôs one of the few places in this part of Europe that wasn‚Äôt bombed in WWII, so it‚Äôs one rarity that preserved its vintage appearance.
Unfortunately, that old-school culture also makes Prague lag the rest of the world in adoption and prevalence of technology. Do you enjoy elevators? Get ready to use some slow, old, questionable elevators that you‚Äôre not sure will hold your weight. The one in my apartment building doesn‚Äôt even have up or down buttons ‚Äî just a call button. When my dog chewed up my laptop charging cord, I quickly found out I couldn‚Äôt get a replacement in the Czech Republic (luckily, my work had an extra lying around). When I lost my Fitbit charger, I was forced to order one from Amazon Germany.
This carries on to other parts of daily life. When I was apartment hunting, almost nobody accepted emails. You had to call, and calling meant you had to speak Czech. Welp.
Welcome to the shitshow that is the Czech technology scene. Missing you rn, America.
10Topic: Customer ServiceWinner: Seattle
Need help at a store? Czechs don‚Äôt give a fuck. Want a shopping cart? Gotta put in a coin to get one. Want a bag for your items? Gotta pay for that too. Need a restroom while shopping? Get ready to pay again.
Generally, Czech store representatives and systems are ruder, less-helpful, and more prohibitive than in the US. It‚Äôs even worse if they figure out you‚Äôre a foreigner.
Check out this poignant quote and related article with more formalized data on Czech customer service:
In the Czech Republic, a basic lack of understanding of the minimum level of courtesy required when dealing with the public seems all too widespread ‚Äî and it‚Äôs costing companies dearly. A survey by telecommunications firm Genesys estimates that Czech businesses lose 1.08 billion US dollars annually because of substandard customer service.
11Topic: Elderly CommunityWinner: Prague
Perhaps because of the prevalence of public transport and the de-emphasis of cars, elderly people are active and all over Prague. It‚Äôs really refreshing to see independent elderly people around the city, a rare sight in the US. If you want to stay active in your senior years, I‚Äôd prescribe Prague.
12Topic: BathroomsWinner: Prague
Do you love knowing who‚Äôs in the bathroom with you based on the shoes sticking out beneath the stalls? Making eye contact through the stall gap? Do you enjoy people hearing you poop? And hearing other people poop?
Europe has none of these things. Water closets are God‚Äôs gift to relieving yourself. They‚Äôre little, private, sealed, closed rooms where you can do your business discretely and in peace. Mmmmmm.
The only downside is that Europe has a bad habit of charging for bathrooms. But with bathrooms this delightful, I‚Äôll take it.
Topic: WaterWinner: Seattle
I ask for few things in life. One of them, however, is free, still, ice water without a lemon in it. Seattle gets this. Prague does not. Most Czech restaurants don‚Äôt offer free water, and when you ask for water, they offer you the option of still or sparkling. And when your paid-for, over-specified water does arrive, it usually includes a lemon. And no ice. Shame on you Prague.
(I realize that most of this is personal preference. Please indulge my rant)
And there you have it! What I love and don‚Äôt love about my two homes, Prague and Seattle. Did you come to the end of this article looking for me to call a winner? I‚Äôm sorry to disappoint. Both cities have a special place in my heart.
--
--

Title: 4 Art Museums in Prague: The Masterpieces You Need to See
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

Listen
Share
The art museums in Prague hold some great works of art that you need to see during your trip. Why listen to my recommendations? I am an artist and I‚Äôve been living in the Czech Republic for 10 months now. In this article, I am sharing with you the must-see art museums in Prague.
Read next: 6 Art Museums in Florence: The masterpieces you need to
I am starting with the Lubkowicz Palace because it holds a collection of artifacts that tell the most about Czech history.
The Palace entry ticket comes with an audio-guide that helps you explore Bohemian and European history through the Lobkowicz family and their collections ‚Äî one of Europe‚Äôs oldest and finest private art collections, comprised of items dating back over 2,000 years. The collection highlights include paintings by Bruegel the Elder, Canaletto, and Vel√°zquez and hand-annotated manuscripts by Mozart and Beethoven.
P.S: The audio guide is narrated in English by two generations of the Lobkowicz family and the collections‚Äô curators (also available in 10 other languages). The additional Prague InSpires Panorama audiotour introduces visitors to the city‚Äôs most iconic landmarks in under 30 minutes from the Lobkowicz Palace balcony.
My favorite museum in Prague is the national gallery (not to be confused with the national museum). With origins dating back to the 18th century, it is one of the oldest, largest, and most respected art museums in Central Europe. What makes this gallery unique is that its collections are spread out in various Baroque palaces, Medieval convents, and castles all around Prague. So, it is not one building but many different building. You can check out the official website for more details on the different buildings, opening hours, and ticket prices.
The National Gallery is particularly well-known for its wide collection of modern artists such as Picasso, Rousseau, Monet, and C√©zanne. the National Gallery has an extensive collection of works by great Czech artists.
One of the most recognizable works in the National Gallery‚Äôs collection is Vincent van Gogh‚Äôs Green Field (1889). This is one of many landscape paintings Van Gogh produced while recovering at a mental asylum in Provence and it shows the painter at the height of his creative powers.
A not-so-popular museum, but if you are an art enthusiast, you definitely know the iconic master of Art Nouveau Alphonse Mucha. However, you may not know that he was actually Czech because he mostly lived in Paris during the Art Nouveau period. Mucha produced illustrations, advertisements, decorative panels, and designs, which became among the best-known images of the period. For that, I think the museum deserves a visit.
At the age of 57, Mucha returned to his homeland and devoted himself to a series of twenty monumental symbolist canvases known as The Slav Epic, depicting the history of the Slavic people. On the 10th anniversary of the independence of Czechoslovakia, he presented the series to the Czech nation. He considered The Slav Epic his most important work.
Not really an art museum but the Clementinum is Prague‚Äôs second-largest building complex after Prague Castle and houses the most beautiful library in the world. Among the 27,000 old printed works, there are, for example, Kepler‚Äôs writings with his handwritten dedication to his friends, the dean, and other professors at the Prague university. The Jesuits founded the Clementinum in 1556 and named it after the former Dominican monastery of St. Clement from 1227, where they settled. In 1775, meteorological data began to be collected here regularly; thus Prague has the longest continuous series of meteorological observations in Europe.
Prague is a gorgeous city that holds a significant number of museums and historical attractions. If I were to pick only one art museum to see in Prague, I‚Äôd visit The National Gallery, as it is the richest, widest and most interesting art collection in Prague. However, make sure to, once in yo

Title: GETTING A HAIRCUT IN PRAGUE: WHAT NOT TO DO.
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
GETTING MY HAIRCUT while traveling is something that I still can‚Äôt take in my stride. Because of this I now look like one of those Barber: What you want? memes. Here‚Äôs my easy step-by-step guide on how not to get a haircut in a foreign country. Haircuts, as they say, are 20:20.
There are two key factors you should aim for when truly trying to devastate your hairdo: laziness and language barriers. Thankfully, I achieved both.Laziness, over time, will allow your hair to look odd. It grows this way and that- always unevenly, of course. Eventually, it will evolve to a look bad enough that if you bump into someone you hadn‚Äôt seen in a while they feel obliged to ask ‚ÄúEverything okay man?‚Äù
By this stage you start to think ‚ÄòYou know what? A bad haircut probably wouldn‚Äôt be worse than this.‚Äô(*Note* If you reach this point, remind yourself: a bad haircut is, in fact, much worse).
This morning, I had that incorrect thought. It was time to get a haircut in Prague.
‚ÄòThe difference between a good haircut and a bad one is a couple of weeks‚Äô my Granny says. As an Irishman, I would never be seen to disagree with my grandmother. But, come to think about it: A travel blog is the safest place to dispute your 93-year old Granny‚Äôs opinion and get away with it.
That‚Äôs if I was to do it. Which I would not.
As mentioned, my hair was more than unruly. It was bordering on passers-by questioning my mental health. Too short to be long hair; too long to be considered short. I looked tragic.
I had 2 work meetings on Google Hangouts later that day. Not the phone ones in your PJs. Video ones where you need to appear compos mentis.It seemed as good a day as any to smarten up.
I researched some Prague barbers and found plenty. There was an American Expat website that offered some decent options. Weighing them all up, I decided it would be best to procrastinate.
I took a break from helpful research and watched YouTube videos on ‚ÄòHow To Cut Your Own Hair‚Äô instead. Almost all of them were imitating a David Beckham haircut of one time or other.
Could I do this myself? I had my own lightweight electric razor‚Ä¶
Could I ask my wife, perhaps? Remembering our hostile afternoon in Cape Cod after how I reacted to her previous attempt, I thought better of it. Back to Google.
It ultimately came down to discovering the barbers closest to Prague‚Äôs Old Town Square, where I am staying. I reviewed the reviews and set my sights on their sites. One, in particular, seemed slick.
The website and Facebook page gave a good first impression. It spoke to my need to think that I‚Äôm cool and stylish at 31. Even the translation for tutto barbuto- ‚Äòfully bearded‚Äô- was pretty badass.
Customers drank scotches and smoked shisha in the online pictures. Smoking Hookah isn‚Äôt my thing. But drinking scotch while getting a haircut would be great to tick off the bucket list. It was 10am.
My wife Rachael and I embarked on the 6-min journey by foot from the Old Town Square to Tutto Barbuto.
By Prague standards, it was mild although my toes were beginning to lose sensation.
Flecks of snow fell lazily on the streets, too few and far between to ever last.When we found Tutto Barbutto, it was dark and empty. For a moment, I thought it was closed.
Before turning to leave, I hurled a tentative ‚ÄòDobr√Ω den?‚Äô towards the back of the shop. A small woman, maybe 26, emerged immediately, greeting me in Czech.
-I‚Äôm sorry, but do you speak English?-No.
We were off to the perfect start.
We were at an impasse. She had been clear she didn‚Äôt speak English. I had zero Czech but 2 impending Google Hangouts. Not to mention, the 99 problems growing out of my head. I decided to push through in English.
-Are you open?
-Yes.
That was good enough for me. I removed my coat and scarf then sat into the barber‚Äôs chair.
The lady who was about to cut my hair had dark features and a Marilyn Monroe portrait on her inner arm. I produced my phone to show her the picture I had screen-shotted as inspiration for whoever cut my hair.
This screenshot technique always strikes me as awkward. You can‚Äôt show them a photo of somebody who is tooooo attractive or it feels as if your drawing comparisons between yourself and the male model staring back at them dreamily from your phone.
Even the act of providing a photo is something I steer clear from when home in Ireland. Doing anything outside what is seen as standard behavior could be met with the most withering critique an Irish person can give a compatriot:
‚ÄúHe‚Äôs getting notions about himself‚Äù.
Looking at the screenshot, she zoomed in.
‚ÄúVery fastidious,‚Äù I thought.
She could have been thinking ‚ÄúThis man has notions,‚Äù in Czech.
To reaffirm we were on the same page, I pointed to the side of my head- albeit, an overgrown one- and said ‚ÄúVery short‚Äù. Then I helpfully pointed to the top of my head and said ‚ÄúLong‚Äù.
I find myself in these lost in translation moments regularly. While in the midst of them, I hope that a sizable smile will fill the gaps and encourage my opposite number to give me the benefit of the doubt while I point at my head and say random words.
-Zero blade?-No, thanks. A one.
I‚Äôm sure I held up one finger and accompanied it with another oversmile.
After a quick wash, the razor purred and hairs began to drop. So long, old friends.
She was painstaking and focused, spending what seemed like 15 minutes on the sides alone. It looked terrific. Suddenly the phone rang and she went to retrieve it.
Rachael came over to the chair for a moment and we both talked about how good I looked before the hairdresser returned.
I‚Äôm a long term insomniac and the night before had been rough. I had laid awake from 3.30am-7 before giving up the ghost of sleep and getting up to work out. It was only 10.30 in the morning, but I‚Äôd already been awake 7 hours. My eyes were heavy.
And now that the adrenaline was wearing off since my hairdresser was so good, I wasn‚Äôt sure I would be able to stay awake in the warm barbershop.Snip.
She chopped about three inches from my hair in one fell swoop. She had clearly experienced my universal gesture of point-at-top-of-head-and-say-long though. Or had she? I waited to see.
Snip.
Snip-snip. Snipsnipsnip.
I looked in stunned silence waiting for her to stop. She didn‚Äôt.
While I knew I needed a serious cut, I had expected to leave with much more hair to brave the bitter Prague weather. That protective layer of hair now lay on the floor beneath me.
As I write this now, it seems so stupid. Why not just stop her? There was something that was making me give her the benefit of the doubt, though. I felt like she had a plan.
Turns out she really didn‚Äôt.
Rach had been on her phone for the last few hellacious minutes. In the mirror, I saw her look up.
‚ÄúKeith!‚Äù
I ignored her call, trying to look calm as if this was all my plan. The man with the plan.
‚ÄúKEITH‚Äù she called again, louder.
I looked at her in eyebrow-raised resignation. Edwina Scissorhands chopped on, oblivious
Rach jumped out of her seat and walked towards the blizzard of hair.
‚ÄúYou‚Äôve cut it too short!‚Äù
The hairdresser paused. After a moment she said:
‚ÄúWas damaged.‚Äù
‚ÄúIt‚Äôs fine,‚Äù I said to no one in particular in consummate Irishness.
And it was fine. Just about as fine as looking like an idiot can be. The strangest think about my Prague haircut was that, at the end, she shaved back my hairline a half-inch or so.
Image of google screenshot for Prague hairdresser and how it turned out.Can you spot the difference between my Prague haircut and the model?When she finished, it didn‚Äôt look so bad. I won‚Äôt claim I looked good but it could have been worse. Through a combo or blow-drying and hair-spraying, she made it seem like she hadn‚Äôt scalped me.
Stepping away from the scene of the massacre, that big broad smile from earlier was a little more difficult to muster. But muster it I did; long enough to pay the 569 Czech Koruna (about $23).
Then I did what any self-respected Irish person would do.I thanked her and left a tip.
If you liked this and want to read more of my travel stories/mishaps, visit my website, sowherewerewe.com

Title: Prague: Fear and Beauty
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

For those who love to travel, live for travel, and always have a story to tell.

--
1
Listen
Share
The Czech capital guards its secrets.
We came late to Prague. By the time we made our way to the red-roofed city, the path to the east was already well-beaten by hordes of budget travelers and lairy British stag parties. An influx of foreign tourists has pushed Prague close to the top of the list of Europe‚Äôs most visited cities, with all the opportunities and problems that kind of popularity creates for the local residents.
But Prague is every bit as beautiful as it was back when it seemed so exotic, smiling shyly behind the Iron Curtain. The Haussmannian grandeur of the Old Town buildings invites comparison with Paris, but Parisiens would never allow their buildings to be painted like this. Bright yellow next to powder blue beside terracotta. And while tourists gape at the astronomical clock that jerks into life twenty-four times a day, the sun ‚Äî when it shines ‚Äî gilds the dark spires of the Church of Our Lady of Tyn and makes the old stones glow as brightly as the painted buildings.
The same force that makes a person wander the world pushes flowers from the ground to salute the distant sun. The artists of Prague don‚Äôt stop painting the old buildings just because they can no longer afford to own them. Among the graffiti of the Old Town, two themes recurred: the Golem, as played by Paul Wegener in the 1920 horror film he directed. And the simple phrase, in English: Life Is Beautiful.
Flowers bloom and die and never leave a mark, and for most of us, this beautiful life is the same.
Few of us shape history, like the dead kings in their cold tombs on the high hill where Prague‚Äôs castle stands. But that doesn‚Äôt keep us from trying. For an additional fee that‚Äôs as steep as the stairs, you can climb the tower of St Vitus Cathedral and look out across the river at Prague. And up there, in the teeth of the wind that rises from the Vltava, you can see the old stones scored with the initials of decades of visitors, the merged letters in a dozen languages forming the ridges and valleys of an insensate fingerprint.
Prague isn‚Äôt as cheap as it used to be when the first intrepid tourists arrived from the West after the fall of Communism. But it‚Äôs still an absolute steal compared to the likes of Paris or London or Barcelona. Two nights at the gorgeous five star Art Nouveau Palace cost 166 euros after tax. Dinner and drinks for two at a Michelin starred restaurant for 200. Prague still represents a great deal for a budget traveler and offers a chance to splash out on high-end experiences at a price you could never hope to pay in other European capitals.
Prague has other marks, too. Scars with gloomier origins than the vandalizing initials of bright and brutish tourists.
On the day we visited, a young woman was lighting a candle in front of the narrow window of the church basement. The stone is still pockmarked with holes, where Nazi bullets once struck sparks from the walls. Seven hundred and fifty soldiers launched attack after attack on the church, but couldn‚Äôt dislodge the men hiding inside.
After hours of fighting, the Germans brought in the fire brigade and ordered them to flood the basement. Not one of the Czech freedom fighters was taken alive. The mission cost them their lives and the lives of anyone connected to them. It also prompted Nazi massacres in villages entirely unconnected with the plot. But it was the only successful assassination of a high-ranking Nazi officer. The war would continue, of course, with or without Reinhard Heydrich, Hitler‚Äôs ‚Äòman with an iron heart.‚Äô But at the cost of their lives, Josef Gabcik, Jan Kubis, Adolf Opalka, Josef Bublik, Jaroslav Svarc, Josef Valcik, and Jan Hruby proved that despite their military prowess, even the highest-ranking officials of the Nazi government could be killed. And 70 years later, Czechs still honor the bravery of men willing to die for their country.
Some fights are worth having. And life is beautiful. So beautiful that sometimes it‚Äôs worth losing.
Prague feels like the kind of place with secrets. It‚Äôs still relatively new to modern mass tourism, having been shut off behind the Iron Curtain within my lifetime. You can see it in the bullet marks, or in the creepy statue of the Commendatore outside the theater where Mozart‚Äôs Don Giovanni premiered. You can see it in the frowning face of the ubiquitous Golem.
Stories make cities what they are, just as they do for people. We become the sum of what we experience, our cathedrals and our bullet holes. Our spires and basements. We may be the wealthiest and most fortunate group of people in human history, and yet so many of us are afraid. Afraid to lose what we have. Afraid to fail. Afraid of others who are themselves prisoners of fear, that makes them lash out and bite anyone they can reach. Fear lives at the heart of our culture, the magic word written down and stuffed into the hollow clay skull of the Golem to make it live.
Tyranny comes in many forms, and fear has always been one of its favorite weapons. Prisons without bars are the hardest to escape. I‚Äôm living proof that you can spend your whole life making what seems like the right decision and never get any closer to what you really want ‚Äî the raw experience of being alive. Inside each of us, an iron-hearted voice commands caution, and while we hoard worthless tokens and live in fear of losing, we miss the bright imperfect world sailing by.
And yet we all want to make our mark. That brief blaze of light across an immensity of darkness, to say in some way to the uncaring universe that we were here. This is mine, a few words held out into the world like writing on water, vanishing even in the act of creation. The rough wind whirls the ticket from my hand, and I carry on without it, lighter for the loss.
This story is published in Writers on the Run. If you‚Äôre interested in submitting your travel stories please visit our submission guidelines.

Prague is a European city I‚Äôve always wanted to visit.
Since I was a child, I marveled at images of its cobblestone streets and remarkable buildings. So, when I got a chance to visit Prague for 24 hours, I was determined to make the most of the opportunity.
Here‚Äôs how I spent 24 hours in Prague:
My boyfriend and I woke up bright and early, buzzing with excitement for the day ahead. As we left our hotel room and wandered the cobblestone streets, we found the city quite empty before 8 am.
We heard a rumor that many people sleep in after a fun night out of drinking. After all, beer is often cheaper than bottled water, and Czechs consume more beer per capita than any other country in the world.
We were relieved to have a quieter beginning to the day. Yesterday, when we‚Äôd wheeled our suitcases from the bus stop to our hotel, we realized that many crosswalks in Prague did not have pedestrian signals. Most of the time‚Ä¶

Title: Prague of David ƒåern√Ω
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
When you visit Prague, the list of landmarks to see is quite obvious ‚Äî The Prague Castle, Old Town, Charles Bridge with its famous statues. But between them you may find some strange‚Ä¶ things, let‚Äôs say. In such a case, it‚Äôs very possible you‚Äôve just come across the work of Czech artist, David ƒåern√Ω. And as strange as they are, all of them are worth seeing.
Here‚Äôs the shortlist of his work list ‚Äî for more, visit davidcerny.cz
One of the most characteristic sculptures of ƒåern√Ω is St. Wenceslas riding a dead horse, hanging in the passage of Lucerna Palace.
If you have already walked on the nearby Wenceslas Square, you might think this looks somehow familiar. Indeed, this sculpture was inspired by the famous Statue of Saint Wenceslas. It‚Äôs even the same in size. But the horse is dead, and upside down. Don‚Äôt ask. Allegedly, it represents the idea of thinking that everything is fine, even if it‚Äôs not.
Nevertheless, move to the nearby Quadrio Shopping Centre ‚Äî to its back entrance, to be precise. You won‚Äôt miss the enormous, steel sculpture of Franz Kafka, the famous Austrian-Czech writer. His head, to be precise.
It‚Äôs 10 meters tall and made of 42 rotating stainless steel panels. It doesn‚Äôt really belong to the Old Town, which is probably the best reason for placing it right there (it stands on the private ground). The Czech sense of humor.
Speaking of heads, one of the most recent works is the monument of Trifot, 12-meter tall sculpture inspired by Day of the Triffids by John Wyndham. To reach it, you should take Metro Line B and get out at Nove Butovice station.
The eyes of the Trifot are actually camera lenses, which are able to take the photos of passers-by. And those photos can be shown on the nearby screens (unfortunately, this was out of order in 2023, when I visited Prague ‚Äî don‚Äôt know if it works now). Quite a nod to the omnipresent user tracking.
But ƒåern√Ω‚Äôs work is not limited to sculptures only. You can see the part of him in everyday objects. Like the counter top in Mlynska Cafe (Kav√°rna Ml√Ωnsk√°) in Kampa Park.
Partly a pub, partly a cafe, Mlynska serves as a cozy place for a drink, located in an old mill. If you sit at the bar, you‚Äôll notice a unique counter top created by ƒåern√Ω. It‚Äôs actually a mix of rubbish found in Vltava, and random stuff left by the visitors ‚Äî all immersed in an artificial resin. In a certain sense, it‚Äôs a picture of local life, stuck forever like archaeological treasures on a museum exhibition.
Speaking of museums, if you want to explore the world of David ƒåern√Ω‚Äôs mind, you should visit Musoleum, where you‚Äôll find many of his other works, including Entropa, his variation on European Union countries.
Oddly enough, even though the work was unveiled in 2009, United Kingdom is not represented (in other words, represented as a missing piece) in the sculpture. It was then a symbol of British isolation from Europe, and only predicted Brexit 7 yeards later.
