Prague
I had not heard a single negative thing about Prague before arriving ‚Äî most of the travelers I had encountered prior had preached about how amazing of a city it is. This had my expectations sky-high for the Czech city, which I hereby declare the Interstellar Mistake (Christopher Nolan, Matthew McConaughey, Hans Zimmer, reality-based space sci-fi‚Ä¶ how could it have not been the best film of all time?!) When I only get to visit a place for a few days, my entire perception of it is largely dependent on the weather while I‚Äôm there (Ireland is beautifully sunny and warm, in case you were unaware). Unfortunately for me, my visit to Prague was accompanied by clouds, rain, and cold weather.
That said, it still is architecturally a magnificent place, thanks partially to it not being blown up by war. After all the historically significant, gigantic, celebrated churches I‚Äôve seen over the past three months, the Gothic churches of Prague are far and away my favorite. The charred-looking stone and ridiculously intricate gold and black ornamentation stand out prominently above the other buildings of the city. The largest of these, St. Vitus Cathedral, sits in the middle of the Prague castle on the top of a hill overlooking the Vltava river. The castle itself is a pretty well protected peek into the past, with the palace, churches, shops, and residencies that once inhabited the space within the castle walls.
Another thing Prague does do well is public / street art. This is also most definitely in response to Soviet rule of the city. One particular space called the ‚ÄúLennon Wall‚Äù celebrates the freedom to write anything on a public wall without an authority covering it up. Every day, hundreds of people come by and paint their own drawings and words on the wall, which is now feet thicker due to so many coats of paint. Beyond this street art, there are many humorous statues with implied political meaning, such as giant bronze babies with barcodes instead of faces, and two men urinating in a pool shaped as the Czech Republic. I don‚Äôt exactly remember the point of that one, but it‚Äôs funny nonetheless. Hopefully one day I‚Äôll be able to return to Prague under clearer weather and lower expectations, and be able to thoroughly enjoy the beauty of the place.

Title: Clear Head in Prague
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--

Share
August 28, 2012.
I had just finished my dietetic internship in NYC at the hospital formerly known as Beth Israel Medical Center, now transitioned to Mount Sinai, and I felt a sense of freedom. Where better to reap the benefits of this long-lost feeling than wander around Eastern Europe, specifically Bohemia, specifically Prague?
I hopped on an ICE fast train from Leipzig, Germany to Prague. Back then I had no smartphone, and I used a paper map to guide my way through the winding European streets. I got around just fine, except for that one time I was lost in the rain at 2 am. I did eventually find my way back to the Hotel Sunflower.
One thing I pack with me while traveling is a notebook and pen to write down thoughts, ideas, things I would like to do and see; places to eat and drink. My weekend in Bohemia included a typical tourist visit to Prague Castle and the Staropramen Brewery, yet it also included some not-for-tourist places such as Tynska Bar & Books, and this other place I had read about that was known for its vegetarian food in the land of pork knuckle and dumplings. The Czech name of the restaurant is Lehka Hlava, which translates to Clear Head.
Perfect, I thought. The name called to me after my long-lost night. I needed to clear my head.
After I arrived and was taken to my table at the restaurant I noticed a table of four women near my table of one. They were laughing, and enjoying their food and wine. Seeing them made me miss my friends back home. I bounced back into the present and ordered a full meal complete with a starter, a main, and a dessert with one glass of wine.
Looking back all these years later I cannot remember exactly what I ordered, but I do remember that the meal I had that evening in Prague was the best meal I had while traveling Bohemia. I remember the bill was equivalent to about 12 US dollars, which has been embedded into my memory since I was a graduate student at NYU at the time‚Äî not rich in money, but rich in books.
Although I cannot recall exactly what I chose on the menu nor did I take any photos of it, I do know that my solo dining experience was welcomed, and the food was honestly delicious.
Now many years later I glance at the menu on my computer. It includes items such as pumpkin and ginger soup with orange juice, vegetable consomm√© with yeast dumplings, spaghetti with tempeh bacon and sauce of baked garlic, g√©rtaix ‚Äî cheese balls with cumin sticks, wasabi dressing, and balsamic reduction, Kimchi-potato pancake ‚Äî traditional Czech potato pancake with kimchi and spring onion, and hot raspberry crumble with mascarpone-ricotta cream.
The menu reflects the diversity of the chefs at Lehka Hlava, and each dish has a goal to both electrify and soothe the senses. I still think about this restaurant now and then. It pops into my mind as ‚Äúthose carefree days.‚Äù It was such a relaxing atmosphere and left me with a sense of, well, clarity. I left Prague happy and with lucidity. I did not get lost that night with my paper map.

Title: Top 7 Must-Visit Art Galleries in Prague for Every Art Lover (2025 Guide)
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

A travel guide to Prague, Czech Republic. Uncover the best tips and insights about the city.

--
Listen
Share
Most people know Prague for its cheap beer and beautiful bridges, but did you know that the city has a blossoming art gallery scene, too?
Prague truly has something for everyone. Are you a fan of historical art? What about contemporary art? The city has it all ‚Äî if you know where to look. But even if you don‚Äôt, don‚Äôt worry. That‚Äôs what this guide is for, after all!
Here‚Äôs a list of some of the best must-see galleries in Prague you can‚Äôt miss.
Fun fact: Prague‚Äôs National Gallery is one of the largest art museums in Central Europe. It has several buildings across the city. Honestly, if you want to see all of it, you might want to extend your trip by a couple of days! That‚Äôs how much art there is for you to admire.
Whether you‚Äôre interested in the old masters, Czech modernism, or international contemporary exhibitions, this gallery needs to be on your travel itinerary.
It‚Äôs a must-see for anyone who‚Äôs looking for a deep dive into Czech and European art.
I‚Äôll admit ‚Äî this one is a personal favorite of mine. There‚Äôs no better way to spend the afternoon in Prague than visiting DOX and seeing whatever exhibition they currently have on. They never miss!
DOX Centre for Contemporary Art is Prague‚Äôs leading modern art space. Here, you can expect thought-provoking exhibitions, modern architecture, and a permanent rooftop airship installation with some cozy beanbags inside.
It‚Äôs located in the Hole≈°ovice district, which is full of artistic caf√©s, beautiful plant stores, and small independent shops that you can get lost in. Perfect for an artsy day out!
This Prague art gallery is a must-see for contemporary art lovers.
Kampa Museum is all about modern European art. They especially spotlight Czech and Central European artists. Here, you can see the works of Franti≈°ek Kupka and Otto Gutfreund, as well as other rotating exhibits.
This beautiful gallery also has an exciting location ‚Äî you can find it on Kampa Island by the Vltava River. That‚Äôs right ‚Äî it‚Äôs on an actual island. In the middle of mainland Europe!
If you‚Äôre looking for a unique setting with stunning views, this is the one for you.
MeetFactory is unlike anything you‚Äôve ever seen before. This contemporary gallery and artist residency was founded by David ƒåern√Ω, a famous Czech artist who also designed the famous Rotating Head of Franz Kafka.
MeetFactory is all about avant-garde exhibitions, live performances, and experimental installations. It‚Äôs perfect for edgier travelers who want to see something different.
If you‚Äôre interested in experiencing Prague‚Äôs alternative art scene, you really shouldn‚Äôt miss this one!
Schwarzenberg Palace is technically part of the National Gallery, but it definitely deserves its own spot on this list. It‚Äôs a beautiful place, which makes sense. After all, it‚Äôs actually a Baroque palace that was only later turned into an art gallery. Its highlights include Czech Baroque and Renaissance paintings and sculptures.
For its historical setting showcasing classic masterpieces, of course. Also, it‚Äôs near Prague Castle, another popular tourist destination ‚Äî why not do a little 2-in-1?
Leica Art Gallery in Prague is a must-visit spot for photography lovers. It specializes in fine art photography by both Czech and international photographers. If that sounds like something you might enjoy, add this one to your itinerary. And don‚Äôt forget to check out the Leica camera store, too!
This one is a must for photography enthusiasts.
Last but not least, we have the Rudolfinum Gallery, which is a historic concert hall with a contemporary art gallery. It‚Äôs located by the Vltava River, near the Old Town, meaning that just walking there will take your breath away.
The Rudolfinum Gallery offers exhibitions of modern and contemporary art, despite how old and majestic it may look from the outside.
This gallery combines fine art with one of Prague‚Äôs most beautiful buildings. It also has a fun name. The Rudolfinum. Try not to think about Rudolph the Red-Nosed Reindeer while putting that name into Google Maps. I dare you.
The Rudolfinum is a gorgeous building, but it‚Äôs not the only one. Prague is a beautiful city with many views worth taking in. This is why river cruises are so popular here. If you want to see more of the city but don‚Äôt have a ton of time to walk everywhere, a cruise is the perfect solution.
You can try this Panoramic Vltava River Cruise by Get Your Guide, which will take you around Prague‚Äôs most famous landmarks, including Kampa Island, Prague Castle, Charles Bridge, and more.
Disclaimer: The above link is an affiliate link. If you choose to go on the cruise, I may earn a small commission at no extra cost to you. No pressure, though!
In case it wasn‚Äôt obvious, Prague‚Äôs art scene is super diverse. Whether you‚Äôre a modern art enthusiast or a lover of the classics, you won‚Äôt be disappointed by checking out these gorgeous galleries. So, don‚Äôt forget to add them to your travel plans.
Which of these Prague art galleries will you visit first? Let me know in the comments!

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt have a girlfriend, but I do know a woman who‚Äôd be mad at me for saying that.‚Äù
-Mitch
I decided on Prague next because Kevin had told me you can get wasted there for 5 bucks. That was enough for me. Kevin always knows the right move. Except for the time he jumped into the Chicago River, drunk as hell, to rescue a shoe. That was dumb. The Czech Republic had yet to switch over to the Euro, and as a result, the exchange rate with the dollar was about 4:1. In simple terms, everything in Prague was cheap compared to other European Union countries. Slovakia was also on the Koruna, but that will come later.
The only issue with Prague was the overnight, 14-hour train ride I needed to take to get there. But that‚Äôs what Tylenol PM is for, or Ambien if you have access. I figured I‚Äôd just zonk out then arrive in the daytime, rested and ready to go. So, I booked a bed in a 4-person room for the 20:00 train that night.
I had a while to kill yet, so I did my laundry and went to an internet caf√© to peruse hostels. I found one called, ‚ÄúHostel One Prague,‚Äù and booked it as soon as I saw pictures of a bar. Again, the stumble home just can‚Äôt be beat. It cost the equivalent of 4 Euros/night (about $6 USD at the time) and looked just weird enough for my taste. I was stoked.
When I got back to the train station at 7pm, I sat down in the corner of the massive waiting area to kill time, for what I thought would be 3 hours.
Let me stop for a second and say military time is some deceptive bullshit. Why is it even used at all? Do soldiers not understand am/pm clocks?
Anyway, I missed my train.
20:00 looks and feels like 10:00pm, I will die on that hill. Tell me I‚Äôm wrong. It‚Äôs an optical illusion.
The following train didn‚Äôt depart until eleven hundred hours the next morning (see how stupid that is?) and going back to either the hotel or the hostel was not an option. Those bridges were torched. So, I slept in the train station cuddling my backpack. It was just me and a few other people who also couldn‚Äôt tell time.
*
April 4, 2006
When I woke up the next morning, I had breakfast before hitting the train station booze shop. I bought whiskey and wine for the ride, and for when I‚Äòd arrive in Prague in the middle of the night. Never show up to a party empty handed. I also got a couple mini baguettes and a bunch of bananas to supplement. I didn‚Äôt want to take the chance of separating them.
The cabin was tinier than I expected, and my three roommates were already there, lying on their beds. The four of us tried to introduce ourselves, but we quickly realized none of us spoke the same language. One guy spoke Cantonese, one French, and the other, German. Names were even difficult, as they all involved different dialects. Communicating verbally was an impossibility. I feared the four of us were in for a silent ride.
After a short while, I pulled out a bottle of wine from my bag and opened it with a corkscrew, making a loud popping sound. Before taking a swig, I looked around the room to get everyone‚Äôs attention, but they were already looking in my direction, smiling and nodding. I motioned to the bottle and asked, ‚Äúeh?‚Äù. We all broke out in laughter.
I put my index finger up, the international sign for ‚Äúwait a minute,‚Äù and went to the bar car to grab four cups. I took some Adderall too, knowing that it was no longer going to be a Tylenol PM type of night. Drugs allow you to execute hairpin turns like an F1 driver.
Back in the cabin, I handed one to each guy before getting in my bed. One at a time, they stood and received their serving, like communion. After our first round, the bottle was finished, so I pulled out another. Then came the whiskey. Within two hours we were all good and drunk, telling stories in our own language without caring if we were understood by the others. The person standing had the floor, and the full attention of the other three. Miming (they love mimes in France, and we were still technically within the border), and facial expressions were all we needed.
When my turn came around, I regaled the guys of my time in Paris, acting out my shitting and vomiting fiasco from a few days prior. They were hysterical. We all were. It was beautiful; four guys from all over the world, getting on like lifelong friends, without even the benefit of language. I couldn‚Äôt have been more grateful for such a warm experience on a ride that otherwise would have been a lonely one, filled with dad thoughts.
The guys and I all had transfers to make, so we parted ways one at a time, hugging each other and exchanging emails as we said goodbye. I was the last to transfer, and when I did, around 1am, I got on the wrong train and ended up in the middle of nowhere, at the Praha-Veleslav√≠n station at 2:00am. It didn‚Äôt even look like city; the area was so desolate. I had absolutely no clue where I was, or where to go from there.
After 10 minutes of walking and smoking, I saw a couple driving down the street, approaching the stop sign where I was standing. I flagged them down, waving my arms like a lunatic. They stopped, as if they‚Äôd had this experience before. Unfortunately, they didn‚Äôt speak English. With miming now out of the question, all I could do was show them my map, and say the word ‚Äúhostel.‚Äù They nodded their heads and waved me into the car. Caroline and I sat next to each other, while Simon sat behind us. He smelled like he hadn‚Äôt showered in a week, and he probably hadn‚Äôt. When the metal chains on his leather jacket clanged against the poor old woman sitting beside him, she clutched her bag and turned towards the window. I felt terrible for her, having to sit next to a drunken stink bomb like that for 2 hours. He was disgusting.
Speaking of disgusting‚Ä¶ I was always embarrassed when my dad and I went out in public together. He was impossible not to stare at because of how fat and unkempt he was. And I was his son, so I got stares too. Food is the worst drug in that way. Most addictions aren‚Äôt noticeable to the naked eye, but with food, there‚Äôs no way to hide it, unless you purge. My mom always told me that everyone is too caught up in their own lives to notice other people‚Äôs insecurities, but I never believed her. I knew they were looking, wondering how a child like me could come from a man like that. I could feel their indictments of him as a father; I could feel their pity. I felt it all. Those feelings have never left me, even long after his death. I can still feel those eyeballs on me.
It was a peaceful first hour. Caroline and I read from our books while knocking knees. The unspoken intimacy was lovely. She was on her second read of a Virginia Woolf book I can‚Äôt remember the name of, just like I was on my second read of my Hunter Thompson book. We both sipped our beers and enjoyed the nice cross breeze wisping through the bus. The sun was out, and we were in just the right place at just the right time.
With only about 15 minutes left in the ride, I reached back to grab another beer from the box on Simon‚Äôs lap. That‚Äôs when I saw the flashing lights behind us. It was a police van, and it was rapidly approaching. When it got closer it became clear that we were the ones being pulled over.
Me: Uh, what the fuck is going on?‚Äù
Simon: It‚Äôs usually just standard shite. Don‚Äôt worry.
Me: Usually?!
Several police officers boarded the bus, all of whom were holding automatic rifles and looking very serious. I swear, in Europe everyone with even a modicum of authority gets a machine gun. They went around checking passports. When they got to me, I was terrified. My bag and pockets were filled with weed, hash, and a bunch of loose Adderall pills. Also, I was American. Being an American in Europe is almost as bad as being black in America. Boy, being black in Europe must be double awful.
I handed the cop my passport, and instead of handing it back, he put it in his pocket and escorted me off the bus. I was the only one singled out. Everyone else just sat comfortably, drinking their beers. The jig was finally up, and my worst nightmare was coming true. ‚ÄúIf this is what happens in the movie Hostel, I‚Äôm going to kill Caroline for not warning me,‚Äù I thought to myself.
He asked me a bunch of questions that I obviously didn‚Äôt understand, while repeatedly checking my passport and shaking his head from side to side. It was like I was being questioned by a squirrel. I had no clue what he wanted from me or how I could appease him. I tried to look like an upstanding gentleman by buttoning up my cardigan and straightening my posture, but it didn‚Äôt seem to be working. He saw right through me.
I could see Simon in the window of the bus. He was giving me the international sign for throat-slashing. I wasn‚Äôt sure if he was implying that I should kill myself to avoid Slovakian prison, or if he was telling me I should find a way to slit the officer‚Äôs throat and escape. Probably the latter, knowing him. Caroline too had come to the window. I could see the concern on her face. If she was scared, I knew I was in trouble.
They had me out on the side of the road for ten agonizing minutes while they talked on their radios. The bus driver came out at one point to ask what the holdup was, and they swiftly sent him back on the bus. Now, everyone was concerned. I got Caroline‚Äôs attention through the window.
Me: Caroline, grab a pen‚Ä¶ My name is Sam Rosenberg, NOT John McEnroe. My mom‚Äôs name is Audrey. She lives in Northbrook, Illinois. Please tell her ‚Äî
Then, it all ended, just like that. No bag check, no pat down, no nothing. They just sent me on my not so merry way, with my passport. The bus driver gave me a snide look, like I‚Äôd messed up his schedule, but I didn‚Äôt care. I‚Äôd dodged another bullet. Simon opened a beer with his teeth and handed it to me.
Simon: This deserves a celebration.
Our hostel wasn‚Äôt the most fashionable, but it was cheap, and right downtown. The room fit 8 people. It was the three of us and 5 Italian guys who were all clearly friends. When we got to the room, they were eating spaghetti with their shirts off. It was wildly apropos. When they offered us each a bowl, Caroline and I politely declined. Simon, on the other hand, scarfed one down in less than a minute.
Simon: You call this pasta? It‚Äôs shite, mate. Sorry to tell you.
They didn‚Äôt understand.
Italian Guy: Si, pasta. Prego, prego.
Me: Prego?
Italian Guy: Si, prego.
Caroline: (understanding the double entendre) Not the brand, Sam.
Simon: Ahem, his name is Johnny.
Caroline: It means ‚Äúyou‚Äôre welcome.‚Äù
Me: Ah, grazie.
Italian Guy: Si, prego.
Right down the street from our hostel was a bar called The Dubliner. It looked exactly like you‚Äôd expect it to look. There‚Äôs no need to even describe it. Irish bars are perfect that way, you always get what you expect, regardless of the country you‚Äôre in. The food and liquor are the same, as is the d√©cor. They are, if nothing else, reliable. And reliability is everything.
Caroline and I sat at a table together, drinking Guinness, while Simon roamed around the bar swilling Jameson and accosting random strangers. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm here with John McEnroe!‚Äù he‚Äôd tell anyone who‚Äôd listen. He was blacked out. 12 beers in 2 hours will do that to you.
Simon got punched in the face and thrown out within an hour. I didn‚Äôt see it but apparently, he spit in some guy‚Äôs face after being called a cunt. Then thee guy decked him with a single punch. As someone who used the word so often, I‚Äôd expect Simon to be less sensitive to being called one himself. Caroline and I were tossed too because we came with him. He tried fighting every single person on the way out, but Caroline and I just stood there and watched. There was no way I was fighting on his behalf. The last time I did that was in 4th grade when a friend got jumped for using a racial slur. I have regretted it ever since and still think of the guy as a racist piece of shit.
When the hullabaloo concluded, Simon‚Äôs face was bloodied, but he still wanted to drink.
Me: You need to go back to the hostel. They won‚Äôt let you into a bar with blood all over your face and shirt. That‚Äôs surely a universal rule.
Simon: Fuck that. When someone in Dublin gets punched in the face, the bar buys them drinks.
Me: We are not in Dublin.
Caroline: Sam and I are going to eat. You can‚Äôt come. You need to rest.
To my amazement, Simon heeded her advice and stumbled back to the hostel to crash. I felt sorry for the Italians because I knew he‚Äôd finish their spaghetti and/or try to fight them. At least it was five against one, and Simon could hardly stand, so I wasn‚Äôt too worried about them.
Caroline and I set out to find the nicest restaurant we could. We‚Äôd both been skimping on money for weeks and finally wanted to splurge now that we were amongst good company. We walked around for half an hour holding hands, chatting about food. Caroline told me she used to cook for her late brother, ‚ÄúDamby,‚Äù as she called him (because she couldn‚Äôt say ‚ÄúDanny‚Äù when she was little). She‚Äôd make him minced meat pies on Sundays after church. They were his favorite, and he‚Äôd eat them inside-out, saving the crust for last (I do the same). The recipe came from her mother, who got it from her mother, who got it from her mother before her.
I told her about my Bubbie, and the fried latkes she‚Äôd make for me after school. I always thought the jelly would cool them down faster, but it really just cooled the exterior, lulling me into a burnt mouth. I never learned my lesson. We traded food story after food story, our faces lit up, until we had none left.
Food is the easiest way to make bonds, Bourdain taught me that, and I‚Äôve always found it to be true. We all eat.
Downtown Bratislava was way more beautiful than I‚Äôd expected. The streets were cobblestone, but the buildings were modern; a dichotomy that somehow worked. It perfectly combined the old world with the new. And the place oozed romanticism. It was like a poem come to life. Everything Disneyland claims to be, Bratislava actually was. If you‚Äôre proposing to someone, I suggest doing it there. You will no doubt get a ‚Äúyes.‚Äù
We found a white-tablecloth, French restaurant to dine in. They didn‚Äôt seem to care about our casual attire even though the place was fancy, which impressed me. Everyone who can afford a meal should be accommodated, regardless of their attire. Miss me with that classist shit. Before ordering we decided we‚Äôd share so we could try more dishes. We got escargot to start. Always start with escargot if they have it. Then we had an omelet, followed by a quiche. For our main courses we shared duck confit and beef bourguignon. Everything was insanely good, like eyes rolling back and moaning good. The price didn‚Äôt matter, though they were on the Krona too, so it only came out to what amounted to $40 USD.
We were enveloped in each other that night. The vibes were electric. We flirted and teased, properly, on the walk back. We were about to enter the hostel, when Caroline grabbed my arm.
Caroline: Do you have a girlfriend?
Me: No. Do you have a boyfriend?
Caroline: No.
I knew an opportunity when I saw one, so I leaned in and gave her a kiss.
Caroline: (Pulling away) Just kidding, I do.
Me: What?!
Caroline: Haha, you should see your face.
Me: Why did you do that?
Caroline: To fuck with you.
Me: I don‚Äôt appreciate that.
Caroline: (mockingly) I‚Äôm Sam, and I don‚Äôt appreciate jokes even though I was a comedian. Shut up and kiss me again, you sensitive man you.
I kissed her again, this time pulling her close.
Me: Whoa, that was awesome. Let‚Äôs do that more.
I usually say some very awkward shit during and after moments of passion. It‚Äôs like the side effect I get from a boner is Tourette‚Äôs. I‚Äôve been known to say ‚Äúthank you‚Äù after I cum. It‚Äôs not something I‚Äôm proud of.
Caroline: I have an idea‚Ä¶ How about we go somewhere else, without Simon, and pretend to be a couple? Like, just for a few days. We can go our separate ways after that.
Me: I dig that. But how are we going to get rid of Simon?
Caroline: Leave that up to me.
We made out for a few more minutes before going upstairs. Simon was still passed out, and the Italian guys weren‚Äôt back yet, so we laid in my bunk and dry humped quietly for a little while. Part of me couldn‚Äôt believe I was hooking up with such an awesome chick, but the other part wished it was Meghan. I kept my mouth shut, as to not ruin our moment, but I felt guilty, like I was using her. Before going to bed, I wrote in my journal:
Why are you like this? Who are you trying to spare in this situation? You‚Äôre not even dating Meghan, and Caroline REALLY likes you. You don‚Äôt have to be in love with her to have some fun. I mean, you just had sex with a prostitute, how is this worse than that? Ignore your silly morals for once and take a chance. Put yourself out there. Meghan would want you to.
It was easier to ditch Simon than we‚Äôd expected because I‚Äôm pretty sure he had a concussion. I tried to wake him up a few times, because I knew you weren‚Äôt supposed to sleep in that situation, but he kept telling me to fuck off. Caroline finally had enough.
Caroline: Simon, Sam and I are leaving. We will say a prayer for you. Drink water and don‚Äôt look directly into bright lights for a few days.
Simon: You cunts. You‚Äôre going to leave me here, like this? Sam, I need more speed.
Me: No. And it‚Äôs Mr. McEnroe to you.
Caroline pulled me out of the room by my arm before we could hear any more of his pleading. I was insulted by everything Simon did, but that demand infuriated me. I wanted to go back in there and smother him with a pillow. I guess that‚Äôs what I get for always seeing the best in people, and for sharing my drugs. Friends like these, eh dude?
Caroline and I went right to the train stop after buying some candy for the trip. She loved the sour stuff. The sourer, the better. In my experience, sweet people like sour candy, and sour people like sweet candy. I‚Äôve ran the numbers, trust me. We didn‚Äôt know where to go, so we looked at a map on the wall.
Me: So where to ma‚Äôam?
Caroline: Why don‚Äôt you just close your eyes and point?
Without waiting for my response, she got behind me and covered my eyes. Then, she spun me around a few times, before placing me back in front of the map. I pointed to a spot.
Caroline: I hear Vienna is nice.
--
--
Writing a memoir, sharing portions here.

Title: Street Photography Locations in Prague: The National Theatre and Its Surroundings
Content:
Sign up

Sign up
Sign in

2
Listen
Share
From time to time, I try to improve my Lightroom catalog‚Äôs structure to better organize my photos ‚Äî and while going through my Prague photos, I started noticing patterns in the places I shoot. Sometimes, I go to certain areas on purpose because I know they‚Äôre great for photos (or I just want to explore something unfamiliar). Other times, I‚Äôm just wandering around without a plan and somehow end up at these familiar places. I realized there are certain locations where I feel more comfortable shooting and where I consistently come home with photos I‚Äôm proud of.
Also, I‚Äôve recently received multiple questions on Glass about the best street photography spots in Prague. So, after having lived in Prague and walked its streets for almost two years now (often with a camera in my bag or in my hand), I thought it might be helpful to write about some of these recommended spots.
If you‚Äôre visiting Prague, or even if you live here and are looking for good places for street photography, these might be useful for you too.
Let‚Äôs start with one of my favorites, a place that always seems to offer something new: the area around the National Theatre (aka N√°rodn√≠ divadlo).
The National Theatre is an impressive building with its grand, neo-classical design right on the banks of the river Vltava. What makes this spot truly stand out, though, is the building behind it: the New Stage (Nov√° sc√©na), or as the locals call it, ‚ÄúThe Ice Cube‚Äù. The New Stage couldn‚Äôt be more different ‚Äî it‚Äôs modernist (brutalist, to be exact), boxy, and covered in textured glass panels that bounce the light, sometimes in unexpected ways. The contrast between these two buildings, side by side, makes for some great photos, especially if you like playing with old vs. new themes.
But to be a bit clich√© here, the buildings are just half of the story. The real magic happens in the life around them. The narrow tram stop in front, with its old red Tatra T3s, is always busy (but not chaotic) with people lined up in a single row, waiting, boarding, or rushing to catch their ride. The open space around the theatre adds a sense of scale, while the narrow passages create more intimate scenes, perfect for experimenting with different compositions, perspectives, and leading lines.
The best time for shooting here is probably a sunny afternoon when the light creates deep shadows and bounces off the glass of the New Stage. This can add depth and contrast to the photos and highlight the theatre‚Äôs detailed, brown facade with a warm feel. This effect can be harder to catch in winter when the sun doesn‚Äôt rise high enough to be above the buildings. But I‚Äôve also been here on dark, rainy days, and the scene was equally interesting.
I won‚Äôt lie ‚Äî sometimes I feel like I might end up with the same shot over and over if I keep going back. But more often than not (and it surprises me!), that isn‚Äôt the case. I‚Äôve tried to figure out what keeps me coming back, and my best answer so far is the mix of the expected and unexpected. One day, you‚Äôll find people going about their usual routines; the next, there might be a street performer, skaters, or a temporary exhibition in the middle of the ‚Äúinner square.‚Äù The stage stays the same, but the act changes. I know, this might sound like a clich√© again ‚Äî what else would you expect in the center of a capital city? ‚Äî but I‚Äôve found most other areas of Prague more predictable. This balance of routine and surprise, old and new, makes the surroundings of N√°rodn√≠ Divadlo an almost endless source of inspiration. At least for me, and at least for now.
Oh, and I‚Äôve found myself growing more fond of these brutalist buildings. And Prague certainly has a few of them. Maybe that‚Äôs part of the reason, who knows!
I think the area around the National Theatre is like a small version of what makes Prague so special from a street photography perspective. It‚Äôs got history, modern architecture, and plenty of street life. If you‚Äôre looking for a spot that will spark new ideas for street photography, this is a good place to start ‚Äî maybe even the best.
Thanks for reading to the end! If you enjoyed this or have any thoughts, I‚Äôd appreciate your üëè claps and comments ‚Äî especially if you‚Äôve already taken photos here or are planning to visit Prague with a camera.
Small note:During my preparation, I came across an article mentioning that the Ice Cube will undergo renovations starting next summer, which are expected to last for several years. So, you might want to hurry up and visit before it starts!

Title: The Two Thakurs
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

Reading the stories and travelogues by the likes of Biswanath Ghosh and Mark Tully.

--
Listen
Share
Which part of Himachal are you from?I am actually not from Himachal, but from Madhya Pradesh.But you‚Äôre a Thakur?Yes, MP as well has Thakurs.
This is how my first interaction with most people at Himachal Pradesh (the northern state that hosts my workplace IIT Mandi) begins, people with last name Thakur being omnipresent here. However, perhaps the most famous Thakur was from West Bengal (a state in the East of India), and interestingly, he is known more commonly as a Tagore in India. At Prague ‚Äî the city of hundred spires ‚Äî though, my stay was booked at Thakurova ‚Äî the Thakur street ‚Äî and so I knew I would be welcome at Czechia.
My trip to Boston (recall Tryst with America?) had made me acquaintance with Prof. Jan Vitek‚Äôs group at Northeastern University. I met him again during ECOOP 2019 (recall Romance at London?) ‚Äî we knew we were working in similar areas ‚Äî so he suggested I visit his laboratory at Czech Technical University, where I would hopefully be able to formalize a working relationship. And thus the seed to a trip to Prague ‚Äî one of my most memorable trips ever ‚Äî was sown.
In general I would have been worried about the cold weather at Prague in January. However, having settled after the London trip at Mandi, in one of the coldest states of India, I wasn‚Äôt much excited (read worried) about the weather. This, however, also translated to not being prepared for the trip at all. My first teaching semester at IIT Mandi ended in December, and it was only after that, that I started planning a trip ‚Äî my longest abroad till date ‚Äî to Prague in January. Two things I was more thoughtful about, though, were (i) The Visa; and (ii) The Trip to Delhi ‚Äî you will get to know a very suspenseful story about both in Rendezvous with Athena. TLDR: The Visa was smooth, I travelled to Delhi a day before this time, and hence obtained a comfortable flight hopping for an hour at Sharjah (the place I knew from childhood for Cricket matches).
Prague is known to be a beautiful city, and a very welcoming one for tourists. I was supposed to stay 12 nights at a hostel-cum-hotel (wrongly known as a dorm) named Masaryk Colej. The second word indicates its association with the college CVUT (Czech Technical University, in English). Travel from the airport was quite comfortable: you buy an hourly ticket for public travel in Prague and can then take any bus, tram, or metro ‚Äî very convenient for those who don‚Äôt understand the currency or the local addresses. So I took a bus and a tram (Pristi zastavka) and reached the hotel. First surprise: I was provided with a map to find my room! And indeed, the map was damn useful ‚Äî you need to pass through a cobweb of rooms (smelling the varieties of food college guys keep cooking in there) to finally reach the corridor that forms the ‚Äúhotel‚Äù part of the huge building. I needed the map on quite a few occasions (specially when I decided to wander around the building trying to get a glimpse of the food).
I used to walk daily to the university, take the lift to the 13th floor (tried the stairs one day!), and come back in the evening. Pretty standard. So what I would do next, is to mainly discuss the interesting trips ‚Äî solo as well as group ‚Äî along with the classical places I visited, the people I met, and the heart-warming experiences that I got in the extremely cold weather (subzero on almost all days). Not to forget the funny stories surrounding the food!
This was the first time I was visiting a place that‚Äôs famous for its exotic food ‚Äî but almost all non-veg. The first day I located a Pizza outlet with vegetarian options, about 1.5 miles from my hotel. I had taken my warmest clothes, but God it was really difficult following Google Map as you need to take your gloves off (I got enlightened about touchscreen-enabled gloves much later). Being in Europe I knew I didn‚Äôt have to worry much about tips and the phrases for taking home versus dining-in as in the US (Europe and India have pretty much similar terminologies, owing to history). Breakfasts were taken care of by the hotel (with two kinds of cupcakes, orange juice, toast, and cheese forming the 365-day menu). Lunches (and some dinner outings on weekdays): I knew I would have enough expertise from the lab in sailing through the university canteen. However, things became adventurous when I decided to try the hotel restaurant for a dinner:
Me: ‚ÄúWhich all options in the menu are vegetarian?‚ÄùShe: [After the previous sentence being looped over 20 times]: ‚ÄúYes, please sit; we will bring you vegetarian.‚Äù
On table I get something that looks very muttonish. After making some noise the chef came out of the kitchen; he understood some English and told I could get a replacement without paying again.
Me: ‚ÄúWhich dish will you get for me?‚ÄùHe: ‚ÄúVegetarian.‚Äù
Finally I got some cauliflower (in its purest vegetarian, read raw, form) and some fried (read oil-soaked) potatoes. I ate about 30% from my plate, then boiled MTR Poha (puffed rice) carried from home in the hot water obtained from the geyser-that-actually-worked-only-in-the-morning, and knew this was the end of trying out my luck at the hotel (apart from breakfast). On the remaining days I mostly sticked to the long menu of a Chinese restaurant next door (147 dishes, 3 vegetarian), an occasional Pizza from the chilly-walk place, and my MTR Pohas cooked with the morning-only geyser.
However, one night we had a fine dinner at an Indian restaurant (where I again found that Indians have a much stronger digestive system, think spices); I tried some tasty soups with two new friends on a beautiful evening; and on the last day finally tried the national dish (which happens to be vegetarian) ‚Äî Fried cheese:
As indicated before, Prague is perhaps the city with the most convenient public transport: You can just install an app and charge it with your card for a day (not expensive at all), get a barcode that is your ticket, and travel as you want in any tram, bus, metro, or train. Moreover, the city is very-well covered ‚Äî you perhaps don‚Äôt need to walk more than a few hundred meters anywhere ‚Äî you will have nicely maintained, well-timed, clean-and-safe public transport available at the blink of an eye. I had listed down a large number of places to visit, and divided them into two days: Day 1 and Day 2, for the Saturday and the Sunday.
If you followed me in America, you know that the first thing on my list in a city that has a zoo, has to be a zoo. So Saturday began with visiting one of the best places hosting animals in the world: The Prague Zoo. Unlike the Zoo at Washington DC, at Prague you are welcomed with the star cast quite near to the entrance:
I spent nearly 3 hours at the zoo, walking about 8 kilometers inside, and ended with a team of as-tall-as-can-get Giraffes, and as-cute-as-can-get Penguins:
The next stop was The Old Town across Charles bridge (challenge: find the river in the lab-view above). Old Town has several attractions from the times Czechia was part of the Soviet Union, with several churches and castles at every turn. While the Prague Castle reminds one of Hogwarts, the Astronomical Clock attracts a huge crowd every hour for witnessing one of the many scientific marvels associated with the same (read more on Wikipedia):
Charles Bridge is a heritage on its own, with so many activities and picture-spots around that you can spend hours walking across and yet find something every time you cross! A beautiful view of the colorful city follows:
I finished traversing the Old Town by filling my bag at a shop full of candies (and forgetting the bag mid-way during my return journey)!
Having explored the crowded places the previous day, I decided to spend a solo Sunday climbing hills and exploring castles ‚Äî both being rare opportunities in a vibrant city. The day was cold and hazy, but I walked and walked like crazy.
Vysehrad is an old castle in a bit far-off location, and should be traveled in broad day-light, is what I was told. Though the far-off part was true, I found the place full of people craving for silent time amidst the hustle and bustle of the cheerful city. You could sit there for hours with a book in hand, appreciating the rare greenery in the coldest of months.
The last I went was The Petrin Hill ‚Äî reminiscent of the hikes I do around Mandi. I went up via a crowded rope-way and came down exploring solitary paths watching the city of hundred spires; as you descend, you realize every climb has its end, but the walk downhill doesn‚Äôt necessarily take you down.
If you ever visit Prague, do roam around the colorful streets, but take a moment walking up/down the Petrin Hill, sitting on that bench I couldn‚Äôt, and wondering ‚Äúwhat to eat next‚Äù :-)
I returned back via Warsaw; the trip was prepended with a day‚Äôs stay with an about-to-be-engaged friend at New Delhi, and appended with a trip to Kolkata ‚Äî a city where you drive ahead with both the legs on breaks (for preserving its classical past) ‚Äî to attend the engagement of the same (more about my old-and-gold friends some time later!).
The series had promised an article every few weeks: it started swiftly, but has been going on rather slow. For me, the year 2020 has been full of remembering (read missing) the travels from 2019, and avid readers are in for many more write-ups. For now, an assurance is to have a few more articles than those promised in the intro A Traveling Year, one of them being exclusively on the rather long airport stays and flight journeys (of course with feedback on the food) I have had in the travel-rich year! So keep reading, and stay on‚Ä¶

Content:

Listen
Share
I‚Äôm leaving the hotel bright and early and as I‚Äôm about to pack up I detected the quintessential bible that ever hotel ought to have (not!!!), only that here they had a rather unusual version of it.
I then stopped at a local bakery where I had the weakest coffee ever. I think I just don‚Äôt know how to (or rather what to) order. This actually begs the question: How much of a language is it courtesy to learn when visiting a country where one doesn‚Äôt speak the language? I understand zero Czech and here in the countryside the folks don‚Äôt tend to speak English. Maybe I should‚Äôve tried German? After all, the city of Litomƒõ≈ôice‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääwhere I spent the night‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääwas once part of the ‚ÄúProvince of German Bohemia‚Äù and the town actually still has a German name: Leitmeritz. Well, I didn‚Äôt end up learning any Czech here at this bakery and instead made myself understandable with pointing at various items in the display case.
After breakfast, I hit the road. As I was passing the train station I saw a cool structure: a bike tower. I guess it‚Äôs for the folks commuting by train to work? This part of the country is certainly set up for cycling, with the Elbe-Labe Cycling Path probably contributing considerably to the local community. Later, I saw another cycle-friendly piece of infrastructure: a solar-powered charging station for e-bike.
Today‚Äôs first section of the route continued taking me along the river Elbe. As it was still rather early in the day, I saw a lot of fisherman sitting by the river and waiting for fish to latch on. There were so many of them and all of them men. I was wondering: How come women don‚Äôt do fishing? Seems like a relaxing activity. Maybe because they need to do the housework and tend to the kids while the men are frolicking their hobby?
On a similarly gender-related note, I noticed the below cycling path signs. Maybe someone would like to write a thesis on stereotypes in (modern) street signage? Questions that come to mind: Who still wears a hat like this? Do men really have the time to walk their daughters to school? Aren‚Äôt they too busy fishing? Discuss.
What I noticed since entering Czechia is that the Elbe here has several dams and so instead of a river, it often looks more like a lake. At one point today, I crossed one of these dams/locks and there were quite a few things to see.
Just like yesterday, I had the option to do a shortcut and arrive in Prague much faster: As rivers tend to meander, you can choose to go a straighter route. I decided to not be straight and instead follow the river path, which added a good 30km. I did this, because one of the highlights along the route was the river mouth where the Vltava (Moldau) and merges into the Labe (Elbe).
By the time I hit Mƒõln√≠k, I have to admit that I was starting to get tired. The next opportunity for food was not for another 25km and I was getting hungry. I stopped at a little convenience store to buy some fruits and water and that tied me over. The wind picked up and at some point I was cycling underneath a big dark cloud, which at eventually unloaded in a swift shower. I quickly found shelter underneath a tree, with view of a lovely castle.
Eventually, I arrived in an industrial-looking town and at the big roundabout I had a fundamental decision to make: Where should I buy my lunch from? The Lidl or the Tesco? Or, in other words: Supporting a German or British corporation? You can ask me next time you see me, which team I voted for. In any case, my fancy lunch consisted of two slices of pepperoni pizza and a sweet roll‚Ä¶all eaten at the back of the large supermarket building next to some vagabonds.
Then came the exciting part of the day and it literally elevated my heart rate: at some point my bike app showed me to cut through some forest area instead of following the river. Upon investigation, I saw that the stretch along the river was deemed ‚Äúdangerous‚Äù by some cyclists. But the reckless person I am, I decided to choose the perilous option. Well, let‚Äôs just say this: I wouldn‚Äôt necessarily recommend it, unless you have a mountain bike and like the thrill of cycling dangerously close to a cliff. To calm my nerves, I was humming the melody of Smetana‚Äôs Die Moldau, which was only fitting as I was cycling along its shores‚Ä¶
Since I‚Äôd sweated so much during this last stretch and since my destination for the day was in relatively close proximity, I decided to sit down at one of the very popular riverside kiosks for a glass of refreshing beer. What a great decision!
Eventually I arrived at the campsite and luckily they still had a space for me. The campground is just outside Prague city center and conveniently located next to a tram stop. After I‚Äôd set up camp, I took said mode of transport instead of my bike and ventured into the city.
Honestly, I was quite knackered and knew it wouldn‚Äôt be a night of partying. But, I wanted to enjoy a good meal and so I consulted Yelp and followed the recommendations for a restaurant called Vinohradsk√Ω Parlament. It‚Äôs a beautiful restaurant and the waiter was fantastic. He recommended a hearty meal for me as I was telling him that I‚Äôd just cycled 100km and was rather famished. Their specialty are Czech dumplings (knedl√≠ky) and this pillowy soft delicacy was perfect to soak up the juices that came with my beef roulade. For dessert, I had another kind of dumpling: this one stuffed with fresh blueberries! Yummy!
Afterwards, I was so tired that‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääafter a brief wander around the city‚Ää‚Äî‚ÄäI got back on the tram to my tent.
Day 18: Prague

Well, they say! Home is where our heart is. I left a small part of my heart at the golden hour over the Charles Bridge.
With the busy life we all have, traveling is the place where you destress. Life with a toddler is never easy. I started to rethink the concept of traveling after my child was born.
Sigh! With the doubts and rethinking, we finally started planning our travel to open our summer in Europe. Springs are really special in Europe. That is when you still can‚Äôt find many tourists in the beautiful cities.
Luckily we started this whole trip with the right planning. We thought to make a fun road trip through the Autobahn. We live in the beautiful city of Utrecht province, and all our planning was around this.
Riding through the autobahn and landscapes of Germany, we were entertained well and our heart was calm. After a long journey and our halts through cute stops in Germany, we finally reached Prague at nearly midnight.
Tiring ourselves through sitting, we just wanted to rest our heads on the pillow, but our little one wanted to swim. Through a lot of convincing, we had a good night‚Äôs sleep. My subconscious mind made me feel for a while, we were still driving in the car, but my tired eyes were not able to focus on thoughts and we slept.
Our next day started with a nice morning view of the city of Prague through the large side windows of our hotel room.
Pro tip: Try to find a hotel where, your little one can enjoy amenities and activities like swimming, playroom, or lawn. This keeps them happy through the day and grownups can have a stroll.
After a great breakfast and swim, we finally started exploring Prague.
Our first stop was at the Prague castle complex, where we walked and witnessed the glorious monuments of St. Vitus Cathedral, a former royal palace, and other museums. The collection of views of the cities was breathtaking. One could also visit Golden Lane in the same complex. Never forget to click a picture here, just a great way to summarise your castle tour.
Pro tip: Check for tickets at any information center in Prague city. There is only a collective ticket available for all the important monuments.
A modern bold building by Architect Vlado Miluniƒá along with Frank Gehry. Originally it was named Ginger and Fred building after the dancers. The bold piece of art is in the middle of the busy street, otherwise on your way to the famous walking route of old Prague city and the famous bridges.
Walking down the 15th-century Golden Lane took us back to those days. This preserved street is just worth experiencing, as most of the fort is reconstructed to adapt to current days.
This was a cute short ride, which our little one enjoyed. The funicular is been in operation since 1891. During the season( Between Apr-May season) you can enjoy cherry blossoms and other beautiful trees on this hill. The hill also has an interesting observatory. But it is a good experience on a sunny day to walk down the hill with your little one
Pro tip: You can have public transport 24-hour tickets at the information center or on any tram/ bus itself. I would suggest watching the YouTube channel HONEST GUIDE. He spoke about everything a tourist needs in Prague to walk like a confident local
Our final destination‚Ä¶..ü•Åü•Åü•Å
We started from our nearest metro station and walked through the beautiful old town of Prague. Our important pit stop was to witness the oldest astronomical clock in the world which is dated back to 1410, at the old town square. What is it? one may ask. If it interests you further, Astronomical clock.
Taking our imagination of walking through the 18th century, we reached the arch of Charles Bridge. Magnificent as it is, it took us to an old world that is built over the Vltava River. The 30 Baroque statues welcomed us to witness the glory of history.
We were lucky enough to reach the bridge in the golden hour. That is when I fell in love with Prague. Romantic Prague! We witnessed a rainbow which made it the perfect end to our romantic walk. We witnessed the sun going down dancing into colorful narration.
Further, when the sun went down. The view into the castle and of the city was spectacular.
I hope you enjoyed my little narration and it helped you to plan your future trip to Prague or made you remember your best evening.
Thank you for reading!

Title: 3 Reasons to Visit Prague, The City of Alchemy
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
is an ancient city filled with a long history of mystery, with much more than meets the eye. I recently had the pleasure of visiting this amazing city in August 2023. It was a last minute trip, so I truly had zero expectations for what to expect. Soon after landing, I realized I had stumbled upon an alchemical city filled with intrigue and magic! You can feel a buzzing energy once you step into this uniquely built city. The buildings and streets all seem to be laid in some perfect, symmetrical grid. Prague Castle sits high up on the hill, giving off an almost invincible feeling as you look upon it. This was the home of the Roman Emperor Rudolph II, who was obsessed with Alchemy, and the pursuit of the Philospher‚Äôs Stone. King Charles built The Charles Bridge in 1357, built strategically with astronomers and numerologists, to align the bridge and towers with the rising and setting of the sun. Prague was the capital of the Holy Roman Empire in 1300‚Äôs, and is where King Charles oversaw The Golden Age of Bohemia.
There is an abundance of mysticism and symbolism throughout the city, which is filled with alchemical bars, fascinating museums, and the famous astrological clock that brings the city center to life. Visiting Prague is certainly a portal to the old world, which lead the way for modern pharmacy and medicines. Praha truly seems to be covered in magic, and I highly recommend you visit this mystic, legendary city. Here are my 3 reasons why Prague should be high up on your travel itinerary.
I am not the biggest fan of cities, but Prague was a city full of wonder and mystery. The roads told a story of a distant past, the aged buildings still etched with beautiful gargoyles, symbols and designs, still dimly shining their radiance. I was immediately in awe at how well preserved the historic buildings and statues were. It truly felt like I was in a medieval movie, moving forward on my own alchemical journey. The city seemed old, yet proud, with all of its traditions and secrets. I am fascinated by stories of alchemy and have enjoyed researching this field for years; and now I stumbled upon a whole alchemical city. Just my luck!
One of the most notable proponents of alchemy was the Roman Emperor Rudolph II, who ruled and lived in Prague until his death in 1612. He was a very curious leader, who encouraged alchemists, astronomers, philosophers to travel to Prague and share their teachings. This was technically their modern day medicine, so Rudolph naturally built his own laboratory at the castle. He was obsessed with find the Philosopher‚Äôs stone, which according to legend is the key to the Elixir for immortal life. He brought over Edward Kelley, a self proclaimed spirit medium, and John Dee, occultist and Mathematician. You can visit a recreation of the alchemical laboratory Rudolph had in the Prague Castle.
This museum houses real alchemical laboratories, only recently discovered in 2002 due to intense flooding and road erosion. Within the museum they found herbs, flasks, and more in an underground complex of labs and rooms. The underground labs still contain original glassworks, rooms, and kilns the alchemist‚Äôs used for transmuting lead to gold. It is an incredible experience to set foot where true alchemists have stepped foot, creating and experimenting with elixirs that have changed the face of medicine today. The underground is truly remarkable, and filled with different tunnels and passageways. They offer a guided tour of 30 minutes, which is actually packed with interesting information and sights, which I highly recommend!
This marvel within Prague is one of the main landmarks you will see in Prague. This bridge, which used to be a main crossing between East and West Europe, was built in 1357 by King Charles in accordance with the palindromic number 13579753. King Charles worked with astronomers and numerologists on how, where, and when to build this historic bridge. By working with the stars and numerology, Charles constructed the bridge to align with planetary energy, and to align with the rising and setting of the sun. Pretty advanced stuff for 700 years ago! Along the bridge there are several sculptures of historical figures that represent Prague‚Äôs long history. You can take a boat tour that take you around the bridge and gives you heaps of interesting information about the bridge, its past, and the Prague Castle.
There are rumors that Prague was laid out in a geometrical shape, adhering to symmetry and planetary grids. I truly feel like this is not far from the truth. I‚Äôve traveled to some amazing energy vortexes in my life, and it was quite surprising to find the energy still strong, even within this bigger city. There are also many underground tunnels, and small street that seem to go on forever. Get lost in these mystic streets, and who knows, maybe you‚Äôll find what you‚Äôre looking for!
This is a no-brainer! Prague Castle is the biggest castle complex in the world, and you can certainly tell when you visit. It stand watch high over Prague, a beautiful sight to see from almost anywhere in the city. The complex and intricate design of the roofs and towers of the castle are truly an ode to the complexities of life and nature. It is remarkable to see such a great feat done and still standing from so long ago. The original Prague Castle was built in the 9th century, yet you can still get a good idea of what the original felt like! It seems time skipped over this part of the world, still revealing clues to our distant past. The castle is filled with sculptures, angels, demons, and scars of its‚Äô past. Walk around the Castle and marvel in its wonder. It is a nice walk up a hill, so do be prepared! It‚Äôs all worth it once you get to the top, as the view from the city is truly amazing. It also holds the Guinness Book of World Record for largest Castle Complex!
I found one of my favorite bars in the world. I really enjoy Alchemy, and its rare to find a place that is Alchemically themed, and done well. I won‚Äôt give away the location, as you will need to find it yourself ( come on, alchemist!), but this is a must do here in Prague. Their bar will brew some mystic elixirs that may enhance Alchemical power and insight. The whole bar has really cool decorations (its very own Hermit), and the menu is filled with illustrations and sayings that will have you rethinking your life.
Prague is a short train ride away from Plzin, the official home of the Pilsner Beer. It actually got ripped off from a famous American brand, which isn‚Äôt totally surprising! Prague is actually the leader in the world for most beers consumed per capita. Prague is lined with traditional pubs and restaurants, ready for you to try some of their unique dishes. It is a charming place with lots of history, and people seem to gravitate to small pubs and places to eat, and just talk and observe the beauty. Get yourself a cold one and kick your feet up, buddy!
Czech goulash is a pretty unique, tasty traditional meal that should try. A Proper homemade Czech Goulash is prepared by first braising chunks of stewing beef with potatoes, tomato, onions, paprika and garlic. This serving is usually served with crusty bread, boiled dumplings or noodles. Wash it down with an ice cold glass of pilsner lager like an original Pilsner Urquell.
I am a big fan of shows like Vikings because I get to fantasize about how it was to live in earlier times. Times before electricity, before the internet and before mobile phones. I was able to really feel like I had stepped in the past in Prague. Being from the States, its rare to see such ancient feeling buildings, roads and infrastructure. You can go to so many museums, shops, cathedrals, and shop within just Prague alone. The city seems to be proud of its rich heritage, and they have preserved much of its history. There are many important historical events and figures that have traversed to the City of Alchemy, and have surely been amazed by its‚Äô charm. Enjoy the never ending wonders within the streets of this magical city.
There is a big bohemian energy in Czech, which makes sense, since it is originally the home of the Kingdom of Bohemia. There are many crystal shops, yoga places, and mystic shops sprinkled throughout. I was lucky enough to know a few friends out there, and was able to see another side of Czechia outside of the city. The forest truly seem to contain fairies within them; there is that mystic charm that I have heard so much about of the enchanting European forests. The soil is fertile and lush, the people content and beautiful in their own ways. There is a quiet and calm energy all throughout the countryside. If you are like me, you enjoy some solitude and retreat into nature and chance you may get. This was a welcome treat after traveling through other busy cities in Europe.
I was able to see some less travelled places in Czech, and the charm only grew from there. The people were very welcoming, and the natural beauty really held me in its arms. It feels a lot more simple in the countryside, where they are unburdened by the heaviness of the city. If you can, take a train outside of the city, take a walk through nature, and eat a mom and pop restaurant. Thank me later.
Get to Prague if you are traveling nearby in Europe! If the mystic, magical, and mysterious intrigues you, I guarantee you will have a great time if you travel to Prague. There is a treasure trove of secrets and history amongst the castles, museums and ancient river. The old cobblestone roads, mixed with goulash and Pilsners, will captivate your senses as you gaze upon historic marvels. Satisfy your craving for more alchemical tools along your hero‚Äôs journey! This geometrically aligned city has more secrets waiting to be revealed. I would take at least 3‚Äì5 days to explore most of Prague and the surrounding towns. Take the leap into the unknown and travel into this City of Alchemy.
Mark Jason

Title: How is visiting Prague as a business traveller different from a tourist?
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
In my Previous work at GoodData, I had a chance to have two business trips to Prague, Czech Republic. Before joining GoodData, I have never been to any European counties east of Germany or Austria. In 2022, our team had trouble finding sales engineers in the Czech Republic, so everyone in our team was taking turns working in Prague to cover the European business timezone. Therefore, I went to Prague to help out the sales representatives in Prague as a temporary sales engineer in May 2022 and September 2022.
First time to ‚ÄúThis Part of Europe‚ÄùThis is my first time visiting the Czech Republic, and also the first time visiting a former Warsaw Pact country. I was very curious about how the country transformed after the Berlin Wall broke 30 years later, and how much does the Czech Republic different from the European countries I have been to. Most of my colleagues asked me whether this is the first time I visit Europe, I told them: ‚ÄúThis is the first time I have been to ‚ÄòThis Part of Europe‚Äô‚Äù.
My first impression of the Czech Republic is Soviet architecture in the suburban, Pre-Modern Austro-Hungarian city-style Downtown, Modern Western European office buildings in the business area. When I arrived in Prague airport, the airport is obviously built during the former Warsaw Pact era the building is very rectangular and lack of decoration, which creates a contradiction when modern Boeing or Airbus aircraft were parked against it. Although the highways looked new and well-maintained, I can still see some poor-maintained Soviet-style buildings in the suburban area. Once the taxi enters Prague‚Äôs city limit, the city's appearance changed to the beautiful 19th-century Austro-Hungarian city-style Downtown, mixed with newly built Western European office buildings. I am able to see the overview memories of the Czechs in the form of Prague architecture.
No One Calls it CzechiaDuring my stay in Prague, I have more opportunities to talk with the locals since I was working with them for a couple of weeks. I literally hear none of the Czech call their country Czechia. They mostly call their country by their full name ‚Äî the Czech Republic, or the country abbreviation ‚Äî CZ (American Zee) or CZ (British Zat). It appears that Czechs in general really don‚Äôt like the new name for their country (I personally call it the Czech Republic too).
Another interesting thing I learnt in Prague is that the relationship between Czechs and Slovakians is not as close as I thought. I learnt from an American YouTuber that Czechs and Slovakians are culturally close so their relationship is as intimate as siblings, but one of my Prague colleagues disagreed.
The City AppearanceDowntown Prague is a very beautiful city where the beauty came from the late Middle Ages and pre-Modern style buildings next to tram routes. The iconic Soviet-style Prague trams ran between those buildings are the only confusion that you think you are visiting a Warsaw Pact country in the latter half of the 20th century, but you realize there are newly built Austrian trams replacing the aging iconic trams when they pass by occasionally.
Sadly, most of my time in Prague was spent at the GoodData headquarter and I did not have a lot of chance to go around the city, besides Prague Castle, Charles Bridge, and Petrin Tower.
Office Culture is a Mixture of American and Continent EuropeAlthough GoodData originated from the Czech Republic, the company culture was relatively Americanized. Besides the office appearance looks very no different from a Tech company in the San Francisco Bay Area, the work culture is basically the same! The atmosphere in the GoodData headquarter embraces creativity, work-life balance, and the work-hard-play-hard mentality. During my stay in Prague, I feel the work environment in the Prague office is the same as in the San Francisco office.
Czechs are very easy to work with: They are not as serious as German, nor lazy. They will deliver what you need on time, as long as they have a proper summer break (3‚Äì4 weeks off), which does not exist in the Anglophone countries. Their impression of American work culture is a hard work culture with an insufficient amount of holidays ‚Äî One of my colleagues mentioned he was impressed (negatively) that American mothers can only take 10 weeks of paid maternity time off that he does not wish to live in the US if his wife and he are planning to have kids.
Czech FoodBesides Pilnser, anyone who visits the Czech Republic should try any duck dish since Czech ducks taste very taste! One of the common duck dishes in the Czech Republic is duck confit (Which is also common in Slovakia, Austria, and maybe Poland?), although my Czech colleagues always laugh at me eating what they eat on Sunday prepared by their grandmas. This grandma's dish usually serves with Czech dumplings and pickles to ease the duck grease.
On my second trip to Prague, half of my team was actually visiting Prague. Therefore, my manager decided to bring us to a team lunch. Although my manager is a Czech who lived in San Francisco, he acts very differently when he is in Prague. When he was bringing us to lunch in San Francisco, he brought us to cafes with health choices; in contrast, he would have brought us to a cafe close to our Prague office too, but the first thing to order is wine. I bet Europeans are very flexible in switching their culture mode wherever they are at.
Prague has quite a big portion of the Vietnamese population (They have mostly immigrated to the Czech Republic in the 70‚Äôs and 80‚Äôs), so there are a lot of Vietnamese restaurants or shops serve pho and Vietnamese sandwiches. Not surprisingly, there are a lot of Chinese restaurants; however, most of those Chinese restaurants not only serve Chinese dishes, but also Japanese, Korean, and Thai dishes as well‚Ä¶
Czechs in General Hates the Communist EraWorking in a company with Czech heritage allows me to understand the Czechs. I thought the Czechs have some degree of good memories from the Communist Era, but I was wrong! The upper managers in GoodData sent memos to us during the pandemic to make up the communication supposed to be done on-site, I remember one of the memos was sent during the week of the celebration of the Velvet Revolution for embracing freedom gained after the end of communist-ruled Czechoslovakia.
During the last week of my first Prague visit, I was planning to watch an opera in the State Opera House. While I was discussing with my colleagues how to get to the opera house from the office, one of my colleagues started to complain about the city planning policy during the Communist Era (Out of nowhere too‚Ä¶but he has a point). He was complaining about the fact that a highway was built next to the opera house, which made complicated and inconvenient pedestrian access and prevented the highway to build straight to avoid the road cutting through the building (If a highway is not straight enough, then it is not fast). Although I tried not to give any opinion on this topic as an outsider, I can see the reputation of the previous era has left a bruise on the Czechs.
Prague Castle and Charles BridgeMy colleagues were nice to bring me to visit Prague Castle and Charles Bridge after Wednesday work and had dinner together next to Prague Castle.
My impression of Prague Castle is not a castle! To me, a castle is a walled building built in the Middle Age or before for the landlord to live; Prague Castle looks like a pre-Modern era palace, which is a couple of hundred years ahead of its time.
We had dinner and beer afterward. And of course, my colleagues ordered something that I never had. One of those is Chicken liver pat√©.
After dinner, we walk from Prague Castle and across Charles Bridge to take the metro. During the walk, my colleagues explained Prague Castle and Charles Bridge. I really enjoyed visiting the sightseeing spots with the locals rather than guides because the locals know what the sightseeing spots are, but they can‚Äôt remember hard fact details like the year when built and historical figures, it makes them more authentic rather than a guide who tries to impress you.
Petrin TowerIf I have to pick one must-see sightseeing spot it has to be Petrin Tower, over Prague Castle or Charles Bridge. I personally am attracted by the architecture of Prague, therefore, Petrin Tower is the best place to view Prague from a bird's view.
BeerI save this topic to the last ‚Äî Beer! Basically: Czech Republic = Beer. So that you can understand how important beer is to the Czechs. Among all the national brands, Pilsner is the best for me. Pilsner is a lager that has a very light body with some pine finish, it is a very refreshing beverage, especially for summer! One good reason to visit Prague: Pilsner is significantly taster when serve in draft beer than in cans!
During my second visit to Prague, my company had an offsite in a local theater in Prague. Interestingly, beer was served between breaks for the whole afternoon, but no one was drunk by the end of all presentations at 6 pm. Czechs simply cannot get drunk on beer (Not sure whether that is a good thing or not). I am not a person who is crazy for nightlife so I don‚Äôt consider myself a good dancer, one of my male colleagues was impressed with my dance move. He asked me how he can dance as well as me, I told him the key is to get drunk since I don‚Äôt have a good answer for him so I joked with him. He was quite a humour to say: ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs the problem! We Czechs are hard to get drunk.‚Äù Quite an answer!
ConclusionI really love Prague, and so does the Czech Republic. I really like the architecture of Prague, the city vibe, the city, and the people! They gave me a good time when I was visiting Prague. It is a very nice place to visit as you would learn a lot from the people and the city. It is also very affordable to visit. A 3-star hotel night (May or October) is less than 100 Euros in the city center, and a decent dine-in meal cost you about 20 Euros with beer and coffee. It is worth your money, not only on seeing Charles Bridge and Prague Castle but also I am pretty sure both Prague and the Czech Republic can give you a Central European vibe that you can enjoy. I am not sure when next time, but next time I got to visit as a tourist! And I really miss Pilsner too!
--

Content:
