Currently, in the middle of the corona pandemic crisis, it might not be the right time to travel unfortunately. Last year I was on a little eurotrip and one of the places I visited was Prague in the Czech Republic. If you‚Äôre sitting at home watching Triple X and dreaming about where to go next after all this is over then here are some budget tips on what to do in one of the most beautiful cities in central Europe.
Walk around in the old town
With documented settlements dating back over a thousand years and current buldings such as the Old Town Hall with the foundation being built in the 14th century, Prague‚Äôs old town called Star√© Mƒõsto in the Czech language will leave you with a magical feeling.
This is a must and quite frankly difficult to avoid since the medieval Star√© Mƒõsto is smack in the middle of the city center. Go see the astronomical clock which was installed in 1410, the old town square, the stands in the narrow streets and the Charles bridge. If you look around closely you might find some cosy hidden restaurants such as the Charles Bridge Restaurant which is basically a floating barge, sitting on the water by the base of the bridge on the Old town side. Pro tip: You might also wanna try the local Czech cuisine at some smaller place around the corner on a side street away from the tourist rush. That‚Äôs generally how I‚Äôve stumbled on some of the best food on my trips. The Czech cuisine resembles other central and east European dishes such as goulash, various soups and pancakes, bread dumplings, schnitzel and baked meat. For a drink you should try any Czech beer. It really doesn‚Äôt matter which one you choose, they all taste magnificient and much better than at home.
Prague is literally a city of bridges, it has over 300 hundred of them, so there are many more to see than just the Charles bridge. Each with their own history to tell. Some other famous ones are the Legion bridge, the M√°nes Bridge and the Palack√Ω Bridge.
Visit the St. Vitus Cathedral and the Castle complex
This huge breathtaking gothic style cathedral is the largest church in the Czech republic. The main tower is over 100 metres high (328+ feet) and the cathedral itself is situated on top of a large hill which is housing the Prague Castle complex. From the hill you are able to see most of Prague‚Äôs center and the nature around it. One of the slopes even has a vineyard.
The castle is very big and was originally built in the 9th century and went on being improved up until the mid 19th century. Because of all the different eras in which it was constructed it consists of different architectural styles. Inside the complex are several museums in which you can learn all about the history of the Czech republic and also the famous so called Golden Lane. There are also several art galleries, small cafe‚Äôs and shops, although it might be bit of a tourist trap. Be wary of the prices and unnecessary touristic small stuff.
Go up the Pet≈ô√≠n Hill
A large hill is situated just off the center on the other side of the Vltava river above the Mal√° Strana district. The top is higher than the castle hill and rises 130 metres above the river. From there you can get some amazing views over Prague. The Pet≈ô√≠n Hill is a popular rectreational area and almost the entire hill is covered in parks. The so called Hunger Wall was built in the 14th century on the hill and is still there to be visited.
There is also a tall Eiffel styled lookout tower which you can visit for a fee. Although for sure a nice view I would however say that it‚Äôs not worth its price, and if you walk past by over to the Strahov Stadium (one of the largest stadiums ever built) there is a nice view point there by the tunnel ventilation tower. Although still in use, the stadium is a remnant of the old communist era. The tunnel towers has an interesting modernism style and were built and designed in the 80‚Äôs and 90‚Äôs by an architect called Ji≈ô√≠ Trnka.
To get to the top of the hill you can either walk, take the bus or tram or the funicular rail. If you‚Äôre walking from the city center there is a restaurant on the way up called Pet≈ô√≠nsk√© terasy. It‚Äôs situated straight up to the west of the Kampa riverside. Grab a bite with Czech styled food and enjoy the view over the city and the castle if you‚Äôre hungry or just step by for a drink.
While not a super fancy place, they do offer weddings and it has a large outdoor terrace. Inside you can enjoy the lumberjack styled pub and restaurant. They also have a large open fireplace that you can watch while you‚Äôre sitting and relaxing reading Frommer‚Äôs.
Check out the V√≠tkov hill Monument
There‚Äôs another hill in the ≈Ωi≈ækov district on the opposite side of the city center which is called V√≠tkov. On top of it is a memorial monument that features a large granite stone plaza and a large grey bulding. A huge bronze statue is standing on a pedestal in front of the building resembling Jan ≈Ωi≈æka, who in 1420 in the Battle of V√≠tkov Hill defeated enemy forces.
The memorial monument was mainly built in the 1930‚Äôs but had to be paused when the WWII started and the Germans occupied the land. It was later finished and was for a while used to promote communism. In 2000‚Äì2009 a renovation work was made by the National Museum and was reopened for the public to enjoy. From this place you will have one of the best views over Prague. It‚Äôs especially extraordinary in the sunset and many people are coming there to watch it.
Bonus tip: Around the Seifertova street nearby are several cocktail bars for having a little preparty or a drink on the way into the Old Town districts. You should maybe not stay too late as it might get noisy in this area and filled with drunk people.
Also nearby, on the other side of the railroad is a beautiful church called the Church of Saints Cyril and Methodius, and just past it is a small asian place called Ng√¥ where they serve fantastic food. This is a convenient area to stay in and with walking distance from the Old Town so look for hotels here. I stayed at Hotel Alwyn which is a pretty good hotel.
Have a drink at a roof bar
Roof bars are getting more and more popular and Prague has them as well. There is for example a nice one on top of the Hotel U Prince, nearby the Old Town Hall, with 360¬∞ views over the city. There is a restaurant so you can enjoy a bite and they make their own signature cocktails. It‚Äôs possible to stumble upon higher priced places but this one is still fairly reasonably priced. Just enter the hotel at street level and look for a glassed elevator, it will take you up to the roof restaurant and terrace. Other roof bars worth a visit are Cloud 9 in the large Hilton hotel, CODA restaurant in the Mal√° Strana district, Duplex in the center and T-anker in the old town.
Generally you will find value for your money in Prague and in the Czech republic. They have their own currency, Czech crowns, but might accept euros in some places. In smaller restaurants they might be slightly reluctant to taking cards for some reason so be sure to bring some cash as well. Situated in central Europe you can get there by car from Germany and Poland, or Austria from the south. There is an international airport for which most European airlines operate to and from the US you can go with Delta or American Airlines.
About the author: Marcus Segerros is a freelance Writer, Content Creator, Designer, Engineer and Business owner with a double BS and University Diploma Degree in Design and technology. Travelling as often as he can, he has visited a numerous number of countries and places and shares travelling tips in his articles.

In full transparency, our Eastern European stint of Budapest ‚Äî Vienna ‚Äî Prague is starting to blur together. While each of these cities are of course different, there are a lot of commonalities in terms of architecture, cuisine, and atmosphere. We were in Budapest and Prague for just over a week each, with only three days in Vienna, but all three stops were also slightly limited by poor weather, travel fatigue, and/or illness making it fairly even across the board. We traveled between them by train which was efficient, comfortable, and a change from planes and cars. Overall, I think Prague was my favourite of these three, but by very slim margins. It had a great mix of everything you could want: it was lively, the architecture is unmatched, many buildings are actually original whereas several in the other cities were destroyed during wars and rebuilt in the same style. Many of the buildings here were also painted pastel colours making the neighborhoods feel unique and cheery.
Activity-wise, Prague (similarly to Budapest and Vienna), was filled with a lot of walking and exploring the area. We did two walking tours, and visited a museum, and aside from that our activities were wandering, eating, and people-watching ‚Äî our favourites! We stayed in a hotel in Prague as well, which was a nice change from our Air BnBs. While very basic, we did have breakfast included. I did miss having a kitchen, but overall it was nice to be in comfy beds with daily room services.
Our first walking tour was an introduction to the city, winding through the Jewish quarter, crossing the Charles Bridge, and finishing at the Lennon Wall. While walking past one of the oldest synagogues in the city we learned the legend of Golem, a clay man brought to life by Rabbi Loew to help protect the Jewish people. The Rabbi would deactivate the Golem on Shabbat, however one week he forgot and the Golem got loose, leaving a path of destruction in his path. After this, the Rabbi never brought Golem to life again, and the form is said to still be locked in the attic of the old-new Synagogue. While this is the most famous Golem legend, he is not the first man of clay as this idea is reflected in stories and Jewish folklore prior to the 16th century. I find legends and folklore very interesting, and both Budapest and Prague offered nighttime ghost and legends tours that we had planned to take but were rained out which was disappointing.
Our tour also took us past the astronomical clock, a famous symbol of Prague. It is an intricate clock with multiple displays dictating the time, positions of the sun and moon, and Zodiac constellations. Given it‚Äôs age (built in the 15th century), it‚Äôs incredible how accurate it is. On the hour each hour is the worlds first puppet show, as a few of the figurines around the clock nod or make similar small movements, leading the square to be packed with people.
Charles Bridge was once the only bridge across the Vltava River, with construction starting in 1357 and ending in the early 15th century. As we crossed we heard buskers playing tunes and passed small stands selling jewelry and paintings.
After crossing the bridge we made our way to the Lennon Wall, named after Jon Lennon from the Beatles. John is not from the Czech Republic, nor did he live there, however when he was shot in New York in 1980, young Prague residents decided to draw on a wall in Prague as a memorial to the musician. Artistic and personal expression was not allowed under the communist regime in power at the time, and so by the next day the officials had painted over the drawings. The artists came back and painted again, only to have it painted over the next day. And so they painted on it again, and this cycle continued. It quickly evolved into a silent protest against communism. The wall still stands, and people continue to add their own artwork and words to it as it has become a symbol of freedom of speech and self-expression.
Our second walking tour was of Prague Castle, timed to see the changing of the guard. the rain held off for 90% of the three hours, and there were gorgeous views from the castle of the city below.
We also visited the Narodni Museum, which is a natural history museum founded in 1818. The exhibitions themselves are what you would expect from this sort of museum, nothing spectacular or unique, but for me the star of the show is the building itself. The detailed tiles and architecture were truly stunning.
We were overdue for a night out and decided to go on a pub crawl as Prague is known to have awesome nightlife that goes all night long. Overall, this was a fun night, but I would say it was not the best pub crawl we‚Äôve gone on. It was a very large group, many coming together from a hostel where a lot of pre-drinking had clearly happened and also meant that it was quite a young crowd. The first couple of places we went to were fairly empty, but our group was large and the pubs were small so we filled them up and it was a fun time. This pub crawl justifies its price by providing a free drink at each stop (typical of European pub crawls), as well as free entry into the largest club in Prague. We went on a Thursday, which we thought would be fine given Prague‚Äôs reputation and that we‚Äôre entering peak tourism season. We were wrong. The final club was not only a twenty-minute walk from the last bar, but it also was completely empty. The club is five floors with different music on each, and it would take a lot of people to fill it up‚Ä¶ but it was really disappointing, with maybe five people in each of the large spaces. We left almost as soon as we got there, waited for twenty minutes in the cold night for the tram which didn‚Äôt come (turns out we were on the wrong street), and wandered through the area until we picked up a free wifi network to call an Uber and make our way home. A bit of an unfortunate end, but a fun evening for the first 3‚Äì4 hours!
After about five days of amazing exploration and soaking in everything the city had to offer, I got my third cold of the trip. David and I both went to bed with throats that felt scratchy. In typical fashion, David‚Äôs immune system won and he woke up feeling ok, mine did not, and I woke up with a full-blown head cold and raw throat that stuck with me for several days, and now a week later is still clinging on with a hoarse cough in the evenings that I just can‚Äôt seem to kick. Our last couple of days were also pouring rain, so they were quiet days, we went out here and there, but mostly enjoyed the hotel and again took some recharge time before heading to our final destination of the entire trip: southern Portugal.
--
--
A Canadian couple on a five month trip around the world sharing our adventures as we go

Title: The Doors of Prague
Content:

Sign up
Sign in

Listen
Share
Prague is the capital of the Czech Republic with a long history as the central city of the region and the first capitol city of Bohemia. Bohemia dates back to 870 where by 1198 the Kingdom of Bohemia was established as part of the Holy Roman Empire. Prague has served as the center of life for the region through trade technology language and culture where much of the art and architecture over the centuries has been thoughtfully preserved. Prague suffered no major damage during the great wars except that many synagogues were robbed and their Jewish community targeted for deportation and execution by the Nazis during World War II.
On a recent visit to Prague my wife and I toured Old Town, the Jewish Quarter, Mal√° Strana, Prague Castle, and Wenceslas Square in New Town primarily on foot and with some assistance from the public tram system. One of the interesting and amazing discoveries on this visit were the Doors of Prague which I am sharing in this article.
Our room for the week was at the Grand Hotel Praha where we had this wonderful view of the Old Town Hall and the Astronomical Clock. The Old Town Hall building is primarily Gothic in design with some elements of Romanesque and other styles.
In addition to the main entrance there were these doors with a pointed arch of Gothic design a round arch of Romanesque design and a rectangular door with elaborate metalwork similar to that of the Romanesque door.
The interior featured many historical meeting rooms reflecting early forms of developing democracies, including the meeting hall for the people, a governing suite, and Senate chambers.
A unique feature of the Old City Hall and the Old Town area are the underground tunnels that connect the basements of many buildings in the area. The city was raised about 2 to 4 meters beginning in the 13th century to protect the city from flooding and to accommodate the construction of dams and locks on the Vitava River. So the original first floor of many buildings are now underground forming a network of connected basements.
Our first full day in Prague was spent exploring the Old Town Square and some of the surrounding streets to the North and East of the square. Old Town Square has a wide variety of beautiful entrance doors. These feature Romanesque designs with transom lights above the doors providing daylighting to the interior even when the doors are closed. Note the center door below featuring a door within a door.
These entrance doors with Baroque design influences feature bars and gates over the windows and doors with intricate design.
Saint Nicholas Church at Old Town Square features a Baroque architectural style with elaborate doors and this elegant window in the center below with intricate metalwork over the glass.
Art Nouveau influences were found too in these Romanesque entrance near Old Town Square with transom lights that have more free-form patterns integrated into the door designs.
Another elaborate gated entrance on Par√≠zsk√° street, and the blend of Gothic and Romanesque features in the Church of Our Lady at Tyn on Tynsk√° street. These were found on our venture up to the Jewish Quarter and back where we toured the Spanish Synagogue completed in 1868 and its Museum on Jewish history and the holocaust.
Dozens of Jewish Synagogues were destroyed in Czechia and tens of thousands of its citizens were deported and murdered by the Nazis during World War II. Fortunately most of the Synagogues in Prague including the Spanish Synagogue we visited were not destroyed. An example of the architectural loss in other parts of the Czech Republic is this beautiful Baroque Synagogue at Holesov with Moorish design elements.
Holesov was designed by the architect Jakob Gartner and completed in 1893 with elaborate Baroque decorative features on the facade and in its doors and windows. It was burned down and demolished by the Nazis in 1941. An excellent display of the facts can be found at the Spanish Synagogue and Museum just minutes north of Old Town Square.
On our second day we ventured across the Vitava River to Petrin Tower, down to Mal√° Strana, and back across the Charles Bridge. We took a tram from Old Town to the base of Petrin Hill Park and then another tram up the hill to Petrin Tower. I highly recommend this route as the hill would have been quite a climb and the trams are free for seniors.
Along the way back we found this collection of entrance doors including Baroque style double doors with Moorish influences at the Strahov Monastery and Romanesque style facades at Mosteck√° street and near the Charles Bridge.
Crossing the Charles Bridge was special because you could see the many statues on the bridge and the spires all around in Old Town, Mal√° Strana, and the Prague Castle. Here is an interpretation of that experience from my wife Ana Mari.
As we wandered back to Old Town on Mari√°nsk√© N√°mest√≠ you can find these new glass doors with transom and side lights, the Art Nouveau facade of the New City Hall which is not that new since it was built in 1911, and around the corner on Linhartsk√° street this gated entrance to the courtyard of a residential complex that can open wide for vehicular traffic or for pedestrians through the door within a door. It actually looked 21st century new.
In the rooms above many of these beautiful buildings are residential quarters. I noticed this early in the mornings when the locals were coming out and leaving for work, some slipping through their door within doors.
Venturing on, these entrances have Romanesque influences found on the doors at Lingartsk√° and Karlova streets. Note again the door within a door in the center image below.
Continuing on Karlova street are more entrances with Baroque and Moorish influences. Note the doors on the right with the large stone bumpers at the base. These were common on many entrances and designed to protect the doors from carts moving in and out from the interior courtyards to the street. Many are still in place and some have been cut or chiseled back as the building use has changed over the years.
Our third day was spent at Prague Castle where we took another tram from Old Town to the top of the hill entering the castle complex from the North. You can walk west from Old Town to the east Castle entrance but it turns into quite a climb by the time you get to Saint Vitus Cathedral.
Saint Vitus Cathedral has Gothic style features as noted by the pointed arches on all of these doors. The front entrance doors have elaborate facades, an interior side door features a door within a door, and one of the back service doors features beautiful stone and metal work.
To the east of the cathedral is St. George‚Äôs Basilica which displays many Romanesque features with its doors sunk deep into the thick stone walls.
Our fourth day included an outing south to Wenceslas Square which led to these finds along the way. A Romanesque style door within a door, a Baroque style entrance with some Moorish influences, and an Art Nouveau styled entrance.
Approaching Wenceslas Square there is a transition from Old Town to New Town where here Romanesque influences can be seen in the entrances on Ryt√≠rsk√° street and Wenceslas Square.
Our last day was a free day for wandering which included a round about route to the southeast to see the Franz Kafka Head by sculptor David Cerny. Along the way we made these discoveries on Jalovcov√° and Husova streets. Note the elaborate designs and textures and another door within a door.
At this entrance on Husova street below, note the door within a door to what looks like private residences on the two floors above. Most of the buildings in Old Town have been limited to about three floors in height except for those churches and public buildings with spires and towers.
In New Town and the Wenceslas Square area there is a change to building heights in the five to seven story range. New Town is what the Wenceslas Square area is called which is not that new given that many of the buildings date back to the early 1900s.
Along the way back we found these Baroque style influences on N√°rodn√≠ and Michalsk√° streets. Note here another door within a door leading to an interior courtyard.
In Closing I‚Äôll share that we found time to relax on a few evenings, me with a good book, and my wife painting. We spent five full days in Prague walking several miles a day to tour Old Town and the surrounding areas. With a redeye flight on the way over we found that the jet-lag is real when it finally hit requiring about 10 hours sleep the first night and making up the rest with an extra hour or two a night through the week.
Prague is a beautiful and historic city and well worth exploring in person. If you have not been there then be sure to put it on your list of future adventures.
Notes and References:
Story, photographs, and slides, by David Smitherman with site visits made in March 2023.
Historical data collected from brochures, onsite inscriptions, Wikipedia, Google Maps, and I-Maps.
Ana Mari Cadilla‚Äôs art can be seen on Instagram at @arte_anita11.
‚ÄúArchitecture of Prague, Czech Republic‚Äù at https://architectureofcities.com/prague#elements
Images from the Spanish Synagogue Museum displays, www.judalco.cz and Mestske muzeum a galerie Holesov.
Architectural Style designations are the authors visual interpretation and do not necessarily represent the official designation or time period of construction.

Title: Top 10 Vegan Restaurants & Caf√©s in Prague: A Local‚Äôs Guide to Plant-Based Dining
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

A travel guide to Prague, Czech Republic. Uncover the best tips and insights about the city.

--
Listen
Share
Traditional Czech food might be very meaty, but that doesn‚Äôt mean that vegans have it tough here. In fact, there are many vegan-friendly places in Prague that even my staunchest meat-eater friends can‚Äôt resist.
What are those? Here‚Äôs a local‚Äôs perspective on some of the plant-based food in Prague in 2025.
Whether you‚Äôre looking for Czech classics with a vegan twist, international cuisine, or budget-friendly options, this guide has you covered.
Eaternia is a popular vegan diner in Prague and genuinely one of my favorite places to eat ever. The first time I had their burger? I almost cried. That‚Äôs how good their food is! It‚Äôs been two years, but my sister and I still talk about that incredible culinary experience to this day.
Menu highlights: The burger menu, obviously. But they also always have traditional Czech desserts and cakes (all 100% vegan) that I would recommend trying.
Location: Prague 5 ‚Äî Sm√≠chov. About 7 minutes away from the Sm√≠chov Train Station.
For the cool diner vibes, including a classic jukebox and funky wallpaper in the restrooms. And the burgers! Have I mentioned the burgers?
St≈ôecha is the place for everyone and anyone wanting to experience traditional Czech food with a vegan twist. It‚Äôs a cooperative restaurant run by formerly homeless people and ex-convicts, supporting their reintegration into society.
Basically, if you eat here, you‚Äôll get to:
Menu highlights: Sv√≠ƒçkov√°, aka soy sirloin in creamy vegetable sauce with traditional Czech dumplings. Personally, I‚Äôm also a big fan of the Budvard goulash.
Location: Nov√© mƒõsto. You can get here by metro (line B, station N√°rodn√≠ t≈ô√≠da) or tram (station Lazarsk√°).
St≈ôecha is affordable, welcoming, and one of the most famous vegan restaurants in Prague.
Safe Space Bookstore & Caf√© is a relatively new spot in Prague (it only recently celebrated its first birthday), but it‚Äôs quickly become one of my favorites. This place is a unique vegan caf√© and queer-friendly bookshop all in one.
There are always fun and inclusive events on, too, so if you‚Äôre looking for a quick vegan lunch, snack, or cocktail alongside some entertainment, why not check out Safe Space?
Menu highlights: Traditional Czech spreads and snacks, including the strange ‚ÄúCzech hot dog.‚Äù
Location: ≈Ωi≈ækov. Get here by bus, tram, or walk from Florenc Bus Station (about 12 minutes).
If you‚Äôre looking for some LGBTQ+ friends or just want an affordable place that has both delicious food and interesting books for you to peruse, Safe Space is the spot for you.
If you like your dining on the bougier side, you have to go to Palo Verde. This Prague vegan bistro is perfect for fancy brunches and celebratory dinners. My sister took a group of her friends here for her birthday, and it was honestly the perfect spot for the occasion!
Menu highlights: Personally, I really enjoyed their kimchi omelette and have heard great things about the red pesto lasagna.
Location: Palo Verde is located in Nov√© Mƒõsto, close to the Muzeum metro station (line C).
Cozy spot. Friendly staff. Fancy vibes. Also, they have board games you can borrow and play!
Let‚Äôs stick with the brunch theme! CHUTNEJ is a spot I kept getting recommended over and over again, until I finally gave in. And it‚Äôs a good thing that I did. This spot is amazing, and it‚Äôs no wonder it has such a great reputation among other Prague vegans.
It‚Äôs not just a brunch spot, either. You can get dinner here, too, as well as some delicious coffee.
Menu highlights: The above-pictured traditional Czech ‚Äúloup√°k.‚Äù I used to eat these a lot as a kid, and it was amazing to see them again in a fully vegan caf√©.
Location: Hole≈°ovice. Take the tram to Letensk√© n√°mƒõst√≠.
The way people rave about this place, why would you not want to visit CHUTNEJ?
Imagin√°rn√≠ zmrzlina is the only place that‚Äôs managed to get me excited about ice cream in recent years. And there‚Äôs a reason for that. This place genuinely has some of the best ice cream ever. Whether you‚Äôre a fan of traditional flavors or prefer more adventurous options, this tiny caf√© has it all.
Menu highlights: The poppy ice cream. Just trust me on this.
Location: Karl√≠n, near the Florenc bus and metro stations.
This is the best ice cream I‚Äôve had in years. And I mean that.
Loving Hut isn‚Äôt exactly for those of you looking for a fine-dining experience, but it is a staple in Prague‚Äôs vegan restaurant scene. It‚Äôs an affordable vegan buffet chain that offers a variety of Asian-inspired dishes.
Here, you serve yourself. Just pick up a box or a plate and load it with whatever you fancy. You pay by weight here, which makes it perfect for those of you on a budget.
Menu highlights: Noodles, curries, dumplings, sushi, and more.
Location: There‚Äôs a bunch of these all over Prague, including N√°rodn√≠ t≈ô√≠da and Karl√≠n.
If you‚Äôre on a budget or in a rush but still want to eat out, try one of these buffets!
Pastva is a small vegan restaurant in Prague that I can wholeheartedly recommend. I took my friend from the UK here, and we had some delicious ‚Äúlango≈°e‚Äù here (as pictured above). We were stuffed by the end of the meal, but I‚Äôm fully planning to come back and try some of their tasty-looking desserts.
Menu highlights: Lango≈°, which is a beloved dish in Czechia. Their risottos look incredible, too!
Location: Andƒõl, Prague 5. Close to the Andƒõl metro station (line B).
For the stylish atmosphere, comfort food, and craft cocktails, of course.
Similar to Loving Hut, Dhaba Beas is an affordable chain of vegetarian and vegan buffets that you can find all over Prague. Most of the meals are India-style, and while I wouldn‚Äôt exactly call them authentic, many of them really do hit the spot if you‚Äôre looking for someone quick and easy.
Menu highlights: They have these little soy pieces in peanut sauce that are to die for.
Location: Trust me, Dhaba Beas is everywhere. If you walk around Prague city center for 15 minutes, you‚Äôre bound to find at least one. But just in case, here‚Äôs a map of all the different locations.
It‚Äôs super affordable, and you pay per weight here, too, so there‚Äôs less danger of unnecessary food waste.
Last but not least, we have Linh‚Äôs Vegan Corner, a place that I just can‚Äôt resist. This Asian-style restaurant has a super comprehensive menu. As vegans, we‚Äôre often used to not having too many options. But not here. This place has a lot on offer, and it‚Äôs honestly a struggle to just pick one or two things each visit.
(Maybe that‚Äôs why I always end up ordering from this restaurant above most others.)
Menu highlights: I‚Äôm obsessed with the Black Magic Udon. Also, the traditional vegan honey cake here is a must!
Location: Vinohrady, aka one of the coolest parts of Prague.
Their Instagram says that this place is just like a fairy tale, and I have to agree. It‚Äôs that good.
Got some questions? Here are some answers.
A: Yes! As this guide shows, Prague has a blossoming vegan scene where you can find everything from casual buffets to cool brunch spots and bougie restaurants (perfect for those Instagram travel pics).
A: Go to St≈ôecha for amazing vegan versions of Czech classic dishes like sv√≠ƒçkov√° (sirloin with creamy sauce), bread and potato dumplings, and beer goulash.
A: Yes! Try Loving Hut and Dhaba Beas for quick vegan meals under ‚Ç¨10.
A: Palo Verde and CHUTNEJ are definitely up there. Or, if you‚Äôre a member of the LGBTQ+ community (or an ally), head to Safe Space for books and brunch!
A: Definitely! Most of the popular, big grocery stores like Albert, Lidl, Billa, and Tesco have all you could possibly need, including plant-based milk, meat alternatives, tofu, tempeh, and vegan snacks. Albert has vegan pastries, too, which are great if you‚Äôre looking for a quick snack. Other than that, DM Drogerie is also a good place if you‚Äôre looking for some fancier vegan products.
A: No! Most restaurant staff in Prague‚Äôs vegan restaurants and caf√©s speak English. In fact, most Czechs speak English, especially those who live in Prague. They‚Äôll probably be happy they get to practice their language skills with you.
Whether you‚Äôre looking for traditional Czech dishes or international cuisine, Prague has a ton of vegan options available to you. This list featured some of my and my friends‚Äô favorite spots, but there are many more. So feel free to explore the city and enjoy the best of vegan food that Prague has to offer.
And please, do let me know if you try any of these spots ‚Äî or if you have other favorites that I forgot to mention.

Title: Czeching Prague off my bucket list
Content:

Immersed in history, overflowing with charm, and speckled with orange-topped roofs lies the city of Prague in the Czech Republic. Whether you love castles, architecture, or are just in need of a good beer, Czech Republic‚Äôs most popular city is one of the most interesting in Europe.
Prague has tonnes to offer with regards to culture, architecture, food, and drink; it has been on the tourist map for decades, and the crowds show no signs of dwindling down.
The Czech have a wonderful spirit. You really do get a feeling that they are not just putting up with all the tourists but instead embracing it, and want to show off their beautiful city. One of the most mind-blowing facts is their beer consumption; which may have something to do with their positivity. According to a local citizen there, the average Czech citizen consumes 300 litres of beer a year. They are serious about their beer and I am all for it! They know how to have and show you a good time. Prague is the perfect place to relax, explore, and get a feel for the history of Europe.

Title: Prague, Dresden, and Berlin 2023
Content:
Sign up

Share
Now sit back and relax because it‚Äôs time to talk about more travel lessons from our first European Christmas! While not an official birthday trip, I have always wanted to experience Christmas in Europe, so as part of our post-pandemic family travel and to celebrate turning 40, we went to Europe with my brother and my parents for two weeks in December.
If you‚Äôve read my entry about our trip with Sergio‚Äôs parents and sister to Paris and Rome, this blog is in a similar vein, with travel planning, tips, and reflections. Each trip is a little different, and the lessons are a little different as well ‚Äî in this case, traveling in winter meant a little extra planning to stay warm and dry.
But let‚Äôs get into it! I can smell the mulled wine‚Ä¶
Sergio and I have long been shoulder-season people ‚Äî a luxury to indulge in if you‚Äôre not a parent and thus married to a school holiday schedule ‚Äî but we tend to split holidays between my family in Washington State and his family in Chihuahua, Mexico. Christmas tends to be family-centered because everyone is together and it‚Äôs easier to see everyone at once.
It‚Äôs not that I don‚Äôt like tradition ‚Äî but Christmas is a special season, and I‚Äôve wanted to experience it elsewhere (say, Hawai‚Äôi) for some time, but it just hadn‚Äôt panned out. Christmas in Europe, however, ended up being a (more immediate) family experience and it was fun to travel in the true off-season.
Depending on your family members, you might have a group of eager travel planning beavers or a low-key set of folks who are happy to travel to a variety of places. For my family, I‚Äôve always found it useful to come with some ideas while putting their preferences in mind (eg; clean and quiet accommodations, easy to see sights, etc.). Europe is chock-full of Christmas markets, but Dresden was one that popped to the top of the list in my research, giving one point on the map and making it easier to choose the end-points on either side ‚Äî Berlin, with which we had some familiarity, and Prague, which my brother knew. That helped us narrow down the list of possibilities and put together the main Prague-Dresden-Berlin itinerary.
I did a lot of the planning with some assumptions (many of the considerations about mobility, walking distances, etc. that I mentioned in my previous post), but I also had the good fortune to learn from our first family trip to Paris and Rome. The biggest difference between the two trips was that we saw virtually no American tourists in any of our cities in December. Really and truly, basically none save a few folks here and there. And maybe this was a pandemic hangover as well, but there weren‚Äôt a lot of tourists in general! There were only two sites that required tickets far in advance (more info later in the post) so it was a relief to be in a space that wasn‚Äôt nearly as crowded. It makes me curious what other European destinations would be great in the winter!
But back to the planning ‚Äî I already wrote about creating a shared doc and a Google Map so anyone can participate. The most important thing I‚Äôve learned? Taking a trip together doesn‚Äôt mean you have to do every activity together! It was something that I knew before, but to have a harmonious two weeks, it helps to have a lot of flexibility so that people can travel at their own pace as well as see those places that most interest them. Case-in-point: My dad had a minor foot injury that meant walking longer distances on back-to-back days was difficult, so that necessitated putting longer walking activities a day or two apart, or choosing activities that he wasn‚Äôt interested in during the afternoons when he was resting.
We chose hotels for our previous trip to Paris and Rome but decided on AirBnbs for this trip. Our options in these December cities were much, much better, and much more affordable, especially when we needed three bedrooms. It‚Äôs hard to find rental apartments with 4.98 stars, but we stayed in three of them and it was lovely. This put us in central neighborhoods with good public transit and access to sights, all super-important to reduce walking and increase accessibility. You probably have a preference for hotels or rentals, but I‚Äôd encourage you to look at both quickly because in some cities there‚Äôs a clear winner.
Now to packing ‚Äî as much as I prefer to pack light, it‚Äôs a little bit more difficult when you‚Äôre traveling in December, and we knew we had to prepare for rain, snow, and wind. Another factor that tipped us towards apartments was that we were able to get two with laundry facilities, making it easier to pack fewer pairs of pants and shirts so that we could make room for snow boots (and souvenirs). The most important items were warm, waterproof shoes, wool socks, very warm jackets, warm gloves, hats, and a scarf. One positive about all of these destinations is that they‚Äôre not fancy cities (we‚Äôre not fancy people!) so a nice sweater or top with dark jeans was enough for any meal out. As a Seattle girl, I must tell you that your winter jacket is likely not warm enough (but if you‚Äôre from Minneapolis or Chicago, you‚Äôre probably prepared).
With everything packed it was just a manner of days before we boarded a plane in Seattle for our SEA-LHR-PRG journey! I tend to feel a little anxious before a big trip, but we had planned very well so sometimes you just have to let the butterflies flutter a bit and just do the damn thing.
So let‚Äôs start with our first stop, which was Prague! There‚Äôs something about Prague that makes it a perfect jet-lag city: The main attractions are in a rather compact area, there aren‚Äôt that many of them, and public transit links most of them togther. We chose a longer layover in LHR to allow for enough time to move throughout Terminal 5 with my parents (the right choice) so we landed in the Czech Republic in darkness, tried to stay awake in the cab for the ride to our apartment, and passed out as soon as heads hit pillows.
The castle complex was a perfect first-day activity ‚Äî whether it was the tomb of Saint Wenceslaus (a duke, not a king as the song suggests) or the Old Royal Palace, we were greeted with beautiful views of the city and kept moving so as not to fall asleep. The views of the old city are beautiful, and depiste the cold there was a festive atmosphere.
For me, the highlight of the city was taking a Christmas Market walking tour with Ji≈ô√≠ (George in English). He took us by tram to some local Christmas markets with a bunch of quirky stops along the way, including sparklers, writing wishes on dove-shaped papers in a cathedral, and drinking some sort of homemade Czech liquor. The introvert in me doesn‚Äôt gravitate towards these sorts of activities, but my biggest travel insight of 2023 was that these local experiences can really make a trip more memorable. Again, a huge benefit of traveling with different people is that you try activites that you otherwise might skip, and for some people those personal connections make the city come alive!
Prague isn‚Äôt a very heavy museum town ‚Äî and I‚Äôm past the point of taking photos in most museums ‚Äî but I can wholeheartedly recommend the Mucha Museum as well as the Museum of Communism. I could spend hours upon hours in a museum (see visiting four Smithsonians in two days in January), but smaller museums are more manageable and allow you to get a taste of something while balancing everyone‚Äôs interests.
Prague really was a short stop, but I felt like it was a city that was doable in a few days. We ended our last day with an incredible walk across the Charles Bridge with the castle shining on the hill above us. It was one wild train ride from Prague to our next stop ‚Äî Dresden!
Dresden was the city I was most excited about for this trip, and it didn‚Äôt disappoint! Are you ready for the Christmas Market to end all Christmas markets? Well, we went to the main market in Dresden which was started in 1434 and it was it‚Äôs 589th year when we visited. It also has the world‚Äôs tallest Weihnachtspyramide (Christmas pyramid, fondly called ‚ÄúThe Twirly‚Äù in our house)! But beyond this, Dresden is a friendly and walkable city with easy-to-navigate public transit, and wind aplenty.
So let‚Äôs talk a minute about how to get around as an American ‚Äî or non-German speaker. As with most places in Europe these days, English fluency is as high as it has ever been, and this is especially true in Germany. Like our trip to France, I was the only person who had any German language skills to use, but there were only a few situations where English alone wouldn‚Äôt suffice. The trickiest items tend to be ticket machines or menus, but with Google Translate you‚Äôll get there. As always, hello, thank you, and please are good to know wherever you go (that‚Äôs Guten Tag, danke, and bitte, if you are wondering).
Dresden was firebombed at the end of the Second World War by the British and the Americans, destroying its inner city and burning alive about 25,000 inhabitants. The city center was largely recontructed in a traditional style (compared to a city like Frankfurt that re-built itself as a modern city), but the beautiful Parade of Nobles (below) survived because they were fired at a higher temperature than the incendiary bombs. It is a procession of famous local nobles from the twelfth to the first years of the twentieth centuries.
Unfortunately not all of the landmarks were so lucky, and because Dresden was part of the Deutsche Demokratische Republik (East Germany, to Americans), many historical buildings remained ruins until German reunification in 1990. What was particularly inspiring was that the town‚Äôs citizens donated 92% of the funds needed to reconstruct the church in the style of the one that was destroyed.
Lastly, Dresden is also a museum city, but one that is still under construction. The Green Vault (no photos inside, sorry) was one of the two attractions this trip that needed an advanced reservation, and security was particularly tight because of a 2019 theft. But its jewelry, porcelain, and decorative collections were amazing ‚Äî but, as in other museums, few benches are available, so consider your companions and give plenty of time for rest. The Zwinger complex (also under construction ‚Äî it was a mud mess!) included one of the quirkier museums of the trip ‚Äî a museum of math and physical instruments. How fantastic to see the evolution of the globe and microscope!
Before we go to Berlin, let‚Äôs take a short break to talk about one of my favorite parts of the trip ‚Äî the food! I look forward to any trip to Germany to eat delicious bread and dumplings and any sort of meat I can imagine. But Berlin in particular is a fantastic food city ‚Äî we had incredible vegan pastries, Persian food, a wide variety of pastries, and fantastic Thai food.
The food at the markets was just as good as I thought it would be. Since I‚Äôm currently not drinking to keep my autoimmune hepatitis in remission, I only partook in a few sips of Gl√ºhwein (literally ‚Äúglow wine,‚Äù or mulled wine), but you can collect little mugs from each market to take home (or return it and get your Pfand ‚Äî deposit ‚Äî back). There was ample Wurst (sausage) and Kn√∂del (dumplings), and a variety of sweet pastries, hot doughnuts, and desserts. Our last Christmas Market in Berlin had indoor tent seating ‚Äî how lovely to sit on faux furs and eat dessert while the wind whips outside!
So the biggest oops! of this trip was renting the Mega Van in Dresden. If you know Sergio at all, you‚Äôll know that he‚Äôs a fantastically-skilled driver, even when we visited England and he drove a mega-van on the opposite side of the car/road and parallel-parked in one go (might I say that I live my life very impressed at his skill in all things and sometimes very jealous because how can he do all this stuff so well?).
Barry and Sergio went to the airport in Dresden to pick up the Mega Van from Hertz ‚Äî and as they left I felt really positive about it. I‚Äôm a big fan of train travel, but our ride from Prague to Dresden was pretty chaotic on the Prague side, and with larger bags and extra space, a car seemed like a great idea. We would have the car ‚Äî with free street parking in Dresden and a garage space in Berlin ‚Äî to enable some day trips and also make it easier to cart luggage. It felt like a great way to ensure more comfort and mobility for my parents too.
But.
‚Ä¶ As soon as I saw the Mega Van I knew this wasn‚Äôt the right decision. First of all, Dresden was so easy to get around that we didn‚Äôt need the car. We did have a reserved garage space in Berlin, but after measuring the van dimensions and the garage dimensions there was no way it was going to fit. We agreed to eat the cost of it and return it so we wouldn‚Äôt have to move it around every eight hours on the street. But this albatross didn‚Äôt go easily! Navigating the van return to the nearby train station was the most stressful part of the whole trip ‚Äî and when we got to the rental car return garage, I was literally outside of the Mega Van running alongside it to make sure that we didn‚Äôt burst a pipe or get stuck on the ceiling (it didn‚Äôt), but after that experience we agreed never again. Never. ever. again.
That being said, if we didn‚Äôt get the Mega Van, we wouldn‚Äôt have had our random drive from Dresden to Berlin with a stop at what we thought was a beautiful castle but was actually an exhibit on a very niche East German film called Three Hazelnuts for Cinderella ‚Äî and if you think it‚Äôs weird, I can‚Äôt even start to convey how bizarre it is to be in an experience where everyone around you knows and loves a thing and it‚Äôs completely lost on you.
Well, at least the outside looked nice.
Did you know that this part of Germany is Luther country? It is ‚Äî and Luther is a complicated guy (I‚Äòd recommend Martin Luther, Renegade and Prophet to learn more about him) but despite the bitter cold Sergio and I decided to stick it out and take a train to Wittenberg (since the mega-van had been returned), so our first day in Berlin was actually spent in Wittenberg. Sergio and I started going to church just a few weeks earlier (worthy of another blog post, but not today) so it was also an opportunity for him to learn a bit more about Lutheranism, as he was raised Catholic.
Wittenberg was a perfect day trip! I imagine December had something to do with it, but we felt like we had the entire town to ourselves! The two main things to see in the town are the two churches ‚Äî the Schlosskirche (Castle Church) and the Stadtkirche (Town Church) of Saint Mary‚Äôs. The former was attached to the university and both the location of the doors where the 99 theses were (supposedly) posted as well as the tomb of Martin Luther himself. Rick Steves had a fantastic walking tour for the city ‚Äî he‚Äôs also Lutheran ‚Äî that helped us to understand the meaning what started in this humble university town.
There isn‚Äôt that much else to do in the winter in Wittenberg, so we had a long, lazy lunch, perused the Christmas Market (which included an accordion choir concert!) and a nearby shopping mall, and then took a long walk back to the train station‚Ä¶ for a train that was almost two hours delayed!
As I always say, never go anywhere without a book‚Ä¶
So despite all of the travel that we‚Äôve done, I‚Äôm not sure that I‚Äôve ever visited a place that I‚Äôd like to live in more than Berlin. And as I researched for this trip I was thrilled to discover that many sites and museums are open over the holiday, even on Christmas Day itself, making Berlin a wonderful place for Christmas.
It‚Äôs easy to be attached to your American view of Christmas ‚Äî everything bedecked in lights and tinsel ‚Äî but that might just be the United States being (yet again) a little extra. For example, Christmas trees are trimmed on Christmas Eve and there were no mall Santas to be found ‚Äî though the Cathedral had a beautiful tree and manger scene. So if you can set aside Christmas expectations, December was a fantastic time to travel with many fewer tourists and attractions to oneself!
My favorite site this trip was the Reichstag Dome climb. The Reichstag is the home of the German Federal Parliament ‚Äî the Bundestag ‚Äî and the building it self is rich in history. It was burned to the ground in the 1930s and not reconstructed until the Berlin Wall fell. The modern dome sits atop a classical building, and within the dome itself you can see all the way to the parliament‚Äôs floor, symbolizing the belief that the people of Germany should know what‚Äôs happening in the government. A wide, gently-sloped ramp circles up and then down the outside of the dome, providing a sweeping view of the city‚Ä¶ that would‚Äôve been better in the daytime.
Since Berlin has so much history and character, it was hard to narrow down all of the sites to visit, but we really enjoyed the DDR Museum (compact and full of daily-life exhibits), the Berlin Wall Memorial (outside and included real parts of the Wall that were still standing), and, of course, Museum Island. While the Pergamon Museum is still closed for renovation (sob!), the Old and New National Galleries are spectactular.
We love you, Berlin. You make any trip a little bit sweeter!
Things are delayed even in Germany ‚Äî in fact, during one train delay on our day trip to Wittenberg, the Germans were saying to one another, ‚ÄúThis wouldn‚Äôt be happening if we were in Switzerland!‚Äù and for the two of you that think that‚Äôs funny, I hope we‚Äôre already friends.
We packed everything up, double-checked that we had our passports ready, set some early alarms, and made it out of the apartment by 7am‚Ä¶ to find out that our flight from Berlin to London was cancelled en route. Poor Sergio was on the phone with British Airways and the calls kept dropping, so it took four or five calls before we were rebooked for the following day. There were a few hotels at the airport and we were able to get some rooms to make our airport experience the following day much easier.
I think everyone else was pretty tired by this point, which was a reminder that two weeks is a long trip from home when you‚Äôre not in your best travel shape. As a maximizer I want to fit the maximum days into a trip if I‚Äôve flown to another continent, but two two-week trips showed me that perhaps it would be better to aim for 10‚Äì12 days abroad so we‚Äôre finishing on a high note!
Me being me I looked up some attractions that didn‚Äôt involve returning into Berlin proper, which included a WWII museum that focused on the Soviet experience (something you learn little about as an American ) ‚Äî and then Sergio and I decided to get another long day of walking in at Tierpark Berlin, their ‚Äúsafari‚Äù park outside of the city center. We went to bed tired and happy, and the homeward journey went off without a hitch.
Well, we‚Äôre at the tail end of this post, so it‚Äôs time to wrap things up on this trip! Whether in this post or my previous entry about traveling with the Ricos, I hope you enjoyed tagging along with us and perhaps came away with a few travel ideas for yourself.
So what‚Äôs next? Let‚Äôs say I‚Äôm an antsy lady unless I‚Äôm dreaming of another trip. Since we‚Äôve had some great road trip energy lately, we‚Äôre gearing up for potential road trips in Norway and France this year! No definite plans, but a lot of planning and excitement about our next trips to the Continent!
Auf Wiedersehen, S

Some cool historical stuff to know about Prague before you go
Defiant. Resilient. Betrayed. Those are the words that come to mind as I walk through the streets of Prague for the first time and learn about this historic city on the Vltava River.
It is hard not to experience Prague and feel the weight of history that bears down of the city and the Czech people, who over the course of the last nearly 700 years, have been ruled for a majority of that time by other states, nations and empires.
Prague got off to a really strong start in the 14th Century under King Charles IV, who strengthened the economy, started the first university in Central Europe and expanded the Prague Castle, including starting construction of St. Vitus Cathedral. He also commissioned the famous bridge across the Vltava, which was started on July 9, 1357, at 5:31 a.m. when he laid the first stone. This is well known because the date and time create a numerical palindrome (1‚Äì3‚Äì5‚Äì7‚Äì9‚Äì7‚Äì5‚Äì3‚Äì1), which meant something to Medieval numerologists, who must have been on to something because the original bridge is still standing strong, 668 years later.

Title: The Ultimate Travel Guide: Prague
Content:
Sign up

Share
A beautiful and unique city known for everything ranging from its rich history to its active nightlife, Prague is a gem in the heart of the Czech Republic that cannot be missed.
Located in the northwest of the Czech Republic, Prague has a beauty that can only be understood by traveling to the city itself. Before starting my trip to Europe, I asked the advice of several other travelers about which destinations they recommend that I travel to. High on the list of many of these travelers was Prague. With so many recommendations, I simply had to visit. But what makes this city such a favorite among both travelers and its inhabitants?
To start with, I found the people of the Czech Republic to be very kind to their visitors; they wanted to share the country that they love so much with anyone who is willing to take the time to visit.
As far as activities go, exploring Prague without a map was one of my favorite experiences in the city. The day I arrived, I decided to wander around in search of food. In the process, I was able to get a glimpse of some of the famous architecture around the city, as well as some of its most iconic sights. After returning to my hostel, I was able to do some research into the history of these locations while also planning out the places I wanted to spend more time with.
As far as specific attractions go, Prague is a perfect city to visit no matter your time frame. With that being said, a few of the most prominent and worthwhile attractions include the Charles Bridge, all of Old Town, Wenceslas Square, Petrin Hills, and Prague Castle. The main sights can be seen in a tour around the city in a day (which requires a ton of walking), but that doesn‚Äôt mean you shouldn‚Äôt spend any more time there.
Now let‚Äôs pretend you have just arrived in Prague and you are eager to see everything you can in just one walking journey. Doing this, I would suggest starting in Wenceslas Square and walking down the slope towards Old Town. A walk through Old Town takes you through the picturesque streets of Prague, while also allowing you to visit the Astronomical Tower, the Old Town Square, and St. Nicolas‚Äô Church; all of which are well worth it if you find yourself in Prague. After seeing these iconic sights, wandering towards the Jewish Quarter of the city provides an opportunity to learn some of the history of the city through the years. From there, walk towards the river to see the concert hall known as Rudolfinum while listening to music written by Czech composers that you might not recognize by name, but you will recognize by their music. Walk along the Vltava River towards the Charles Bridge where you should take your time to take in the atmosphere and the unique architecture of the bridge as well as the views of Old Town and Prague Castle as they face off across the river. This walk brings you to the other side of the river where you can see the somewhat surprising Lennon Wall as well as taking a trip to Prague Castle.
This walking trip provides an opportunity to see most major sights in Prague. Like with any city, it is possible to go into more detail if you so desire, and Prague is a city that deserves that extra attention.
There are museums and historical sites littered throughout the city, and they are not hard to find. I visited the National Technical Museum in a quieter part of the city and I was blown away by the size and level of detail that the museum provided. Anyone with enough interest could spend a full day exploring every detail. In addition to that, the Jewish museum in the Jewish Quarter is well known and has the reputation of being very good, but I did not have the time to visit it, unfortunately. The Prague Castle allows for entry that is free of charge, but a ticket is required to visit some parts of the complex. Purchase of this ticket depends on the level of detail you wish to go into, and the amount of time you have to spend there.
The activity that I highly recommend is taking a trip to the Petrin Hills where you can buy a ticket to ascend Petrin Tower where the views of the city are simply breathtaking.
These examples stand as just a few options for ideas on how to make your trip to Prague as complete as you can want. After taking a walk around the city to see all of the sights, taking the public transportation provides for a welcome rest from all of the walking. The transportation is cheap and cost is based on time which makes it perfect for travelers who want unlimited travel for just a few days. As far as additional public transportation goes, taxis can be found throughout the city, but be sure to find a good price. In many instances, getting an Uber will be far more convenient and allow for the best possible price.
The Czech Republic is a beautiful country and its capital city is the culmination of the country‚Äôs beauty. Prague is a city that should be on every traveler‚Äôs list for its uniqueness, its culture, and its people.
Originally published at https://www.theodysseyonline.com on April 9, 2018.

In the heart of Prague, a city steeped in the history of the Czech Republic and adorned with ancient architecture, my lens embarked on a journey through the juxtaposition of tradition and modernity. Arriving on a cold, foggy night, Tochukwu couldn‚Äôt help but worry about the weather‚Äôs impact on his photo walk. However, as dawn broke and the city emerged from the mist, he felt a surge of anticipation.
The grand doors of historic buildings greeted me, their intricate designs creating a breathtaking backdrop for my subjects. As Tochukwu roamed the streets, he encountered a young woman, her weary steps echoing against the ancient stones. Entering through the colossal doors, she became a silent storyteller, a fusion of fatigue and the timeless beauty of Prague. The echo was clear for many others that he saw passing the ancient streets of Prague, as the walls laid a perfect canvas for my imagination.
But the city was not frozen in time. Construction workers toiled, transforming the ancient into the modern. Amid the scaffolding, a mapping car glided through the streets, documenting the metamorphosis. The synergy of human effort and technological advancement was a captivating dance, a visual representation of Prague‚Äôs evolution.
As Tochukwu framed scenes of change, he couldn‚Äôt ignore the emergence of local delivery startups like Wolt, challenging the global dominance of giants like Uber Eats and Bolt. It seemed as though the city had its rhythm, a beat that the local players danced to, dominating the delivery scene while the international names loomed in the background.
Yet, amidst the transformations, Prague held steadfast to its traditions. A local Christmas market, set up by merchants near the city centre, breathed life into the streets. The aromas of festive delights mingled with the sounds of cheerful chatter, creating a timeless haven amid the bustling changes.
Prague also embraced alternative transport, with cyclists weaving through the cobbled streets. Although the city lacked dedicated lanes, it provided ample parking spaces for bicycles, promoting a green and sustainable mode of commuting. Each photograph of a bicycle parking space or a cyclist captured a moment and a testament to the city‚Äôs commitment to eco-friendly living.
Amidst it all, an old woman, framed against the grand doors, puffed on her cigarette. It is a seemingly mundane act, yet poignant against the backdrop of ancient structures. It spoke of continuity, a personal ritual unfazed by the changing tides of time.
And then there were the old trams‚Äîpractical, reliable, and seemingly timeless. Moving people 24/7, these trams became the city's veins, circulating life through its historic arteries.
In one poignant frame, Tochukwu captured the essence of a young woman navigating the intricate tapestry of life in Prague. Her journey homeward was a visual symphony ‚Äî headphones in place, encapsulating a world of personal melodies or knowledge development, and in her grasp, a pack of tissues, an unspoken emblem of responsibilities both personal and professional. The photograph silently whispered of the delicate balance she maintained, seamlessly weaving the threads of her personal aspirations with the demands of her professional endeavours.
Prague revealed its story in every photograph‚Äîone of contrasts, resilience, and the harmonious coexistence of the old and the new. As the shutter clicked, each frame became a chapter, a testament to the city‚Äôs dynamic spirit and the ever-unfolding narrative of its streets.

Title: 7 Reasons You Need to Add Prague to Your Bucket List
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Ah Prague,
Forget Paris being the city of love. Prague, in my opinion, takes the prize! It‚Äôs one of the most well-preserved and beautiful cities in the world. I‚Äôve had the pleasure of visiting several times and I never seem to get bored! There is always something new to discover or somewhere new to explore. Despite the cobblestones causing me to stumble every few steps or almost being hit by a tram, I have fallen in love with this charming medieval city.
Since my first trip there at sixteen, which was a bazillion years ago, I have been back 5 times. And no matter how many times I visit, I never seem to shake off the feeling that I am walking through a fairytale. I still haven‚Äôt found prince charming, but the hunt isn‚Äôt over!
Everything from the historical bridges to the hidden cobblestoned alleyways to the vibrant buildings, Prague really is a place that should be on everyone‚Äôs bucket list.
To inspire your inner wanderlust, and hopefully get you to start planning your trip to Prague, these are the things that made me fall in love with the city. If this list doesn‚Äôt convince you, I don‚Äôt know what will!
Walking through Prague feels like visiting a neverending history museum. It‚Äôs one of the very few European cities not destroyed by the World War II bombings, so most of the architectural beauty is original and more than eight centuries old. Each building has a distinct style and color, and to me, that is one of the things that makes this city so special. I love walking around and imagining who lived in them right after they were built or what they were used for.
A few of my favorite architectural gems are Charles Bridge, National Theater, and Municipal House. Prague is best explored by ditching the map and just getting lost. You never know what you might find.
Prague has a reputation for being one of the most beautiful cities in Europe and there is no better way to experience that beauty than from an elevated vantage point. There are so many places to get spectacular views, you really can‚Äôt go wrong. My personal favorite is the Letna Park Beer Garden. On a warm day, it‚Äôs the perfect spot to grab a cold beer and gaze out at the picturesque city below or better yet, watch the sunset. There is no better way to end your day.
One of my favorite aspects of Prague is the vibrancy. It‚Äôs a city with so much going on day in and day out and can be overwhelming to pick and choose where to go and what to do, but being in a city with too much choice has never been a bad thing in my book. Let‚Äôs just hope indecisiveness isn‚Äôt your weakness because then you might have a problem.
Prague‚Äôs mystery is one I have yet to crack, and I hope to keep it that way. With a history dating back over 2000 years and the fact that all the buildings are original and intact, makes it one of the most interesting, spellbinding and mysterious cities in Europe. I always seem to discover a new part of the city every time I visit.
These days, finding cheap destinations in Europe has become more difficult. Unfortunately, Prague isn‚Äôt as cheap as some of it‚Äôs Eastern European neighbors, but that doesn‚Äôt mean that it‚Äôs not one of the more affordable places to visit. You can easily find budget-friendly activities and restaurants scattered all over the city.
One of my favorite resources for finding budget-friendly things to do is Like a Local. Locals will give you tips on restaurants, attractions, shopping and nightlife and a lot of times they will recommend places that tourists don‚Äôt normally know about. You can save quite a bit of money if you are willing to venture out of the city center.
Smazeny Syr is a delicious traditional Czech food you can‚Äôt leave Prague without trying. This fried cheese dish is found pretty much everywhere from the simplest food cart to the classiest restaurant. Fast food places will usually serve it as a sandwich, which makes for a pretty amazing snack after a night out, but most commonly it is served on its own with a side salad or potatoes. Don‚Äôt order it on your first day because you might not want to try anything else.
Is there anything like watching a sunset after a busy day of sightseeing? I personally think it‚Äôs the best way to finish off a day. Ohhh, that rhymes! Prague has several vantage points where you can witness mother natures phenomenon. Many of the places will have cafes where you can grab a drink, find a seat as you watch the sun slowly sinking below the horizon.
A few of my favorite spots to watch the sunset are, Letna Park, Stefanikuv Most (a bridge with less foot traffic than Charles Bridge), Vy≈°ehrad, and Prague Castle. Although watching the sunset with Prague Castle in the background is pretty incredible.

Title: 6 Things you Must Do in Prague
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
The Charles bridge is one of the busiest spots in Prague because of its beautiful gothic structure and central location. If you wanna avoid the crowds, head over later in the day as it gets dark. But if you‚Äôre looking for a souvenir or a performance make sure you get there before 4 to see the street performers work their magic or buy a painted picture of the city‚Äôs scenery. For the best views on the Charles Bridge, take in a sunset view or climb the tower at the foot of the bridge for just 100 Czech crowns (around 5 U.S. dollars) for some beautiful views at the top.
The Prague castle is one of the most visited spots in Prague and it boasts incredible architecture at the top of a hill offering spectacular views. Head there on a weekday for less crowds. If you‚Äôre traveling on a budget you can get inside the back area for free, or pay a small fee to get closer up to the front and see the whole thing. To avoid walking up the big hill, take the tram up the hill and walk back down for the beautiful views.
This monastery has been named the most beautiful library in the world. Go just two tram stops beyond the Prague Castle for a chance to see the beautiful painted ceilings. The monastery does have a charge to go inside, as well as a small fee to be able to take pictures of the inside. Also note that you cannot go fully inside the rooms but can get a view beyond a roped off area.
The dancing house is a marvel of Czech modern cubist architecture along the Vlatva river. Take a tour of the museum and gallery or ride the elevator to the top floor for a restaurant and outdoor deck. Just order a drink or some food and get access to the outdoor viewing area with a 360 view. Fun fact: you can see 9 different bridges in the distance from the top of Dancing House!
For one of the most iconic Prague sights, head to Old Town Square and the astronomical clock tower. A huge crowd gathers as the time reaches the hour and people wait for the clock to change. Get there 15‚Äì20 minutes early for the best views. The clock also has an inside museum that gives you its history and lets you see the other side of the characters that pop out of the clock.
Wenceslas Square has been called the Times Square of Prague. It‚Äôs just a short walk from Old Town and named after the Czech Saint Wenceslas. It has a combo of shops and restaurants, with several traditional Czech restaurants as well as street food. Right in the heart of Wenceslas Square is also a bustling nightlife with a variety of clubs and bars that stay open late and attract large crowds. You can also hope to catch an outdoor food festival, held seasonally and offering street food like sausages and hot wine and beer.

Vienna, Slovakia, Budapest and Prague are very common tourist stops in the central Europe vacation circuit. The architecture has similar trends (some cities survived the World Wars better than others), their history is tied together by royal families, common wars and the development of governments as they stand today.
We really enjoyed our guide and the history lesson she shared on our walking tour in Prague. She explained they had three massive invasions in the last few decades: first, by the Germans who stripped their culture and language and replaced it with German. Second by the Soviets who drew the iron curtain for many years. And then most recently by tourists‚Ä¶ who have come to explore this relatively new country (it separated from Slovakia in 1993) and is still trying to solidify its routines for decades before.
We also learned a few shocking pieces of history‚Ä¶ Prague is actually one of the best preserved cities in Europe. Why you ask? Because Hitler wanted to retire in Prague. So he didn‚Äôt bomb it.
It was only bombed twice: once by the Americans by mistake (funny right?), who thought they were bombing Dresden in Germany. Both cities are super close, and I guess they just made the mistake. And then by the Nazis, two days before the end of the war. But not much was destroyed.
Another one that is even more grim ‚Äî Prague has the best preserved Jewish quarter in Europe. And that is because Hitler wanted to keep it as a museum of the extinct Jewish race. Yeah, pretty dark stuff.
Lots was absorbed here. We met some great people and hung out a few times during our stay as well as had the chance to watch the most crazy football match‚Ä¶ England vs. Croatia with a bar that had hundreds of UK fans!! A few thousand people in a biergarden outside, mostly intoxicated. Whenever a team would score a goal, beers were flying in the air. Full beers, I should mention. A 0.5L beer in Prague costs about 2$, so people are not too careful when they challenge gravity with it. We went back home covered in ale.

Sigmund Freud likes to hang around. üòâ Fun fact: this was a statue in memory of his crazy experiments, and caused a high call volume of 911 calls in the city as locals and tourists assumed it was a real person.
‚ÄúWhy don‚Äôt you Taj Mahal the shit out of it?‚Äù is what the Rolling Stones said when they decided to paid for the lights on the Prague Castle since at night in the 1990‚Äôs, since it had no lights on it until then.
The Summer Palace, and the astronomer who made discoveries from this location was killed by a blater infection‚Ä¶ as he was too nervous to go to the bathroom and leave his meal with the king‚Ä¶
England vs. Croatia semi-final game at a beer garden in Prague. All I can say is that UK fans are crazy‚Ä¶and a few beer showers were had.
