Title: Prague Land Ownership Mapping ‚Äî Unearthing the Foundations of Affordability Crisis
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

This blog series presents the results of the common investigation of Dark Matter Labs and the Institute of Human Rights and Business which seeks to explore the opportunities and barriers to just transition in the built environment through perspectives of urban land ownership.

--
1
Listen
Share
This blog post on urban land ownership in Prague is the 3rd article in the series. The collaboration between Dark Matter Labs and the Institute of Human Rights and Business (IHRB) resulted previously in mapping of Copenhagen and aims to continue its investigation further in Athens and Lisbon.
Through findings in this blog, we aim to question the importance of ownership data protection rules in the context of Europe‚Äôs rising costs of living crisis. The difficulty of access paralyses the research arena and informed public discourse on distribution of wealth and social responsibility (incl. involvement of journalists, academics, city administrations, etc.) further jeopardizing spatial justice. Ultimately, this hinders facilitation of adequate policy, law enforcement and action against exploitative practices such as property flipping, foreign investments, tax avoidance, money laundering and future responses to climate impacts.
Across Czechia, housing prices rose by more than 130% between 2015‚Äì2021 (Czech Statistical Office) and continue to do so. The average gross income, on the other hand, only grew by 40%. Today, an average Prague resident needs ca 14.3 average gross annual salaries to buy a 70 m2 new dwelling, making Prague one of the least affordable housing markets in the EU. These numbers are even more stark if net annual salaries are considered (see: Prices, Gross Incomes, Net Incomes) or if one looks at the actual current prices. Even when earning high salaries, Prague residents who do not own property have been priced out from access to housing, not to mention the more vulnerable groups.
Ownership mapping in Prague started with a conversation with the Cities for Rent: Investigating Corporate Landlords Across Europe project. This initiative, coordinated by the Arena for journalism in Europe, ‚Äúmarked the first step towards more cross-border collaborative research into the crisis of housing affordability and how it affects people‚Äôs lives‚Äù. Gaby Khazalov√°, winner of the European Press prize, investigated several issues including land ownership, data transparency, housing policy flaws, sale of municipal land or The hidden empire of the Tykaƒç family which controls over ca 350 short-term rental apartments in the centre of Prague and has linkages with tax havens (Cyprus, Bahamas and the Panama papers case). In her article, the author rightly points out that while the majority of attention in housing crisis debates focuses on the lack of apartments on the market for purchase or rent, ‚Äúwhat lies beneath‚Äù is the fundamental factor shaping our cities: i.e. land ownership. This hypothesis was also a starting point for the objectives of IHRB‚Äôs Building for Today and the future project.
In Prague, as in other cities, land ownership is foundational to this state of affairs, and issues around it guide the structure of this blog:
The State Administration of Surveying and Cadastre is the key source for Prague‚Äôs real estate data. The application makes it possible to obtain selected data on plots, buildings, units (apartments or non-residential premises) and building rights, registered in the real estate cadastre, as well as information on the status of proceedings for the purposes of registering ownership and other rights of authorised entities to real estate in Czechia, or for the purpose of confirming geometric plans.
Ownership data can be viewed for free plot by plot (CAPTCHA)
Viewing the real estate cadastre (CN) does not require any registration and is free. The application is intended exclusively for data viewing (plot by plot), as any acquisition or extraction of data by automated means is not allowed.
Core institutions have limited access
Our investigation revealed that the Institute of Planning and Development of the Capital City Prague (IPR Praha) ‚Äî Prague‚Äôs main policy-making unit for urban architecture, planning, development, design, and administration ‚Äî as well as the City of Prague itself only has partial access to the cadastral registry of land ownership.
This is because the cadastre aims to disseminate data for smaller areas, a common demand. Public entities have the privilege of accessing cadastral data pertaining to their administrative area at no cost, but its use is limited to public administration purposes and cannot be redistributed to third parties (IPR).
All about money?
We were informed by the cadastre office that the range and condition for CN data provision are ruled by the Decree Nr 358/2013 Coll. Large quantities of data can be acquired, with pricing per plot ranging between 50 Kƒç to 100 Kƒç (2‚Äì4 euro depending on level of information provided). For a dataset covering the entire city of Prague, we were quoted a figure of 931 928 Kƒç (ca. 38.200 EUR), a figure prohibitive for this project, but also for many researchers, journalists, and the general public.
Prevention against automated data harvesting methods is in place
As the State Administration of Surveying and Cadastre prohibits any form of automated data scraping we chose not to engage with this method. We, however, performed a test to what extent such an option would be technically possible. Our test revealed that data is hard to access this way, but that it is possible to check plot ownership one by one through this website. Example:
After solving CAPTCHA which aims to prevent scraping, a list of owners should appear ‚Äî in the example above we chose a site of Bubny Development.
We attempted to utilize the cadaster office‚Äôs API, developing a script with the Puppeteer JavaScript library. This script was designed to navigate the necessary webpage, complete the form, and interact with buttons. However, our progress was impeded once more due to the CAPTCHA. Even when attempting to use a headless browser to circumvent this challenge, the website failed to load without JavaScript enabled. In essence, it appears that intentional measures have been implemented to make accessing the data difficult.
With current machine learning methods, it is possible to overcome captcha, however, this method would enter clearly (dark) grey zone legal grounds.
Revealing Prague‚Äôs largest landowners is not an easy task. We leveraged a mix of GIS analysis, a manual check of the data register, literature review and interviews. As obtaining a whole data set for Prague is beyond the budget of the project, we were only able to scratch the surface and point to major actors in the city who are widely known to local researchers and journalists. This list includes the main developers of large-scale sites, particularly:
This map reveals further major urban developments.
Our investigation revealed that Prague‚Äôs largest type of landowners are:
This distribution shows that the City of Prague as well as the state still own substantial assets that, coupled with adequate policies, can be leveraged against the developments of the last decades which led to increasing unaffordability.
How much and what kind of land the city has with potential for the construction of residential housing is still not fully mapped. The contribution organization Pra≈æsk√° developersk√° spoleƒçnost, which is supposed to register vacant city plots and plan their development, has a certain overview. According to its representative Martin ƒåervinka, unlike many cities in the west, Prague has relatively enough land for the next few decades.
The Prague development company currently has land with the potential for the construction of six to eight thousand apartments. According to ƒåervinka, however, it can be estimated that the city may still have land for approximately another ten to twelve thousand apartments.
‚Äî Denik Referendum, (Gaby Khazal ‚Äî Urban Journalism Network)
‚Üí Explore the data above in HERE
You can filter it based on the type of owner, plot size and land use type. Some of the most interesting compositions are e.g. plots larger than 5000 sqm & owned by ‚ÄúRemaining domestic legal entities‚Äù ‚Äî this means companies. Several large parcels of land in this category are owned by real estate companies.
By hovering over a parcel you can then check who is the owner through this website (see also the Data Access and Methodology sections below).
The Institute of Planning and Development of the Capital City of Prague (IPR) estimates that the city needs 9,000 new apartments per year to fill the housing gap and accommodate the growing urban population, while another estimation calls for 20,000 to return prices to reasonable levels. However, the lack of supply and increased demand only tell part of the story.
As cheap mortgages were available for years, housing became a popular investment product resulting, for example, in ca 220,000 investment flats in Prague, mostly in the historical centre. Furthermore, some of the following factors helped push homes out of reach for many:
These policies have reinforced the emerging global narrative which depicts city authorities as powerless in the face of developers, but this myth can be debunked through recognition of a new set of capabilities within administrations.
Municipalities can recognize the power of ownership data and its usage as tools for regaining agency in city development.
As European real estate prices keep rising under the prevailing economic, taxation and housing policy regimes, many urban problems call for reforms around land ownership, its leverage power, and data transparency at the EU, national and city levels.
Lack of easily accessible ownership datasets of land ownership, human-business networks and real estate transactions creates a condition where speculation can happen behind the scenes, away from the civic eyes and sense-making capabilities. In an attempt to protect individuals, GDPR data protection rules end up hiding exploitative behaviours, for example by making it impossible to reveal linkages to tax havens, uneven accumulation of wealth through the ownership multiple apartments or land sites, shell companies, and more. As a consequence, the right to land, and housing are further undermined.
Unfortunately, the European Court of Justice recently declared that the public access of registers containing information about beneficial owners of businesses breaches the right to privacy. Consequently, not just Luxembourg but also the Netherlands has restricted access to the registry of real owners following the verdict. This further sets a precedent for other member states despite having been highlighted by Denik Referendum, journalists and experts as a significant regression in endeavours to enhance transparency and uncover unjust financial transactions.
In the Prague context, wide transparency and ease of access for all to land, real estate ownership, transaction and business register data would entail:
Current land registry systems are predominantly centralized with data maintained by the govenrmnet or a central authority making the system vulnerable to corruption, hacking, fraud, registration gaps. An update through a transformation of land registry to a blockchain database could alter the data governance framework and render beneficial effects. While benefits and dangers should be taken into consideration this idea has already numerous examples in practice (initiatives undertaken by governments in Republic of Georgia, Sweden, Ukraine, as well as Ghana, Brazil, Honduras, India and Japan).
All of this could play a key role in improving housing affordability by unlocking:
In this context, the current continuation of the aforementioned Cities for Rent initiative ‚Äî the Urban Journalism Network and its project Ground Control aims to gather investigative journalists from around Europe to address land ownership issues. These include, for now (links contain relevant articles) actors from:
Furthermore, the Institute of Human Rights and Business as well as Dark Matter Labs continue its missions around special justice and alternative modes of governance and ownership.
We hope that this growing network can not only spread awareness around issues of land ownership, spatial justice, and data transparency but also contribute to city, government and EU and policy change. Any kind of paradigm shift allowing for a halt to rising costs of living requires strengthening of these networks through collaboration, funding, increased capacities as well as engagement, creativity and recognition of agency by the city and state authorities.
First, through spatial data analysis process our team manged to obtain a map which allows for more targeted search via the Cadaster platform.

The first light of dawn slips through the curtains of our hotel room. I glance over at my girlfriend, already awake, her eyes tracing the soft glow filtering in. Neither of us know why we‚Äôre up so early. It‚Äôs not jet lag or the faint hum of the city outside. So maybe, it‚Äôs the anticipation of wanting to see a side of Prague that most visitors miss.
We step outside into the cool morning air. The cobblestones feel damp beneath our feet. Street lamps cast soft halos in the mist, and somewhere in the distance, a bird begins to sing. The city feels quiet, almost like it‚Äôs waiting for something to happen.
We turn the corner together and spot the Old Town Hall. Its underground played a pivotal role in the Prague Uprising against Nazism. Attached to it is the Astronomical Clock, a medieval wonder that shows the positions of the Sun, Moon, Earth, and Zodiac constellations.
Humanity has tried to measure time for millennia. From the Maya in Mesoamerica to Mesolithic hunter-gatherers in the UK‚Ä¶

Title: A buttload of things to know if you‚Äôre visiting Prague
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Going to Prague? Get ready for your Czech vacation with these tips.
Some of these things are common around Europe; some are specific to Prague. I‚Äôve lived in Prague for over a year. Since I‚Äôve only lived in Prague, I‚Äôll just say you should know these for the Czech Republic, and I won‚Äôt speak for elsewhere.
Prague is separated into sections by numbers, which will often be referred to in addresses or directions. If you‚Äôre a visitor, you‚Äôll most likely spend your time around Prague 1 and Prague 2, which host quintessential Prague sightseeing.
Most buildings addresses in the Czech Republic have two numbers. For example, my former apartment‚Äôs building number was 535/2. The building in this picture would have the number 800/50. Both these numbers will appear on placards outside each building, though sometimes only one number will be listed on an address. Knowing this may make navigating a little less confusing.
Going back to the example of my old apartment, the full address was Kubova 535/2. The street name, Kubova, is listed before the numbers, as is the norm with Czech address conventions. In the US, a street may be something like 123 Smith St. In the Czech Republic, that would look something like Smith 123/1.
Public transport is the best and cheapest way to get around Prague. While Prague is a very walkable city, knowing how to navigate its public transport is crucial. Let‚Äôs make sure you know how to do it.
To legally use public transport in the Czech Republic, you need to both buy and validate your ticket near the start of your journey. Purchase will always happen before entry. Validation will happen before entry for metro, and on entry for buses and trams. If you don‚Äôt understand, don‚Äôt worry. Everything is explained below.
First thing to know: all public transport tickets are the same for Prague‚Äôs metros, buses, and trams. You don‚Äôt need to buy separate tickets for each.
To purchase tickets, look for a ticket machine. Most ticket machines will look like this:
This older style of machine accepts:
They also have a newer style that looks like this, or a variation of this, but are much rarer:
This newer style of machine accepts:
To buy a ticket, hit the button next to the ticket you want, put your payment method in, and the ticket will subsequently be printed for you.
These ticket machines can be found in all metro stations and the airport. Frustratingly, most bus stops and tram stops don‚Äôt have them. If you can‚Äôt find a machine near a stop, look for the nearest tobacco shop, as they always carry tickets.
Tickets are separated by lengths of time and zones. For a regular tourist, as long as you‚Äôre staying within the main parts of Prague (which is almost everyone), you don‚Äôt need to worry about zone. Only pick a ticket based on how long you plan to spend traveling that day.
The most common ticket lengths are:
You can also text to purchase a ticket if you have a valid Czech phone number through O2, T-mobile, or Vodafone (local Czech carriers). If you want to use this method but don‚Äôt have a Prague phone plan, you can pick up a SIM card at almost any Czech corner store or phone carrier store. Note: please don‚Äôt buy a phone ticket until you need it as these tickets can‚Äôt be saved for later ‚Äî they don‚Äôt require validation and are active immediately after confirmation of purchase.
Once you‚Äôve successfully purchased your ticket, you‚Äôll also have to validate the ticket.
To understand the difference between purchase and validation, first you have to recognize that Czech tickets are time-based, meaning you can buy a ticket that lasts for a specific amount of time, say 90 minutes. The purchase of the ticket gives you the right to ride for 90 minutes, during any 90-minutes. Validation indicates the start/end time of that 90-minute window.
Validation machines look like this:
To validate, insert the ticket into the slot indicated by the arrow on the validator. Push the ticket in until you feel a punch on the ticket. The punch will display the starting time and date for the validity of your ticket. You are authorized to ride from the time that you purchase + the duration of the ticket you bought.
Validators are found in the metro station, near the area where you enter the station. You must validate your ticket upon entry to the station; you cannot validate a ticket after you‚Äôve boarded a train. Validators for trams and buses, however, are found inside the vehicles themselves. You can only validate tram and bus tickets after entry.
If you purchased your ticket via phone, you do not need to validate it. The timing for the phone ticket starts when you receive confirmation for your purchase. Because of this, make sure not to buy a phone ticket before you need it!
You have the right to ride the transport for the duration your ticket indicates starting from the time you validate. If you‚Äôve already validated your paper ticket and are going to ride another leg of public transport while it‚Äôs still valid, you do not need to validate again (how many times did I just said valid?). You can also switch public transport types during this time, which means you can walk off the metro and onto a tram. As long as your ticket is valid, you don‚Äôt have to do anything during this switch.
Remember: a Czech public transport ticket is not valid unless it‚Äôs validated!
Please note you must buy a separate ticket for a large piece of luggage. To do this on a coin machine, press the discount ticket button (a separate button on the machine) before pressing the time duration you want. On the newer machines, discounted tickets should be an option you navigate to on the touch menu. This discounted ticket legally lets you carry the luggage on public transport.
These discounted fares can also be used on tickets for seniors, between 65‚Äì70 years old, and children aged 6‚Äì15. Riders older than 70 and riders younger than 6 do not have to pay fare.
A detailed breakdown of fares and costs can be found here.
In my research for this article, I stumbled across a Prague multi-day tourist pass that pre-pays for public transport and attractions. I haven‚Äôt used it, so I can‚Äôt vouch for its value, but I wanted to throw it out there as an FYI. More info here.
Fare is enforced inconsistently and randomly. If you‚Äôre entering the metro station or if you‚Äôre actively riding the tram or bus, you may be approached by a fare enforcer. These are uniformed transport employees (though sometimes they dress like a normal person to go undercover) who ask to see your public transport ticket. They will show a badge to identify themselves in all cases.
If your fare is valid, they will let you go. If it‚Äôs not, you will be charged 800 crowns (~$40). Fare will rarely be checked, but the fine is hefty if you get caught without it.
If you are caught without fare, you will get a written notice and will immediately pay the entirety of the fine.
In the US, public transport doors will usually open automatically at every stop or at the discretion of an operator. This is not the case in Europe. Many times, riders have to physically press a button to open public transport doors. If a train, tram, or bus has come to a complete stop and the doors aren‚Äôt opening, look for a button on or near the door to let yourself on.
If you‚Äôre using escalators to get on/off public transport, or literally anywhere else in Prague, always always always stand on the right side and make sure you‚Äôre not blocking the left side. Right is for standing, left is for walking. People will be sour if you don‚Äôt follow this norm and block the path.
Totally! And it‚Äôs actually pretty cheap. I‚Äôve used it more times than I like to admit. Regardless, you can definitely use Uber here, but you‚Äôll look like a tourist. There‚Äôs also an Uber competitor called Taxify that‚Äôs worth checking out if you‚Äôre into ridesharing.
Czechs can‚Äôt stand the sound of sniffling. People will get annoyed with you for sniffling in public. Instead, Czechs almost always carry around travel-sized tissue packets and constantly blow their noses. This brings me to my next point‚Ä¶
Literally everywhere. Sitting right next to you on the train? They‚Äôll blow their noses. In conversation? They‚Äôll blow their noses. While eating? They‚Äôll blow their noses. Americans consider this pretty gross. It took me a while to get used to the constant nose blowing and seeming obliviousness to American norms around this. Now that I‚Äôm used to it, it makes hanging out with people while you‚Äôre suffering with a cold a lot more manageable, albeit still unsightly.
This one‚Äôs a little bit of a stereotype, but Czechs love wearing socks and sandals. I will admit that anecdotally, I‚Äôve seen way more sock + sandal combinations here than anywhere else, and I studied engineering. Luckily, looks like it‚Äôs fashionable now?
You‚Äôll see these all over Prague. Czechs love putting them on their backpacks and baby strollers. They‚Äôre *everywhere*.
You‚Äôll also see these all over Prague. I have no idea why.
Czechs have a habit of staring intensely into each other‚Äôs eyes while toasting over drinks. It‚Äôs very disconcerting.
Americans think Europeans‚Äô habit of a kiss on each cheek in greeting is invasive. Europeans, in turn, think pressing bodies against each other (aka hugging) in greeting is weird. Get used to lightly kissing people if you want to move here.
When Czechs enter or exit elevators or waiting rooms, they say hello and goodbye, respectively. For example, if you get called into the doctor‚Äôs office after sitting in the waiting room, you‚Äôre supposed to say a soft goodbye to the room. When you get on an elevator, you say hello to the other riders. It‚Äôs a really weird thing from an American standpoint, but here I‚Äôm pretty sure I come off very cold because I usually forget to do this.
Czechs do not wear shoes in their homes. Nearly every home or apartment will have an entryway in the beginning where you‚Äôre expected to take your shoes off. If you want to keep them on in the home for any reason, make sure to ask the host for permission first.
The Czech Republic‚Äôs national language is, well, Czech. It‚Äôs part of the Slavic language family and is similar to other languages you‚Äôre probably not super familiar with, like Polish and Slovak. To get a sense of what Czech sounds like, here‚Äôs a video of Let It Go in Czech.
In Prague, absolutely not. I know people who live here that have decided not to learn Czech; it‚Äôs that easy to get around with English. You‚Äôll also find a lot of people who speak Russian and German. The options are (figuratively) endless.
If you leave Prague and head out to the countryside, though, be prepared to have a lot more trouble with the language barrier.
Hello: dobry denYes: anoNo: neThank you: dekuji (pronounced dee-yeh-koo-yee)Please: prosim
The Czech word for ‚Äúyes‚Äù is ano, which often gets shortened to no. So in the Czech Republic, if someone says no, they might really mean yes. Be prepared to be confused.
Fakt jo in Czech, pronounced facked yo, sounds a lot like, well‚Ä¶ you get it. In Czech it‚Äôs a phrase for ‚Äúreally?‚Äù So don‚Äôt worry, you‚Äôre not hearing Czechs yell expletives at each other, just asking for clarification. If you want to know when they‚Äôre swearing at each other, the word you‚Äôre listening for is prdel (pronounced pruh-dell).
As a courtesy, a lot of places will have menus in English. Those English menus, however, are often riddled with mistranslations. I‚Äôve seen dishes that were supposed to be vegetarian come out with meat on them because the translation was wrong (something about mixing up the word peppers with peppered sausage). Below is an image of my personal favorite.
In English, if you want to offer someone a drink, you say ‚ÄúWould you like some tea?‚Äù In the Czech language, the same phrase is structured as ‚ÄúWouldn‚Äôt you like some tea?‚Äù
When Czechs speak English, it‚Äôs common for them to say ‚Äúdon‚Äôt you want‚Äù instead of ‚Äúdo you want,‚Äù because that‚Äôs how it‚Äôs said in their native tongue. Knowing this fosters understanding, because getting asked a question the Czech way sounds imposing and rude to Americans. For me, it took a sec to recover from my doctor asking me ‚ÄúDidn‚Äôt you gain some weight?‚Äù
Though not formally an English-speaking city, Prague has lots of signs in English. They do write things slightly differently than we would, so here‚Äôs some phrases you should know:
Czechs use a denomination called a crown. At the time of this writing, 1 US dollar = ~20 crowns.
When given a number in crowns, the easiest way to roughly convert in your head is to move the decimal point to the left by one place, then divide by 2.
So if your bill is 350 crowns, moving the decimal place to the left by one place gives you 35, divide by 2 gives you 17.5. So 350 crowns = ~$17.50.
In the US, dates are written as MM/DD/YYYY. In other parts of the world, it‚Äôs normal to write DD/MM/YYYY. So if you see 08/12/2018, that‚Äôs December 8th in Europe, not August 12th. You‚Äôve been warned.
In the US, we use periods to separate whole numbers from fractions of numbers. $5.10 means ‚Äúfive dollars and one-tenth of a dollar.‚Äù In Europe, they‚Äôd write the same number as 5,10 crowns.
For a larger number, we‚Äôd write something like $1,000.34. In Prague, they‚Äôll use spaces instead of commas and commas instead of periods. So the same number on your bill at a restaurant may look like 1 000,34 crowns (that‚Äôs about $50).
Weirdly enough, they‚Äôll sometimes write ‚Äúcents‚Äù on a bill or transaction, even though the smallest monetary denomination Prague has is a 1 crown coin.
Get ready to think hard every time you have to use numbers.
In casual conversations, Czechs stick to the same time scale Americans do ‚Äî saying a time between 1 and 12.
In more formal communications, however, times are often communicated using military time. If you make a dinner reservation, you can call and ask for seating at 20:00. A concert may start at 19:00. Your doctor appointment is at 13:45. Czechs do not use AM and PM. Get used to reading and understanding these numbers.
Americans count on their hands starting with the pointer finger as 1. Europeans use their thumbs as 1. This means that counting to 2 on your fingers looks like a peace sign in the US, but like a finger ‚ÄòL‚Äô for Europeans.
Americans use quotation marks that look like ‚Äúthis.‚Äù Czechs use ones that look like ‚Äûthis.‚Äù
American phone numbers have 10 digits ‚Äî like (012) 345‚Äì6789. Czech phones numbers have 9‚Äì for ex. 123 456 789. As a note, the Czech country code is +420, so your entire phone number may be +420 123 456 789.
Czechs and Americans have different keyboard layouts for typing. The biggest change is that Czechs and Americans switch the places of the y and z keys on their keyboards. If you use a public computer, be prepared for immense frustration. Muscle memory is real, folks.
Czech apartment buildings don‚Äôt leave building hallway lights on, as is common in the US. They also don‚Äôt typically use automatic sensors. Instead, Czech hallways are often lined with timed light switches that you press when you enter the building. They will also be placed on every floor in the building so you can hit them as you leave your apartment. After a few nights of blindly stumbling around dark stairwells, identifying the light switch is a godsend.
On a personal note, I was too afraid to touch these when I moved here, thinking they were someone‚Äôs doorbell or that I would flood the apartments with light. Learn from my mistakes ‚Äî it‚Äôs okay to press them.
Similar to the light switches, some main building doors have physical buttons that you need to press to exit. If you find yourself stupidly shoving a stubborn door, take a step back and check for an exit switch next to it.
While smoke detectors are required in basically every building in the US, they are rarely required or enforced in Czech buildings. My apartment, for example, had no smoke alarms equipped. Know this beforehand as it can be scary if you‚Äôre expecting them and they‚Äôre not there.
In the Czech Republic, you don‚Äôt have to tip, but people usually do a little (This is not true if the receipt or server indicates service is not included. In that case, see my next paragraph). The typical rule is that you loosely round up. For example, if your meal was 136 crowns, round up to 150 when you pay. If you had really great service, a tip of up to 10% is standard. Paying just for the food is fine, however, as service is built into the price.
Though not common, some places will not include service in the bill. If this happens, the receipt will indicate it. This usually only occurs in tourist areas. At that point, paying 10% would be typical.
If you tip in cash, which is always preferred, it‚Äôs standard to give the tip to the service provider directly. Leaving the tip on the table is not common practice here.
If you tip by card, you have to tell them the amount before they swipe your card. You never specify a tip on a receipt. You will always pay meal and tip together in one transaction.
If you indicate you want to pay by card, the servers will bring out a card terminal to you. You‚Äôll then pay by card at your table.
Alternatively, they may ask you to walk with them to a register where you pay. They will never take your card and walk off. As another quirk, when ready to pay, patrons will sometimes pre-emptively walk up to the cash registers, even in a sit-down place, and wait for a host or waiter to check them out. This is faster and expected, not rude or out of place.
Further, credit card technology is different in Europe. While chip payments are the new, gold standard in the US, Europe is one step ahead with contactless payments being the norm. These are payments powered by near-field communication chips, like the stuff used in Apple or Android pay on your phone. To pay with Czech bank cards, just tap your card near a terminal and your payment will be accepted. Since you probably don‚Äôt have a Czech bank card, all this means for you is that the waiters will often fumble around with a chip payment, not have a pen on them for signing a receipt, and will ask you if your card is contactless (it‚Äôs probably not). Hopefully knowing this will lend you some patience, help you not answer ‚Äúhuh?‚Äù to the contactless question, and make you wonder why American banks are so behind.
Of note also is that Europeans pay almost exclusively with debit cards; credit cards are not nearly as common, though establishments will still accept them.
If you pay in cash, waiters will usually also start and finish the transaction at your table. They‚Äôll bring a large wallet filled with bills, at which point they‚Äôll take your cash and give change at the table.
Europe does not always cater kindly to separate checks. In the Czech Republic, often they will ask what you had and do the math right in front of you on paper to separate a bill before asking each party to pay their portion. Splitting individual items is rarely possible. The wait staff may get salty if you try to ask for complicated bill splittings.
In the US, reservations are typically only made for fancy restaurants, crowded restaurants, for large parties, or for special occasions. If you show up without a reservation, you put your name on a list and wait until you get seated.
The Czech Republic is different. In the Czech Republic, even casual restaurants take reservations. Any place, casual or not, will almost certainly be full on Fridays or Saturdays, just like the US, but Czech restaurants won‚Äôt have a wait out the door. If you don‚Äôt have a reservation and they‚Äôre full, they‚Äôll turn you away. Even seemingly empty restaurants will sometimes tell you they‚Äôre full, as a whole bunch of reservations are about to show up and the place is consistently booked throughout the evening.
If you want to have a place to eat, especially a good one, call ahead and make a reservation.
It‚Äôs common for Czech restaurants to have shared coat stands, like a coat rack or closet. When I dine with my European friends, they‚Äôll often look for the coat rack and hang up their belongings next to strangers‚Äô things. This is uncommon in the US where we just throw our coats behind our chairs. I tend not to participate as I‚Äôm slightly skeptical of leaving my belongings unattended and because I will forget my coat literally every time I eat.
To non-Americans, American service staff seem disingenuous, disconcertingly friendly, and over-attentive. This is because American staff aren‚Äôt paid a living wage and depend on tips for their salary. This crazy attentive service is necessary for wait staff to dream of maintaining a standard salary and is expected by American restaurant-goers.
In Europe, the pace of restaurants is slower. Waiters are paid a working wage and aren‚Äôt dependent on tips, however much they‚Äôre appreciated. If you want a waiter‚Äôs attention, you often have to catch their eye and wave them over, as they won‚Äôt be visiting at a regular pace. When you‚Äôre done with your meal, you again have to gesture for them; they won‚Äôt be looking to swing by as soon as you‚Äôre finished. To Americans, this wait service can seem apathetic and rude.
European waiters on the whole don‚Äôt have the sticky-sweet American demeanor, but Czechs take that to a whole new level. Czech wait staff are, on a good day, uninterested. On a bad day they are downright hostile.
Personally, the disengaged and often rude service staff in the Czech Republic are one of the reasons I don‚Äôt want to stay here long-term. I miss American friendliness, however shallow, like crazy.
If you‚Äôd like a take-out box after your meal, you will be charged a small fee for the box and bag.
If you pay with an American card, you‚Äôll be prompted during purchase on if you‚Äôd like to pay in crowns or USD. The guidance I‚Äôve heard is that you‚Äôll usually get a better exchange rate if you pay in the local currency. I suggest that.
Don‚Äôt let this stock image fool you. On the whole, Czech food is very bland, with a heavy emphasis on carbs and meat. There are almost no fruits or vegetables in Czech specialties. Just a lot of meat, a lot of gravy, and a lot of bread.
Dumplings are everywhere in the Czech Republic, which I was super excited about when I moved here. Turns out, dumplings here aren‚Äôt like Asian dumplings or even Polish dumplings. They‚Äôre not steamed or fried, and they don‚Äôt have any filling. They‚Äôre basically just cylinders of white bread. #disappointed
Czechs love their pate (pronounced pah-tay), which is a raw, minced-beef dish, usually served as an appetizer. You‚Äôll see this all over the place. I may have tried it once but honestly it puts me off a little, so I can‚Äôt speak much to its taste. I have had the salmon pate, however, and that was pretty good (in my head I convinced myself it was sushi).
Not specifically Czech but found everywhere. It‚Äôs chunks of beef and pork smothered in dark gravy.
They turn their goulash dish into a soup as well! Found on menus everywhere.
A mixture of a light broth, potatoes, onions, and‚Ä¶ garlic.
Do you like mozzarella sticks? Then you‚Äôll love the Czech main course of fried cheese. Hold the marina sauce, though. Czechs usually serve this with some variation of tartar sauce.
This dish has nothing to do with birds, but is yet another pork dish with dumplings and gravy.
Maybe because they‚Äôre so close to Germany, Czechs have pickled cabbage all over the menu. They have two kinds: a sweeter red variety and a more sour white cabbage.
Czechs‚Äô own version of Cola! It can come in a variety of odd flavors too, for example, melon.
Yet another meat + gravy +dumplings dish. This one, however, comes with a twist. They serve it with a citrus slice on top (usually lemon or orange), and cover that citrus slice with cranberries and whipped cream. They also sometimes bake cranberries into the dumplings on this dish as well. I‚Äôm not a believer in combining sweet with meat dishes, so I find this dreadful. Worth a shot if you‚Äôre looking for a true Czech meal though.
Two quintessential beers to try in the Czech Republic. I‚Äôm not a beer person, so please take my advice here with a grain of salt.
Czechs love eating duck, so be prepared to see it on menus galore.
Czech open-faced sandwiches that come with a variety of toppings.
Not historically Czech but delicious nonetheless. This is a pastry, crunchy on the outside, soft in the middle. Dough is coated in a mixture of cinnamon, sugar, vanilla, and a bunch of other flavors, then slow roasted to perfection. You can also choose the filling of your choice ‚Äî chocolate, nutella, vanilla custard, ice cream ‚Äî and enjoy!
Lemonade is on Czech menus galore. That said, it‚Äôs not American lemonade. American lemonade is water, sugar, and lemon flavoring. Czech lemonade is carbonated water, and a light flavoring that needs to be specified and isn‚Äôt necessarily lemon. Think of it more like a light, flavored soda. Czech lemonades will often come in a long list of flavors. Some common ones are raspberry, cucumber, and ginger. Some places may even have lemonade on the menu but not lemon-flavored lemonade. Watch out!
I don‚Äôt know if this is a Czech thing or if I‚Äôve just had bad luck, but the few times I‚Äôve ordered milkshakes in the Czech Republic, they‚Äôve been the temperature and consistency of chocolate milk. I don‚Äôt know if Czechs believe in putting ice cream in milkshakes. Beware.
If you decide to visit a McDonald‚Äôs here, note that there is no ranch dressing, and most of your beloved favorite sauces aren‚Äôt there, either. The sauce menu will be different, and so will the main courses. Some standards, like fries and nuggets, remain, but the Czech menu also includes localized items like a fried camembert sandwich (camembert is a popular cheese in the Czech Republic). European McDonald‚Äôs also tend to have a much richer dessert section, including pastries, like croissants. Visiting McDonald's in different parts of the world is a treat to see how the menu is localized. Czech McDonald‚Äôs official site and menu are here.
You often see this on the menu. This is just a European word for arugula.
In America, pepperoni is a thinly-sliced sausage. In Italy and other places in Europe, pepperoni pizza means a pizza covered in bell peppers. In the Czech Republic specifically, pepperoni can sometimes mean either one. If you‚Äôre going to order pepperoni pizza, be careful to clarify which one you‚Äôre getting. If, at a place you‚Äôre visiting, pepperoni means a pizza covered in bell peppers and you want the American pepperoni pizza, look for one that has salami.
If you see pancakes written on a menu, they actually mean what Americans think of as crepes. If you want real, IHOP-style pancakes, look for American pancakes, though they are not very common in Prague.
There‚Äôs a European law that what‚Äôs written on the menu is what you pay. This means that the written price already includes tax and tip, so there will be no surprises when you pay your bill.
Beer is literally cheaper than water in the Czech Republic, which is part of the reasons tourists love it here. Remember that water is almost never free in the Czech Republic.
While smoking hasn‚Äôt been common in US restaurants in decades, Czechs can still smoke while seated outside. Smoking inside of Czech restaurants was only abolished in the last few years, and some Czechs think even that is too strict.
Americans love ice water more than Europeans, but Czechs in particular don‚Äôt like any sort of cold drink. I‚Äôve seen Cokes served warm, and waiters will almost never serve ice by default. As a non-beer drinker I‚Äôm not sure how the beer is served, but honestly I wouldn‚Äôt be surprised if it was warm.
For whatever reason, Czechs call potato wedges American potatoes.
In Europe, eating fries with ketchup is replaced by the default of eating fries with mayonnaise. Don‚Äôt ask me.
In the US, you either get a coke in a bottle (rare at a restaurant), or coke in a glass, but never both. In Prague, they always serve glass-bottle sodas alongside a glass. This is true for any soda and even water, which is almost never free and always comes in bottles.
This name means two different candies in the Czech Republic vs the US!
If you haven‚Äôt traveled abroad before, you should know that outlets look different in different parts of the world. You‚Äôll need an international adapter for whatever country you‚Äôre going to, to make your plugs compatible with the other country‚Äôs wall outlets. If you‚Äôre traveling with friends, bring extras, because a lot of people don‚Äôt know this. Skyscanner has a great list of which adapters work in each country. Note that these most basic ones don‚Äôt convert anything electrically, they just make the outlet shapes physically compatible.
If you‚Äôre going to use anything that requires a lot of power from the wall, you‚Äôll also need a converter, which converts European power output to something needier American electronics can handle. You‚Äôll need this for things like hair dryers and hair straighteners.
This article is a handy guide for when to use adapters vs converters vs transformers (transformers are covered in an upcoming article, on what to know for moving to Prague).
For reference, Prague outlets look like this:
For any more information, the gold standard is the YouTube channel Honest Guide, an effort run by two local Czechs who go into detail about everything you need to know about Prague. This includes trustworthy places to exchange money, what Czech food is like, major attractions: everything. Czech üëèüèª them üëèüèª out üëèüèª.
Good luck with your Prague trip planning and enjoy your time in the beautiful Czech Republic!

My Guide in the Czech Republic (main part Prague)
In this article, I am going to answer the FAQ about Prague and give you some tips about the city.
I have been living in the city for 4 years and whenever I go for a walk in the old town, I feel like it is my first time visiting the city. That‚Äôs why I decided to work as a tour guide for a while. I don‚Äôt do it anymore, except private tours from time to time.
So, let Is go through the things that you want to know before coming to the Magical City.
*I will recommend videos to watch or website(s) to visit in each section, some of the videos may don‚Äôt have accurate information such as exchange rate but the information is useful no matter when you come to Prague ;)
The Czech Republic is not in the eurozone, the official currency of the Czech Republic is the Czech crown (Kƒç/ in English CZK). 1 euro is around 25CZK. You will find a link to the Czech National Bank and to a website with the best exchange point in Prague in the end of this section.
Coins: 1, 2, 5, 10, 20 and 50 CZK * All the coins are useful (not the case with euros ‚Äî 1cent, 2cent, 5cent) Banknotes: 100, 200, 500, 1000, 2000 and 5000 CZK
*You should avoid the 2000 and 5000 banknotes for small purchases.
Although CZK is the official currency in the Czech Republic, you still can pay by Euro almost everywhere specially in Prague. However, you will not get the best exchange rate except in the international chains (supermarkets, coffee chains, fast-food chains, ‚Ä¶).
Czech National Bank
How to exchange money by (Honest Guide)
Prague without cash by (Honest Guide)
Public transport is efficient in Prague in a way that you don‚Äôt need a rental car or taxis. Actually, it is cheaper and faster xD. There are 3 lines of Metro, 10s of tramways, and 100s of buses.
The tickets for a single trip are for 30 minutes (for 24czk) or 90 minutes (for 32czk). The daily ticket (24h) is for 110czk and if you are here for 3 days (72h) your ticket costs 310czk.
*If you are willing to stay more than 5 days, I recommend buying a monthly ticket for 570czk
For more details check these videos:
How to buy a ticket (Honest Guide)
Travelling around the city (Honest Guide)
Prague Public Transport at Night (Honest Guide)
How to get from Prague‚Äôs airport to the city center (Honest Guide)
GOING TO PRAGUE BY TRAIN OR BUS (Honest Guide)
To find transport connection, check out this website (they have also mobile app) www.idos.cz
To rent bikes use Rekola, but you will need a credit card to use the app.
You can use Uber and yeah it is possible to pay by cash or taxi companies like Tick Tack, Nejlevnƒõj≈°√≠ Taxi or MODR√ù ANDƒöL (if you went out with your car and end up drinking beers with your friends, they can give you a ride for you and your car xD at night).
*Ride for the airport to the city center should cost you around 500czk (20 euro), be careful from scams.
You have many options such as Hotels, Hostels, Airbnb, apartments, etc. I am going to describe the different areas by character so that it helps you choosing the right place.
Old town : you won‚Äôt need transportation since everything is close to you. However, a lot of going on around and there is a big possibility that you won‚Äôt have a calm night.
Lesser town (mal√° strana) : It is near the castle, Charles Bridge and many beautiful parks. You will need transportation and there are almost no supermarkets nearby (most of the prices are for tourists).
New Town : A great neighborhood, restaurants and caf√©s are excellent in the area. Most of your neighbors are tourists, those who hurry up are called the locals. You will need transportation and fortunately there are two metro stations in the area and many tramways pass by that zone.
The rest of the areas are cheaper, calmer (exception: ≈Ωi≈ækov) and most of the residents are locals, so you won‚Äôt be scammed.
During my work as a tour guide, I met tens of people who planned their stay in Prague just one day or two days and double of that period in Budapest (sometimes more time for Bratislava than Prague :D). I think you know what I am going to say by now. Minimum days to spend in Prague should be 3 or 4 days. If you want to enjoy the city and yourself, one week to 10 days.
Plan A ‚Äî 3 days:
You should not enter every monument/museum in your way. Consider taking transportation so that you won‚Äôt be tired by the end of the day.
Plan B ‚Äî royal stay:
Life is good, you have enough time to visit the main monuments, party, enjoy the traditional Czech cuisine and save energy for the next city/country.
Plan Z ‚Äî Underestimated city / just 1 night or even less
You can start by Prague Castle (don‚Äôt spend more than 60 -90 minutes in that area)than follow the Royal way (Coronation route). Next stop will be Charles Bridge that will lead you to the old Town Square. You should be tired by now from walking, so reward yourself by a hot coffee in Skautsk√Ω Institut or another place (avoid the coffees in the square if you don‚Äôt want to be scammed) .
You should have enough time to enjoy a traditional dish. Later on, go to Wenceslas Square.
*This can be done the other way around (from Wenceslas Square to the Castle, but I recommend the first direction because Prague Castle in on the top of the Hill).
COOLEST DISTRICT in PRAGUE (Honest Guide)
1000czk without accommodation is fair enough. I will tell you why :
Transport: 110czk for 24h
Food: 600czk (150‚Äì200 per meal)
Coffee&cake: 150czk (coffee for 50czk, cake for 100czk)
The rest can be used for entrance to museum (sometimes it will cost you 250 czk, but generally around 150czk or less)
The list is so long, you should make your priorities. If you like museums, Prague offers museum for any kind of thing (Torture, toys, chocolate, Lego, Apple Inc.,). You love outdoors?.. well Prague offers that too, but if you can‚Äôt stand cold weather, you should visit the City during Spring or Summer Season.
The must visit list that I recommend is the following:
Charles Bridge, Prague Castle, Old Town Square, Prague Zoo, Wenceslas square, National museum, etc.
However, those are the typical ones, there are other monuments and places to visit. Check out the following videos:
PRAGUE CASTLE (Honest Guide)
10 BEST INSTAGRAM SPOTS IN PRAGUE (Honest Guide)
MUST SEE HIDDEN GEM IN THE HEART OF PRAGUE (Honest Guide)
SECRET PLACES IN PRAGUE (Honest Guide)
The traditional Czech cuisine is so authentic. The food is heavy, tasty and not healthy :D Main ingredients are meat (mainly pork), potatoes, cabbage and flour. So, don‚Äôt expect salads or vegetarian food.
The best thing that you will enjoy, in the Czech Republic, are snacks and cakes.
I recommend reading this article:
https://www.tasteofprague.com/pragueblog/traditional-czech-food-in-prague-what-to-have-and-where-to-have-it
Here is also a playlist of videos from Honest Guide that I recommend to watch (included vegetarian restaurants):
Restaurants in Prague (Honest Guide)
Safety:
The City is safe and secure, but be careful in the crowded areas. There are no ghettos or not recommended areas. The Czech Republic is one of the safest countries in the world üòä.
Halal food:
There are some restaurants that offer halal food. Most of them are near to the city center. Here is a list of the restaurants, I will try to cover all the areas in Prague:
Mangal Restaurant is located in the Wenceslas square. Address: V√°clavsk√© n√°mƒõst√≠ 64, Praha
Barakat is near the mosque of the center. Address: Opletalova 28, Praha
Istanbul Kebab is also near the mosque of the center, less than 100 meters from Barakat. Address: Politick√Ωch vƒõz≈à≈Ø, 17, Praha
Jordan Restaurant in the lesser town (mala strana). So, if you are hungry and you still near the castle this should be your destination. Address: Malostransk√© n√°mƒõst√≠ 36/22, Praha
Saf√≠r is a good Lebanese restaurant. You can find it in different malls (OC Nov√Ω Sm√≠chov, Ark√°dy Pankr√°c, OC DBK ‚Äî Budƒõjovick√° , OC Chodov) * OC stands for Commercial Center. Here is their website http://www.isafir.cz , but it is not updated.
*if you are so into halal things, you should go 100% vegan in this country or buy expensive food from bio supermarkets/restaurants.
Different products use pork gelatin or other extracted products from pork. These products can be yogurt, sweet bakery (even croissant), etc.
If you want to have bolognaise or burger with mashed beef meat, make sure that is not mixed with pork (in non halal places).
Mosques:
Mosque of the center: Opletalova 930/28, 110 00 Praha 1 (be advised, it is located inside a building)
Mosque Alfirdaus : Na Ko≈°ince 502/1, 180 00 Praha 8-Libe≈à
Mosque of ƒåern√Ω Most: Blatsk√° 1491, 198 00 Praha 9
Other tips:
Keep in mind that the Czech Republic is in the CENTER of Europe and not in the East. Also avoid saying Czechia, no one like it.

Title: Why Prague Shines
Content:
Sign up

Sign up
Sign in

--
3
Listen
Share
I suspect that on a clear day, when seen from the moon, Prague glitters like a sparkler. It seems like every Old-World store window gleams with crystal: bowls, bottles, bells, boxes, baskets, trays, vases, ladles, plates, jugs, wine glasses, brandy snifters, beer steins, cups and saucers, napkin holders, atomizers, and assorted tchotchkes.
All that glitter sparked an idea: Buy a chandelier.
Did it matter that all I had to carry souvenirs in was a daypack? That crystal chandeliers are made of hundreds of pieces of fragile and weighty glass? That I was already carrying 18 traditional, hand-painted, blown Czech Easter eggs?
No, it didn‚Äôt matter because my husband and I had just bought a charming Victorian house in San Francisco. The showpiece dining room featured a 10-foot-high ceiling, embossed wainscoting, a bay window, a built-in Victorian hutch, an antique dining table, and, suspended down from the flowery ceiling-rose disk in the middle of the dining room: an out-of-place, two-foot-diameter, Japanese paper lantern that looked like a glowing, white beach ball.
We needed a crystal chandelier.
But we were house-poor.
At home I had checked big-box stores and boutique lighting ‚Äúshoppes,‚Äù but no chandeliers were less than $1,000, way out of our range.
Now I wandered in Prague, the Crystal Capital of the World.
My three-day trip was a personal reward after a rough week on a writing assignment in Bratislava, the capital of Slovakia. Blocky, gray, Soviet-era architecture matched blocky, gray sky and overwhelmed the tiny historic quarter. I needed picturesqueness. I needed pizzazz. I needed Prague.
Staromestsk√© n√°mest√≠ ‚Äî Prague‚Äôs medieval-to-Renaissance Old Town Square ‚Äî featured warm yellow, pastel blue, and soft peach baroque buildings with flat facades, pointed tops, and curving lines set in restful balance. Soulful violins and upbeat guitars from the lively music scene sent their melodies through the narrow alleys. Aromas of chicken paprikash, potato dumplings, and garlic soup from caf√©s and home kitchens comforted me.
Of course, I couldn‚Äôt possibly buy a chandelier. It was ridiculous enough that I imagined I could safely carry a dozen and a half hollowed eggs back to California, but their rich red and yellow colors, complex geometric patterns, and symbolism of protection seduced me.
In a shop up the hill toward Prazsky hrad ‚Äî Prague Castle ‚Äî crystal seduced me, too. I saw a chandelier for US$250 ‚Äî including sea-mail shipping. For a day I agonized about the money, but the fact that it could be shipped ‚Äî for free ‚Äî finally won me over. Late in the afternoon I was leaving Prague, I made the commitment and returned to buy it.
A different clerk was on duty.
‚ÄúOh, no, we cannot possibly ship this sea-mail. This must go airmail,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúThat will cost $100 more.‚Äù
In the rapid switch to capitalism, the Czechs were clicking ‚Äî but this development moved my chandelier out of reach.
Deeply saddened, I hurried down the hill because I needed to take the subway soon to catch the bus to the airport for the last flight to Bratislava. Across the Karluv most or Charles Bridge, which spans the River Vltava, I passed another lighting store.
A chandelier hanging in the window was perfect: hundreds of delicate crystals draped in rows ‚Äî not ostentatious, not gaudy. It was 4,440 koruna or about US$185. Even adding air-mail costs it was acceptable.
I went inside. The middle-aged saleswoman spoke no English and I no Czech so we muddled through with my pathetic German and gestures.
She had no more chandeliers of that model. Could I have the one in the window? Yes. She was so kind. We took it down together. She found a battered, yellow, cardboard box ‚Äî three feet square by two feet high. We stuffed it with newspaper and tied it with many swirls of string.
What were the costs for shipping? No shipping. No shipping? I would have to carry it.
I dashed to the money changer, checked my watch, waited in line, checked my watch again, and told the clerk how many koruna I needed. He told me how much that would be in U.S. travelers‚Äô checks.
I got the cash, dashed back to the store ‚Äî and the saleswoman pointed out that I was short by a few koruna.
Time was getting very tight now. I was glad I had already bought my subway pass.
I ran back to the money changer and explained the situation. He said, ‚ÄúOh, I did not realize you needed exact amount for purchase.‚Äù I gave him another travelers‚Äô check, he gave me more koruna, and I flew back to the store. Transaction finally complete, I checked my watch, waved a ‚ÄúThank you!‚Äù and skedaddled.
Carrying my daypack with the blown eggs and struggling with the awkward box and its heavy glass contents, I waddled around the corner to the subway station. I had seen the station many times so was comfortable that all would work out now.
Down the steps I wobbled. Stairs to the lower level were boarded up. I traipsed around in search of others. No luck. The cavernous station held delis and clothing stores, but no information booth. My heart rate increased, and sweaty palms made it harder to grip the clumsy box.
I lumbered to a magazine stand. I couldn‚Äôt afford to wait in the long line. ‚ÄúBitte, wo sind die Zuge?‚Äù I shouted in German. ‚ÄúPlease, where are the trains?‚Äù
‚ÄúGeschlossen,‚Äù said the harried clerk without looking my way.
‚ÄúGeschlossen?‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúClosed? You can‚Äôt ‚Äòclose‚Äô a train! I have to get to the bus for the airport!‚Äù You could take a train out of service, but this was a perfectly fine, obviously functioning subway station so you couldn‚Äôt just ‚Äúclose‚Äù a train.
‚ÄúThe station is closed,‚Äù said a tall, thin, dark-haired Czech man in his mid-30s standing next to me. The white plastic bag of vegetables he carried contrasted with his brown business suit. ‚ÄúThe nearest station is . . . ‚Äú and then he said something like ‚Äúup, left, right, street, around, under, right, blocks, down.‚Äù
Hyperventilation befuddled my brain. I stared at him.
He took the scruffy box and handed me the bag of vegetables. We hoofed up the stairs and dashed for several blocks through the streets of Prague, twisting left, turning right, ducking through breezeways, and finally ending up at the entrance to another subway station.
My benefactor then took his vegetables, handed me the box, and said something like ‚Äúin, right, up, along, left, over, behind, across, right.‚Äù
Again, I stared at him.
Again, he grabbed the box, gave me the veggies, led me through the dark subway maze, and deposited me on a platform. He pointed in the direction the train would go. He placed the box on the platform, and I handed him his vegetables. I bubbled over with ‚Äúthank you‚Äù and ‚Äúdanke schon‚Äù and ‚Äúb√Ωt zav√°z√°n tebe,‚Äù and he laughed as I got on the train.
So I made the bus and caught the flight but had to check the chandelier like a suitcase. The next morning before dawn I took another bus to Vienna and again had to check the chandelier as luggage on the flight home. I changed planes in New York; and when I arrived in San Francisco, the box was there ‚Äî a little battered, but upright and more-or-less the same size.
I opened it and checked the 1,392 crystals. Only one had broken. All 18 of the eggs survived, too.
The chandelier shone beautifully in our Victorian dining room. When we moved nine years later, we took it with us ‚Äî I couldn‚Äôt bear to leave it and all it represented.
As valuable and delicate as a crystal chandelier is, the more worthy ‚Äî and fragile ‚Äî factor is the kindness of human beings, and the memory I treasure most is of the smiling face and shining heart of the handsome Czech man with his suit and vegetables.
Find more of April Orcutt‚Äôs stories at Medium.com/BATW-Travel-Stories, Medium.com/Travel-Insights-And-Outtakes, AprilOrcutt.Medium.com, and AprilOrcutt.com.

Prague is pretty, I‚Äôll give you that. I have some fond memories from my first visit in 2011. I swear it wasn‚Äôt such a tourist hotspot 13 years ago but maybe it was and I was so enchanted by its architecture I didn‚Äôt notice the crowds.
Our group was royally ripped off by taxis as soon as we arrived at the station. We didn‚Äôt have time to do the currency conversions. We had booked an apartment close to the station, not realising Prague, like many other European cities, had more than one train station and our accommodation happened to be close to the other station.
medium.com
The more you travel, the more you learn. That first experience left a bad taste in our mouths. The taxi fares had used all of our allotted spending money for Prague so we had to cut back. No dining out for us so we ordered a pizza and calzone takeaway. It turned out the taxi debacle was a commonplace occurrence in Prague as in other cities. But we were inexperienced travellers and always booked accommodation within walking distance of the station. Except in Prague.

Title: Czechia: Prancing Through Prague
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

Life by way of travel.

--
Listen
Share
Prague is a beautiful city. The river flows through the heart of it with the Disney-looking castle perched atop a hillside in the background. Its baroque and romanesque architecture give it an air of elegance that is incredibly unique.
The Old Town Square is the main area boasting beautiful buildings and the famous Orloj, an astronomical clock that sings at the top of every hour. It was teeming with tourists, so we didn‚Äôt stay too long in that area. And, unfortunately similar to Amsterdam, many of the streets were overflowing with trash and graffitied walls, which degraded the beauty of the city. In addition, overwhelming crowds and poor weather influenced our perception of Prague. It was obscenely hot the first few days, which gave us limited time to prance about before the sun scorched down on us and we had to take refuge inside shady cafes. But, the last few days cooled off and it even started raining out of the blue so we had to take cover again.
Despite an abundance of tourists and hot weather, we found that the best way to enjoy ourselves was by venturing out of the main town squares and finding solace along the side streets. Wandering along Old Town‚Äôs cobblestone streets was a great way to spend our time because we felt like this was more of an ideal way to experience this archetypal European city. I also had a chance to discover a specialty of Czech desserts: the trdeln√≠k chimney. It‚Äôs a funnel-cake filled with soft-serve ice cream and smells like a cinnamon roll. You can often find bakers on the streets baking the dough on a rotating spit then rolling it in cinnamon and sugar before filling it up with soft-serve. It was delicious confection for any sweet-tooth to enjoy!
In Vrtba garden, I got to see a photoshoot with a fashion model walking throughout the grounds. And I followed in her footsteps popping some poses myself.
We also got a great view walking up the steps of the Italian-style gardens and seeing the city beyond them. But, the best sights (and sounds) were yet to come‚Ä¶
The walk to Prague Castle was one of our favorite parts of the city. First, we started the walk from the Powder Tower, then up and over Charles Bridge. Charles Bridge is an attraction all by itself. Built in the 14th century, it‚Äôs lined with: sculptures of religious images and prolific Czech figures, street performers, artists and peddlers. It provides some of the most scenic views of the city over the Vltava River.
After crossing the bridge, we wound through cobblestone lanes and then climbed 200+ steps up to the castle entrance. Though the hike up to the castle is a bit of a workout, it‚Äôs worth it to get a spectacular view of Prague. In particular, the view at the top from the Starbucks (yep, you read that correctly; they pick the best locations!) situated in an outdoor patio setting overlooking the city was incomparable.
Once we arrived at Prague Castle, there‚Äôs no shortage of things to do. The compound includes a pretty expansive collection of eclectic buildings with museums, cafes, and archways connected by the internal castle roads. It‚Äôs a self-sufficient city unto itself similar to Windsor Castle. And, after the trek uphill we found a nice little offshoot area next to a cafe where we could sit, listen to a fountain, and cool off.
One of the best things we did was attend an organ concert in St. Vitus Cathedral, in the heart of the castle complex. St. Vitus is a 14th century Gothic church housing the tombs of many Bohemian kings and Holy Roman Emperors. It‚Äôs also the home to a great organ that‚Äôs about 3 stories tall! We got to hear the prodigious instrument in all of its glory at a special evening concert. The booming sound of the pipes reverberated through the gothic arches making the church come alive! I can only imagine how awesome it must have been to the Bohemians back in the day when this baby was first installed. The event was unbelievably special, and I savored the moment listening to the sweet tempo and the rich tones of the organ. It has inspired me to start tickling the ivories once again!

Title: Coming to Prague? I‚Äôm a local, and here‚Äôs what I love to do here
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
I‚Äôve lived in Prague for 25 years, and I get asked pretty frequently about good things to do, so I figured I‚Äôd put it into a list.
In terms of events calendars, I‚Äôd check the Expats.cz (www.expats.cz) calendar, the Prague TV (www.prague.tv) calendar, and the Czech Tourism site (which is good, but kinda basic ‚Äî http://www.czechtourism.com/home/).
Here‚Äôs something you might not know: Vietnamese culture is strong in Prague. Vietnamese are the third-largest ethnic minority in the Czech Republic (behind Slovaks and Ukrainians), and there are a number of places to get great Vietnamese food, including the sprawling SAPA marketplace (Anthony Bourdain visited there when he came to Prague a couple of years ago). SAPA is like a huge swap meet. It‚Äôs kind of hard to get to, but a really unexpected thing to find in Prague. (Map: https://goo.gl/maps/wKypyCh5AW32)
Barring that, I‚Äôd recommend visiting Banh Mi Makers on Dlouh√° t≈ôida in the Old Town for a great Banh Mi sandwich. In fact, the building that houses Banh Mi Makers is a gourmet shopping center that also hosts one of the must-visit restaurants in town, the stand-up Na≈°e Maso butcher shop Map: https://goo.gl/maps/XacKM4neyct. If you have enough lead time, I highly recommend reserving their ‚ÄòNoc s ≈ôezn√≠kem (Night With A Butcher)‚Äô an absolutely massive six-course
Just down Dlouh√°, you have Lokal, which is a retro-style pub that serves some of the freshest Pilsner Urquell outside of Pilsen. And next door you have the Roxy and NoD spaces, which are great for catching a DJ gig or maybe a performance (check the website at www.roxy.cz).
In terms of vegetarian fare, I like the Maitrea restaurant near the Old Town Square, and Radost FX Cafe, and I highly recommend the Eska restaurant in the up and coming Karlin neighborhood. It just got a Michelin Bib Gourmand, and while it isn‚Äôt a strictly vegan restaurant, it‚Äôs a place that focuses on bread and things made with yeast or fermentation. It‚Äôs excellent.
One place that‚Äôs kinda touristy but still excellent is the rooftop bar at the Hotel U Prince, just off the Old Town Square. Walk into the hotel, all the way to the back, and you‚Äôll find a glass elevator. Take that to the top and walk up some stairs, and you‚Äôll be rewarded with one of the most spectacular views of the city you could ever imagine. And it‚Äôs even heated in the winter. https://www.terasauprince.com/terrace
The Maurer Grand Restaurant list (and app) has a ton of great restaurant recommendations too. http://www.grandrestaurant.cz/home/?lng=en
Prague has some great design shops if you know where to look. I especially like Tuzeks (http://tuzeks.eu/), which is a play on words on the old Communist hard-currency shops. Tuzeks sells retro Czech design (the lamps and chairs are great). https://goo.gl/maps/L7u5hKYkTG62
In the last couple of years we‚Äôve seen a lot of design stores open up, and one of my favorites is the Chemistry Design Store (https://www.facebook.com/thechemistrydesignstore/), which has a lot of funky prints, glasswork, and some of the coolest turntables I‚Äôve ever seen (made by 440 Audio ‚Äî http://www.440audio.eu/). I also love the Modernista store in several locations, including the House of the Black Madonna. They specialize in faithful reproductions of Czech art deco, cubist and modernist pieces, and they‚Äôre gorgeous. http://www.modernista.cz/?lang=en
The Museum of Decorative Arts is also off the beaten path and is excellent, and has a wonderful museum shop, also run by Modernista (https://goo.gl/maps/1WdovwAG1Ro). Bonus: The windows, especially the ones in the stairways, overlook the Jewish Cemetery. I‚Äôm of two minds on whether the cemetery itself is worth going to. It‚Äôs usually mobbed, and it‚Äôs pretty pricey to get in. But the synagogues are beautiful. I‚Äôd instead recommend the small Jewish cemetery under the Zizkov TV tower. While there, you can check out the bar up on top of the TV tower, as well as checking out the Palac Akropolis, still my favorite concert venue in town, with two separate DJ bars.
I also like the scruffy ≈Ωi≈ækov neighborhood where the Akropolis is located, which, pound for pound, has the highest concentration of bars, restaurants and cafes in town. That and the more upscale Vinohrady neighborhood next to it are good.
Being an old fart, I don‚Äôt get out as much as I‚Äôd like to. But when I do, I like the Naplavka riverwalk (https://goo.gl/maps/66HK8PEoGEH2) and the Krymska street neighborhood (https://goo.gl/maps/3PfbNjZEM5r). Naplavka is not so great in the wintertime, but is the place to be in spring and summer. And Krymska is ground zero for Prague hipsters. Pretty great.
Clubwise, some of Prague‚Äôs must-visit places include the Palac Akropolis (www.akropolis.cz), Roxy, Rock Cafe, Radost FX, and definitely the Cross Club, which must be seen to be believed ‚Äî Atlas Obscura has a nice writeup here: http://www.atlasobscura.com/places/cross-club
I live close to the up-and-coming Letna neighborhood, which is anchored by the Bio Oko arthouse cinema and cafe (https://goo.gl/maps/rLkuMmDs9YF2). That neighborhood has the National Technical Museum, a must-see for geeks (https://goo.gl/maps/a9h6YqqUp6v) and Letna Park‚Äôs beer garden (https://goo.gl/maps/Dqvzyh8HNEs), which has one of the best views in town. In between are all kinds of great cafes and bars.
I‚Äôd strongly recommend getting a metro pass for the time you‚Äôre here. It‚Äôs cheap and so much less hassle. I‚Äôd also recommend (if you have mobile data) the Google Maps app, which also gives you timetables and nearest transit stops.
Prague taxis are a total ripoff, and I definitely do not recommend taking a taxi from the street. Use one of the services instead. I use Tick Tack Taxi (www.ticktack.cz), Taxi AAA (http://www.aaataxi.cz/en/), and Uber, which works well (although, like everywhere, surge pricing is something to watch for).
If you‚Äôre heading toward Vienna, I‚Äôd recommend either ƒåesk√Ω Krumlov or Mikulov. ƒåesk√Ω Krumlov is one of my favorite places on the planet and an amazing UNESCO World Heritage site ‚Äî it‚Äôs an entire town from the 14th century flawlessly preserved. Just gorgeous. Mikulov, in southern Moravia, is in the wine region, and is also a really nice place to be, moreso in summertime. Plus, there‚Äôs a nice waterpark just outside of town (http://www.aqualand-moravia.cz/en)/.
If you‚Äôre heading north toward Berlin, I‚Äôd recommend taking a day to check out Bad Schandau, a spa town with a kickass thermal bath (http://www.toskanaworld.net/web/en/therme_bad_schandau/home.asp), and the Czech and Saxon Switzerland national park, famous for its sandstone formations, including a couple of natural bridges.

Title: What & Where to Eat and Drink in Prague
Content:

We had explored many places before going to Prague because of our love to discover new places. Some of the places I list below are the places we had previously explored, and some of them we found by chance. PS: We tried to explore some concept places rather than the most popular places on this trip.
Cafefin is not a breakfast place where you can spend hours as we are used to. For example, you wake up so early, you‚Äôre in a hurry, you want to have a healthy and delicious breakfast. Then here is the right address! This busy and popular cafe is the first Vietnamese coffehouse in Prague. There are mini tables and the stools at the long bar that you can sit. The staff are incredibly friendly. The Vietnamese baguette category in the menu attracted our attention. Baguette varieties were not the kind we were used to, but I have to say that I liked it very much! The cafe is also known for its sweet chao rice and homemade yoghurt with black rice.
The weather was very cold in April. Therefore, when we were too cold, we would urgently sit in any caf√© we found by chance. That‚Äôs also how we discovered Tricafe. :) Tricafe was such a pleasant place that we have wanted to stay for 2 hours. We felt like we were at home with old-looking wooden tables, armchair seats in our grandmothers‚Äô house and rocking chairs. You could read books from their library or you could take a glance at drawings on the wall as a mini exhibition. By the way their coffee was pretty good.
Trdelnik has started to spread after Easter markets that were established in Czech Republic in 2002 and it has become one of the symbols of Prague. We have gone to Prague during Easter so we had the opportunity to experience it in the Easter markets. Trdelnik is made from rolled dough that is wrapped around a stick, then grilled and topped with sugar and walnut mix. I‚Äôve tried the Nutella version of it. You can find different versions of Trdelnik in various shapes and with different flavors. Especially in the summer, you can find Trdelnik with different kinds of ice cream in Prague.
Restaurant Bella Vista has the best view in the city. Its panoramic view stretches from the Petrin Tower all the way to Prague Castle Hillsides. It streches from the west to the north, it provides spectacular views of greenish copper cupolas, narrow cobblestone streets, bridges connecting both river banks and green gardens from red-roof tops of centuries-old houses. Actually, we had come here to visit the Strahov Monastery. After the visit to the monastery, this amazing view has made our day! We couldn‚Äôt leave there without drinking a green lager to the accompaniment of this view.
Kantyna is a restaurant where you can taste great meats in Prague. In the entrance part, you can choose the meats that you would like to eat in the butcher section or if you are in a hurry, you can prefer the meats that are already cooked. We chose to choose our meat from scratch and we started to wait at our table. Alcoholic and non-alcoholic beverages are also available, but we wanted to try local beer with our meats. This was the first place we stopped by after we got off the plane. We were very lucky because this place was so close to the hostel. Since I got back from Prague, I‚Äôve been telling everyone about this place. The meats were absolutely incredibly delicious.
Cafe Slavia was the place where Nazƒ±m Hikmet had written some poems in Prague. There is a portrait of Nazƒ±m Hikmet which is painted by one of the Czech artists. However, the place also inspired many important literary artists. Kafka also had been going to this cafe while writing his novels.
First of all, if you want to go this place, you have to make a reservation. That‚Äôs why we‚Äôve waited too long to sit, but the friendly staff was really helpful. I really like their food presentation. They served a meat with a kind of bread that they called ‚Äúknedliky‚Äù and cranberry marmalade. It was really delicious!
I‚Äôm a real John Lennon fan and that‚Äôs why I don‚Äôt recommend this place. We really wanted to have a drink at John Lennon Pub. However, we could not spend more than 10 minutes. Due to the fact that the waiters didn‚Äôt let us have a drink here. They said we could sit here if we ate something. If we only wanted to have a drink, we couldn‚Äôt sit even if there were available tables inside. There wasn‚Äôt anything there to connect with John Lennon except his photos. I would love to have waiters understand and embrace his spirit.
The Hemingway Bar is the most popular cocktail bar in Prague. This place deserves all highest points because of the friendly waitresses and the wide cocktail menu. The name of the cocktail in the photo is Snow Globe. I used to like to watch the snow globe when i was a kid. I felt the same feelings because of this cocktail. Watching the coconut particles brought me back to my childhood. If you travel to Prague, I‚Äôd say that you should go to Hemingway Bar.
Enjoy your trip!

Title: Visit Prague: What to do, where to go?
Content:
Sign up

Sign up
