Share
Prague seemed like the wisest choice for my next destination, given they were still on the Koruna (information I acquired from the ladies in Paris). They had yet to switch over to the Euro, and as a result, the exchange rate with the dollar was about 4:1. In simple terms, everything in Prague was cheap compared to other European Union countries. Slovakia was also on the Koruna, but that will come later.
I didn‚Äôt know much about Prague, other than that my friend, Kevin, told me I needed to go because ‚Äúyou can get wasted there for 5 bucks.‚Äù That was enough for me. Kevin always knows what he‚Äôs talking about. The only problem was the overnight, 14-hour train ride. But that‚Äôs what Tylenol PM is for, or Ambien if you have access. I figured I‚Äôd just zonk out then arrive in the daytime, rested and ready to romp. So, I booked a bed in a 4-person room for the 20:00 train that night.
I had a while to kill yet, so I did my laundry and went to an internet caf√© to peruse hostels. I found one called, ‚ÄúHostel One Prague,‚Äù and booked it as soon as I saw pictures of a bar. Again, the stumble home just can‚Äôt be beat. It cost 8 Euros/night (about $10 USD at the time) and looked just weird enough for my taste. I was stoked.
When I got back to the train station at 7pm, I sat down in the corner of the massive waiting area to kill time, for what I thought would be two and a half hours.
Let me stop for a second and say military time is bullshit. Why is it even used at all? Do soldiers not understand clocks? What the fuck are we doing here? Come on.
Anyway, I missed my train.
20:00 looks and feels like 10:00pm, I will die on that hill. Tell me I‚Äôm wrong. It‚Äôs an optical illusion.
The following train didn‚Äôt depart until eleven hundred hours the next morning (see how stupid that is?) and going back to either the hotel or the hostel was not an option. Those bridges were burned and shit on. So, I slept in the train station cuddling my backpack. It was me and a few other people, who I assume also couldn‚Äôt tell time.
When I woke up the next morning, I had breakfast before hitting the train station booze shop. I bought whiskey and wine for the ride, and for when I‚Äòd arrive in Prague in the middle of the night. Never show up to a party empty handed. I also got a couple more baguettes and a bunch of bananas (I didn‚Äôt want to take the chance of separating them), to supplement the Adderall I was going to take once the ride began. There‚Äôs nothing like Adderall when you need to kill 14 hours. Shit, you could stare at a clock for the entire time and still enjoy it. At least that‚Äôs how the drug made me feel.
The cabin was tinier than I expected, and my three roommates were already there, laying on their beds. The four of us tried to introduce ourselves, but we quickly realized none of us spoke the same language. One guy spoke Cantonese, one French, and the other, German. Names were even difficult, as they all involved different dialects. Communicating verbally was an impossibility. I feared the four of us were in for a silent ride.
After a short while, I pulled out a bottle of wine from my bag and opened it with a corkscrew, making a loud popping sound. Before taking a swig, I looked around the room to get everyone‚Äôs attention, but they were already looking in my direction, smiling. I motioned to the bottle and asked, ‚Äúeh?‚Äù. We all broke out in laughter.
‚ÄúI‚Äôll be right back,‚Äù I told them.
I went to the bar cart and asked for four cups. Back in the cabin, I handed one to each guy before getting in my bed. One at a time, they receive their serving, like communion. After our first round, the bottle was finished, so I pulled out another. Then came the whiskey. Within two hours we were all loose as geese. We took turns telling stories in our own language without caring if we were understood by the others. The person standing had the floor, and the full attention of the other three. Miming (they love mimes in France, and we were still technically within the border), and facial expressions were all we needed. Words, as usual, were unnecessary.
When my turn came around, I regaled the guys of my time in Paris, acting out my shitting and vomiting fiasco from a few days prior. They were hysterical. We all were. It was beautiful; 4 guys from all over the world, getting on like lifelong friends, without even the benefit of language. I couldn‚Äôt have been more grateful for such a warm experience on a ride that otherwise would have been a lonely one, filled with dark thoughts. Anything to avoid thinking about my dad.
The guys and I all had transfers to make, so we parted ways one at a time, hugging each other and exchanging emails as we said goodbye. I was the last to transfer, and when I did, around 1am, I got on the wrong train. Or maybe it was the second transfer I screwed up; I can‚Äôt remember. Either way, I ended up in the middle of nowhere, at the Praha-Veleslav√≠n station at 2:00am. It didn‚Äôt even look like I was in Prague, the area was so desolate. I had absolutely no clue where I was, or where to go from there.
After 10 minutes of smoking and walking around, I saw a couple driving down the street, approaching the stop sign where I was standing. I flagged them down, waving my arms like a lunatic. They stopped, as if they‚Äôd had this experience before. Unfortunately, they didn‚Äôt speak English. With miming now out of the question, all I could do was show them my map, and say the word ‚Äúhostel‚Äù. They nodded their heads and waved me into the car. If they weren‚Äôt so old I wouldn‚Äôt have gotten in. Have you ever seen an old serial killer? No, obviously not. As soon as they tried to snatch you, you could just rip their frail arms right off. It would be that easy. Now that we‚Äôre on the topic, I wonder how old the oldest serial killer was? Can‚Äôt be older than 50, right? I mean, it‚Äôs a young man‚Äôs game, all that trudgery.
After 10 minutes of driving, we stopped in a parking lot with a bunch of taxis in it and the couple motioned for me to get out. I thanked them by leaning forward and grabbing their shoulders. I for sure could have ripped their arms off. Without their kindness, I would have had to spend another night on a train station floor. I wanted to thank them, to show my appreciation, I just didn‚Äôt know how. To cover all my bases, I bowed, crossed my heart, blew them kisses, and curtsied. They laughed and went on their way. I still wonder what they were doing out so late. Or maybe it was the morning for them, and they were going to the Czech equivalent of a Denny‚Äôs. Old people keep weird hours.
The cabbie spoke to me, in what I assumed was Czech, for the entire 15-minute ride. He knew I had no clue what he was saying, but I think that‚Äôs what emboldened him. He was angry about something, probably politics (only politics, or maybe a spouse, can get a person that mad). When he‚Äôd look back in the rear-view mirror, I‚Äôd shake my head up and down in agreement like, ‚Äútotally. I can‚Äôt believe that either. Those motherfuckers.‚Äù Never comment on someone‚Äôs politics, especially when they‚Äôre driving you around in a foreign country at two in the morning. It‚Äôs best to just listen and agree, then form your opinions later.
When I checked in, the manager told me people were still drinking in the ‚ÄúCave Bar‚Äù downstairs. It was an actual cave with stone walls and an echo, very cool. If people were drinking that late, I knew I was in the right place.
The first person to introduce himself was an Irish lad named Simon.
I‚Äôve always hated the name Simon. It was my grandfather‚Äôs name, and he was a miserable, racist old bastard. One time he told me he didn‚Äôt want my Indian friend, Naveen, over at the house because he, ‚Äúwreaked of curry.‚Äù I used to pray for him to die. And when he did, I helped myself to his collection of Member‚Äôs Only jackets.
Irish Simon was all of 5'7'‚Äô, 190 lbs., most of which was stored in his robust belly. He had on a punk-style outfit with a mohawk and piercings. He was in his late thirties but came off like a disgruntled teen. His manic energy was off-putting, but he did have a charm to him.
Simon: ‚ÄúHow the fuck are ya, ya cunt? I‚Äôm Simon. You need a drink.‚Äù
Me: Jesus, man, nice to meet you too. I‚Äôm Sam.
Simon: I‚Äôm going to call you John McEnroe.
Me: Because I look like John McEnroe?
Simon: Because I said so.
Caroline: Ok, Simon. Let‚Äôs be nice.
Caroline was there from Australia, on ‚Äúholiday‚Äù. The Australian government partially pays for their post-uni holidays, an act so anti-American it‚Äôs hard for me to even conceive. In America we don‚Äôt go on ‚Äúholiday‚Äù to explore other cultures, we ‚Äúvacation‚Äù in apocalyptic places like Galveston, TX.
She was 24 years old but seemed older because of how confident and worldly she was. Her smile was beautiful, but she didn‚Äôt flash it often. She had long brown hair and bangs that laid atop her eyebrows. She was dressed casually, in jeans and a sweater. Some may have seen her as overweight, but I didn‚Äôt. I thought she was pretty. She also had Simon wrapped around her finger, which was impressive. The moment he‚Äôd say something too crass she‚Äôd tell him to shut up, and he‚Äôd listen. He‚Äôd even apologize, which amazed me.
Simon: Sorry for calling Sam a cunt. He‚Äôs not a cunt. Happy, Caroline?
Simon was just there fucking off, avoiding his life in Dublin. I remember him mentioning a kid, but I didn‚Äôt ask any questions because I feared his answers. He and Caroline had just met the day prior, though it seemed like they went way back. The cave had a way of doing that. We drank beers and took shots until the remainder of the Jameson bottle I had was gone. I gave Simon a few Adderall to christen our new friendship. I can always spot a fellow speed freak. He swallowed them right away, against my advice.
Me: If you take them tonight, you won‚Äôt be able to sleep.
Simon: I know how speed works, ya fuck.
Caroline and I called it a night around 4:30 am, while Simon went for a walk until the bars opened. For better or worse, I was now a part of a crew.
I slept like a drunken baby until noon the next day. When I came down to the common area, breakfast had already been made, by Caroline. It was a simple spread of toast, eggs, sausage, and potatoes, but I could tell she knew how to cook. Turning raw potatoes into crispy ones without the use of a fryer is not easy. You need to remove some of the starch by first soaking or blanching them. She used the latter method and nailed it. I was impressed, even turned on. She was motherly as well, a quality that inherently attracts me. I appreciated the way she made sure everyone was fed, before eating herself. She was, for all intents and purposes, the Hostel mom. All hostels had one, but like in life, many of them stink.
After breakfast, Caroline and I went on a walk to a nearby bookstore. The place was gigantic and had a line a block long.
Me: There must be a book signing.
Caroline: No, there‚Äôs a line because they only let a small amount of people in at a time. Its so shoppers feel comfortable.
Me: Do you know what Black Friday is?
Caroline: No, but it sounds scary.
Me: It is. It‚Äôs the day of the year when middle class American people wake up at 4:00am to fist fight over who gets to buy toys.
Caroline: How is this legal?
Me: It‚Äôs part of the fabric of our nation.
Inside the bookstore, we had the whole two floor almost all to ourselves. It felt like we were on one of those dates that only happens in movies, where a guy rents out a whole ice rink for a romantic skate. At one point, when she grabbed my hand and pulled me to her favorite section, I could have sworn we were on a date.
When we got back to the Hostel, Simon was in the cave, drinking by himself, so we joined him.
Simon: How was the li-bary, ya fucks?
Me: (mockingly) I rented a good book. It‚Äôs called ‚ÄúWanking Guys Off in Alleys for Dummies,‚Äù by Simon‚Äôs mom.
Simon: Now that‚Äôs the Johnny Mac I like.
Me: We‚Äôre still doing this?
Caroline: Johnny‚Ä¶ The umpire has the final say. You play tennis, you should know this.
Me: Fine, I‚Äôll be John McEnroe.
Simon: It wasn‚Äôt up for debate, cunt.
After a few rounds, we went to a bar down the street, one that Simon had been frequenting. The three of us shared a joint on the way there. Simon, fittingly, would forget to pass it because he wouldn‚Äôt stop rambling on. I had to keep reminding him, which got old quick. ‚ÄúUh, hey buddy. Remember, weed burns even while you‚Äôre not hitting it. If it was your weed, I wouldn‚Äôt say anything. But, seeing as I paid for it, you should keep it moving.‚Äù
The bar was spectacular. Some might not have liked it, but I sure did. It reminded me of a Day‚Äôs Inn conference room, with its‚Äô white stucco walls, and foldable card tables. There was no TV. In fact, there was nothing in there at all. It was just a plain room with a tiny bar, that housed the beer. No liquor was sold, just bottles of Czech beer. When we entered there were 5 guys sitting at a table, all of them old as sand. They waved us over to join them. We up pulled seats, and they motioned to the bartender with three fingers in the air. The bartender, who must‚Äôve been 80 years old, walked them over to our table. Simon immediately opened his using his teeth, a truly unhinged act. We all clinked bottles, and from there on we were all best friends. Who needs language when you have drinks?
Those old men could drink, let me tell you. After 5 or 6 beers the bartender came over and placed an unmarked bottle filled with a clear liquid, onto the table. I know moonshine when I see it, and that was it. We took shots out of tiny paper cups like you find in the dentist‚Äôs office until none of us could stand. One of the old guys fell on the way to the bathroom. Caroline and I picked him up, while Simon and the others laughed. Apparently, that happened to him often.
We sang and danced to Czech radio music, and acted like fools for hours. My face hurt from smiling.
Our bill came out to about $5 USD. Kevin was right, obviously. I left way more than that, and we stumbled home.
Caroline and I held hands on the way back. I could tell she wanted me to kiss her, but the time wasn‚Äôt right. Simon was still there, leeching. Every time we got close, he would scoff.
Simon: Ahh, fuck off you two.
Me: Thank you, Simon. I really appreciate you doing this.
Simon: Ooohhh, he‚Äôs pissed. Don‚Äôt throw your racket at me, Johhny Mac.
When we got back, Caroline and I still wanted to hang out, so we told Simon we were going to bed. Caroline, in her motherly way, insisted Simon do so too. After she tucked him in, her and I went down to the cave bar. We drank water and talked. Water is truly the key to pulling off alcohol and drug addiction. 2 gallons a day, at least, if you want to stay limber.
Caroline: So, why are you here by yourself, in Europe?
Me: I‚Äôm running.
Caroline: From what?
Me: Myself. Since my dad died, I feel like I can‚Äôt stop. If I do, I‚Äôll have time to think. And I don‚Äôt want to think.
Caroline. I understand.
Me: Why are you here?
Caroline: Same reason, really. My younger brother died last year. When I‚Äôm home in Perth, I can‚Äôt get him out of my mind. He died in a car accident, along with our dogs.
Me: That‚Äôs terrible.
Caroline: How about we run together?
Me: I‚Äôd like that. Where to next?
Caroline: I heard Bratislava was nice.
Me: Where is that?
Caroline: It‚Äôs the capital of Slovakia. Have you ever seen the movie ‚ÄúHostel‚Äù?
Me: No.
Caroline: Good. Don‚Äôt. Tomorrow we can take a bus. It‚Äôs a short ride.
By the time I got up the next morning, Simon had already weaseled his way into our plans. During breakfast, Caroline gave me a look as if to apologize. I couldn‚Äôt be upset though; Simon was a persistent one, I would have given in too.
Simon: Let me get some more of that speed. That was good shit.
Me: Goddamn you, Simon.
I gave him the 10mg pill, which he took immediately, in front of everyone.
Simon: Hey Johnny, we‚Äôre going to get pissed today, aren‚Äôt we?
Me: You just watch yourself, Ok? And please, don‚Äôt open any more beers with your mouth. It makes me sick.
It was only a 2-hour ride from Prague to Bratislava, but that didn‚Äôt deter Simon from bringing along a whole case of beer. He bought it though, and carried it, so I didn‚Äôt complain. Plus, it was nice to get some reciprocation after getting him high with my good Amsterdam weed for the past two days. The beer was the only luggage he took. I didn‚Äôt ask if he had more clothes, or any belongings at all, but I was curious. Best not to ask questions you don‚Äôt want the answers to.
He was 2 beers deep before we even boarded. With each one, he‚Äôd covertly pop the cap off then put it back on, before pretending to open it with his teeth, giving me a childish look in the process. At that point I‚Äôd stopped caring, but he wouldn‚Äôt let it go. He was an instigator that way. I‚Äôve never understood why some people show affection by teasing. You can only pull off teasing if you‚Äôre funny and have tact. Otherwise, you just sound like an annoying asshole. Timing is everything.
Caroline and I sat next to each other, while Simon sat behind us. He smelled like he hadn‚Äôt showered in a week, and he probably hadn‚Äôt. When the metal chains on his leather jacket clanged against the poor old woman sitting beside him, she clutched her bag and turned towards the window. I felt terrible for her, having to sit next to a drunken stink bomb like that for 2 hours. He was disgusting.
Speaking of disgusting‚Ä¶ I was always embarrassed when my dad and I went out in public together. He was impossible not to stare at because of how fat and unkempt he was. And I was his son, so I got stares too. Food is the worst drug in that way. Most addictions aren‚Äôt noticeable to the naked eye, but with food, there‚Äôs no way to hide it, unless you purge. My mom always told me that everyone is too caught up in their own lives to notice other people‚Äôs insecurities, but I never believed her. I knew they were looking, wondering how a child like me could come from a man like that. I could feel their indictments of him as a father; I could feel their pity. I felt it all. Those feelings have never left me, even long after his death. I can still feel those eyeballs on me.
It was a peaceful first hour. Caroline and I read from our books while knocking knees. The unspoken intimacy was lovely. She was on her second read of a Virginia Woolf book I can‚Äôt remember the name of, just like I was on my second read of my Hunter Thompson book. We both sipped our beers and enjoyed the nice cross breeze wisping through the bus. The sun was out, and we were in just the right place at just the right time.
With only about 15 minutes left in the ride, I reached back to grab another beer from the box on Simon‚Äôs lap. That‚Äôs when I saw the flashing lights behind us. It was a police van, and it was rapidly approaching. When it got closer it became clear that we were the ones being pulled over.
Me: Uh, what the fuck is going on?‚Äù
Simon: It‚Äôs usually just standard shite. Don‚Äôt worry.
Me: Usually?!
Several police officers boarded the bus, all of whom were holding automatic rifles and looking very serious. I swear, in Europe everyone with even a modicum of authority gets a machine gun. They went around checking passports. When they got to me, I was terrified. My bag and pockets were filled with weed, hash, and a bunch of loose Adderall pills. Also, I was American. Being an American in Europe is almost as bad as being black in America. Boy, being black in Europe must be double awful.
I handed the cop my passport, and instead of handing it back, he put it in his pocket and escorted me off the bus. I was the only one singled out. Everyone else just sat comfortably, drinking their beers. The jig was finally up, and my worst nightmare was coming true. ‚ÄúIf this is what happens in the movie Hostel, I‚Äôm going to kill Caroline for not warning me,‚Äù I thought to myself.
He asked me a bunch of questions that I obviously didn‚Äôt understand, while repeatedly checking my passport and shaking his head from side to side. It was like I was being questioned by a squirrel. I had no clue what he wanted from me or how I could appease him. I tried to look like an upstanding gentleman by buttoning up my cardigan and straightening my posture, but it didn‚Äôt seem to be working. He saw right through me.
I could see Simon in the window of the bus. He was giving me the international sign for throat-slashing. I wasn‚Äôt sure if he was implying that I should kill myself to avoid Slovakian prison, or if he was telling me I should find a way to slit the officer‚Äôs throat and escape. Probably the latter, knowing him. Caroline too had come to the window. I could see the concern on her face. If she was scared, I knew I was in trouble.
They had me out on the side of the road for ten agonizing minutes while they talked on their radios. The bus driver came out at one point to ask what the holdup was, and they swiftly sent him back on the bus. Now, everyone was concerned. I got Caroline‚Äôs attention through the window.
Me: Caroline, grab a pen‚Ä¶ My name is Sam Rosenberg, NOT John McEnroe. My mom‚Äôs name is Audrey. She lives in Northbrook, Illinois. Please tell her ‚Äî
Then, it all ended, just like that. No bag check, no pat down, no nothing. They just sent me on my not so merry way, with my passport. The bus driver gave me a snide look, like I‚Äôd messed up his schedule, but I didn‚Äôt care. I‚Äôd dodged another bullet. Simon opened a beer with his teeth and handed it to me.
Simon: This deserves a celebration.
Our hostel wasn‚Äôt the most fashionable, but it was cheap, and right downtown. The room fit 8 people. It was the three of us and 5 Italian guys who were all clearly friends. When we got to the room, they were eating spaghetti with their shirts off. It was wildly apropos. When they offered us each a bowl, Caroline and I politely declined. Simon, on the other hand, scarfed one down in less than a minute.
Simon: You call this pasta? It‚Äôs shite, mate. Sorry to tell you.
They didn‚Äôt understand.
Italian Guy: Si, pasta. Prego, prego.
Me: Prego?
Italian Guy: Si, prego.
Caroline: (understanding the double entendre) Not the brand, Sam.
Simon: Ahem, his name is Johnny.
Caroline: It means ‚Äúyou‚Äôre welcome.‚Äù
Me: Ah, grazie.
Italian Guy: Si, prego.
Right down the street from our hostel was a bar called The Dubliner. It looked exactly like you‚Äôd expect it to look. There‚Äôs no need to even describe it. Irish bars are perfect that way, you always get what you expect, regardless of the country you‚Äôre in. The food and liquor are the same, as is the d√©cor. They are, if nothing else, reliable. And reliability is everything.
Caroline and I sat at a table together, drinking Guinness, while Simon roamed around the bar swilling Jameson and accosting random strangers. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm here with John McEnroe!‚Äù he‚Äôd tell anyone who‚Äôd listen. He was blacked out. 12 beers in 2 hours will do that to you.
Simon got punched in the face and thrown out within an hour. I didn‚Äôt see it but apparently, he spit in some guy‚Äôs face after being called a cunt. Then thee guy decked him with a single punch. As someone who used the word so often, I‚Äôd expect Simon to be less sensitive to being called one himself. Caroline and I were tossed too because we came with him. He tried fighting every single person on the way out, but Caroline and I just stood there and watched. There was no way I was fighting on his behalf. The last time I did that was in 4th grade when a friend got jumped for using a racial slur. I have regretted it ever since and still think of the guy as a racist piece of shit.
When the hullabaloo concluded, Simon‚Äôs face was bloodied, but he still wanted to drink.
Me: You need to go back to the hostel. They won‚Äôt let you into a bar with blood all over your face and shirt. That‚Äôs surely a universal rule.
Simon: Fuck that. When someone in Dublin gets punched in the face, the bar buys them drinks.
Me: We are not in Dublin.
Caroline: Sam and I are going to eat. You can‚Äôt come. You need to rest.
To my amazement, Simon heeded her advice and stumbled back to the hostel to crash. I felt sorry for the Italians because I knew he‚Äôd finish their spaghetti and/or try to fight them. At least it was five against one, and Simon could hardly stand, so I wasn‚Äôt too worried about them.
Caroline and I set out to find the nicest restaurant we could. We‚Äôd both been skimping on money for weeks and finally wanted to splurge now that we were amongst good company. We walked around for half an hour holding hands, chatting about food. Caroline told me she used to cook for her late brother, ‚ÄúDamby,‚Äù as she called him (because she couldn‚Äôt say ‚ÄúDanny‚Äù when she was little). She‚Äôd make him minced meat pies on Sundays after church. They were his favorite, and he‚Äôd eat them inside-out, saving the crust for last (I do the same). The recipe came from her mother, who got it from her mother, who got it from her mother before her.
I told her about my Bubbie, and the fried latkes she‚Äôd make for me after school. I always thought the jelly would cool them down faster, but it really just cooled the exterior, lulling me into a burnt mouth. I never learned my lesson. We traded food story after food story, our faces lit up, until we had none left.
Food is the easiest way to make bonds, Bourdain taught me that, and I‚Äôve always found it to be true. We all eat.
Downtown Bratislava was way more beautiful than I‚Äôd expected. The streets were cobblestone, but the buildings were modern; a dichotomy that somehow worked. It perfectly combined the old world with the new. And the place oozed romanticism. It was like a poem come to life. Everything Disneyland claims to be, Bratislava actually was. If you‚Äôre proposing to someone, I suggest doing it there. You will no doubt get a ‚Äúyes.‚Äù
We found a white-tablecloth, French restaurant to dine in. They didn‚Äôt seem to care about our casual attire even though the place was fancy, which impressed me. Everyone who can afford a meal should be accommodated, regardless of their attire. Miss me with that classist shit. Before ordering we decided we‚Äôd share so we could try more dishes. We got escargot to start. Always start with escargot if they have it. Then we had an omelet, followed by a quiche. For our main courses we shared duck confit and beef bourguignon. Everything was insanely good, like eyes rolling back and moaning good. The price didn‚Äôt matter, though they were on the Krona too, so it only came out to what amounted to $40 USD.
We were enveloped in each other that night. The vibes were electric. We flirted and teased, properly, on the walk back. We were about to enter the hostel, when Caroline grabbed my arm.
Caroline: Do you have a girlfriend?
Me: No. Do you have a boyfriend?
Caroline: No.
I knew an opportunity when I saw one, so I leaned in and gave her a kiss.
Caroline: (Pulling away) Just kidding, I do.
Me: What?!
Caroline: Haha, you should see your face.
Me: Why did you do that?
Caroline: To fuck with you.
Me: I don‚Äôt appreciate that.
Caroline: (mockingly) I‚Äôm Sam, and I don‚Äôt appreciate jokes even though I was a comedian. Shut up and kiss me again, you sensitive man you.
I kissed her again, this time pulling her close.
Me: Whoa, that was awesome. Let‚Äôs do that more.
I usually say some very awkward shit during and after moments of passion. It‚Äôs like the side effect I get from a boner is Tourette‚Äôs. I‚Äôve been known to say ‚Äúthank you‚Äù after I cum. It‚Äôs not something I‚Äôm proud of.
Caroline: I have an idea‚Ä¶ How about we go somewhere else, without Simon, and pretend to be a couple? Like, just for a few days. We can go our separate ways after that.
Me: I dig that. But how are we going to get rid of Simon?
Caroline: Leave that up to me.
We made out for a few more minutes before going upstairs. Simon was still passed out, and the Italian guys weren‚Äôt back yet, so we laid in my bunk and dry humped quietly for a little while. Part of me couldn‚Äôt believe I was hooking up with such an awesome chick, but the other part wished it was Meghan. I kept my mouth shut, as to not ruin our moment, but I felt guilty, like I was using her. Before going to bed, I wrote in my journal:
Why are you like this? Who are you trying to spare in this situation? You‚Äôre not even dating Meghan, and Caroline REALLY likes you. You don‚Äôt have to be in love with her to have some fun. I mean, you just had sex with a prostitute, how is this worse than that? Ignore your silly morals for once and take a chance. Put yourself out there. Meghan would want you to.
It was easier to ditch Simon than we‚Äôd expected because I‚Äôm pretty sure he had a concussion. I tried to wake him up a few times, because I knew you weren‚Äôt supposed to sleep in that situation, but he kept telling me to fuck off. Caroline finally had enough.
Caroline: Simon, Sam and I are leaving. We will say a prayer for you. Drink water and don‚Äôt look directly into bright lights for a few days.
Simon: You cunts. You‚Äôre going to leave me here, like this? Sam, I need more speed.
Me: No. And it‚Äôs Mr. McEnroe to you.
Caroline pulled me out of the room by my arm before we could hear any more of his pleading. I was insulted by everything Simon did, but that demand infuriated me. I wanted to go back in there and smother him with a pillow. I guess that‚Äôs what I get for always seeing the best in people, and for sharing my drugs. Friends like these, eh dude?
Caroline and I went right to the train stop after buying some candy for the trip. She loved the sour stuff. The sourer, the better. In my experience, sweet people like sour candy, and sour people like sweet candy. I‚Äôve ran the numbers, trust me. We didn‚Äôt know where to go, so we looked at a map on the wall.
Me: So where to ma‚Äôam?
Caroline: Why don‚Äôt you just close your eyes and point?
Without waiting for my response, she got behind me and covered my eyes. Then, she spun me around a few times, before placing me back in front of the map. I pointed to a spot.
Caroline: I hear Vienna is nice.
--
--
Writing a memoir, sharing portions here.

Title: The Prague Solo Adventure That Changed How I See Myself (And Why Your Prague Itinerary for Solo Female Travelers Should Be Your Next Big Move)
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Hey there, fellow wanderers!
Picture this: a slightly panicked introvert standing in the middle of Old Town Square at 6 AM, clutching a lukewarm coffee and wondering what on earth she‚Äôs doing in Prague all by herself. That was me, three years ago ‚Äî more anxiety than passport stamps, about to embark on what would become the most life-changing week ever.
Spoiler alert: I didn‚Äôt just fall in love with Prague‚Äôs fairy-tale architecture and ridiculously good goulash (seriously, the food is incredible!). I discovered a version of myself I never knew existed ‚Äî the one who could navigate cobblestone streets confidently, eat dinner alone without checking her phone every five seconds, and actually enjoy her own company.
And honestly? I‚Äôm pretty sure you will too.
After four years of guiding tourists around Turkey‚Äôs stunning coastlines, I thought I had this whole travel thing figured out. I knew how to handle cranky tourists, navigate crowds without losing anyone, and make sure everyone felt safe and entertained. I was the person with all the answers, the backup plans, the emergency snacks.
But here‚Äôs the kicker ‚Äî I‚Äôd never actually traveled just for me. Wild, right?
Every trip was about managing other people‚Äôs experiences, schedules, and expectations. I was always ‚Äúon,‚Äù always responsible for someone else‚Äôs good time. Sound familiar?
So when I finally booked that solo trip to Prague, I honestly had no clue what I was getting myself into. My friends thought I was either incredibly brave or slightly unhinged (jury‚Äôs still out on that one). My family worried I‚Äôd spend the whole week talking to pigeons and eating sad hotel room crackers.
Oh boy, was I wrong about everything.
The real transformation didn‚Äôt happen at the famous Prague Castle or on that Instagram-perfect Charles Bridge everyone raves about. Nope. It happened on day three, in this tiny caf√© tucked away in Lesser Town, where I spent two glorious hours reading a book, sipping what might have been the best coffee of my life, and realizing something mind-blowing:
I was genuinely enjoying my own company for the first time in‚Ä¶ well, maybe ever.
Okay, let me be completely honest with you ‚Äî Prague totally spoiled me for other cities. It‚Äôs like the universe took notes on what anxious introverts need and designed the perfect solo travel playground.
Here‚Äôs why Prague works so beautifully for us nervous first-timers:
It‚Äôs Ridiculously Safe (Even for Overthinkers Like Me)
I walked everywhere. Day, night, through winding medieval streets that looked straight out of a fairy tale. The scariest thing that happened? Getting mildly turned around near Wenceslas Square (which, fun fact, isn‚Äôt actually a square but more like a really long street ‚Äî Prague loves keeping you on your toes!).
The city center is compact, well-lit, and there are always people around. Plus, Czech people are generally pretty reserved and respectful, which means you won‚Äôt deal with aggressive street harassment or pushy vendors trying to sell you overpriced ‚Äúauthentic‚Äù souvenirs every five minutes.
Basically, Prague lets you dip your toes into solo travel without throwing you into the deep end.
Your Wallet Will Actually Love You
One of my biggest solo travel fears was accidentally bankrupting myself on overpriced tourist food. You know that panic when you realize you just paid ‚Ç¨25 for a sad sandwich near the Eiffel Tower? Yeah, Prague laughs at that nonsense.
I ate like an absolute queen for the price of a mediocre airport meal back home. Traditional Czech meals with beer (yes, beer!) often cost less than a single appetizer in most major European cities. This means you can actually enjoy yourself without constantly calculating exchange rates and having mini panic attacks about your credit card bill.
It‚Äôs Like Living Inside a Disney Movie (But Real)
I‚Äôm not being dramatic when I say Prague looks like someone took every fairy-tale castle, medieval fantasy, and romantic European dream and smooshed them together into one impossibly beautiful city. Walking through the streets genuinely feels like you‚Äôve stepped into a storybook.
Which is perfect when you‚Äôre writing your own adventure story, right?
Day 1: Arrival and the Classic ‚ÄúWhat Have I Done?‚Äù Moment
I checked into my adorable little hotel in New Town (pro tip: stay somewhere central but not smack in the middle of tourist chaos), dumped my overpacked suitcase, and immediately felt that familiar flutter of anxiety.
You know the feeling ‚Äî that voice in your head going, ‚ÄúCongratulations, you‚Äôve officially made a terrible decision. Enjoy eating alone for a week, weirdo.‚Äù
Instead of hiding in my room scrolling social media like my introvert brain suggested, I forced myself to take a gentle walk toward the Powder Gate and Municipal House. The architecture literally stopped me in my tracks. I stood there for a solid ten minutes just gawking at all the intricate details on the Municipal House facade like some kind of architectural tourist (which I totally was).
That evening, I found this cozy restaurant with bar seating ‚Äî my secret weapon for solo dining ‚Äî and had my first taste of sv√≠ƒçkov√°. I was super skeptical about meat drowning in cream sauce (it sounds questionable, right?), but oh my goodness, it was absolutely incredible.
The elderly Czech woman sitting next to me smiled and nodded approvingly when I practically licked my plate clean. My first genuine human connection of the trip, and it was over mutual appreciation of comfort food. Perfect.
Day 2: Playing Tourist (But Flying Solo Style)
Old Town Square was everything I‚Äôd drooled over in Instagram photos and somehow even more magical in person. The famous Astronomical Clock show happens every hour, and yes, it‚Äôs honestly a bit underwhelming (sorry, Prague tourism board!), but there‚Äôs something genuinely special about being part of that collective moment with strangers from around the world.
The real treasure was the Church of Our Lady Before T√Ωn with its dramatic Gothic spires that look like something straight out of a Tim Burton movie. I found a nearby caf√©, ordered another incredible coffee (Prague‚Äôs coffee game is seriously underrated), and spent an hour sketching the towers in my travel journal while people-watching.
This became my daily ritual ‚Äî finding quiet spots to observe and actually process what I was seeing instead of just snapping photos and moving on.
The Jewish Quarter hit me right in the feels in ways I hadn‚Äôt expected. The weight of history, the stunning beauty of the Spanish Synagogue with its intricate Moorish design, the sobering reality of the Old Jewish Cemetery ‚Äî it reminded me why solo travel can be so powerful. You can take all the time you need to really feel and process heavy experiences without worrying about someone else‚Äôs comfort level or schedule.
Day 3: The Charles Bridge Revelation (AKA My ‚ÄúI Can Do This‚Äù Moment)
Here‚Äôs where things got interesting. I dragged my not-a-morning-person self out of bed at sunrise (definitely not easy!) to experience Charles Bridge without the usual crowds of selfie-stick wielding tourists.
Standing there in the golden morning light, with just a few dedicated joggers and adorable dog walkers for company, I had what I can only describe as a moment of pure, unexpected contentment.
I wasn‚Äôt frantically taking selfies or checking how many likes my last post got. I was just‚Ä¶ there. Present. Enjoying the view and my own thoughts without any distractions or obligations.
It sounds almost too simple, but when you‚Äôre used to constantly managing other people‚Äôs experiences or being ‚Äúon‚Äù all the time, these moments of genuine solitude feel absolutely revolutionary.
Lesser Town became my favorite neighborhood that day. It‚Äôs like stepping through a portal into the past, with narrow cobblestone streets (wear good shoes, trust me!) and baroque buildings painted in the most gorgeous soft pastels.
I stumbled upon the John Lennon Wall, completely covered in colorful graffiti and Beatles lyrics, and learned from a friendly local that it had been a symbol of peace and freedom during Communist times. These unexpected mini-history lessons happen constantly when you‚Äôre traveling solo ‚Äî you actually have time to read the plaques, strike up random conversations, and really absorb the stories instead of rushing to the next photo op.
Day 4: Castle Conquering and Confidence Building
Prague Castle day meant serious uphill walking (note to past self: ALWAYS pack your most comfortable walking shoes!). The castle complex is absolutely massive ‚Äî we‚Äôre talking small-city-on-a-hill massive. St. Vitus Cathedral made me actually gasp out loud with its soaring Gothic arches and stained glass windows that look like giant jewels.
But honestly? The real highlight was Golden Lane, this absolutely charming street of tiny, colorful houses where castle guards and craftspeople used to live. I spent almost an hour exploring each miniature dwelling, imagining the daily lives of people who once called these dollhouse-sized homes their own.
The confidence boost of navigating this enormous complex completely by myself ‚Äî reading maps, making decisions about what to see and what to skip based purely on my own interests ‚Äî felt like a masterclass in trusting my own judgment.
Day 5: Hidden Gems and Personal Discoveries
Vy≈°ehrad Fortress became my absolute favorite discovery. It‚Äôs way less crowded than Prague Castle but equally stunning, with incredible views over the Vltava River and the city spread out below like a living postcard.
The peaceful cemetery where famous Czech artists and writers are buried became my spot for quiet reflection. I know that sounds morbid, but there was something deeply moving about walking among the elaborate tombstones and thinking about all the creative souls who once called Prague home.
I packed a little picnic lunch (cheese, bread, and local fruit from a market) and spent hours just sitting on the fortress walls, watching boats drift down the river and thinking about my life back home. These moments of pure solitude were becoming addictive in the absolute best way.
Day 6: Confidence in Full Bloom
By this point, I was navigating Prague‚Äôs winding streets like I‚Äôd lived there for months. I‚Äôd found my favorite caf√© (Caf√© Louvre, where Einstein apparently used to hang out ‚Äî how cool is that?), discovered hidden gardens perfect for morning reading sessions, and even ventured into neighborhoods completely outside the tourist bubble.
The Museum of Alchemists and Magicians was wonderfully weird and perfectly Prague ‚Äî quirky, mysterious, and slightly magical. That evening, I treated myself to dinner at this fancy restaurant I would never have chosen if I were worried about accommodating someone else‚Äôs preferences or budget.
Eating alone at a white tablecloth establishment felt like such a grown-up, confident thing to do. The waiter was lovely, recommending wine pairings and chatting about his favorite Prague neighborhoods. Another reminder that most people are genuinely kind when you‚Äôre open to connection.
Day 7: Saying Goodbye to My Transformed Self
My last morning, I made one final pilgrimage to Charles Bridge for sunrise. This time, I wasn‚Äôt nervous or uncertain about being alone. I was simply a woman who had spent a week getting to know herself in one of the world‚Äôs most beautiful cities.
The difference in my confidence from day one to day seven was honestly shocking. I‚Äôd gone from anxious and uncertain to genuinely excited about solo adventures.
Solo Doesn‚Äôt Equal Lonely (Revolutionary Concept, I Know)
This was my biggest fear going in and my most surprising revelation coming out. I had rich, meaningful experiences every single day. Sometimes through brief but lovely interactions with locals or fellow travelers, but mostly through rediscovering the genuine joy of my own company.
I‚Äôd somehow lost that in years of constantly accommodating other people‚Äôs needs, schedules, and preferences. Prague gave it back to me.
You‚Äôre Way More Capable Than Your Anxiety Wants You to Believe
Every small decision ‚Äî which charming street to wander down, where to grab lunch, how to spend an unexpected free afternoon ‚Äî built my confidence muscle. By the end of the week, I was making quick, intuitive choices and trusting my instincts in ways that genuinely surprised me.
That confidence didn‚Äôt magically disappear when I got home. It showed up in work meetings, personal relationships, and daily decision-making in ways I never expected.
Slow Travel is the Secret Sauce
Without anyone else‚Äôs agenda to consider, I could linger in places that spoke to my soul and skip things that didn‚Äôt interest me. I spent an entire afternoon in the peaceful Franciscan Garden just because it felt right. I revisited my favorite caf√© three times because the coffee was perfect and the atmosphere made me genuinely happy.
No rushing, no compromising, no ‚Äúwe should probably see this because it‚Äôs famous.‚Äù Just pure, authentic exploration based on what actually interested me.
Where to Stay for Maximum Comfort and Confidence
Old Town is super convenient but touristy and expensive (and honestly kind of overwhelming). I absolutely loved New Town ‚Äî central enough to walk everywhere but with more authentic local flavor and much better prices.
Vinohrady is perfect if you want to feel like a temporary Prague resident, with incredible caf√©s and tree-lined streets that feel genuinely residential.
Pro tip: Look for places with 24-hour reception and stellar reviews from other solo female travelers. I always read reviews specifically mentioning solo travel experiences ‚Äî they‚Äôre gold mines of practical information.
The Art of Solo Dining (It‚Äôs Way Easier Than Your Brain Thinks)
Prague‚Äôs caf√© culture is absolutely perfect for solo travelers. Look for places with bar seating or communal tables where eating alone feels natural and intentional rather than awkward.
Traditional beer halls and pubs are surprisingly solo-friendly too ‚Äî there‚Äôs something about the casual, communal atmosphere that makes dining alone feel completely normal. Plus, locals often eat alone, so you definitely won‚Äôt stand out.
My foolproof strategy: always carry a book or journal. It gives you something to do with your hands and makes the whole experience feel purposeful rather than like you‚Äôre waiting for someone who‚Äôs running late.
Getting Around Like You Own the Place
Prague‚Äôs public transport is excellent and super safe, but honestly, you can walk to most major attractions from the city center. The medieval layout can be confusing (I got turned around more times than I care to admit), but that‚Äôs part of the charm.
The tram system runs frequently even late at night, and it‚Äôs efficient and reliable. Get a multi-day transport pass for convenience, and always use official taxis with yellow roof lights and clear company logos.
Download offline maps before you go ‚Äî Prague‚Äôs winding streets can be tricky, and you don‚Äôt want to drain your phone battery when you need GPS most.
Safety Tips That Actually Matter (Not the Scary Stuff)
Keep your bag zipped and in front of you in crowded tourist areas ‚Äî pickpockets definitely target distracted visitors around major attractions like Old Town Square and Charles Bridge. Save your accommodation‚Äôs address in your phone and grab one of their business cards to keep in your wallet.
Most importantly: trust your instincts. If something feels off, remove yourself from the situation. But honestly? The biggest safety threat in Prague is falling so hard for the city that you start researching apartment rental prices (definitely guilty as charged).
Here‚Äôs what nobody tells you about solo travel: it‚Äôs not really about the destination at all. Prague was absolutely incredible, but the real journey was completely internal.
I learned to trust my judgment, genuinely enjoy my own company, and make decisions based on what I actually wanted rather than what I thought I should want or what would make other people happy.
This newfound confidence didn‚Äôt conveniently stay in Prague when I flew home. It followed me into job interviews, personal relationships, family dynamics, and daily decision-making. It fundamentally changed how I approach challenges and how I see myself in the world.
If you‚Äôre reading this and feeling that familiar flutter of excitement mixed with absolute terror, that‚Äôs your sign. That‚Äôs exactly how I felt three years ago, standing in my kitchen with a Prague guidebook, wondering if I was actually brave enough to book the trip.
Here‚Äôs the truth: I wasn‚Äôt particularly brave. I was just curious enough to feel the fear and explore anyway.
Prague is waiting for you right now. Not just the city with its stunning architecture, incredible food, and fairy-tale streets, but the version of yourself you‚Äôll discover wandering those ancient cobblestones. The woman who can confidently navigate foreign cities, make decisions based on her own desires, and genuinely enjoy her own amazing company.
Your Prague itinerary for solo female travelers isn‚Äôt just another vacation plan ‚Äî it‚Äôs an invitation to meet the most interesting person you‚Äôll ever travel with: yourself.
So pack your curiosity, leave those doubts at home, and get ready for the most important conversation of your life. Prague is an excellent listener, and I have a feeling you might be surprised by what you discover you have to say.
Ready to start planning your own transformation? Your solo Prague adventure is just one brave click away. Trust me, your future self will thank you for being curious enough to take that first step.

Travel blog for solo female travelers, introverts, fashion lovers, and future bloggers.

Title: Top 7 Must-Visit Art Galleries in Prague for Every Art Lover (2025 Guide)
Content:

A travel guide to Prague, Czech Republic. Uncover the best tips and insights about the city.

--
Listen
Share
Most people know Prague for its cheap beer and beautiful bridges, but did you know that the city has a blossoming art gallery scene, too?
Prague truly has something for everyone. Are you a fan of historical art? What about contemporary art? The city has it all ‚Äî if you know where to look. But even if you don‚Äôt, don‚Äôt worry. That‚Äôs what this guide is for, after all!
Here‚Äôs a list of some of the best must-see galleries in Prague you can‚Äôt miss.
Fun fact: Prague‚Äôs National Gallery is one of the largest art museums in Central Europe. It has several buildings across the city. Honestly, if you want to see all of it, you might want to extend your trip by a couple of days! That‚Äôs how much art there is for you to admire.
Whether you‚Äôre interested in the old masters, Czech modernism, or international contemporary exhibitions, this gallery needs to be on your travel itinerary.
It‚Äôs a must-see for anyone who‚Äôs looking for a deep dive into Czech and European art.
I‚Äôll admit ‚Äî this one is a personal favorite of mine. There‚Äôs no better way to spend the afternoon in Prague than visiting DOX and seeing whatever exhibition they currently have on. They never miss!
DOX Centre for Contemporary Art is Prague‚Äôs leading modern art space. Here, you can expect thought-provoking exhibitions, modern architecture, and a permanent rooftop airship installation with some cozy beanbags inside.
It‚Äôs located in the Hole≈°ovice district, which is full of artistic caf√©s, beautiful plant stores, and small independent shops that you can get lost in. Perfect for an artsy day out!
This Prague art gallery is a must-see for contemporary art lovers.
Kampa Museum is all about modern European art. They especially spotlight Czech and Central European artists. Here, you can see the works of Franti≈°ek Kupka and Otto Gutfreund, as well as other rotating exhibits.
This beautiful gallery also has an exciting location ‚Äî you can find it on Kampa Island by the Vltava River. That‚Äôs right ‚Äî it‚Äôs on an actual island. In the middle of mainland Europe!
If you‚Äôre looking for a unique setting with stunning views, this is the one for you.
MeetFactory is unlike anything you‚Äôve ever seen before. This contemporary gallery and artist residency was founded by David ƒåern√Ω, a famous Czech artist who also designed the famous Rotating Head of Franz Kafka.
MeetFactory is all about avant-garde exhibitions, live performances, and experimental installations. It‚Äôs perfect for edgier travelers who want to see something different.
If you‚Äôre interested in experiencing Prague‚Äôs alternative art scene, you really shouldn‚Äôt miss this one!
Schwarzenberg Palace is technically part of the National Gallery, but it definitely deserves its own spot on this list. It‚Äôs a beautiful place, which makes sense. After all, it‚Äôs actually a Baroque palace that was only later turned into an art gallery. Its highlights include Czech Baroque and Renaissance paintings and sculptures.
For its historical setting showcasing classic masterpieces, of course. Also, it‚Äôs near Prague Castle, another popular tourist destination ‚Äî why not do a little 2-in-1?
Leica Art Gallery in Prague is a must-visit spot for photography lovers. It specializes in fine art photography by both Czech and international photographers. If that sounds like something you might enjoy, add this one to your itinerary. And don‚Äôt forget to check out the Leica camera store, too!
This one is a must for photography enthusiasts.
Last but not least, we have the Rudolfinum Gallery, which is a historic concert hall with a contemporary art gallery. It‚Äôs located by the Vltava River, near the Old Town, meaning that just walking there will take your breath away.
The Rudolfinum Gallery offers exhibitions of modern and contemporary art, despite how old and majestic it may look from the outside.
This gallery combines fine art with one of Prague‚Äôs most beautiful buildings. It also has a fun name. The Rudolfinum. Try not to think about Rudolph the Red-Nosed Reindeer while putting that name into Google Maps. I dare you.
The Rudolfinum is a gorgeous building, but it‚Äôs not the only one. Prague is a beautiful city with many views worth taking in. This is why river cruises are so popular here. If you want to see more of the city but don‚Äôt have a ton of time to walk everywhere, a cruise is the perfect solution.
You can try this Panoramic Vltava River Cruise by Get Your Guide, which will take you around Prague‚Äôs most famous landmarks, including Kampa Island, Prague Castle, Charles Bridge, and more.
Disclaimer: The above link is an affiliate link. If you choose to go on the cruise, I may earn a small commission at no extra cost to you. No pressure, though!
In case it wasn‚Äôt obvious, Prague‚Äôs art scene is super diverse. Whether you‚Äôre a modern art enthusiast or a lover of the classics, you won‚Äôt be disappointed by checking out these gorgeous galleries. So, don‚Äôt forget to add them to your travel plans.
Which of these Prague art galleries will you visit first? Let me know in the comments!

My final destination in my post-graduation European trip was Prague, the capital of the Czech Republic. There are many things to do in this city and I particularly like the variety in food, especially in meats. Duck, rabbit, deer, geese, and wild boar meat are quite common in restaurants throughout the city. From high-end restaurants to more casual dining places, Czech food offers a lot of variety. The Prague nightlife is also great, and I would sometimes have less time in the day to go sightseeing because I would return to my hotel late at night to catch up on sleep after an eventful evening.
One of the first places I visited in Prague was Prague Castle. The castle‚Äôs history dates back to 870, when it was first used as a church and a fort. The fort later became a medieval castle, and served as the residence of the Kings of Bohemia, the Holy Roman Emperors, the Presidents of Czechoslovakia, and currently it is the official office of the President of the Czech Republic.
Visiting Prague Castle was quite sentimental for me because I visited the castle when I was 15 and had fond memories of that visit. It was great to see it again and I had a sense of nostalgia walking around. Occasionally I would recognize something I remember from six years ago. Title: ‚Äú5‚Äù beautiful places to visit in ‚ÄúPrague‚Äù ‚ù§
Content:

This magical city of Prague! No other place can leave such a living memory. No other city looks at its visitors with such wonderful eyes. Prague is the city that can make you fall in love with it!
In this article, we are going to give you 5 most popular tourist tips for curious travelers. Slowly carrying out all the points and enjoying your trip, you will get the most complete impression of this wonderful city and its traditions.
Let‚Äôs start our unforgettable sightseeing tour around Prague!
1. Walk along the Charles Bridge
Prague‚Äôs oldest bridge is built of sandstone blocks, flanked at each end by fortified towers (Lesser Town Bridge Towers, Old Town Bridge Tower). From 1683 to 1928, thirty statues of saints were carved to decorate the bridge, the most famous of which is the statue of St John of Nepomuk.
From the bridge, you will have amazing views over many Prague‚Äôs medieval towers, churches, and palaces. The view towards Lesser Town, dominated by the Prague Castle complex, is very picturesque.
The best time to visit Charles Bridge is early in the morning or at night when it is not crowded. You can climb two towers standing on both ends of the Bridge for a magnificent view of Prague and the bridge from above.
You can get to the Charles Bridge when taking the tram number 12, 20, 22 or 23, getting off at station Malostranse Namesti.
The Charles Bridge over the Vltava River is definitely one of the most beautiful places in Prague. Its towers and sculptures are worth to be seen!
2. Admire the architecture of Old Town Square and watch a unique Astronomical Clock performance
Wander through the Old Town Square (Staromƒõstsk√© n√°mƒõst√≠), where the true heart of Prague beats!
The elegant tower of the Old Town Hall with the world famous Astronomical Clock, the monumental Church of St. Nicholas and countless colorful houses of many styles give this place a unique atmosphere, which will mesmerize you if you decide to take a look at its charm.
Not avoiding a crowd of tourists, watch a performance on an Astronomical Clock at the Old Town Hall, called ‚ÄúThe Apostle Parade‚Äù. Its main function was to depict the movement of the Sun and the Moon; showing the time was merely a secondary element. The Apostle figures became part of the clock in the middle of the 16th century.
Very much has been written about the performance itself, but nothing will convey that atmosphere of mystery and admiration that reigns over the square during this performance. For a greater impression during the presentation, be sure to remember that the clock was built in the 15th century and has not undergone any tangible changes since that time.
The Apostle parade can be seen on the Prague Astronomical Clock every hour on the hour from 9 a.m. till 11 p.m. However, it is better to watch it in the morning, when there are relatively few people on the square. To take the most advantageous place, come to the clock 15 minutes beforehand.
While walking along the historical center, try famous Czech trdelnik, a kind of spit cake, made from rolled dough that is wrapped around a stick and topped with sugar and walnuts. Here you can eat a fried sausage and drink Czech beer.
All this must be done by sitting on a free bench and enjoying the surrounding pictures. In winter, the beer can be replaced with hot mulled wine or grog.
3. Enjoy a classic performance in Prague National Theatre
The National Theatre in Prague belongs to the most important Czech cultural institutions with a rich artistic tradition. Today the National Theatre consists of three artistic ensembles ‚Äî opera, ballet, and drama. Operas are sung mostly in Italian and are accompanied by both Czech and English subtitles.
Visit Giuseppe Verdi¬¥s La Traviata and Aida, Camille Saint-Saens¬¥ Samson and Dalila, or very popular Georges Bizet¬¥s Carmen. If you want to see something by Czech authors, there is Bedrich Smetana¬¥s Hubicka (The Kiss), Tajemstvi (The Secret), and famous Rusalka.
Another scene of the National Theater is the Estates Theater. On this stage, Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart¬¥s La Clemenza di Tito, Don Giovanni, La Nozze di Figaro, and The Magic Flute are staged.
If you prefer the Ballet, you can visit Adolphe Charles Adam¬¥s Giselle or project Solo Pro tri (Solo for three).
Both of the buildings are very nice, performances are well prepared, done by the best Czech and world dancers and singers, prepared by great directors and choreographers. So if you like Opera or Ballet, it is worth to visit the National Theatre, as it can be a great cultural experience, and a way how to spend a pleasant evening in Prague.
Do you want to visit the smallest street in Prague and go inside these tiny houses?
4. Golden Lane or Zlat√° uliƒçka!
On the eastern side of the Prague Castle, not far from St. George‚Äôs Basilica, there is an unusual street called Zlat√° uliƒçka. It is considered a symbol of Prague, its historical heritage.
Colored facades of tiny houses emerge on the cobblestone pavement. Sixteen old buildings have survived here. Zlat√° uliƒçka itself is a kind of museum. In nine of them, there are mini-museums dedicated to the former inhabitants of the street. The rest are souvenir shops.
There is a legend that alchemists lived on this street, receiving elixirs of eternal youth, gold, and a philosopher‚Äôs stone for the Emperor.
In the house ‚Ññ 22 lived Franz Kafka; he worked here on the collection ‚ÄúThe Village Doctor‚Äù. Now there is a bookshop in this building.
In the house ‚Ññ 14, marked with a sign depicting a cat, an owl, and a crystal ball, a fortune teller had her salon. Here is also a small house under ‚Ññ 27, once inhabited by a local healer. The house is filled with drugs and herbs, as befits a medieval pharmacy. A jeweler‚Äôs workshop can be viewed in the house ‚Ññ 15.
Try to find a house near the last lantern and ghosts of alchemists, prisoners of the White Tower and other former residents!
If you haven‚Äôt visited this magical street yet or missed it while being in Prague, I think now you are looking forward to making this destination your point number one.
Zlat√° uliƒçka is open every day 9:00‚Äì17:00. After 18:00 admission is free. But keep in mind that most souvenir shops are closed by this time.
How to get there? Go subway line A or tram 5, 12, 18, 20, 22 to the stop Malostransk√°.
5. Finally, climb the Pet≈ô√≠n Hill and watch Prague from the Observation Tower
There are many parks and gardens in Prague, but we strongly recommend you to visit Pet≈ô√≠n Hill as it offers a stunning view of the city‚Äôs red brick roofs.
Built as a mini version of Paris‚Äôs Eiffel Tower, the Petrin Observation Tower is 60m high. Climb 300 steps to reach the top of the tower, and the view over Prague is magnificent.
In the spring, hundreds of apples and cherries blossom there, filling the air with a heady aroma. Have a pleasant stroll around the rose garden.
Other attractions include an observatory, a museum, a telescope, a hall of mirrors, a church, and many nice cafes.
By the way, next to the Pet≈ô√≠n Hill, there is the Kinsk√Ω Garden (Zahrada Kinsk√Ωch). It is rather easy to go from one park to another, just find an arch in the wall that separates them. By the way, in the Kinsk√Ω Garden, you can find the Transcarpathian ancient church.
Once you have enjoyed the views of Prague, we recommend you to have dinner in Nebozizek Restaurant near Pet≈ô√≠n Hill. You can reach it on foot or by funicular.
To reach the Observation Tower at the top of Pet≈ô√≠n Hill, take the Funicular Railway. It departs from Ujezd street in the Lesser Town (Mal√° Strana), near Ujezd tram stop.
I think now you must be ready for an amazing trip to Prague. We hope our recommendations for your unforgettable sightseeing tour around Prague will be helpful and you will enjoy it!
If you had something to take away, add a clap / respond / highlight / follow me and subscribe to get emails as soon as I publish. We all go further when we help each other!‚Äù
Cheers ‚Äî KS !!

Some cool historical stuff to know about Prague before you go
Defiant. Resilient. Betrayed. Those are the words that come to mind as I walk through the streets of Prague for the first time and learn about this historic city on the Vltava River.
It is hard not to experience Prague and feel the weight of history that bears down of the city and the Czech people, who over the course of the last nearly 700 years, have been ruled for a majority of that time by other states, nations and empires.
Prague got off to a really strong start in the 14th Century under King Charles IV, who strengthened the economy, started the first university in Central Europe and expanded the Prague Castle, including starting construction of St. Vitus Cathedral. He also commissioned the famous bridge across the Vltava, which was started on July 9, 1357, at 5:31 a.m. when he laid the first stone. This is well known because the date and time create a numerical palindrome (1‚Äì3‚Äì5‚Äì7‚Äì9‚Äì7‚Äì5‚Äì3‚Äì1), which meant something to Medieval numerologists, who must have been on to something because the original bridge is still standing strong, 668 years later.

Title: The Ultimate Travel Guide: Prague
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
A beautiful and unique city known for everything ranging from its rich history to its active nightlife, Prague is a gem in the heart of the Czech Republic that cannot be missed.
Located in the northwest of the Czech Republic, Prague has a beauty that can only be understood by traveling to the city itself. Before starting my trip to Europe, I asked the advice of several other travelers about which destinations they recommend that I travel to. High on the list of many of these travelers was Prague. With so many recommendations, I simply had to visit. But what makes this city such a favorite among both travelers and its inhabitants?
To start with, I found the people of the Czech Republic to be very kind to their visitors; they wanted to share the country that they love so much with anyone who is willing to take the time to visit.
As far as activities go, exploring Prague without a map was one of my favorite experiences in the city. The day I arrived, I decided to wander around in search of food. In the process, I was able to get a glimpse of some of the famous architecture around the city, as well as some of its most iconic sights. After returning to my hostel, I was able to do some research into the history of these locations while also planning out the places I wanted to spend more time with.
As far as specific attractions go, Prague is a perfect city to visit no matter your time frame. With that being said, a few of the most prominent and worthwhile attractions include the Charles Bridge, all of Old Town, Wenceslas Square, Petrin Hills, and Prague Castle. The main sights can be seen in a tour around the city in a day (which requires a ton of walking), but that doesn‚Äôt mean you shouldn‚Äôt spend any more time there.
Now let‚Äôs pretend you have just arrived in Prague and you are eager to see everything you can in just one walking journey. Doing this, I would suggest starting in Wenceslas Square and walking down the slope towards Old Town. A walk through Old Town takes you through the picturesque streets of Prague, while also allowing you to visit the Astronomical Tower, the Old Town Square, and St. Nicolas‚Äô Church; all of which are well worth it if you find yourself in Prague. After seeing these iconic sights, wandering towards the Jewish Quarter of the city provides an opportunity to learn some of the history of the city through the years. From there, walk towards the river to see the concert hall known as Rudolfinum while listening to music written by Czech composers that you might not recognize by name, but you will recognize by their music. Walk along the Vltava River towards the Charles Bridge where you should take your time to take in the atmosphere and the unique architecture of the bridge as well as the views of Old Town and Prague Castle as they face off across the river. This walk brings you to the other side of the river where you can see the somewhat surprising Lennon Wall as well as taking a trip to Prague Castle.
This walking trip provides an opportunity to see most major sights in Prague. Like with any city, it is possible to go into more detail if you so desire, and Prague is a city that deserves that extra attention.
There are museums and historical sites littered throughout the city, and they are not hard to find. I visited the National Technical Museum in a quieter part of the city and I was blown away by the size and level of detail that the museum provided. Anyone with enough interest could spend a full day exploring every detail. In addition to that, the Jewish museum in the Jewish Quarter is well known and has the reputation of being very good, but I did not have the time to visit it, unfortunately. The Prague Castle allows for entry that is free of charge, but a ticket is required to visit some parts of the complex. Purchase of this ticket depends on the level of detail you wish to go into, and the amount of time you have to spend there.
The activity that I highly recommend is taking a trip to the Petrin Hills where you can buy a ticket to ascend Petrin Tower where the views of the city are simply breathtaking.
These examples stand as just a few options for ideas on how to make your trip to Prague as complete as you can want. After taking a walk around the city to see all of the sights, taking the public transportation provides for a welcome rest from all of the walking. The transportation is cheap and cost is based on time which makes it perfect for travelers who want unlimited travel for just a few days. As far as additional public transportation goes, taxis can be found throughout the city, but be sure to find a good price. In many instances, getting an Uber will be far more convenient and allow for the best possible price.
The Czech Republic is a beautiful country and its capital city is the culmination of the country‚Äôs beauty. Prague is a city that should be on every traveler‚Äôs list for its uniqueness, its culture, and its people.
Originally published at https://www.theodysseyonline.com on April 9, 2018.

In the heart of Prague, a city steeped in the history of the Czech Republic and adorned with ancient architecture, my lens embarked on a journey through the juxtaposition of tradition and modernity. Arriving on a cold, foggy night, Tochukwu couldn‚Äôt help but worry about the weather‚Äôs impact on his photo walk. However, as dawn broke and the city emerged from the mist, he felt a surge of anticipation.
The grand doors of historic buildings greeted me, their intricate designs creating a breathtaking backdrop for my subjects. As Tochukwu roamed the streets, he encountered a young woman, her weary steps echoing against the ancient stones. Entering through the colossal doors, she became a silent storyteller, a fusion of fatigue and the timeless beauty of Prague. The echo was clear for many others that he saw passing the ancient streets of Prague, as the walls laid a perfect canvas for my imagination.
But the city was not frozen in time. Construction workers toiled, transforming the ancient into the modern. Amid the scaffolding, a mapping car glided through the streets, documenting the metamorphosis. The synergy of human effort and technological advancement was a captivating dance, a visual representation of Prague‚Äôs evolution.
As Tochukwu framed scenes of change, he couldn‚Äôt ignore the emergence of local delivery startups like Wolt, challenging the global dominance of giants like Uber Eats and Bolt. It seemed as though the city had its rhythm, a beat that the local players danced to, dominating the delivery scene while the international names loomed in the background.
Yet, amidst the transformations, Prague held steadfast to its traditions. A local Christmas market, set up by merchants near the city centre, breathed life into the streets. The aromas of festive delights mingled with the sounds of cheerful chatter, creating a timeless haven amid the bustling changes.
Prague also embraced alternative transport, with cyclists weaving through the cobbled streets. Although the city lacked dedicated lanes, it provided ample parking spaces for bicycles, promoting a green and sustainable mode of commuting. Each photograph of a bicycle parking space or a cyclist captured a moment and a testament to the city‚Äôs commitment to eco-friendly living.
Amidst it all, an old woman, framed against the grand doors, puffed on her cigarette. It is a seemingly mundane act, yet poignant against the backdrop of ancient structures. It spoke of continuity, a personal ritual unfazed by the changing tides of time.
And then there were the old trams‚Äîpractical, reliable, and seemingly timeless. Moving people 24/7, these trams became the city's veins, circulating life through its historic arteries.
In one poignant frame, Tochukwu captured the essence of a young woman navigating the intricate tapestry of life in Prague. Her journey homeward was a visual symphony ‚Äî headphones in place, encapsulating a world of personal melodies or knowledge development, and in her grasp, a pack of tissues, an unspoken emblem of responsibilities both personal and professional. The photograph silently whispered of the delicate balance she maintained, seamlessly weaving the threads of her personal aspirations with the demands of her professional endeavours.
Prague revealed its story in every photograph‚Äîone of contrasts, resilience, and the harmonious coexistence of the old and the new. As the shutter clicked, each frame became a chapter, a testament to the city‚Äôs dynamic spirit and the ever-unfolding narrative of its streets.

Title: My 2‚Äìday Trip to Prague
Content:

As a Master‚Äôs student living in Munich for almost a year, I hadn‚Äôt ventured outside of Germany much, except for a brief visit to Maastricht. After finishing my exams two weeks ago, my friends and I decided to take a weekend trip to Prague. Being students, we couldn‚Äôt afford a longer trip without stretching our finances, and we all had commitments the following week. So, we planned a straightforward two-day trip, determined to make the most of our limited time.
Our plan was simple: catch a Flixbus from Munich to Prague at 7 a.m. on Saturday, arriving at noon, and return by 8 p.m. on Sunday. We booked a hostel near the city center so we could explore Prague on foot without worrying about public transportation. It seemed foolproof ‚Äî what could go wrong?
Well, things didn‚Äôt go quite as planned. We all made it to the bus on time, only to discover that the seats we had booked together in row 20 didn‚Äôt exist. The bus wasn‚Äôt configured as expected, and when we asked the Flixbus employee, he simply shrugged, saying there wasn‚Äôt much they could do. So, we reluctantly sat in random seats, separated from each other.
The journey was supposed to be straightforward, but when we made a stop in Regensburg, things took a turn. The bus, already nearly full when we left Munich, was supposed to be a two-story vehicle, but instead, it was a single-story bus. At Regensburg, there were many passengers waiting to board, but not enough seats. It quickly became clear that there had been a mix-up. The employees informed the waiting passengers that they‚Äôd have to wait for the next bus, which would arrive in two hours. This didn‚Äôt sit well with two elderly Ukrainian women who boarded the bus and refused to get off until the next bus arrived. As a result, we were all forced to wait for two hours.
Frustrated by the delay, we decided to grab some coffee to stay awake, as we were all pretty tired from the early start. While waiting outside the bus, a young Canadian couple approached us, asking for directions to the bakery where we had bought our coffee. The guy went to get their drinks, while the girl stayed and joined our conversation. We learned that they were from Quebec and had been exploring Europe for a week, also heading to Prague. When the guy returned, we chatted for about an hour, discussing everything from European culture to the situation with the two Ukrainian women holding up our trip.
About 20 minutes before the other bus was due to arrive, a shy teenage girl slowly joined our conversation. We found out she was from Prague and had been taking a German course in Regensburg. Her local knowledge came in handy, and we asked her for recommendations on what to see and do in Prague.
Finally, after what felt like an eternity, the second bus arrived, and the extra passengers boarded. We resumed our journey, but by the time we reached Prague, I was in desperate need of a bathroom. After handling that situation, we checked in at our hostel, which was conveniently located near the city center. The hostel was basic, a small room on the 5th floor with four beds and no windows, but thankfully it had air conditioning, as the weather was quite warm.
We took quick showers and headed out to explore the city. By then, it was already 3 p.m., so we started with a checking out the exterior of the National Czech Museum, right next to our hostel. Prague‚Äôs architecture immediately captivated us ‚Äî vibrant colors, tiled streets, and historic buildings at every turn.
Feeling hungry, we went to a Czech restaurant recommended by the girl we met on the bus and tried traditional dishes like Sv√≠ƒçkov√° and Czech goulash, accompanied by the famous Czech beer. Fun fact: the Czech Republic has the highest beer consumption per capita in the world, which was surprising to learn, given that I live in Bavaria.
After our meal, we made our way to the Old Town Square, passing the quirky Dancing House and numerous tourists along the way. We couldn‚Äôt resist trying Trdeln√≠k, a sweet treat made of a cinnamon roll-like cone filled with ice cream and fruits. Delicious as it was, it attracted a lot of bees ‚Äî something to keep in mind if you ever try it!
At the Old Town Hall, we met up with the Canadian couple again to see the Prague Astronomical Clock. Afterward, we walked through the city, crossing the beautiful Charles Bridge over the Vltava River, surrounded by stunning views and people enjoying boat rides. We decided to save the boat ride for the next day and continued towards Prague Castle. The hike up to the castle was challenging, but the view was worth it. Although the ticket booth for the castle interior was closed, we explored the castle grounds and admired the colorful, doll-like houses on Golden Lane.
By this point, we had walked nearly 15 kilometers and were ready for dinner. After trying several places that were either full or had closed kitchens, we found a laid-back burger place where we ate and drank until 11 p.m. Exhausted, we finally called it a day and returned to our hostel.
The next day, we started with breakfast at a local caf√©, then headed to the Czech National Museum. This museum was incredible, with rooms dedicated to everything from minerals and history to World War II and various species of animals. We spent four hours there, completely absorbed in the exhibits.
After the museum, we met up with the Canadian couple again for a planned boat ride on the Vltava River. However, the boat operator warned us of an impending storm, which we didn‚Äôt believe at first because the weather seemed fine. Fast forward a little, and we were running through the rain to the nearest restaurant. The storm dashed our hopes for the boat ride, but we found a fantastic Italian restaurant where we spent the next two hours waiting for the rain to subside, enjoying great pizza, beer, and conversation.
As the rain eased, we reluctantly made our way back to the bus station, still a bit wet and tired. Despite a half-hour delay, the return bus ride was uneventful, and we finally arrived in Munich at 3 a.m., facing long routes home via public transport.
Despite the challenges and setbacks, the trip to Prague was incredibly satisfying. The city left a lasting impression, and I‚Äôm already eager to return to explore more ‚Äî like the Jewish Cemetery, beer bath, Sex Machine Museum, Beer Museum, Ice Bar, Torture Museum, and many more fascinating places.
I‚Äôm writing this recollection of my trip to Prague in order to preserve the beautiful memories I had. I hope you enjoy it as much as I did!

Content:
