Title: Caf√©s and coffeehouses in Prague 1
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
2
Listen
Share
After ‚Äî back in May 2000 ‚Äî I secured my monthly Metro pass, moved into my crash-pad, and got all of the visa, residence, and working permit paperwork half-way done, the real problem started: Where to get a coffee that actually deserves its name? Plus, what caf√© or coffeehouse in good old Praha 1 (roughly) can you sit in comfortably and read, write, watch people, and/or chat? Back then, Prague didn‚Äôt have much that compared favorably to the coffeehouses in Vienna[1], or even some Starbucks outlet.
Things have seriously changed since then. It started around 2002 with a series of CoffeeHeaven outlets, a Polish coffee and sandwich chain that modeled itself after Starbucks but which had to sell years back all its outlets to London-based Costa Coffee. These days it seems that Costa Coffee has at least one shop on every downtown block. I still have my CoffeeHeaven bonus card, and Costa Coffee honor it, and I feel very smug every time I use it.
Around 2007‚Äì8, Starbucks finally invaded Prague with a couple of strategically located outlets and has since added a number of outlets, mostly in downtown. Google Starbucks in Prague. You can have your first SBUX fix at the airport. There are outlets for example at V√°clavsk√© n√°m. 40 (corner ≈†tƒõp√°nsk√°), Jungmannova 34, Sp√°len√° 74/18 (near metro station N√°rodn√≠ t≈ô√≠da), and a couple of them near Old Town Square and so on. Can‚Äôt really miss them. The offerings are standard, as is the coffee and the food-stuff they offer. I have come to appreciate them because many of them are spacious (e.g., second level at V√°clavsk√© n√°m. or the yuuuge Jungmannova outlet), they have free and reasonably good wifi (and no one cares whether you sit there for hours and hammer away), and the staff tends to be friendly and know what they are doing. Unfortunately that is often not true for many of the Costa Coffee places which can be claustrophobic, are run by staff that occasionally seems in over its head, and just seem less well-trained and efficient than their SBUX counterparts. That said, the Costa Coffee outlet in the V√°clavsk√© n√°m. (‚ÄúRokoko‚Äù) pas√°≈æ remains one of my fav meeting places, increasingly though due to its centrality and short walking distance from my Praha workplace rather than the foodstuff or coffee they offer.
There are, of course, scores of nice stand-alone places (or minor chains such as mamacoffee, about which more in a sec) where you can have a good kava and read, write, chat comfortably, and/or dream. In short, places that fulfil the Rubinstein criterion, i.e., a place ‚Äúwhere you can ‚Ä¶ think!‚Äù (I note parenthetically that for Ariel ‚Äî who drinks strongly watered down instant coffee ‚Äî it is all about the ambiance, while for me it is about both the environs and the quality of the coffee!)
In the neighborhood where I live (Prague 10, Vr≈°ovice), there were ‚Äî before the pandemic ‚Äî about a dozen cafes (no less than three within 20 meters of the Rusk√° tram stop) of which many were quite nice. Unfortunately, half of them have shut down. If you happen to be in my hood, do try this one which happens to pass the Rubinstein test with flying colors. As does this one, just a hundred meters down the road.
But this write-up is about cafes and coffee houses in Praha 1. So there. Talking about places that don‚Äôt exist any longer but that nurtured my coffee addiction while living in Prague: a shout-out to now defunct Ebel Coffee House, Kawa Kawa Kawa, and the Tonkin caf√©!
Prague‚Äôs is still not quite comparable to the coffee culture that exists in Sydney or Melbourne but getting a good coffee in Prague is no longer the very real problem it was back in May 2000. Tripadvisor, under Restaurants in Prague, subsection Coffee & Tea, currently lists 367 places.
Below are the results of my recent, and very diligent, research in matters kava in Prague 1 (downtown). Suggestions for places I missed, or even dissenting opinions, are always welcome. Send to aortmann@gmail.com, or comment below if you like.
I take responsibility for all errors in judgement.
My current favorites follow presently (places I don‚Äôt much like have their own section at the end); note that none of my thirteen recommendations has made it to the top ten in the Tripadvisor ranking of best 10 caf√©s in Praha 1 (City Center). I am sure that those in the Tripadvisor top ten fail the Rubinstein test (Coffee Places where you can ‚Ä¶ think!)
Divadelini kavarna, attached to STUDIO DVA DIVADLO, Wenceslas Square 56, nestled away in a pasaz (Fenix palace/Palac Fenix)
Located in a pasaz off Vaclavske namesti but hidden enough to normally not being discovered by tourists, this has been one of my favorites for years.
You can sit inside and outside (in the pasaz that is), they offer coffee and wine and some fine food stuff such as omelettes, pancakes, hommos and avocado sandwiches, cheesecake with raspberry sauce, chocolate curd cake, etc.
A great place to have conversations while sipping a coffee, or a glass of wine for that matter. Note the pictures on the wall ‚Äî portraits of less or more famous Czech actors. Don‚Äôt be surprised if you see one of these folks at the table next to you. That‚Äôs because this is the place where the actors go, after the show and before, and before and after practices at the attached divadlo, too.
The restaurant/kavarna is open from 9:00 am to 23:00 on weekdays and at 11:00 on weekends or holidays; breakfast is served until 11 only. So no omelettes on the weekend. Shucks because their omelettes are to die for.
They do have free wifi.
I can‚Äôt find them on Tripadvisor or Facebook.
Warning: There‚Äôs a bunch of divadelini kavarnas out there, so make sure you go to right one.
Monkey Coffee House Opletalova 922/8 Praha 1 (and also Pod Harfou 995/23)
A somewhat Spartan coffee house although they also have wine on offer. They (and I‚Äôm talking about the Opletalova site which opened early in 2023) have some sweet stuff (brownies, banana bread, impressive croissants) but various kinds of excellent coffees (including hand brews) and it‚Äôs a great place to have conversations while sipping a coffee.
The Opletalova site opens at 8 am and closes at 6 pm, all week including weekends (as of now) when they currently start at 10 am.
They do have free wifi.
You can find them on Tripadvisor and Facebook although most of the pictures there are for the Pod Harfou site for now. They are on Instagram, too. My Tripadvisor review is here.
Bonus: Across the street from them is a place that offers a well-stocked assortment of Italian food imports, from coffee capsules, to chocolate, to grappa, and vino. Also, a few meters to the right there‚Äôs a cafe with lots of fabulous cakes etc. and next to that is a bakery with incredibly good bread.
Cafe Academia Vaclavske Namesti 792/34
This is in the middle of the city and Tourist Central. But you won‚Äôt know because the cafe is clearly frequented mostly by locals, last but not least (older) ladies reading in the books from the bookstore. ;-)
The cafe is nestled away on the second floor, in the back, of the Academia bookstore (which in fact is where you find the academic books). The coffee is surprisingly good. (Not quite of Monkey Coffee House quality but then what is ?!) They also have some sweet and tempting stuff (and even a cheese or ham&cheese toast, with salad) and a few house wines, in case you want to ease into winetime. ;-)
The bookstore of which the cafe is a part of is large and one of the better ones in Prague. (They have a sizable section of English language books downstairs.)
While the cafe is quite nice ‚Äî real flowers and comfy chairs and all, with service that has some upside potential‚Äî , there is also balcony overlooking V√°clavsk√© n√°mƒõst√≠ on the other side of the second floor. Great view!
They are open from 9‚Äì19:30 on weekdays and 10‚Äì18:30/17:30 on weekends.
They do not have free wifi but my eduroam connected automatically and just fine. (There is also free wifi in much of downtown Prague, so you should be able to log in from pretty much everywhere.)
You can find the Academia cafe on Tripadvisor and Facebook. They are on Instagram, too.
Spell Jind≈ôi≈°sk√° 939/20, nestled away in a yard, entrance next to the (awful) Green Tomato restaurant, and attached to a hair studio
You can sit inside and outside, they offer coffee (not bad, but not of Monkey Coffee House quality) and some sweet stuff including a bowl with tvarok and fruit that is excellent. They have wine, too.
Another great place to have conversations while sipping a coffee, or a glass of wine or two.
They are open from 7:00 am to 20:00 on weekdays and open at 8:00 and 10:00 on weekends when they close earlier (14:00 and 18:00 it seems).
They do have free wifi.
You can find them on Tripadvisor and Facebook and also Instagram.
The Barrister caf√© and winebar (Kav√°rna | Vin√°rna) ≈†tƒõp√°nsk√° 629/59 (across the street from the Alcron Hotel, a few metres down the street, literally a stone‚Äôs throw away from Wenceslas Square)
A wide and stylish space, where you can sit and read and write. And have conversations. And where you can segue from coffee time to wine time without having to change the location. What‚Äôs not to like?
The coffee is good, as are the wine offerings. They do have some sweets, and a couple of other food offerings. Their menu is here. For downtown Prague the prices are reasonable.
The service is friendly and professional, mostly.
Open every weekday 8:00 to 22:00 and during the vikend from 9:00 to 22:00 and 13:00, respectively.
They have free wifi.
You can find them on Instagram here and on Facebook here (mostly in Czech though). The do have a (claimed) Tripadvisor page but there are no reviews yet as of 26 June 2025. Give it a try!
Sicily caf√© Senov√°≈æn√© n√°m. 994/2 Praha 1
It is both a kavarna and restaurant. You can find their offerings here (in Czech and English); lots of nice stuff (lots of veg(etari)an options).
It‚Äôs a good place to work, shoot the breeze, or have conversations although it does get quite crowded around lunch time, so if you like to work there, it is best to go there in off-peak hours.
They open at 8:30 on weekdays and 9:30 on the weekend and close at 22:00 (except Sunday when they close at 21:00).
Breakfast weekdays until 12:00 and weekends all day.
They have free wifi although ‚Äúsometimes it don‚Äôt work‚Äù as a waitress (who clearly could not care less) informed me on a recent outing.
You can find them on Tripadvisor and Facebook. My 2016 Tripadvisor review is here.
Mama caf√© Vodiƒçkova 10 Praha 1 (about 5 minutes leisurely walk from V√°clavsk√© n√°mƒõst√≠, follow the tram tracks)
It‚Äôs part of a chain that has other branches in Prahe 2, 3, 4, and Praha 7. There is apparently another related caf√© in Praha 1 (Caf√© NEZISK at Poho≈ôelec 2). A trust-worthy informant tells me that the Vinohrady (also Praha 2) site is even better than the Vodiƒçkova site.
The Vodiƒçkova site is both a kavarna and restaurant that has daily menus of brekkie (scrambled eggs, curd pancakes, granola), various hummus related dishes (e.g., hummus with pita, hummus bowl, mezze plate), and sandwiches (e.g with egg spread or green pea spread); lots of veg(etari)an options. You can substitute the pita with veggie sticks if you so desire. Plus plenty of sweet stuff (cakes!) of tempting quality. You can find their offerings here (in Czech and English and several other languages). The food is really quite good and relatively inexpensive. Say, simple scrambled eggs are 165 koruns and come with a lovely serving of coleslaw, or some other salad du jour. The espresso is on the bitter side for my taste; the latte, even if strong, is on the weak side.
It‚Äôs a great place to work though, shoot the breeze, or have conversations although it does get quite crowded quickly (e.g., on a recent Saturday morning at 10 a.m. all seats were occupied), so if you like to work there, it is best to go there in off-peak hours.
They open at 8:00 on weekdays and 9:00 on the weekend and close at 22:00 (except weekends when they close at 20:00). Service tends to be exceptionally nice.
They do have free wifi (and it works best on the upper floor which is also much more spacious than the ground floor.)
You can find them on Tripadvisor and Facebook.
Prague Bakeshop Kozi 1
This place existed when I moved to Prague in 2000. It was under different ownership then and has been a bit modernized but it is basically the same configuration and many of the same goodies and the same coffee cups etc.
It‚Äôs not a place where you could work; too crowded especially during peak hours. (Beware of pocket thiefs then in particular.) The saving grace are the wooden benches outside. In fact, that‚Äôs where you find me many Saturday and Sunday mornings. That‚Äôs because it‚Äôs the best place in downtown Prague to get a good coffee at 7 a.m. every day of the week. (Yes, that includes Saturdays and Sundays.) Plus, the area in which the Prague Bakeshop is located (very very close to Old Town Square), is absolutely peaceful and gorgeous that early in the morning. (Well, mostly, if you can ignore the drunkards, and shady characters, that spill out of the bars across the street. Most of them are fun to watch.)
A great way to start the day. In fact, I can‚Äôt think of a much better way to start it. Try their croissants, dorty (cakes), kolaces (tarts, tortes, pies), sandwiches, or quiches. Or their coffee (which for my taste is on the weak side but drinkable).
Open every day 7‚Äì21.
They now have (free) wifi. Took them a long time to get there! (Pro-tip: It sometimes does not work but outside you can log into the free wifi of the James Dean club across the street.)
You can study their menu here, in both Czech and English.
You can find them on Tripadvisor and Facebook. My 2018 Tripadvisor review is here.
Head Shot Coffee Palack√©ho 720/5, located in the Franciscan Gardens, in the corner furthest away from the entrances
A fairly small space with a lovely outside, where you can sit and write. And have conversations. It‚Äôs not the kind of place that a tourist would easily find; it seems indeed frequented by locals mostly.
HSC offers various kinds of coffee and an inviting selection of deliciously looking cakes etc. A few sandwiches and hummus, too.
Open every week day from 8:00 to 19:30. Saturdays and Sunday they are currently open from 10:00 to 18:00.
They have free wifi.
You can find them on Tripadvisor, and Facebook and Instagram.
Caf√© Truhl√°rna Franti≈°k√°nsk√° zahrada, Jungmannovo n√°m. 751/19 (when you enter the Gardens from Jungmanova namesti, 50 meters to the left)
A fairly small space with a lovely outside, where you can sit and write. And have conversations. It‚Äôs not the kind of place that a tourist would easily find but they do occasionally, although the Truhlarna folks advertise themselves and their wares on a blackboard outside in Czech only; it seems frequented by locals mostly.
The cafe offers various kinds of coffee and an inviting selection of deliciously looking cakes etc. A few sandwiches, too. Very friendly staff.
Open every day except Sunday from 8:30 to 20:00 except for Saturday and Sunday when they start at 10:00.
They have free wifi and their network is called zahrahda; password is posted at the counter.
You can find them on Tripadvisor, and Facebook and Instagram.
Goodlok caf√© Jungmannovo namEsti 18 (next to the entrance to Francescan Gardens, near the SBUX on Jungmannovo namEsti)
A wide open space, where you can sit and write. And have conversations. Although I suspect, it being in Tourist Central neighborhood, the staff would not look at you too kindly if you sit there for hours at a time. Or for that matter, potential visitors.
Goodlok offers various kinds of coffee and an inviting selection of fruit juices and kombuchas. They also have omelettes (very good indeed, I had), kimchi-toasts, and other offerings. Food is served until 15:00 Personnel is friendly.
Open every weekday 8:00 to 18:00; not open on weekends it seems.
They have free wifi.
You can study their menu here, in Czech.
You can find them on Tripadvisor (two sites! here and here, few reviews but raves all the same), and Instagram.
Kavarna Adria formally, N√°rodn√≠ 40, but adjacent to Jungmannovo namEsti (on the second floor of the massive Pal√°c Adria building)
This is an amazing space (including a very large terrasse), where you can sit and write. And have conversations. It is still to some extent Tourist Central neighborhood (last but not least since the place is written up in many a tourist guide), alas ‚Ä¶ my experiences have been mostly good. But then I rarely get anything complicated. Mostly caffe lattes (strong) or double espressos, occasionally the cheese omelette, very occasionally a poppy seed cake, etc. I should mention that the dozen or so cakes Adria has on offer are superb and if you are sweet-tooth, you definitely want to try a couple at least.
Service runs the gamut and I am not surprised to see service on Tripadvisor rated a dismal 3.5. With some reporting pretty bad experiences.
Open weekdays 8:00 to 23:00, and weekends from 9:00 to 22:00.
They have free wifi.
You can study their (lunch) menu here, in Czech and English.
Coffee Cube Black Jungmannovo n√°m. 6/767 (Thanks, Michael!)
Fantova kavarna Wilsonova 300/8
Tynska Literarni Kavarna Tynska 630/6
Kavarna Kampus Hybernsk√° Hybernsk√° 4 (Thanks, Sebastian!)
Super Tramp Coffee Opatovick√° 160 (Thanks, Elisaveta!)
Liliov√° (Choco Caf√©) Liliov√° 250/4 (Thanks, Adela!)
So these are my favorite places right now, most of them not well-known but I am confident you will not be disappointed. There are many more well-known cafes and coffeehouses in Prague such as Caf√© Louvre (not bad actually but failing the Rubinstein test), Caf√© Slavia, Caf√© Savoy (all on the tram 22 line, within a kilometer), Cerna Madona/Grand Caf√© Orient, BISTRO, Caf√© Boulevard (currently an astonishing 1.5 on Tripadvisor! Avoid!), etc.
[1] As Lenka Reinerova ‚Äî may she rest in peace ‚Äî put it, ‚ÄúWhere, so I ask myself often when I wander through my Prague, have all the coffeehouses gone; those coffeehouses where, over a cup of good black coffee, you could spend much of the day discussing, making plans, hearing the latest gossip, watching ‚Äî or getting to know ‚Äî interesting people, making friends, or even falling in love.‚Äù (Das Traumcaf√© einer Pragerin [my caf√© in the sky, 1996; my translation.)

Title: 2 Days in Prague with Mari-Alina Timoshchuk ‚Äî Part 1
Content:
Sign up

Sign up

4
Listen
Share
‚ÄúThe streets of Prague were a fantasia scarcely touched by the twenty-first century ‚Äî or the twentieth or nineteenth, for that matter. It was a city of alchemists and dreamers, its medieval cobbles once trod by golems, mystics, invading armies.‚Äù ‚Äî Laini Taylor
The first sttlement of what is now Prague has been traced to the second half of the 9th century. The oldest building was Vy≈°ehrad (‚Äúcastle‚Äù), set on a commanding right bank hill. It was followed by what was to become Hradƒçany, set on an equally commanding left bank site a little downstream.
The name Prague, also known as Praha in Czech, is believed to originate from an old Slavic word, pr√°h, which means ‚Äúthreshold‚Äù or ‚Äúford‚Äù. This refers to Prague‚Äôs location at a crossing point of the Vltava River and possibly to the city‚Äôs low-lying areas as a ‚Äúthreshold‚Äù to the Prague Castle. Another theory suggests the name comes from the verb ‚Äúpra≈æit‚Äù meaning ‚Äúto roast‚Äù or ‚Äúto burn,‚Äù possibly referring to the practice of removing forest cover by fire.
I think there‚Äôs a few cities in the world that have a genuine amount of magic in them, and Prague is definitely one of them. Once known as the nucleus of the Bohemian state Prague exudes it‚Äôs rich and complex history through every brick and spire.. I‚Äôll give you an overview of how we spent our two days in this magical city and hopefully it can help with your own trip planning to this incredible destination.
After arriving in the Czech airport it‚Äôs very simple to take public transport in the form of a bus to Old Town Square which is like Disney World for history lovers.
The square‚Äôs center is home to a statue of religious reformer Jan Hus, who was burned at the stake in Konstanz for his beliefs. There are also memorials to the ‚Äúmartyrs‚Äù (including Jan Jesenius and Maxmillian Hostalek) who were beheaded on that spot during the Old Town Square execution by Hasburgs after the Battle of White Mountain. Ironically, greater than 70% of the Czech Republic identifies as religiously unaffiliatd with atheism being the most prominent non-religious affiliation.
Since this was the last leg of our honeymoon my husband splurged on the suite looking over the Old Town Square and a direct view of the incredible Astronomical Clock.
Straight out of the Golden Compass the Astronomical Clock (or Prague Orloj) is an icon of the Czech Republic. The clock mechanic, has 3 main cmponents: (1) the astronomical dial, representing the position of the sun and moon; (2) statues of various Catholic saints standing on either side of the clock; (3) ‚ÄúThe Walk of the Apostles,‚Äù an hourly show of moving apostle figures and other sculptures, notably a figure of a skeleton that represents Death, striking the time, and a calender dial with medallions representing the months.
According to legend, the city will suffer if the clock is neglected and its operation placed in jeopardy.
Prague is known as the ‚ÄúCity of a Hundred Spires‚Äù (or sometimes ‚ÄúCity of 500 Spires‚Äù) because of the numerous turrets, towers, and spires that dot the city‚Äôs skyline. These spires, found on churches, castles, townhouses, and other historical structures, are a defining feature of Prague‚Äôs architectural landscape. The name was popularized by a 19th-century mathematician who counted the spires, and while the exact number has varied over time, the city‚Äôs skyline remains iconic for its spires.
We spent our first day just soaking in the amazing sites and history of the city. The city is very walkable and at every turn you can see architecture from a plethora of centuries all coming together to make a uniquely distinct Prague.
You can‚Äôt miss the Powder Tower, which is a dramatic 65 meter tall gothic tower built as one of the 13 gates to the city. This monumental entrance was taken by the Czech kings entering into Old Town during their coronation processions. It‚Äôs name comes from its former rol as a gunpowder store. A viewing gallery is located at a height of 44 meters providing a dazzling view of Prague.
No trip to Prague is complete without a walk (or 3‚Ä¶or 5) across the Charles Bridge. This bridge is guardd by thirty statues and sculptures of saints representing the great personalities of European and global history, each f whom somehow moved the world and changed it for the better. The spirituality of the saints gives Charles Bridge a mystical aura, a sort of open-air temple enclosed by the bridge towers. The bridge is particularly spectacular at night when the light of the gas lamps sculpts the architectural stone.
To make a wish, you can rub the figure of Jan Nepomuk which has been worn to a fine polish from centuries of previous wishes. For your second wish you will need to head towards the middle of the bridge. Yes you heard that right ‚Äî this is a BOGO wish bridge situation. On the parapet of the bridge is a bronze statue of a saint with 5 stars around his head. To make a wish, put the finger of your right hand on the 5 stars. In this case, the left hand should be on the legs of Nepomuk. Then you need to step on the gold nail with your right foot. All three of these conditions must be completed for the second wish to come true.
Additionally around the city you can find a plethora of unique shops and markets. I particularly loved all the jewelery and glass stores. Prague, and by extension the Czech Republic, is famous for its glass, particularly Bohemian glass and crystal, due to a long tradition of craftsmanship, high quality, and unique designs.
One of my favorite things about Prague was the people. The hospitality in Italy and so much of Europe is gracious and a little over the top, but being in Prague I felt there was a certain down to earth and straightforward nature that was succinct but polite all at the same time. Being Ukrainian, I felt straight at home.
The food in Prague was absolutely incredible. One of our favorite restaurants was called Mincovna which was the former location of the Prague Mint. Every dish we tried there was incredible but I particularly loved the rabit and dumplings.
Of course, no discussion about Prague would be thorough without commenting on its rich beer culture. Pilsner Urquell is located adjacent to Prague and Straropramen, a major brewery, is a popular tourist destination with a visitor center and tours. The brewery‚Äôs history dates back to 1869, and it offers a diverse range of beers, including their flagship Staropramen brand. Prague also has smaller, independent breweries and brewpubs, some of which are listed in other search results.
I‚Äôm not a big beer fan but I really enjoyed the beer in Prague. In the Czech Republic, you‚Äôll often encounter beers poured with a significant head of foam, which is considered an important part of the beer‚Äôs experience. This style, sometimes referred to as ‚Äúml√≠ko,‚Äù is intentionally designed to have a thick, creamy head. This foam serves to keep the beer cold, fresh, and even adds a layer of sweetness that balances the beer‚Äôs bitterness
I highly recommend getting a good tour of the city since trying all of Pragues tasty treats is easiest with a well equipped guide (and who doesn‚Äôt like good company?).
Our food tour guide took us to see a plethora of Prague food classics included open faced sandwiches, which was a personal favorite as a I grew up eating them in my Ukranian family.
My personal favorites on the tour were the enormous (and I mean ENORMOUS) pork hok and pork schnitzel.
Our food tour guide not only covered the food of the city but also it‚Äôs history and culture. One particular story I enjoyed was of a Czech christmas food tradition, particularly in Prague, involving a carp. According to her it‚Äôs tradition to buy a live carp, bring them home, and keep them in the bathtub until Christmas Eve, sometimes naming them and treating them like pets. The carp is then cooked, often fried and served with potato salad, and is a key part of the Christmas Eve meal.
In my opinion the best evening sweet treat in Prague is the Trdeln√≠k. This is a kind of spit cake and variant of K√ºrt≈ëskal√°cs. It is made from dough that is wrapped around a stick, then baked and topped with sugar and walnut mix and filled with ice cream. Aka ‚Äî pure ice cream heaven.
In Part 2 of this 2 day trip I‚Äôll cover our second day in Prague which consisted of a bike tour, trip to the modern art museum, and the most incredible library tour. Hope this helped in your own travel plans!
--
--
4
Aspiring oral and maxillofacial surgeon, bookworm, corgi mom

Title: Dark History, Darker Tourism: Exploring Prague‚Äôs Abandoned Past
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
History is impossible to remove from the minds of inhabitants, especially an entire nation‚Äôs past. It reminds them of everything they, or those before them, fought for and eventually lost. The hardship and torment can be seen in the very architecture, and if walls could talk, they‚Äôd surely cry out. Regular buildings no longer hold their innocence as every physical object takes on a new negative connotation.
Countries like Germany have dealt with this positively, owning up to the war crimes their ancestors committed. The Czech Republic, however, has not.
The capital city of Prague is a metropolis that, despite its newfound cultural optimism, has been beaten down by tyranny and existed under the boot of powers much larger than their own.
Yet, there is a previously unknown demographic of travelers that would be ecstatic to uncover the darker sides of the nation‚Äôs history. These individuals travel the world, specifically visiting the strangest and most infamous tourist attractions offered ‚Äí and sometimes restricted ‚Äí on the map. Visiting historical sites closely connected to death or tragedy is known as ‚ÄúDark Tourism.‚Äù
Dark tourists get engrossed in the past in the oddest ways possible, whether on a stroll through the highly irradiated city of Chernobyl or a drive past the assassination spot of President John F. Kennedy. When death and tragedy strike, you can be sure, a dark tourist will be there a few hundred years later, Geiger Counter and a digital camera in-hand.
Despite being highly criticized as yet another way to desecrate or exploit a historical area and the dead associated with it, the popularity of Dark Tourism has risen in the last decade.
With the popularization of shows like the Netflix Original ‚ÄúDark Tourist,‚Äù hosted by a New Zealander journalist, David Farrier, a whole new generation of dark tourists have emerged. Those who have seen Farrier‚Äôs excursions have witnessed an exponential amount of dark, thrilling, and outright controversial historical sites and experiences.
This is not your family‚Äôs average summer trip up to Mount Rushmore. In the show, Farrier meets Pablo Escobar‚Äôs charismatic enforcer, Popeye, in Columbia, and is guided through Escobar‚Äôs former apartment by the drug lord‚Äôs sister-in-law. David then witnesses an exorcism in Mexico and participates in a faux illegal border crossing. That‚Äôs just the first episode. Viewers see the danger and the controversy as appealing elements to this strange take on the typical family vacation.
The popularity of dark tourism has brought light to areas otherwise forgotten by society. Along with the extension of tourism, there is a necessity to address these events as something that has indeed happened and impossible to be neglected further. Cue the Czech Republic.
Under the site of what was once a 14,200-ton statue of the international icon of tyranny, Joseph Stalin, lives Prague‚Äôs newest and most innovative dark tourism hotspot. Organized by ‚ÄúPost Bellum,‚Äù an organization preserving Czech historical memory, this new exhibit opened to touch all recent modern cases of threatened life in the Czech Republic.
The exhibit offers a truly immersive look into Czech oppression of the 20th century. A dark, narrow-gated hallway with the only intruding sunlight from the doorway behind, leads visitors‚Äô way to the viewing room. As the gate stops further down, ominous spotlights greet you.
From there you are thrown straight into a memorable experience filled with artificial gunfire, neon lighting, and even a secret police interrogation similar to those done to political prisoners in the early 1950s. A projector lights up the floor with planes bombing the terrain. The room paints a grim moving picture of Czech Jews being herded into concentration camps, like unsuspecting cattle to the slaughter.
You are then transported into the crypt of St. Cyril and St. Methodius Cathedral, where the paratroopers sent to assassinate Reinhard Heydrich, high-ranking German Nazi official, are killed by overwhelming German forces. The room begins flooding and gunfire ricochets off the cement walls. Though only a simulation, the threat of danger seems real.
Dark tourists will immediately be intrigued by the immersive experience of reliving central Europe‚Äôs most gruesome moments. However, the purpose of this exhibit is not to purely glorify violence.
The experience is meaningfully disorientating, revealing a fraction of what the country has had to go through to shape itself into how we know it today. It is no coincidence that this exhibit correlates with the 100th anniversary of Czechoslovakia‚Äôs establishment, as it was designed to illustrate the long process of cultural identity.
There is a separate portion of the exhibit with an enclosed screening room where you can hear actual testimonials by those who lived in the eras of outright oppression. Jewish concentration camp survivors, former Communist party members, and victims of the vast oppression have all been recorded to give an oral first-person report of what transpired. This puts a face to the chaos and gives you an opportunity to sympathize.
Prague has limited museums covering this era, and none of them offer this intense look into almost a century of oppression and hardship. Presenting this narrative using particular lighting and audio arrangements convey the point well, simultaneously attracting dark tourists. That is what may just normalize the nation‚Äôs dark history: a darker form of tourism.
--
--
Peter is an undergraduate student, currently studying at the Anglo American University in Prague. He is a photographer, videographer, and writer.

Title: Prof. Kocka‚Äôs Warning from Prague: What Are We About to Forget?
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Prof. J√ºrgen Kocka spoke in Prague on Germany‚Äôs complex remembrance culture, addressing Nazi crimes, Germans as victims, expulsion, and the rise of populism. His reflections offer timely lessons for democracy.
On May 13, 2025, the Academy of Sciences of the Czech Republic hosted one of the most distinguished German historians of our time, Prof. J√ºrgen Kocka. In a packed lecture hall at N√°rodn√≠ 3, Prague, an audience of scholars, students, and interested citizens listened to his lecture: ‚ÄúMemory, Conflict and Research. Dealing with a Difficult Past.‚Äù This event was organized by the Collegium Carolinum, the German Historical Institute Warsaw, and the Leibniz Institute for History and Culture of Eastern Europe.
Prof. Kocka, born 1941 in Hejnice (Haindorf), northern Bohemia, expelled as a child, is uniquely positioned to reflect on the interwoven German and Central European histories. His academic journey led him to Bielefeld, Berlin, UCLA, and his research has shaped the international discourse on modern and social history.
The lecture offered a sweeping analysis of how Germany has dealt with its difficult 20th-century past, the Nazi dictatorship, its crimes, and the legacy of flight and expulsion in the aftermath of World War II. Kocka clearly distinguished between the Federal Republic and the GDR in their contrasting approaches to the Nazi past. While the West pursued a painful, slow, and self-critical confrontation, the East projected the Nazi past as a capitalist aberration, distancing its socialist present from any guilt.
‚ÄúCommemoration becomes more abstract, less concrete, more institutionalized, more routinized‚Äù
Prof. Kocka observed, highlighting the challenges faced by younger generations in maintaining a vivid connection to the past. The second part of his lecture focused on Germans as victims -specifically, the millions who suffered flight and expulsion. Kocka underlined how difficult and politically charged this topic remained for decades, as many expellee organizations mixed legitimate memory with territorial claims. Only after 1990, with the definitive recognition of Germany‚Äôs eastern borders, could reconciliation with the neighbor countries and a more open remembrance culture develop.
Kocka gave special mention to the growing role of museums and local remembrance initiatives, such as the Isergebirgsmuseum in Bavaria, that now foster dialogue across former national divides.
However, his most thought-provoking section addressed recent shifts. In recent years, Germany has faced the rise of right-wing populism, symbolized by the Alternative f√ºr Deutschland (AfD).
‚ÄúAfD speakers have demanded a 180-degree reversal of the course of our historical culture.‚Äù
Kocka warned, that AfD tries to play down the importance of the Nazi dictatorship and describe it as a minimal and excusable aberration, as a piece of foolishness.
At this point, I would like to add my personal comment. While I fully understand Prof. Kocka‚Äôs analytical caution, I believe the rise of the AfD also reflects deeper dissatisfaction in parts of society. In both East and West Germany, many people feel that the traditional parties have lost touch with the everyday concerns of their voters. The growing appeal of populists is not only about historical memory, but also about social frustration.
There is a Czech proverb that captures this dynamic very well:
‚ÄúKdo seje v√≠tr, skl√≠z√≠ bou≈ôi‚Äù
‚ÄúHe who sows the wind shall reap the storm.‚Äù
Germany, a country that has had bitter experience with the consequences of political radicalization, should not forget that social alienation can undermine even the strongest democratic values.
This makes it all the more important for academic voices and civil society to remain vigilant, proactive, and open to dialogue across political and social divides. Only by understanding the roots of discontent can democratic institutions regain trust and legitimacy. In this sense, I am convinced that contributions like the one from Prof. Kocka are more important than ever.
As a researcher in the field of heritage language and collective memory, I see interesting parallels. Just as the third generation often loses the linguistic link to its ancestors , as my research on heritage language in the Riesengebirge shows , there seems to be a fading awareness of the historical foundations of Germany‚Äôs democratic consensus. This makes active remembrance work, both local and transnational, indispensable.
‚ÄúHistorians are better in describing and explaining the past than in predicting the future.‚Äù
Prof. Kocka concluded, offering a thoughtful reflection on the continuing challenges ahead. I would like to thank Prof. Kocka, the organizers, and the many participants who made this event in Prague a memorable intellectual exchange. It was a valuable contribution to a highly relevant, ongoing debate.
Deutsch Prof. Kockas Warnung aus Prag: Was wir gerade dabei sind zu vergessen?
Original Prof. Kocka‚Äôs Warning from Prague: What Are We About to Forget?

Title: A quick review of Webexpo Prague 2013
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
The mix of design, business and IT was very welcome. I learned most from talks outside my own area of expertise. That‚Äôs also what attracts me in interaction design: talking with clients and users, and learning new things from different subjects. I talked with everybody in the conference, from the speakers to the guy making the tea. The conference had a very open and relaxed atmosphere and there were several cool things besides the talks such as: 3d printing, Google Glass, and even a professional masseur. Another neat idea was the discomfort zone, where people were allowed to debate freely and play devils advocate without consequences. Also great were the after-conference parties and events. Sadly, the design workshop on Thursday didn‚Äôt happen due to lack of attendees.
The quality of the talks was very good overall. But it seemed that every design or business presentation has lists of ‚Äúideas‚Äù, ‚Äúkey takeaways‚Äù, ‚Äúguidelines‚Äù or ‚Äúinsights‚Äô. A lot of them seemed trivial or made up on the spot (‚Äúlisten to your users‚Äù, really?). It would have been better for most talks to stick to one message! Now, I‚Äôll break that rule straight away and present some take-aways :)
Marli Mesbov gave a great presentation on the importance of story telling. Stories work better than short tag lines, which is probably related to Key Take Away 1 (no take-aways).
Stories work for conversion and for your clients to positively remember you. Do you remember the fairytale of the boy who cried wolf? Don‚Äôt you think that carries the message better than ‚Äúdon‚Äôt alarm us for nothing‚Äù? The average attention span went down from 12 seconds in 2000 to a mere 8 seconds in 2012, so better make your story captivating!
Besides working on your site, stories also work great for doing design. It‚Äôs an old saying, but still good advice: instead of designing for users, design for a story.
Lastly, a story can be used to instruct a client on how to use the website. Instead of delivering a 100 page styleguide which people don‚Äôt read, you can make a short story, a trailer or just a word (‚Äúdictionary‚Äù, ‚Äúphonebook‚Äù), which ‚Äòexplains‚Äô the site to the client.
It was great to hear some self-conscious critique on terms we use within the field. Our terms are confusing and their meaning differs per person and company: UX, service design and even interaction design (but less). Some people include visual design in there, programming, marketing‚Ä¶ All very confusing! And what to think of terms like ‚Äòexpert‚Äô or ‚Äòguru‚Äô? Instead, it‚Äôs better to describe what you do and how it benefits the client or project.
Bad user experience costs money, which is what we tell our clients also But it was great to see some examples, such as Expedia losing 12 million dollar because of a form field or Best Buy losing 300 million dollar by requiring an unnecessary login. This holds especially for mobile use: a lot of apps are used only once or thrown away within a month. Avi Itzkovitch had some nice examples how to overcome such bad experience by making more use of context. For instance by adapting the interface based on location, time of day or usage pattern.
I wish it could be a wholehearted yes! I had a lot of fun, met great people and learned a lot, but‚Ä¶ Some things nagged a bit, like the cancelled design workshop, the open doors in some design talks and the endless lists of recommendations. Another thing is the overlap in the program: breaks were different for each track making it difficult to switch. That might be why designers mostly went to the design track and programmers to the development tracks, making the mingling a lot less. On top of that, all speakers were ‚Äúsafe choices‚Äù, nobody went really overboard or crazy with some thought-provoking talk. Still, it was fun and I learned useful things, so, I guess it‚Äôs four out of five stars. For a visual impression, see the Facebook photostream
Webexpo puts the talks online (very slowly), so which ones should you see?

After a 5-hour train trip from Vienna, we arrived in Prague to find they don‚Äôt accept euro! I think if you want to be in the EU, one of the stipulations should be you must adopt the euro as your official currency. (enough of me on my soapbox!)
So still trying to work out the money conversions, we hired two taxis to take us to our hotel. They did quote us 800 Czech crowns for each car, but our brains were too tired to work out we were being ripped off! 32 euro was the approximate conversion for each cab!
We found out later, 260 Czech crowns was what each should have been! The next day, I found out that everyone gets ripped off by the taxi drivers in Prague, so I didn‚Äôt feel so bad. It‚Äôs just that they are the first taste you have of a new city, and we didn‚Äôt feel like spending another cent here!
So we decided to stay put in our lovely apartment and play Bananagrams. We started on the verandah but soon became chilled to the bone (even with drinking the red wine from the minibar) so moved inside. Our determination not to spend another cent was soon diminished by our hunger and Keeley and Kiryn headed out to find us some dinner ‚Äî which they did, extremely successfully. Pizza and calzone ‚Äî a new taste sensation! And VERY cheap!

Title: Prague ‚Äî A Winter Wonderland
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
A few days before Christmas, I received the Winter Holidays Edition of the Prague for Expats Newsletter. It began by saying:
‚Äúwe hope you are enjoying snowy Prague, as it really is the best time for long walks through the city and its surroundings‚Äù
I was a little taken aback by this, and my initial reaction was to question whether the author had ever visited Prague in the snow. Actually, TBH, that was my second reaction. My first wasn‚Äôt suitable for a family-oriented blog! Like many cities, Prague, in the snow, is far from being a good place for long walks. It‚Äôs not even a good place for short walks, especially in the city centre or ‚Äúhistoric Prague‚Äù as it‚Äôs called in the guidebooks. For several days that week before Christmas, I felt more locked down than during the official lockdowns during the pandemic. During the pandemic, we were just discouraged from going out, but the snow is a different matter, and like many locals, I dread snowfall in the deep midwinter. The cold I can handle, which is good because it can get mighty chilly! But, not the snow‚Ä¶
Sure, from the comfort of a room with a view, Prague is absolutely stunning under a shroud of pristine white snow. The hills surrounding the city take on a bleakness in the pale grey light, but the scenery becomes stunning when the skies turn blue. Be forewarned. Once you step outside, walking around Prague becomes a nightmare. In her 2011 song, ‚Äú50 Words for Snow‚Äù, Kate Bush got really close to the mark with ‚Äúanklebreaker‚Äù.
The problem is Prague's pavements combined with the huge footfall of thousands of tourists. It takes very little time for the white snow to turn into an ashy dirty wet sludge which on Prague‚Äôs mosaic pavements becomes a skating rink even before the wet sludge starts to refreeze. When it‚Äôs cold enough (as it was last week), the sludge quickly turns into invisible sheets of ice which are treacherous to both body and ego. Let‚Äôs face it; no one likes to look like a clown when they‚Äôre walking down a street full of people; it‚Äôs embarrassing enough when you can‚Äôt be seen!
But the problems don‚Äôt just come from under your feet. You‚Äôre constantly at risk of an attack from above as snow begins to melt on the rooftops, there‚Äôs a threat of baby avalanches, icicles spearing you and huge dollops of icy meltwater, which almost always seem to land on your glasses (or bald patches).
Prague city authorities are quick to get the gritting wagons and carts out, but this compounds the problem. Even after ten days, some of the more heavily gritted pavements are still covered in pin-sharp little stones which get stuck in the soles of your shoes and need to be picked out with that penknife attachment you never use for getting stones out of horse's shoes!
I have yet to find a single pair of shoes that can deal with Prague pavements regardless of the weather. Some are great in the summer; some work well in the rain, but none work well in any snow conditions ‚Äî not even proper mountain boots! I had a pair of ECCO Gore-tex shoes which were the best all-rounders, but sadly, these have been decimated by five years of constant usage walking around the city.
So, don‚Äôt be fooled by the tour guides, the glossy guidebooks and the slick videos showcasing our beautiful city under a fresh fall of snow. Call up an Uber to take you to Petrin Hill, up to Prague Castle, or over to Vitkov Hill, walk a few hundred yards, and marvel at the panoramas. Then get back in your taxi and get comfy in the hotel bar until the thaw has completed.
Unless, of course, you really want to put the Czech health system to the test or find out how good your insurance is!
I am a semi-retired independent management consultant specialising in organisational change management and better Ways of Working. I‚Äôm from the UK but based in Prague in the Czech Republic. I mainly write about developing better ways of working, working in the Apple ecosystem, and my adopted home in Prague. I‚Äôm still fairly new to Medium (so please be gentle with me!) but if you‚Äôve enjoyed this, please check out some of my other articles or even follow me if you‚Äôd like to be notified when I publish new material

Content:

The first light of dawn slips through the curtains of our hotel room. I glance over at my girlfriend, already awake, her eyes tracing the soft glow filtering in. Neither of us know why we‚Äôre up so early. It‚Äôs not jet lag or the faint hum of the city outside. So maybe, it‚Äôs the anticipation of wanting to see a side of Prague that most visitors miss.
We step outside into the cool morning air. The cobblestones feel damp beneath our feet. Street lamps cast soft halos in the mist, and somewhere in the distance, a bird begins to sing. The city feels quiet, almost like it‚Äôs waiting for something to happen.
We turn the corner together and spot the Old Town Hall. Its underground played a pivotal role in the Prague Uprising against Nazism. Attached to it is the Astronomical Clock, a medieval wonder that shows the positions of the Sun, Moon, Earth, and Zodiac constellations.
Humanity has tried to measure time for millennia. From the Maya in Mesoamerica to Mesolithic hunter-gatherers in the UK‚Ä¶

Title: A buttload of things to know if you‚Äôre visiting Prague
Content:

Going to Prague? Get ready for your Czech vacation with these tips.
Some of these things are common around Europe; some are specific to Prague. I‚Äôve lived in Prague for over a year. Since I‚Äôve only lived in Prague, I‚Äôll just say you should know these for the Czech Republic, and I won‚Äôt speak for elsewhere.
Prague is separated into sections by numbers, which will often be referred to in addresses or directions. If you‚Äôre a visitor, you‚Äôll most likely spend your time around Prague 1 and Prague 2, which host quintessential Prague sightseeing.
Most buildings addresses in the Czech Republic have two numbers. For example, my former apartment‚Äôs building number was 535/2. The building in this picture would have the number 800/50. Both these numbers will appear on placards outside each building, though sometimes only one number will be listed on an address. Knowing this may make navigating a little less confusing.
Going back to the example of my old apartment, the full address was Kubova 535/2. The street name, Kubova, is listed before the numbers, as is the norm with Czech address conventions. In the US, a street may be something like 123 Smith St. In the Czech Republic, that would look something like Smith 123/1.
Public transport is the best and cheapest way to get around Prague. While Prague is a very walkable city, knowing how to navigate its public transport is crucial. Let‚Äôs make sure you know how to do it.
To legally use public transport in the Czech Republic, you need to both buy and validate your ticket near the start of your journey. Purchase will always happen before entry. Validation will happen before entry for metro, and on entry for buses and trams. If you don‚Äôt understand, don‚Äôt worry. Everything is explained below.
First thing to know: all public transport tickets are the same for Prague‚Äôs metros, buses, and trams. You don‚Äôt need to buy separate tickets for each.
To purchase tickets, look for a ticket machine. Most ticket machines will look like this:
This older style of machine accepts:
They also have a newer style that looks like this, or a variation of this, but are much rarer:
This newer style of machine accepts:
To buy a ticket, hit the button next to the ticket you want, put your payment method in, and the ticket will subsequently be printed for you.
These ticket machines can be found in all metro stations and the airport. Frustratingly, most bus stops and tram stops don‚Äôt have them. If you can‚Äôt find a machine near a stop, look for the nearest tobacco shop, as they always carry tickets.
Tickets are separated by lengths of time and zones. For a regular tourist, as long as you‚Äôre staying within the main parts of Prague (which is almost everyone), you don‚Äôt need to worry about zone. Only pick a ticket based on how long you plan to spend traveling that day.
The most common ticket lengths are:
You can also text to purchase a ticket if you have a valid Czech phone number through O2, T-mobile, or Vodafone (local Czech carriers). If you want to use this method but don‚Äôt have a Prague phone plan, you can pick up a SIM card at almost any Czech corner store or phone carrier store. Note: please don‚Äôt buy a phone ticket until you need it as these tickets can‚Äôt be saved for later ‚Äî they don‚Äôt require validation and are active immediately after confirmation of purchase.
Once you‚Äôve successfully purchased your ticket, you‚Äôll also have to validate the ticket.
To understand the difference between purchase and validation, first you have to recognize that Czech tickets are time-based, meaning you can buy a ticket that lasts for a specific amount of time, say 90 minutes. The purchase of the ticket gives you the right to ride for 90 minutes, during any 90-minutes. Validation indicates the start/end time of that 90-minute window.
Validation machines look like this:
To validate, insert the ticket into the slot indicated by the arrow on the validator. Push the ticket in until you feel a punch on the ticket. The punch will display the starting time and date for the validity of your ticket. You are authorized to ride from the time that you purchase + the duration of the ticket you bought.
Validators are found in the metro station, near the area where you enter the station. You must validate your ticket upon entry to the station; you cannot validate a ticket after you‚Äôve boarded a train. Validators for trams and buses, however, are found inside the vehicles themselves. You can only validate tram and bus tickets after entry.
If you purchased your ticket via phone, you do not need to validate it. The timing for the phone ticket starts when you receive confirmation for your purchase. Because of this, make sure not to buy a phone ticket before you need it!
You have the right to ride the transport for the duration your ticket indicates starting from the time you validate. If you‚Äôve already validated your paper ticket and are going to ride another leg of public transport while it‚Äôs still valid, you do not need to validate again (how many times did I just said valid?). You can also switch public transport types during this time, which means you can walk off the metro and onto a tram. As long as your ticket is valid, you don‚Äôt have to do anything during this switch.
Remember: a Czech public transport ticket is not valid unless it‚Äôs validated!
Please note you must buy a separate ticket for a large piece of luggage. To do this on a coin machine, press the discount ticket button (a separate button on the machine) before pressing the time duration you want. On the newer machines, discounted tickets should be an option you navigate to on the touch menu. This discounted ticket legally lets you carry the luggage on public transport.
These discounted fares can also be used on tickets for seniors, between 65‚Äì70 years old, and children aged 6‚Äì15. Riders older than 70 and riders younger than 6 do not have to pay fare.
A detailed breakdown of fares and costs can be found here.
In my research for this article, I stumbled across a Prague multi-day tourist pass that pre-pays for public transport and attractions. I haven‚Äôt used it, so I can‚Äôt vouch for its value, but I wanted to throw it out there as an FYI. More info here.
Fare is enforced inconsistently and randomly. If you‚Äôre entering the metro station or if you‚Äôre actively riding the tram or bus, you may be approached by a fare enforcer. These are uniformed transport employees (though sometimes they dress like a normal person to go undercover) who ask to see your public transport ticket. They will show a badge to identify themselves in all cases.
If your fare is valid, they will let you go. If it‚Äôs not, you will be charged 800 crowns (~$40). Fare will rarely be checked, but the fine is hefty if you get caught without it.
If you are caught without fare, you will get a written notice and will immediately pay the entirety of the fine.
In the US, public transport doors will usually open automatically at every stop or at the discretion of an operator. This is not the case in Europe. Many times, riders have to physically press a button to open public transport doors. If a train, tram, or bus has come to a complete stop and the doors aren‚Äôt opening, look for a button on or near the door to let yourself on.
If you‚Äôre using escalators to get on/off public transport, or literally anywhere else in Prague, always always always stand on the right side and make sure you‚Äôre not blocking the left side. Right is for standing, left is for walking. People will be sour if you don‚Äôt follow this norm and block the path.
Totally! And it‚Äôs actually pretty cheap. I‚Äôve used it more times than I like to admit. Regardless, you can definitely use Uber here, but you‚Äôll look like a tourist. There‚Äôs also an Uber competitor called Taxify that‚Äôs worth checking out if you‚Äôre into ridesharing.
Czechs can‚Äôt stand the sound of sniffling. People will get annoyed with you for sniffling in public. Instead, Czechs almost always carry around travel-sized tissue packets and constantly blow their noses. This brings me to my next point‚Ä¶
Literally everywhere. Sitting right next to you on the train? They‚Äôll blow their noses. In conversation? They‚Äôll blow their noses. While eating? They‚Äôll blow their noses. Americans consider this pretty gross. It took me a while to get used to the constant nose blowing and seeming obliviousness to American norms around this. Now that I‚Äôm used to it, it makes hanging out with people while you‚Äôre suffering with a cold a lot more manageable, albeit still unsightly.
This one‚Äôs a little bit of a stereotype, but Czechs love wearing socks and sandals. I will admit that anecdotally, I‚Äôve seen way more sock + sandal combinations here than anywhere else, and I studied engineering. Luckily, looks like it‚Äôs fashionable now?
You‚Äôll see these all over Prague. Czechs love putting them on their backpacks and baby strollers. They‚Äôre *everywhere*.
You‚Äôll also see these all over Prague. I have no idea why.
Czechs have a habit of staring intensely into each other‚Äôs eyes while toasting over drinks. It‚Äôs very disconcerting.
Americans think Europeans‚Äô habit of a kiss on each cheek in greeting is invasive. Europeans, in turn, think pressing bodies against each other (aka hugging) in greeting is weird. Get used to lightly kissing people if you want to move here.
When Czechs enter or exit elevators or waiting rooms, they say hello and goodbye, respectively. For example, if you get called into the doctor‚Äôs office after sitting in the waiting room, you‚Äôre supposed to say a soft goodbye to the room. When you get on an elevator, you say hello to the other riders. It‚Äôs a really weird thing from an American standpoint, but here I‚Äôm pretty sure I come off very cold because I usually forget to do this.
Czechs do not wear shoes in their homes. Nearly every home or apartment will have an entryway in the beginning where you‚Äôre expected to take your shoes off. If you want to keep them on in the home for any reason, make sure to ask the host for permission first.
The Czech Republic‚Äôs national language is, well, Czech. It‚Äôs part of the Slavic language family and is similar to other languages you‚Äôre probably not super familiar with, like Polish and Slovak. To get a sense of what Czech sounds like, here‚Äôs a video of Let It Go in Czech.
In Prague, absolutely not. I know people who live here that have decided not to learn Czech; it‚Äôs that easy to get around with English. You‚Äôll also find a lot of people who speak Russian and German. The options are (figuratively) endless.
If you leave Prague and head out to the countryside, though, be prepared to have a lot more trouble with the language barrier.
Hello: dobry denYes: anoNo: neThank you: dekuji (pronounced dee-yeh-koo-yee)Please: prosim
The Czech word for ‚Äúyes‚Äù is ano, which often gets shortened to no. So in the Czech Republic, if someone says no, they might really mean yes. Be prepared to be confused.
Fakt jo in Czech, pronounced facked yo, sounds a lot like, well‚Ä¶ you get it. In Czech it‚Äôs a phrase for ‚Äúreally?‚Äù So don‚Äôt worry, you‚Äôre not hearing Czechs yell expletives at each other, just asking for clarification. If you want to know when they‚Äôre swearing at each other, the word you‚Äôre listening for is prdel (pronounced pruh-dell).
As a courtesy, a lot of places will have menus in English. Those English menus, however, are often riddled with mistranslations. I‚Äôve seen dishes that were supposed to be vegetarian come out with meat on them because the translation was wrong (something about mixing up the word peppers with peppered sausage). Below is an image of my personal favorite.
In English, if you want to offer someone a drink, you say ‚ÄúWould you like some tea?‚Äù In the Czech language, the same phrase is structured as ‚ÄúWouldn‚Äôt you like some tea?‚Äù
When Czechs speak English, it‚Äôs common for them to say ‚Äúdon‚Äôt you want‚Äù instead of ‚Äúdo you want,‚Äù because that‚Äôs how it‚Äôs said in their native tongue. Knowing this fosters understanding, because getting asked a question the Czech way sounds imposing and rude to Americans. For me, it took a sec to recover from my doctor asking me ‚ÄúDidn‚Äôt you gain some weight?‚Äù
Though not formally an English-speaking city, Prague has lots of signs in English. They do write things slightly differently than we would, so here‚Äôs some phrases you should know:
Czechs use a denomination called a crown. At the time of this writing, 1 US dollar = ~20 crowns.
When given a number in crowns, the easiest way to roughly convert in your head is to move the decimal point to the left by one place, then divide by 2.
So if your bill is 350 crowns, moving the decimal place to the left by one place gives you 35, divide by 2 gives you 17.5. So 350 crowns = ~$17.50.
In the US, dates are written as MM/DD/YYYY. In other parts of the world, it‚Äôs normal to write DD/MM/YYYY. So if you see 08/12/2018, that‚Äôs December 8th in Europe, not August 12th. You‚Äôve been warned.
In the US, we use periods to separate whole numbers from fractions of numbers. $5.10 means ‚Äúfive dollars and one-tenth of a dollar.‚Äù In Europe, they‚Äôd write the same number as 5,10 crowns.
For a larger number, we‚Äôd write something like $1,000.34. In Prague, they‚Äôll use spaces instead of commas and commas instead of periods. So the same number on your bill at a restaurant may look like 1 000,34 crowns (that‚Äôs about $50).
Weirdly enough, they‚Äôll sometimes write ‚Äúcents‚Äù on a bill or transaction, even though the smallest monetary denomination Prague has is a 1 crown coin.
Get ready to think hard every time you have to use numbers.
In casual conversations, Czechs stick to the same time scale Americans do ‚Äî saying a time between 1 and 12.
In more formal communications, however, times are often communicated using military time. If you make a dinner reservation, you can call and ask for seating at 20:00. A concert may start at 19:00. Your doctor appointment is at 13:45. Czechs do not use AM and PM. Get used to reading and understanding these numbers.
Americans count on their hands starting with the pointer finger as 1. Europeans use their thumbs as 1. This means that counting to 2 on your fingers looks like a peace sign in the US, but like a finger ‚ÄòL‚Äô for Europeans.
Americans use quotation marks that look like ‚Äúthis.‚Äù Czechs use ones that look like ‚Äûthis.‚Äù
American phone numbers have 10 digits ‚Äî like (012) 345‚Äì6789. Czech phones numbers have 9‚Äì for ex. 123 456 789. As a note, the Czech country code is +420, so your entire phone number may be +420 123 456 789.
Czechs and Americans have different keyboard layouts for typing. The biggest change is that Czechs and Americans switch the places of the y and z keys on their keyboards. If you use a public computer, be prepared for immense frustration. Muscle memory is real, folks.
Czech apartment buildings don‚Äôt leave building hallway lights on, as is common in the US. They also don‚Äôt typically use automatic sensors. Instead, Czech hallways are often lined with timed light switches that you press when you enter the building. They will also be placed on every floor in the building so you can hit them as you leave your apartment. After a few nights of blindly stumbling around dark stairwells, identifying the light switch is a godsend.
On a personal note, I was too afraid to touch these when I moved here, thinking they were someone‚Äôs doorbell or that I would flood the apartments with light. Learn from my mistakes ‚Äî it‚Äôs okay to press them.
Similar to the light switches, some main building doors have physical buttons that you need to press to exit. If you find yourself stupidly shoving a stubborn door, take a step back and check for an exit switch next to it.
While smoke detectors are required in basically every building in the US, they are rarely required or enforced in Czech buildings. My apartment, for example, had no smoke alarms equipped. Know this beforehand as it can be scary if you‚Äôre expecting them and they‚Äôre not there.
In the Czech Republic, you don‚Äôt have to tip, but people usually do a little (This is not true if the receipt or server indicates service is not included. In that case, see my next paragraph). The typical rule is that you loosely round up. For example, if your meal was 136 crowns, round up to 150 when you pay. If you had really great service, a tip of up to 10% is standard. Paying just for the food is fine, however, as service is built into the price.
Though not common, some places will not include service in the bill. If this happens, the receipt will indicate it. This usually only occurs in tourist areas. At that point, paying 10% would be typical.
If you tip in cash, which is always preferred, it‚Äôs standard to give the tip to the service provider directly. Leaving the tip on the table is not common practice here.
If you tip by card, you have to tell them the amount before they swipe your card. You never specify a tip on a receipt. You will always pay meal and tip together in one transaction.
If you indicate you want to pay by card, the servers will bring out a card terminal to you. You‚Äôll then pay by card at your table.
Alternatively, they may ask you to walk with them to a register where you pay. They will never take your card and walk off. As another quirk, when ready to pay, patrons will sometimes pre-emptively walk up to the cash registers, even in a sit-down place, and wait for a host or waiter to check them out. This is faster and expected, not rude or out of place.
Further, credit card technology is different in Europe. While chip payments are the new, gold standard in the US, Europe is one step ahead with contactless payments being the norm. These are payments powered by near-field communication chips, like the stuff used in Apple or Android pay on your phone. To pay with Czech bank cards, just tap your card near a terminal and your payment will be accepted. Since you probably don‚Äôt have a Czech bank card, all this means for you is that the waiters will often fumble around with a chip payment, not have a pen on them for signing a receipt, and will ask you if your card is contactless (it‚Äôs probably not). Hopefully knowing this will lend you some patience, help you not answer ‚Äúhuh?‚Äù to the contactless question, and make you wonder why American banks are so behind.
Of note also is that Europeans pay almost exclusively with debit cards; credit cards are not nearly as common, though establishments will still accept them.
If you pay in cash, waiters will usually also start and finish the transaction at your table. They‚Äôll bring a large wallet filled with bills, at which point they‚Äôll take your cash and give change at the table.
Europe does not always cater kindly to separate checks. In the Czech Republic, often they will ask what you had and do the math right in front of you on paper to separate a bill before asking each party to pay their portion. Splitting individual items is rarely possible. The wait staff may get salty if you try to ask for complicated bill splittings.
In the US, reservations are typically only made for fancy restaurants, crowded restaurants, for large parties, or for special occasions. If you show up without a reservation, you put your name on a list and wait until you get seated.
The Czech Republic is different. In the Czech Republic, even casual restaurants take reservations. Any place, casual or not, will almost certainly be full on Fridays or Saturdays, just like the US, but Czech restaurants won‚Äôt have a wait out the door. If you don‚Äôt have a reservation and they‚Äôre full, they‚Äôll turn you away. Even seemingly empty restaurants will sometimes tell you they‚Äôre full, as a whole bunch of reservations are about to show up and the place is consistently booked throughout the evening.
If you want to have a place to eat, especially a good one, call ahead and make a reservation.
It‚Äôs common for Czech restaurants to have shared coat stands, like a coat rack or closet. When I dine with my European friends, they‚Äôll often look for the coat rack and hang up their belongings next to strangers‚Äô things. This is uncommon in the US where we just throw our coats behind our chairs. I tend not to participate as I‚Äôm slightly skeptical of leaving my belongings unattended and because I will forget my coat literally every time I eat.
To non-Americans, American service staff seem disingenuous, disconcertingly friendly, and over-attentive. This is because American staff aren‚Äôt paid a living wage and depend on tips for their salary. This crazy attentive service is necessary for wait staff to dream of maintaining a standard salary and is expected by American restaurant-goers.
In Europe, the pace of restaurants is slower. Waiters are paid a working wage and aren‚Äôt dependent on tips, however much they‚Äôre appreciated. If you want a waiter‚Äôs attention, you often have to catch their eye and wave them over, as they won‚Äôt be visiting at a regular pace. When you‚Äôre done with your meal, you again have to gesture for them; they won‚Äôt be looking to swing by as soon as you‚Äôre finished. To Americans, this wait service can seem apathetic and rude.
European waiters on the whole don‚Äôt have the sticky-sweet American demeanor, but Czechs take that to a whole new level. Czech wait staff are, on a good day, uninterested. On a bad day they are downright hostile.
Personally, the disengaged and often rude service staff in the Czech Republic are one of the reasons I don‚Äôt want to stay here long-term. I miss American friendliness, however shallow, like crazy.
If you‚Äôd like a take-out box after your meal, you will be charged a small fee for the box and bag.
If you pay with an American card, you‚Äôll be prompted during purchase on if you‚Äôd like to pay in crowns or USD. The guidance I‚Äôve heard is that you‚Äôll usually get a better exchange rate if you pay in the local currency. I suggest that.
Don‚Äôt let this stock image fool you. On the whole, Czech food is very bland, with a heavy emphasis on carbs and meat. There are almost no fruits or vegetables in Czech specialties. Just a lot of meat, a lot of gravy, and a lot of bread.
Dumplings are everywhere in the Czech Republic, which I was super excited about when I moved here. Turns out, dumplings here aren‚Äôt like Asian dumplings or even Polish dumplings. They‚Äôre not steamed or fried, and they don‚Äôt have any filling. They‚Äôre basically just cylinders of white bread. #disappointed
Czechs love their pate (pronounced pah-tay), which is a raw, minced-beef dish, usually served as an appetizer. You‚Äôll see this all over the place. I may have tried it once but honestly it puts me off a little, so I can‚Äôt speak much to its taste. I have had the salmon pate, however, and that was pretty good (in my head I convinced myself it was sushi).
Not specifically Czech but found everywhere. It‚Äôs chunks of beef and pork smothered in dark gravy.
They turn their goulash dish into a soup as well! Found on menus everywhere.
A mixture of a light broth, potatoes, onions, and‚Ä¶ garlic.
Do you like mozzarella sticks? Then you‚Äôll love the Czech main course of fried cheese. Hold the marina sauce, though. Czechs usually serve this with some variation of tartar sauce.
This dish has nothing to do with birds, but is yet another pork dish with dumplings and gravy.
Maybe because they‚Äôre so close to Germany, Czechs have pickled cabbage all over the menu. They have two kinds: a sweeter red variety and a more sour white cabbage.
Czechs‚Äô own version of Cola! It can come in a variety of odd flavors too, for example, melon.
Yet another meat + gravy +dumplings dish. This one, however, comes with a twist. They serve it with a citrus slice on top (usually lemon or orange), and cover that citrus slice with cranberries and whipped cream. They also sometimes bake cranberries into the dumplings on this dish as well. I‚Äôm not a believer in combining sweet with meat dishes, so I find this dreadful. Worth a shot if you‚Äôre looking for a true Czech meal though.
Two quintessential beers to try in the Czech Republic. I‚Äôm not a beer person, so please take my advice here with a grain of salt.
Czechs love eating duck, so be prepared to see it on menus galore.
Czech open-faced sandwiches that come with a variety of toppings.
Not historically Czech but delicious nonetheless. This is a pastry, crunchy on the outside, soft in the middle. Dough is coated in a mixture of cinnamon, sugar, vanilla, and a bunch of other flavors, then slow roasted to perfection. You can also choose the filling of your choice ‚Äî chocolate, nutella, vanilla custard, ice cream ‚Äî and enjoy!
Lemonade is on Czech menus galore. That said, it‚Äôs not American lemonade. American lemonade is water, sugar, and lemon flavoring. Czech lemonade is carbonated water, and a light flavoring that needs to be specified and isn‚Äôt necessarily lemon. Think of it more like a light, flavored soda. Czech lemonades will often come in a long list of flavors. Some common ones are raspberry, cucumber, and ginger. Some places may even have lemonade on the menu but not lemon-flavored lemonade. Watch out!
I don‚Äôt know if this is a Czech thing or if I‚Äôve just had bad luck, but the few times I‚Äôve ordered milkshakes in the Czech Republic, they‚Äôve been the temperature and consistency of chocolate milk. I don‚Äôt know if Czechs believe in putting ice cream in milkshakes. Beware.
If you decide to visit a McDonald‚Äôs here, note that there is no ranch dressing, and most of your beloved favorite sauces aren‚Äôt there, either. The sauce menu will be different, and so will the main courses. Some standards, like fries and nuggets, remain, but the Czech menu also includes localized items like a fried camembert sandwich (camembert is a popular cheese in the Czech Republic). European McDonald‚Äôs also tend to have a much richer dessert section, including pastries, like croissants. Visiting McDonald's in different parts of the world is a treat to see how the menu is localized. Czech McDonald‚Äôs official site and menu are here.
You often see this on the menu. This is just a European word for arugula.
In America, pepperoni is a thinly-sliced sausage. In Italy and other places in Europe, pepperoni pizza means a pizza covered in bell peppers. In the Czech Republic specifically, pepperoni can sometimes mean either one. If you‚Äôre going to order pepperoni pizza, be careful to clarify which one you‚Äôre getting. If, at a place you‚Äôre visiting, pepperoni means a pizza covered in bell peppers and you want the American pepperoni pizza, look for one that has salami.
If you see pancakes written on a menu, they actually mean what Americans think of as crepes. If you want real, IHOP-style pancakes, look for American pancakes, though they are not very common in Prague.
There‚Äôs a European law that what‚Äôs written on the menu is what you pay. This means that the written price already includes tax and tip, so there will be no surprises when you pay your bill.
Beer is literally cheaper than water in the Czech Republic, which is part of the reasons tourists love it here. Remember that water is almost never free in the Czech Republic.
While smoking hasn‚Äôt been common in US restaurants in decades, Czechs can still smoke while seated outside. Smoking inside of Czech restaurants was only abolished in the last few years, and some Czechs think even that is too strict.
Americans love ice water more than Europeans, but Czechs in particular don‚Äôt like any sort of cold drink. I‚Äôve seen Cokes served warm, and waiters will almost never serve ice by default. As a non-beer drinker I‚Äôm not sure how the beer is served, but honestly I wouldn‚Äôt be surprised if it was warm.
For whatever reason, Czechs call potato wedges American potatoes.
In Europe, eating fries with ketchup is replaced by the default of eating fries with mayonnaise. Don‚Äôt ask me.
In the US, you either get a coke in a bottle (rare at a restaurant), or coke in a glass, but never both. In Prague, they always serve glass-bottle sodas alongside a glass. This is true for any soda and even water, which is almost never free and always comes in bottles.
This name means two different candies in the Czech Republic vs the US!
If you haven‚Äôt traveled abroad before, you should know that outlets look different in different parts of the world. You‚Äôll need an international adapter for whatever country you‚Äôre going to, to make your plugs compatible with the other country‚Äôs wall outlets. If you‚Äôre traveling with friends, bring extras, because a lot of people don‚Äôt know this. Skyscanner has a great list of which adapters work in each country. Note that these most basic ones don‚Äôt convert anything electrically, they just make the outlet shapes physically compatible.
If you‚Äôre going to use anything that requires a lot of power from the wall, you‚Äôll also need a converter, which converts European power output to something needier American electronics can handle. You‚Äôll need this for things like hair dryers and hair straighteners.
This article is a handy guide for when to use adapters vs converters vs transformers (transformers are covered in an upcoming article, on what to know for moving to Prague).
For reference, Prague outlets look like this:
For any more information, the gold standard is the YouTube channel Honest Guide, an effort run by two local Czechs who go into detail about everything you need to know about Prague. This includes trustworthy places to exchange money, what Czech food is like, major attractions: everything. Czech üëèüèª them üëèüèª out üëèüèª.
Good luck with your Prague trip planning and enjoy your time in the beautiful Czech Republic!
