My Guide in the Czech Republic (main part Prague)
In this article, I am going to answer the FAQ about Prague and give you some tips about the city.
I have been living in the city for 4 years and whenever I go for a walk in the old town, I feel like it is my first time visiting the city. That‚Äôs why I decided to work as a tour guide for a while. I don‚Äôt do it anymore, except private tours from time to time.
So, let Is go through the things that you want to know before coming to the Magical City.
*I will recommend videos to watch or website(s) to visit in each section, some of the videos may don‚Äôt have accurate information such as exchange rate but the information is useful no matter when you come to Prague ;)
The Czech Republic is not in the eurozone, the official currency of the Czech Republic is the Czech crown (Kƒç/ in English CZK). 1 euro is around 25CZK. You will find a link to the Czech National Bank and to a website with the best exchange point in Prague in the end of this section.
Coins: 1, 2, 5, 10, 20 and 50 CZK * All the coins are useful (not the case with euros ‚Äî 1cent, 2cent, 5cent) Banknotes: 100, 200, 500, 1000, 2000 and 5000 CZK
*You should avoid the 2000 and 5000 banknotes for small purchases.
Although CZK is the official currency in the Czech Republic, you still can pay by Euro almost everywhere specially in Prague. However, you will not get the best exchange rate except in the international chains (supermarkets, coffee chains, fast-food chains, ‚Ä¶).
Czech National Bank
How to exchange money by (Honest Guide)
Prague without cash by (Honest Guide)
Public transport is efficient in Prague in a way that you don‚Äôt need a rental car or taxis. Actually, it is cheaper and faster xD. There are 3 lines of Metro, 10s of tramways, and 100s of buses.
The tickets for a single trip are for 30 minutes (for 24czk) or 90 minutes (for 32czk). The daily ticket (24h) is for 110czk and if you are here for 3 days (72h) your ticket costs 310czk.
*If you are willing to stay more than 5 days, I recommend buying a monthly ticket for 570czk
For more details check these videos:
How to buy a ticket (Honest Guide)
Travelling around the city (Honest Guide)
Prague Public Transport at Night (Honest Guide)
How to get from Prague‚Äôs airport to the city center (Honest Guide)
GOING TO PRAGUE BY TRAIN OR BUS (Honest Guide)
To find transport connection, check out this website (they have also mobile app) www.idos.cz
To rent bikes use Rekola, but you will need a credit card to use the app.
You can use Uber and yeah it is possible to pay by cash or taxi companies like Tick Tack, Nejlevnƒõj≈°√≠ Taxi or MODR√ù ANDƒöL (if you went out with your car and end up drinking beers with your friends, they can give you a ride for you and your car xD at night).
*Ride for the airport to the city center should cost you around 500czk (20 euro), be careful from scams.
You have many options such as Hotels, Hostels, Airbnb, apartments, etc. I am going to describe the different areas by character so that it helps you choosing the right place.
Old town : you won‚Äôt need transportation since everything is close to you. However, a lot of going on around and there is a big possibility that you won‚Äôt have a calm night.
Lesser town (mal√° strana) : It is near the castle, Charles Bridge and many beautiful parks. You will need transportation and there are almost no supermarkets nearby (most of the prices are for tourists).
New Town : A great neighborhood, restaurants and caf√©s are excellent in the area. Most of your neighbors are tourists, those who hurry up are called the locals. You will need transportation and fortunately there are two metro stations in the area and many tramways pass by that zone.
The rest of the areas are cheaper, calmer (exception: ≈Ωi≈ækov) and most of the residents are locals, so you won‚Äôt be scammed.
During my work as a tour guide, I met tens of people who planned their stay in Prague just one day or two days and double of that period in Budapest (sometimes more time for Bratislava than Prague :D). I think you know what I am going to say by now. Minimum days to spend in Prague should be 3 or 4 days. If you want to enjoy the city and yourself, one week to 10 days.
Plan A ‚Äî 3 days:
You should not enter every monument/museum in your way. Consider taking transportation so that you won‚Äôt be tired by the end of the day.
Plan B ‚Äî royal stay:
Life is good, you have enough time to visit the main monuments, party, enjoy the traditional Czech cuisine and save energy for the next city/country.
Plan Z ‚Äî Underestimated city / just 1 night or even less
You can start by Prague Castle (don‚Äôt spend more than 60 -90 minutes in that area)than follow the Royal way (Coronation route). Next stop will be Charles Bridge that will lead you to the old Town Square. You should be tired by now from walking, so reward yourself by a hot coffee in Skautsk√Ω Institut or another place (avoid the coffees in the square if you don‚Äôt want to be scammed) .
You should have enough time to enjoy a traditional dish. Later on, go to Wenceslas Square.
*This can be done the other way around (from Wenceslas Square to the Castle, but I recommend the first direction because Prague Castle in on the top of the Hill).
COOLEST DISTRICT in PRAGUE (Honest Guide)
1000czk without accommodation is fair enough. I will tell you why :
Transport: 110czk for 24h
Food: 600czk (150‚Äì200 per meal)
Coffee&cake: 150czk (coffee for 50czk, cake for 100czk)
The rest can be used for entrance to museum (sometimes it will cost you 250 czk, but generally around 150czk or less)
The list is so long, you should make your priorities. If you like museums, Prague offers museum for any kind of thing (Torture, toys, chocolate, Lego, Apple Inc.,). You love outdoors?.. well Prague offers that too, but if you can‚Äôt stand cold weather, you should visit the City during Spring or Summer Season.
The must visit list that I recommend is the following:
Charles Bridge, Prague Castle, Old Town Square, Prague Zoo, Wenceslas square, National museum, etc.
However, those are the typical ones, there are other monuments and places to visit. Check out the following videos:
PRAGUE CASTLE (Honest Guide)
10 BEST INSTAGRAM SPOTS IN PRAGUE (Honest Guide)
MUST SEE HIDDEN GEM IN THE HEART OF PRAGUE (Honest Guide)
SECRET PLACES IN PRAGUE (Honest Guide)
The traditional Czech cuisine is so authentic. The food is heavy, tasty and not healthy :D Main ingredients are meat (mainly pork), potatoes, cabbage and flour. So, don‚Äôt expect salads or vegetarian food.
The best thing that you will enjoy, in the Czech Republic, are snacks and cakes.
I recommend reading this article:
https://www.tasteofprague.com/pragueblog/traditional-czech-food-in-prague-what-to-have-and-where-to-have-it
Here is also a playlist of videos from Honest Guide that I recommend to watch (included vegetarian restaurants):
Restaurants in Prague (Honest Guide)
Safety:
The City is safe and secure, but be careful in the crowded areas. There are no ghettos or not recommended areas. The Czech Republic is one of the safest countries in the world üòä.
Halal food:
There are some restaurants that offer halal food. Most of them are near to the city center. Here is a list of the restaurants, I will try to cover all the areas in Prague:
Mangal Restaurant is located in the Wenceslas square. Address: V√°clavsk√© n√°mƒõst√≠ 64, Praha
Barakat is near the mosque of the center. Address: Opletalova 28, Praha
Istanbul Kebab is also near the mosque of the center, less than 100 meters from Barakat. Address: Politick√Ωch vƒõz≈à≈Ø, 17, Praha
Jordan Restaurant in the lesser town (mala strana). So, if you are hungry and you still near the castle this should be your destination. Address: Malostransk√© n√°mƒõst√≠ 36/22, Praha
Saf√≠r is a good Lebanese restaurant. You can find it in different malls (OC Nov√Ω Sm√≠chov, Ark√°dy Pankr√°c, OC DBK ‚Äî Budƒõjovick√° , OC Chodov) * OC stands for Commercial Center. Here is their website http://www.isafir.cz , but it is not updated.
*if you are so into halal things, you should go 100% vegan in this country or buy expensive food from bio supermarkets/restaurants.
Different products use pork gelatin or other extracted products from pork. These products can be yogurt, sweet bakery (even croissant), etc.
If you want to have bolognaise or burger with mashed beef meat, make sure that is not mixed with pork (in non halal places).
Mosques:
Mosque of the center: Opletalova 930/28, 110 00 Praha 1 (be advised, it is located inside a building)
Mosque Alfirdaus : Na Ko≈°ince 502/1, 180 00 Praha 8-Libe≈à
Mosque of ƒåern√Ω Most: Blatsk√° 1491, 198 00 Praha 9
Other tips:
Keep in mind that the Czech Republic is in the CENTER of Europe and not in the East. Also avoid saying Czechia, no one like it.
Here are playlists (if you don‚Äôt want to watch all of them, I selected some videos from the playlist. You will find them below the playlists)

HOW TO SAVE MONEY in PRAGUE‚ÄôS CITY CENTRE (Honest Guide)

Title: Czechia: Prancing Through Prague
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

Life by way of travel.

--
Listen
Share
Prague is a beautiful city. The river flows through the heart of it with the Disney-looking castle perched atop a hillside in the background. Its baroque and romanesque architecture give it an air of elegance that is incredibly unique.
The Old Town Square is the main area boasting beautiful buildings and the famous Orloj, an astronomical clock that sings at the top of every hour. It was teeming with tourists, so we didn‚Äôt stay too long in that area. And, unfortunately similar to Amsterdam, many of the streets were overflowing with trash and graffitied walls, which degraded the beauty of the city. In addition, overwhelming crowds and poor weather influenced our perception of Prague. It was obscenely hot the first few days, which gave us limited time to prance about before the sun scorched down on us and we had to take refuge inside shady cafes. But, the last few days cooled off and it even started raining out of the blue so we had to take cover again.
Despite an abundance of tourists and hot weather, we found that the best way to enjoy ourselves was by venturing out of the main town squares and finding solace along the side streets. Wandering along Old Town‚Äôs cobblestone streets was a great way to spend our time because we felt like this was more of an ideal way to experience this archetypal European city. I also had a chance to discover a specialty of Czech desserts: the trdeln√≠k chimney. It‚Äôs a funnel-cake filled with soft-serve ice cream and smells like a cinnamon roll. You can often find bakers on the streets baking the dough on a rotating spit then rolling it in cinnamon and sugar before filling it up with soft-serve. It was delicious confection for any sweet-tooth to enjoy!
In Vrtba garden, I got to see a photoshoot with a fashion model walking throughout the grounds. And I followed in her footsteps popping some poses myself.
We also got a great view walking up the steps of the Italian-style gardens and seeing the city beyond them. But, the best sights (and sounds) were yet to come‚Ä¶
The walk to Prague Castle was one of our favorite parts of the city. First, we started the walk from the Powder Tower, then up and over Charles Bridge. Charles Bridge is an attraction all by itself. Built in the 14th century, it‚Äôs lined with: sculptures of religious images and prolific Czech figures, street performers, artists and peddlers. It provides some of the most scenic views of the city over the Vltava River.
After crossing the bridge, we wound through cobblestone lanes and then climbed 200+ steps up to the castle entrance. Though the hike up to the castle is a bit of a workout, it‚Äôs worth it to get a spectacular view of Prague. In particular, the view at the top from the Starbucks (yep, you read that correctly; they pick the best locations!) situated in an outdoor patio setting overlooking the city was incomparable.
Once we arrived at Prague Castle, there‚Äôs no shortage of things to do. The compound includes a pretty expansive collection of eclectic buildings with museums, cafes, and archways connected by the internal castle roads. It‚Äôs a self-sufficient city unto itself similar to Windsor Castle. And, after the trek uphill we found a nice little offshoot area next to a cafe where we could sit, listen to a fountain, and cool off.
One of the best things we did was attend an organ concert in St. Vitus Cathedral, in the heart of the castle complex. St. Vitus is a 14th century Gothic church housing the tombs of many Bohemian kings and Holy Roman Emperors. It‚Äôs also the home to a great organ that‚Äôs about 3 stories tall! We got to hear the prodigious instrument in all of its glory at a special evening concert. The booming sound of the pipes reverberated through the gothic arches making the church come alive! I can only imagine how awesome it must have been to the Bohemians back in the day when this baby was first installed. The event was unbelievably special, and I savored the moment listening to the sweet tempo and the rich tones of the organ. It has inspired me to start tickling the ivories once again!

Title: Prague in the Movies
Content:

A personal tour guide of Prague and Czech Republic

--
Listen
Share
Prague is a hot destination for the movie production. And not only the city itself, but all Czech Republic. Especially in the last decades there are more and more foreign producers exploring the beauties of our country.
One of the main reasons why we are so popular are lower prices and tax incentives. Only in Prague you can find Barrandov movie studios, the largest film studio in the country and one of the largest in Europe, nicknamed ‚ÄúEuropean Hollywood.‚Äù And, the most important, is the architecture. It offers the new and old, romantic and scary places. You do not need to travel anywhere else to find Venice, Paris or Vienna on the same street! :-)
Many, many movies were filmed in Prague and here I‚Äôm bringing you a few of them, in this limited space. It might be also a nice idea what to watch them prior coming to Prague ;-)
Mission: Impossible 1 (1996) and 4: Ghost Protocol (2011)
Nothing is impossible for Tom Cruise. To run across the Charles Bridge just within a few seconds or stealing from the Russians atPrague Castle. Large parts of these movies were shot not only in the historical centre (Old Town Square, National Museum, Wenceslas Square, Kampa Island, Municipal House‚Ä¶) but also in wider Prague areas ‚Äî Vy≈°ehrad Castle or Strahov Stadium.
Btw, Mission: Impossible 1 was the very first foreign movie made in Prague after the fall of communist regime.
Amadeus (1984)
Probably the best and the most known movie ever made in Prague is Amadeus. Filmed in 1984, so when we still had communistic regime, by Czech director Milo≈° Forman (who had to leave the country because of the same regime). The plot of the movie is set in Vienna, telling the story of two rival composers ‚Äî Mozart and Salieri. It won eight Oscars including Best Picture, Best Actor and Best Director. That‚Äôs pretty good, isn‚Äôt it?
The best filming location to visit is the Estates Theatre, where the real Mozart premiered his opera Don Giovanni. Among others, try to stop in Wallenstein Garden, Strahov Monastery, St. Giles church or Colloredo ‚Äî Mansfred Palace.
Casino Royale (2006)
Agent 007 had to make it to Prague one day, no doubt about it. Some of the place where he is walking, running and shooting were filmed in Strahov Monastery, National Museum or Prague Airport that was supposed to be‚Ä¶ well, Miami Airport :)
Actually, most of the movie was shot in other towns, such as Loket and Karlovy Vary. Especially in Karlovy Vary, the movie makers decided to use again famous Grandhotel Pupp ‚Äî that you might know from another movie, The Last Holiday with Queen Latifah and G√©rard Depardieu.
Operation: Daybreak (1975) or Anthropoid (2016)
One of the most important moments in the history of WW2 is the arrival of the Butcher of Prague and his eventual assassination in 1942 by two Czechoslovakian paratroopers. There are several Czech movies dedicated to this operation. Speaking about those made in English language, you must watch Operation: Daybreak and the new Anthropoid movie, both filmed also on the authentic locations. They display the bravery of Czechs and how terrible price we had to pay.
To find out more about what really happened in 1942, join my Memorial Tour.
Child 44 (2015)
Movie based on a book that tells the story of the Russian military police (Tom Hardy and Gary Oldman) investigating a series of a child murders during the Stalin era in Russia. Movie makers decided to come to Prague especially because of the underground stations (dated back to communistic time) but also for the interiors. One of them is the National Museum. However, the director Ridley Scott did not like the facade of the National Museum and asked to repaint it. He was quite confused when the city did not allow him to do it. :)
Btw, did you know that for the filming, producers had to stop the operation of Prague‚Äôs underground? That happened for the first time in our history. You can imagine how locals were happy about it :)
Les Mis√©rables (1998)
Probably the best version of Victor Hugo‚Äôs story and made in Prague! The cast is perfect, starring Liam Neeson, Uma Thurman or Geoffrey Rush and the setting even more splendid. For many travellers Prague really look like a small Paris and if not, it is easy to make by using film effects. That‚Äôs how the movie makers replaced St.Vitus Cathedral for Notre Dame de Paris in one scene, but in the other one you can see our Cathedral back again :)
Yentl (1984)
Barbra Streisand and the song ‚ÄúPapa, Can You Hear Me?‚Äù, who would not know it? It comes from the movie called Yentl that tells a story of a Jewish girl disguises herself as a boy to enter religious training. It won also one Oscar, Golden Globe and the nomination for Grammy Awards.
xXx (2002)
An extreme sports athlete, Vin Diesel, is recruited by the government on a special mission. The movie itself is nothing special, but the scene on Vltava river is pretty amazing. Also several sights from historical centre appear in the movies, such as T√Ωn Church, Old Town Square, Municipal House or Charles Bridge.
And the winner for the Best Shot in Prague is‚Ä¶
The Best Offer (2013)
The story of an elderly man working in auctions, the collector or the painting, was mostly filmed in Italy. However, at the final of the movies, the main character (Geoffrey Rush) decides to come to Prague. He enters the room of the hotel, opens the window and the first thing he sees is the famous Astronomical Clock. What an amazing shot! Only afew seconds, but it makes you feel you need to come to this city. Watch and decide. :)
Btw, the restaurant mentioned in the movie. Night&Day, does not actually exist :)
Looking for more?
‚Ä¶and many more :)
Here you can see some photos from the streets of Prague, directly from the set. And try to guess what movies it is from :)

Title: Coming to Prague? I‚Äôm a local, and here‚Äôs what I love to do here
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
I‚Äôve lived in Prague for 25 years, and I get asked pretty frequently about good things to do, so I figured I‚Äôd put it into a list.
In terms of events calendars, I‚Äôd check the Expats.cz (www.expats.cz) calendar, the Prague TV (www.prague.tv) calendar, and the Czech Tourism site (which is good, but kinda basic ‚Äî http://www.czechtourism.com/home/).
Here‚Äôs something you might not know: Vietnamese culture is strong in Prague. Vietnamese are the third-largest ethnic minority in the Czech Republic (behind Slovaks and Ukrainians), and there are a number of places to get great Vietnamese food, including the sprawling SAPA marketplace (Anthony Bourdain visited there when he came to Prague a couple of years ago). SAPA is like a huge swap meet. It‚Äôs kind of hard to get to, but a really unexpected thing to find in Prague. (Map: https://goo.gl/maps/wKypyCh5AW32)
Barring that, I‚Äôd recommend visiting Banh Mi Makers on Dlouh√° t≈ôida in the Old Town for a great Banh Mi sandwich. In fact, the building that houses Banh Mi Makers is a gourmet shopping center that also hosts one of the must-visit restaurants in town, the stand-up Na≈°e Maso butcher shop Map: https://goo.gl/maps/XacKM4neyct. If you have enough lead time, I highly recommend reserving their ‚ÄòNoc s ≈ôezn√≠kem (Night With A Butcher)‚Äô an absolutely massive six-course
Just down Dlouh√°, you have Lokal, which is a retro-style pub that serves some of the freshest Pilsner Urquell outside of Pilsen. And next door you have the Roxy and NoD spaces, which are great for catching a DJ gig or maybe a performance (check the website at www.roxy.cz).
In terms of vegetarian fare, I like the Maitrea restaurant near the Old Town Square, and Radost FX Cafe, and I highly recommend the Eska restaurant in the up and coming Karlin neighborhood. It just got a Michelin Bib Gourmand, and while it isn‚Äôt a strictly vegan restaurant, it‚Äôs a place that focuses on bread and things made with yeast or fermentation. It‚Äôs excellent.
One place that‚Äôs kinda touristy but still excellent is the rooftop bar at the Hotel U Prince, just off the Old Town Square. Walk into the hotel, all the way to the back, and you‚Äôll find a glass elevator. Take that to the top and walk up some stairs, and you‚Äôll be rewarded with one of the most spectacular views of the city you could ever imagine. And it‚Äôs even heated in the winter. https://www.terasauprince.com/terrace
The Maurer Grand Restaurant list (and app) has a ton of great restaurant recommendations too. http://www.grandrestaurant.cz/home/?lng=en
Prague has some great design shops if you know where to look. I especially like Tuzeks (http://tuzeks.eu/), which is a play on words on the old Communist hard-currency shops. Tuzeks sells retro Czech design (the lamps and chairs are great). https://goo.gl/maps/L7u5hKYkTG62
In the last couple of years we‚Äôve seen a lot of design stores open up, and one of my favorites is the Chemistry Design Store (https://www.facebook.com/thechemistrydesignstore/), which has a lot of funky prints, glasswork, and some of the coolest turntables I‚Äôve ever seen (made by 440 Audio ‚Äî http://www.440audio.eu/). I also love the Modernista store in several locations, including the House of the Black Madonna. They specialize in faithful reproductions of Czech art deco, cubist and modernist pieces, and they‚Äôre gorgeous. http://www.modernista.cz/?lang=en
The Museum of Decorative Arts is also off the beaten path and is excellent, and has a wonderful museum shop, also run by Modernista (https://goo.gl/maps/1WdovwAG1Ro). Bonus: The windows, especially the ones in the stairways, overlook the Jewish Cemetery. I‚Äôm of two minds on whether the cemetery itself is worth going to. It‚Äôs usually mobbed, and it‚Äôs pretty pricey to get in. But the synagogues are beautiful. I‚Äôd instead recommend the small Jewish cemetery under the Zizkov TV tower. While there, you can check out the bar up on top of the TV tower, as well as checking out the Palac Akropolis, still my favorite concert venue in town, with two separate DJ bars.
I also like the scruffy ≈Ωi≈ækov neighborhood where the Akropolis is located, which, pound for pound, has the highest concentration of bars, restaurants and cafes in town. That and the more upscale Vinohrady neighborhood next to it are good.
Being an old fart, I don‚Äôt get out as much as I‚Äôd like to. But when I do, I like the Naplavka riverwalk (https://goo.gl/maps/66HK8PEoGEH2) and the Krymska street neighborhood (https://goo.gl/maps/3PfbNjZEM5r). Naplavka is not so great in the wintertime, but is the place to be in spring and summer. And Krymska is ground zero for Prague hipsters. Pretty great.
Clubwise, some of Prague‚Äôs must-visit places include the Palac Akropolis (www.akropolis.cz), Roxy, Rock Cafe, Radost FX, and definitely the Cross Club, which must be seen to be believed ‚Äî Atlas Obscura has a nice writeup here: http://www.atlasobscura.com/places/cross-club
I live close to the up-and-coming Letna neighborhood, which is anchored by the Bio Oko arthouse cinema and cafe (https://goo.gl/maps/rLkuMmDs9YF2). That neighborhood has the National Technical Museum, a must-see for geeks (https://goo.gl/maps/a9h6YqqUp6v) and Letna Park‚Äôs beer garden (https://goo.gl/maps/Dqvzyh8HNEs), which has one of the best views in town. In between are all kinds of great cafes and bars.
I‚Äôd strongly recommend getting a metro pass for the time you‚Äôre here. It‚Äôs cheap and so much less hassle. I‚Äôd also recommend (if you have mobile data) the Google Maps app, which also gives you timetables and nearest transit stops.
Prague taxis are a total ripoff, and I definitely do not recommend taking a taxi from the street. Use one of the services instead. I use Tick Tack Taxi (www.ticktack.cz), Taxi AAA (http://www.aaataxi.cz/en/), and Uber, which works well (although, like everywhere, surge pricing is something to watch for).
If you‚Äôre heading toward Vienna, I‚Äôd recommend either ƒåesk√Ω Krumlov or Mikulov. ƒåesk√Ω Krumlov is one of my favorite places on the planet and an amazing UNESCO World Heritage site ‚Äî it‚Äôs an entire town from the 14th century flawlessly preserved. Just gorgeous. Mikulov, in southern Moravia, is in the wine region, and is also a really nice place to be, moreso in summertime. Plus, there‚Äôs a nice waterpark just outside of town (http://www.aqualand-moravia.cz/en)/.
If you‚Äôre heading north toward Berlin, I‚Äôd recommend taking a day to check out Bad Schandau, a spa town with a kickass thermal bath (http://www.toskanaworld.net/web/en/therme_bad_schandau/home.asp), and the Czech and Saxon Switzerland national park, famous for its sandstone formations, including a couple of natural bridges.

Discovering Beautiful Prague Hacks
Ahoj!
Now,if you have visited the beloved continent Europe ,you already know what a gem it is for travelers.It‚Äôs almost safe to say that it is every traveler's dream destination. Not only does it have over 40 countries to be explored (most without any visa restrictions)it offers a chance to experience rich history and cultures given most European countries have different languages.This said I put myself on a challenge to explore the world a little bit more,to experience other cultures and appreciate the diversity it brings through travel and what better time to do so whilst living in Europe.This brings me to why am writing this article,I fell in love with the beautiful city Prague ever since I embarked on a 4 day trip to celebrate my birthday. It left a lasting impression because of its beauty and rich history and would like to share some hacks and tips for first time travelers based on my experience there.
1 . Pick an accommodation location that minimizes traveling
Even though Prague is a fairly affordable city in terms of cost of living ,i‚Äôd recommend finding accommodation around the namesti republiky . Here you‚Äôll find a vast amount of key monuments within its vicinity (Kotva Department Store, Municipal House, Powder Tower, Czech National Bank and Palladium shopping mall) . In addition all other key places e.g Prague castle,National Theater,Jewish Quarter are accessible by foot hence you save on the 32czk ticket that allows you 90 mins of travel using the buses/trams/metros. However should you choose an accommodation that requires you take the public transportation i‚Äôd highly recommend taking the 3 day pass ticket that costs 310 CZK.
This is not a sponsored article but am sharing the accommodation that I stayed and felt I really had value for money
emporio-prague-apartments.com
2. Be smart when it comes to currency conversion
If you are arriving from other country you should know that Czech doesn‚Äôt use Euros and instead uses Czech koruna(CZK). Hence prior to getting here I would recommend either have some loose cash around 5 euros to change at the airport exchange bureaus which give an awfully bad rate or pay your transportation by card. Please note the ticket machines only accept coins or card.Ticket cost from the airport to the Namesti republiky city center costs 32 CZK which is an equivalent of about 1.28 euros.
Recommended Exchange bureaus that had the most competitive rates eXchange, Kaprova 14/13, 110 00 Josefov, Czechia
Alfa Prague S.r.o., Na P≈ô√≠kopƒõ 957, 110 00 Star√© Mƒõsto, Czechia
Another important thing to be mindful about is the cash withdrawals or payments when using cards because of the bank conversions. Locals have recommended that its better to pay in czk than your bank currency when using a card for payments.
3.Maximize your itinerary (Use the free maps shared either in hotels or airport!)
Am sure if you google what to do in Prague in x number of days you‚Äôll find tonnes of information. Whilst this is nice as it gives you an idea of what is available I highly recommend that you pick up the free maps offered at the airports on your way out,they are really handy in giving you a visual of where the places you ought to visit are!! I got a really cool map at the airport that had listed all the key places to visit,metro line guide and Prague city tourism information. I found this to be truly useful as it enabled me make an optimized visit schedule since I could see the location of each place I wanted to visit and the proximity to other places.
4.Book a free tour prior to arriving
You‚Äôd be amazed at how much you learn about Czech through these free tours which at the end you give whatever amount you see best.
Fun fact : Did you know which music Neil Armstrong took to the moon? wait for it‚Ä¶Anton√≠n Dvo≈ô√°k‚Äôs New World Symphony is the answer! :) .He was a famous Czech composer. I didn‚Äôt know this until i had this tour :p.
Link to the free tour that i used
freewalkingtourprague.eu
5.Eat,Explore,Reflect and Repeat
Travelling is fun but even better when we can use that chance to learn about a new culture and people. Explore the local foods and experiences ,you must agree having Italian cuisine in Prague is probably a not so good idea. Also take time to reflect and appreciate the precious moments and memories made in the new place.
My short recommended list of top foods and things to do
Hidden gem I stumbled upon :Restaurace U Dvou Velbloud≈Ø, Ko≈æn√° 474, 110 00 Star√© Mƒõsto, Czechia
Hidden gem i stumbled upon :Na≈°e maso, Dlouh√° 727/39, 110 00 Star√© Mƒõsto, Czechia
There are two points at the Charles bridge that you can make a wish (Statue of St John Nepomuk and the statue in the picture below) :) i made my wish for ‚Ä¶
If you are a lover for animals this is totally worth it !. For (250 CZK) as entrance fee, I got to see so many amazing animals and reconnect with mother nature through the trail walks.
Accessing the Prague castle courtyards and gardens is free. The golden lane is free to access after closing hours (please note that the houses aren‚Äôt accessible however). Whilst you have plenty to do I highly recommend buying one of the tickets to access some Prague castle structures.Depending on which circuit you choose you either pay 350 CZK or 250 CZK. I chose to go with the circuit B ticket that gave me access to the Old Royal Palace,Basilica of St.George,Golden Lane and the St.Vitus‚Äôs Cathedral. There is so much history in these places and for a moment at the golden lane I felt as if I traveled back in time.
There‚Äôs so much to share and this is definitely not exhaustive . However I shared my top hacks I believe are handy for first time travelers to Prague. Thank you for taking time to read this article and don‚Äôt forget to share your Prague stories.
Dekuji!!

Content:

We had explored many places before going to Prague because of our love to discover new places. Some of the places I list below are the places we had previously explored, and some of them we found by chance. PS: We tried to explore some concept places rather than the most popular places on this trip.
Cafefin is not a breakfast place where you can spend hours as we are used to. For example, you wake up so early, you‚Äôre in a hurry, you want to have a healthy and delicious breakfast. Then here is the right address! This busy and popular cafe is the first Vietnamese coffehouse in Prague. There are mini tables and the stools at the long bar that you can sit. The staff are incredibly friendly. The Vietnamese baguette category in the menu attracted our attention. Baguette varieties were not the kind we were used to, but I have to say that I liked it very much! The cafe is also known for its sweet chao rice and homemade yoghurt with black rice.
The weather was very cold in April. Therefore, when we were too cold, we would urgently sit in any caf√© we found by chance. That‚Äôs also how we discovered Tricafe. :) Tricafe was such a pleasant place that we have wanted to stay for 2 hours. We felt like we were at home with old-looking wooden tables, armchair seats in our grandmothers‚Äô house and rocking chairs. You could read books from their library or you could take a glance at drawings on the wall as a mini exhibition. By the way their coffee was pretty good.
Trdelnik has started to spread after Easter markets that were established in Czech Republic in 2002 and it has become one of the symbols of Prague. We have gone to Prague during Easter so we had the opportunity to experience it in the Easter markets. Trdelnik is made from rolled dough that is wrapped around a stick, then grilled and topped with sugar and walnut mix. I‚Äôve tried the Nutella version of it. You can find different versions of Trdelnik in various shapes and with different flavors. Especially in the summer, you can find Trdelnik with different kinds of ice cream in Prague.
Restaurant Bella Vista has the best view in the city. Its panoramic view stretches from the Petrin Tower all the way to Prague Castle Hillsides. It streches from the west to the north, it provides spectacular views of greenish copper cupolas, narrow cobblestone streets, bridges connecting both river banks and green gardens from red-roof tops of centuries-old houses. Actually, we had come here to visit the Strahov Monastery. After the visit to the monastery, this amazing view has made our day! We couldn‚Äôt leave there without drinking a green lager to the accompaniment of this view.
Kantyna is a restaurant where you can taste great meats in Prague. In the entrance part, you can choose the meats that you would like to eat in the butcher section or if you are in a hurry, you can prefer the meats that are already cooked. We chose to choose our meat from scratch and we started to wait at our table. Alcoholic and non-alcoholic beverages are also available, but we wanted to try local beer with our meats. This was the first place we stopped by after we got off the plane. We were very lucky because this place was so close to the hostel. Since I got back from Prague, I‚Äôve been telling everyone about this place. The meats were absolutely incredibly delicious.
Cafe Slavia was the place where Nazƒ±m Hikmet had written some poems in Prague. There is a portrait of Nazƒ±m Hikmet which is painted by one of the Czech artists. However, the place also inspired many important literary artists. Kafka also had been going to this cafe while writing his novels.
First of all, if you want to go this place, you have to make a reservation. That‚Äôs why we‚Äôve waited too long to sit, but the friendly staff was really helpful. I really like their food presentation. They served a meat with a kind of bread that they called ‚Äúknedliky‚Äù and cranberry marmalade. It was really delicious!
I‚Äôm a real John Lennon fan and that‚Äôs why I don‚Äôt recommend this place. We really wanted to have a drink at John Lennon Pub. However, we could not spend more than 10 minutes. Due to the fact that the waiters didn‚Äôt let us have a drink here. They said we could sit here if we ate something. If we only wanted to have a drink, we couldn‚Äôt sit even if there were available tables inside. There wasn‚Äôt anything there to connect with John Lennon except his photos. I would love to have waiters understand and embrace his spirit.
The Hemingway Bar is the most popular cocktail bar in Prague. This place deserves all highest points because of the friendly waitresses and the wide cocktail menu. The name of the cocktail in the photo is Snow Globe. I used to like to watch the snow globe when i was a kid. I felt the same feelings because of this cocktail. Watching the coconut particles brought me back to my childhood. If you travel to Prague, I‚Äôd say that you should go to Hemingway Bar.
Enjoy your trip!

Title: Visit Prague: What to do, where to go?
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
1
Listen
Share
My first trip to Prague was in 2015, and I have been living in Prague almost for a year now. Considering the touristic season is already here (it was more than 20 degrees whole week!), I thought I should better create a post answering questions that I get from friends about visiting Prague and share the places I visited for the last 3 years with you all.
This post is ideal if you are planning to visit Prague for a short amount of time (more than a day, less than a month) and want to visit the key places of the city according to my experience. The post is not giving clear transportation methods (how long it takes from A to B, which trams go there etc), and only intends to initiate a list of places that I find worth visiting at your first Prague trip.
Prague has a beautiful Old Town (Star√© Mesto) and it is a perfect place to start your trip. There you can see the Prague Astronomical Clock (currently being renovated until August 2018) which is the oldest functioning astronomical clock in the world. You will find its place in old town by just joining the always-waiting tourist groups in front of the clock because every hour twelve apostles appear from small windows of the clock. This parade takes almost a minute and is definitely worth watching. If you want to read more about the figures and the apostles of the clock, read here.
After you walked around the Old Town, you can move to Charles Bridge (Karl≈Øv most) which is one of the bridges that crosses the Vltava River. The historical bridge hosts 30 sculptures and sculpture groups on its walls. Although it is the most crowded place in the daytime due to the heavy interest of tourists, you would not want to miss the view from the bridge and the daylight look on the sculptures. I recommend visiting the bridge again in the evening to experience the charming lit version of the bridge and the beautiful city under the evening lights one more time.
From the Charles Bridge you can connect to Kampa Island. There is a little channel called ƒåertovka (Devil‚Äôs Channel) with an old mill (not functioning anymore). Around the old mild there is a Vodn√≠k (can be translated as Water Demon) sitting and watching for the possible souls to store in porcelain bottles* :) At the same time, this happens to be my favourite part of Kampa Island. Also, there is a restaurant next to the mill, and it has a cute balcony and two tables outside, by looking to it I always think it can be good choice for a romantic dinner ‚ù§
* In Czech folklore, it is believed that evil vodn√≠ci (plural of vodn√≠k) try to drown people when they happen to swim in their territory and store the souls of the drowned in porcelain bottles.
From the little channel bridge, you can walk to John Lennon Wall. In my opinion, currently it looks like more of a name+surname wall of the people who sprayed their names onto the wall, but it should be seen for the worthy cause of the wall, against wars, and inspired by John Lennon‚Äôs peaceful acts.
Kampa Park is very pretty in the spring, a must-see for visitors in summer. You can see bronze statues of three crawling babies*, by the Czech sculptor David ƒåern√Ω and have some photos with them like I did :) The sculptor is known as a controversial artist and you can find his installations at many different spots in Prague. For example, he is the artist behind the famous Head of Franz Kafka and Man Hanging Out; the man in the subject is Sigmund Freud who was born in Moravia, depicted as hanging by one hand not sure if to hold onto or let go.
* There is an ugly TV tower in Prague and some of the crawling babies added on it to make it a bit prettier. If you happen to visit TV tower area, you can see the crawling babies climbing to the tower :) The babies that climb to the tower are made from fiberglass, a bit lighter than their bronze siblings at Kampa Park :)
While you are at Kampa Island, you can visit Museum Kampa, one of the many modern art museums in Prague. I haven‚Äôt visited the museum myself but it is on my to-do list. You should find Kampa‚Äôs yellow penguins as they are pretty cute and don‚Äôt forget to check them again in the evening because they are also lit!
Another must-see place, and also very popular by all tourists, is Prague Castle (Pra≈æsk√Ω hrad). The castle complex is really big and considered the largest ancient castle in the world and St. Vitus Cathedral is situated within the complex. You can also get one of the best views of Prague from the walls surrounding the castle complex. I am known to take more photos whenever we visit the castle area with our guests who visit the castle for the first time :)
But what I like the most about the castle is the surrounding gardens. Awesomely designed gardens make spring/summer or for that matter any good weather trip worthwhile! Currently, as you can see at the first photo of the post, spring is very inviting, and the castle gardens are full of nice trees, flowers and awaking greens ‚ù§ You can check all the gardens listed here: https://www.hrad.cz/en/prague-castle-for-visitors/gardens
Talking about castles and nice weathers, I also recommend visiting Vy≈°ehrad (means upper castle in Czech). From Vy≈°ehrad, you can get an amazing river view one which you can‚Äôt get from Prague Castle. Probably by now, you already know that I can get very excited about city gardens, and as expected from me, I very much liked Vy≈°ehrad gardens, too ‚ù§
Prague is full of parks and gardens, and I am very grateful that I am living in a city that everybody can access the green areas easily! We (me and my husband) are living in Vinohrady (means vineyards in Czech) and the closest park to us is Gr√©bovka. As declared in the name of Vinohrady, Gr√©bovka also has one remaining vineyard from the many historical vineyards once covered all park area in the 14th century. The vineyard has a cute wooden gazebo restaurant & wine bar where they can also have weddings :) And my favourite part of the vineyard is that it also has a winery where you can get the wine of the same vineyard ‚ù§
In my opinion, Gr√©bovka is the most romantic park in Prague and we enjoy our evening walks (even more romantic, thanks to the authentic street lamps of Prague ‚ù§) there. If you‚Äôre staying in the same area, I recommend checking this park as well, if you like daylight park visits more, picnic season is already open!
Up until now, I listed almost all the basic touristic must-see places in Prague. If your trip is 2‚Äì3 days long, you possibly have enough places to discover in the city. But if you are more like nature-lover type and prefer doing outdoor activities maybe you can also check the nature parks I enjoyed visiting.
Divok√° ≈†√°rka (Wild ≈†√°rka) is a nature reserve and named after a female mythological warrior ≈†√°rka. There is a small canyon in the park, and it is pretty good for trekking. As a plus, you can also have a nice view after you climb the hill. It is a perfect place for enjoying nature in Prague without getting too far* from the city.
* From where we live, it takes about an hour to get there, but it totally worths the effort.
Stromovka is a very beautiful and large park. It was established in the 13th century as a game reserve and converted into a park later in 19th century. The park has a style of an English landscape garden, and there is a pond that I liked very much spending time around it.
Prokopsk√© √∫dol√≠ (Prokop Valley) is an amazing place to see and from where we live it takes almost the same time as ≈†√°rka to go there. There are two small rivers, a beautiful lake, and a natural reserve area. There are playgrounds for children and benches to rest if you want to have a rest. When we first visited the area, I fell in love with nature there, and I want to visit as much as possible this year.
These are all my favourite outdoor spaces so far and let me know if you can suggest some more for me to visit this year!
Before we finalise the post, I want to mention two places I saw families with kids enjoying their time there, and you might want to add these places to your travel plan if you have children.
Disclaimer: We don‚Äôt have a child so that I don‚Äôt have a personal experience in any of the places that I recommend from a child-friendly view. I just thought it might give some ideas to the guests with kids.
Prague Zoo is a very good place to visit, even if you are not a child nor have a child :) But I highly recommend, if you have a child ‚ù§ The admission price for a family of 4 (2 parents + 2 children) is 600 CZK (about 24 EUR ‚Äî April 2018). I usually have mixed feelings about the zoos but this one does not feel like an animal prison, instead, the animals have a lot of space, they wander seemingly freely and inspire kids to learn about them in a natural looking and feeling setup. When I visited the zoo in 2015, I thought except polar animals all animals are doing fine, but the condition of polar animals did not seem enough to me to support them in Prague hot summer :(
I know, Prague Zoo was seriously damaged when the flood hit the city in 2002, and hope the animals will get better treatment after the flood‚Äôs effects completely reverted.
My second suggestion for families with kids would be visiting Mo≈ôsk√Ω svƒõt (Sea World) Aquarium. It was relatively small and boring for adults but kids were having a lot of fun there when we visited the aquarium in 2016. The ticket price for a family of four is 850 CZK (about 34 EUR ‚Äî April 2018).
Overall, I think Prague is an enchanting city with its different styles of architecture from the Gothic, Renaissance and Baroque era. Dark towers, colourful and unique style of historical buildings, doors, windows, bridges, and cobblestone streets (unpack those high heels now!) carries the memories of a long eventful history. Prague also offers a great deal of green within the city with parks and natural areas. I think everyone can find a reason to love Prague and bring good memories back to home, or maybe make it their new home ‚ù§

Title: Prague like a local
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

Chronicalling trips, collecting tips + tricks to make travel come alive.

--
Listen
Share
The first time I travelled to the Czech Republic was in the early 1990s. Communism was collapsing and, despite the obvious scars of decades of oppression, there was hope in the air. Modern and democratically leaning, Czechia (yes it‚Äôs really called that now) along with Poland, Hungary, and Slovakia (or the Visegrad Group) showed promise in bridging the East-West divide. I‚Äôve travelled back many times since, happily noting the transformation of Prague from a city behind the Iron Curtain to a modern, upbeat, western city that has retained cool elements of its communist past.
To me, no neighbourhood displays this better than ≈Ωi≈ækov ‚Äî a grittier, historically working-class quarter infused with hipster caf√©s, craft brew pubs, and cool retro designers. With its awesome blend of old and new Prague, ≈Ωi≈ækov is not to be missed.
FRIDAY4PM Shake off the jet lag with a nice walk in Park Rajsk√° Zahrada and stop by the beer garden for a quick refreshment before heading out to dinner.
6PM Nothing beats jet lag better than Czech comfort food and a well poured beer. Head to Hostinec U Vodoucha, a classic hospoda packed with locals, for an authentic experience. I suggest the Pork Knuckle (189 koruna) and a pint of Mord√Ω≈ô 12¬∞ (45 koruna). The richness of the pork combined with the pickled veggies and a good lager to wash it down can‚Äôt be beat.
9 PM After dinner walk back to Namesti Ji≈ô√≠ z Podebrad to take in nighttime views of the church, Kostel Nejsvƒõtƒõj≈°√≠ho Srdce P√°nƒõ, and then head underground to BeerGeek. A craft brew house that‚Äôs constantly rotating its great selection of draft beers, they also offer small bites including a HUGE selection of chicken wings (monkey wings) that pair perfectly with what‚Äôs on tap. The bar‚Äôs warm, fun atmosphere draws people in and it can get pretty crowded on a Friday night so if you‚Äôd rather climb back into bed, check out their selection of to-go beers.
SATURDAY9AM Rise and shine! ≈Ωi≈ækov is home to Vitkov Hill, a national monument to Jan ≈Ωi≈æka‚Äôs victory over the Crusaders in 1420. It‚Äôs also a great place to take a quick run or hike to wake up. If you climb to the top you‚Äôll be rewarded with spectacular views of Prague from the base of the massive equestrian statue of Jan ≈Ωi≈æka.
11 AM Refreshed, and having taken in the stunning views of Prague head back down to My Coffee Story. A modern, neighbourhood coffee shop that serves great espresso and a nice selection of breakfast foods. Try the soft boiled eggs, Tri vejce ve skle, (135 koruna) or the homemade waffle with fresh fruit and mascarpone (110 koruna) to get your morning started off right.
1PM ≈Ωi≈ækov is home to some great up-and-coming local designers. A few of my favorite shops include the √ºber hip, cult, Czech bag brand, Playbag on Borivojova and Botas 66 on Krizkovskeho, which carries a wide range of runners, designed after Communist era Czech sport shoes, Botas or botasky. With new designs ranging from whimsical rainbow to classic brown leather this stop is sure to be a hit no matter what your style.
Let the Communist exploration continue with a visit to Bohemian Retro, a vintage shop specializing in items from pre-1989 Czechoslovakia. Despite the selection being a little more tired than I remember, it is still worth a quick stop. A more modern assortment of women‚Äôs wear can be found at SugarBat, which carries a wide variety of retro clothing that they describe as ‚Äúpin-up, rockabilly and goth styles.‚Äù Nearby, on M√°nesova, lingerie designer Zuzana Kubickova‚Äôs showroom and studio has a stunning selection of women‚Äôs intimates along some beautiful outerwear collections.
3PM Czechs love to grab coffee and a sweet afternoon snack. Stop by the newly opened Donut Shop and grab a coffee and brown-butter (56 koruna), or maple-bacon (54 koruna) doughnut to-go. Do as the locals do, and head back to the many benches at the square to enjoy your snack while you take in the sites and do a little people watching.
4PM Freshly refueled, or perhaps in need of another cup of coffee, saunter on over to Jirak Farmer‚Äôs Market. Described by Taste of Prague as ‚Äúone of the best things to do in Prague,‚Äù this quaint market has the rare distinction of being on Wednesday to Saturday. The food and decorations change with the season, and the selection of fresh fruits, meats, coffee, wine and hot food items in fabulous. People rave about the crepes from Galetka, and the coffee from Kavovy Klub.
5PM End your shopping experience with a visit to NeverEnough. The local design shop sports an in-house bar, great music and friendly staff. Grab a cocktail or beer while perusing NeverEnough brandwear (my favourite) in addition to a more limited selection of shirts from several European designers.
8PM For upscale food in a relaxed environment, head to Riccardo Lucque‚Äôs La Bottega Gastronomica. The airy bistro has perfect window seats overlooking Mahlerovy Sady Park which makes for great people watching while enjoying the fine selection of delicious daily dishes, homemade pasta and divine wines.
SUNDAY10AM A visit to Prague wouldn‚Äôt be complete without a classic Czech breakfast of kol√°ƒç from Antoninovo Pekarstvi. Be sure to try the makovy (poppy seed), and tvaroh (similar to cottage cheese), as well as the seasonal fruit selection. Apricot is always a favourite.
Noon The strange, somewhat ugly TV tower, with freaky climbing babies, built on an old Jewish cemetery defines ≈Ωi≈ækov‚Äôs (and Prague‚Äôs) landscape. To catch a wonderful last bird‚Äôs eye view, take the elevator to the observatory (230 koruna) where you can watch films about Prague.
WHERE TO STAYAirBnB has a great selection of apartments for rent that are perfectly located to enjoy the most of ≈Ωi≈ækov. Use this link to get a $40 credit!

musings from a solo trip around the world

--
Listen

I always thought eastern Europe would be cold and grey and Prague is no exception. But, as I walk past grungy stone walls under a slate sky, I notice the city‚Äôs canvas begin to fill with color. Each loud scarf or alleyway stencil builds anticipation toward my colorful destination, The Lennon Wall. However, as I weave through the side streets of this quiet, cobblestoned neighborhood in search of this mural homage to the late Beatle‚Äôs front-man, the wall is nowhere to be found! Just before I turn to my map for guidance, I spot a huddle of travelers staring at a simple message written across whitewashed facade in the distance. ‚ÄúWall Is Over.‚Äù
All that remains from this crowdsourced feat of artistic expression were these big block letters. What a buzz kill! But then, as I look closer, I see a streak of fresh paint coloring the outline of an umbrella in the bottom right corner. Maybe this is a more apt portrait of Prague‚Äôs beauty. A place with a medieval core spared from world-war destruction, a towering castle beyond the reach of any mere mortal, and a body of citizens freed from communism just 15 years prior still teems with the rumblings of creative individuality. Just hours after the wall was painted over, as is customary practice every four years, the people have already begun to fill the space with life.
Prague is alive. The buildings‚Äô imposing exteriors contain the thumping passion of proud Czechs. I could hear the city‚Äôs collective effervescence in the the fraternal ‚Äúƒåau!‚Äù as anyone enters or leaves a room or through the cracked window of an underground pub. The beer is cheap, tasty, and omnipresent. More signs for Pilsner Urquell (the local water) fill the streets than stoplights. With early sunsets, bars that never close, and pints that range from $1‚Äì1.50 USD, it is no wonder Prague‚Äôs happening nightlife is no secret to the world. One simply needs to step outside to hear packs of fashionable young people that make the streets feel like the hallways of the United Nations. To walk the streets is to share a drink with both the buildings and their inhabitants ‚Äî each additional round bringing you closer to the city‚Äôs pulsing soul.
It is hard to decide whether the streets are more beautiful by day or by night. By day, the signature burnt orange roofs that top the baroque buildings give the old town a sense of cohesion, as if to cross the Charles Bridge is to step into a 14th century universe. By night, streaks of light shoot up Gothic facades like shooting stars, creating long shadows that imbue even the most ordinary storefront with a sense of magic. The Vlatava River snakes through the city like a moat for the Castle, while trams carry the lifeblood that courses through the city‚Äôs veins. Prague‚Äôs hip energy remains inclusive and accessible. Like leaving a dinner party at the house of an incredibly welcoming host, I felt a sense of home that demands a speedy return.

Title: Prague, Czech Republic: The Podol√≠ Swimming Stadium (Plaveck√Ω Stadion Podol√≠)
Content:

Website: https://pspodoli.cz/en/
My ranking: 4.5 stars out of 5
Heading to Prague, Czech Republic? My top pool pick is the Podol√≠ Swimming Stadium. There are a number of pools to choose from including the newish Aquacentre ≈†utka but I have selected the Podol√≠ pool as #1 as it is historically interesting and the 3 pools are amazing.
The pool complex was built in the 1960s on the site of a former quarry mine along the river Vltava. It was recently added to the national cultural monuments of the Czech Republic.
You have three pools to explore here! The complex features both an outdoor AND indoor 50m pool, a 33m long outdoor diving pool, a huge spiraling slide, a steam room, a Finnish sauna (wood-burning stove), a solarium, a rehabilitation centre and a restaurant. I am a big fan of swimming rehabilitation so it was nice to see the rehab services prominently displayed. We don‚Äôt promote this much externally in BC/Canada?
The inside pool (pictured above) is designed with a big wave along the roof by Czech architect Richard Podzemny. The large viewing area for the outdoor pool is situated on top of the wavy roof. The pool is deep, clean and well maintained with crystal clear water. You need to go through the warm drying off area, showers and then wash your feet as you exit to the pool, which helps keep the water nice and clean.
I had a fantastic swim in each of the pools on a hot summer evening. My favourite was the indoor 50m which was quiet and peaceful as everyone was outside enjoying the sun.
I was surprised at the lack of lifeguards! For 3 pools they had two lifeguards in bright orange shorts (that we saw; perhaps it was a shift change or they‚Äôre in disguise?). However, the lifeguards were very active in patrolling and telling people what not to do such as jumping off the side edge into the pool. They may or may not have blown the whistle at my kids.üò¨
The change rooms are old and Soviet-era looking but they have modernized the locker system. When you arrive you‚Äôre given a wrist band (pictured here below on my son). You use this to enter and exit the facility and it connects to a locker of your choice. Very cool!
One interesting thing is that this pool is connected to Czech Television at the top of the hill, improving the energy use of both. Cold water is pumped up to the TV building to cool down the studio rooms and servers. The heated water is then pumped back to the stadium and heats up the pool. The water never drops below 26C, even in the outdoor pool in the winter.
Finished your swim? Make sure to stop by the restaurant on-deck and pick up a pint of beer and ‚ÄúNakl√°dan√Ω Hermel√≠n‚Äù (Czech marinated cheese ‚Äî a classic Czech pub food, one of my favourites).

Title: Memorial Tour in Prague
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

A personal tour guide of Prague and Czech Republic

--
Listen
Share
Many tourists wonder how Prague could survive the war without any significant damage. Not that much true though, but comparing to other cities in Europe, Prague was one of the lucky ones. In this post I would like to take you for a virtual tour to tell you more about what you can experience on my Memorial Tour. Just in case you are still note decided to book.
Memorial Tour usually starts next to the Municipal House. This is the best place to talk about changes in our history, how we transformed from thousand years old Czech Kingdom to Czechoslovakian Republic and how Nazis took control over the country. The Municipal House was the location of the Czechoslovak Declaration of Independence in 1918. It is here, where literally, the freedom was born.
Let‚Äôs immerse to the streets of Old Town and talk about how life changed under Nazi rule. Did you know, that in the first days of occupation, Nazis ordered a change-over to a right-hand traffic system, and we had only 9 hours to prepare for it? Many brave people joined protests that culminated in November 1939 when all Czech universities were closed and over 1200 students were sent to Nazi concentration camps. We will see the Charles University, the symbol of democracy and fight for the freedom.
There are so many brave people that put their lives for our country. Many of them were members of the resistance, many others died in the last days of the war when they stood against Nazi occupiers. Streets of Prague were full of barricades from any material they could find ‚Äî cobblestones, furniture, cars‚Ä¶ We will see the traces of this fights, that are still visible ‚Äî you just have to know where to look. And of course, we will also talk about the Jewish community and their members, who were send to various concentration camps all over Europe. Did you know, that Nazis made a decision to protect all synagogues, just to use them as their museums?
The major part of our Memorial Tour will be about one of the bravest actions that was ever done ‚Äî Operation Anthropoid. The Butcher of Prague or The Blond Beast are two (of many more) nicknames of Reinhard Heydrich, the new governor of Czech lands. He arrived to Prague in 1941 and immediately started persecutions of Czech political and intellectual personalities. He also gave orders to establish a ghetto and to start with the Jewish transports. He eventually paid for all what he did to Czechs in 1942 when two Czechoslovakian paratroopers from the resistance tried assassinate him. To know how it all happened we will visit the church of St. Cyril and St. Methodius in New Town district.
Are you interested to know more, to see it all? Just join me for Memorial Tour.
P.S. I will try to show you also the Petschek Palace. This building was build shortly before the WW2 for the merchant banker Julius Petschek, with all the modern gadgets such as tube post or paternoster lift. During the Nazi occupation the Palace became the Gestapo headquarters. The horrific tortures and interrogations took place in its basement, and there is a small exhibition about what happened in the rooms nowadays. Petschek Palace is used by the Ministry of Trade and Industry today, therefore the visit is only on request.
Are you interested to know more, to see it all? Just join me for Memorial Tour provided by Prague Journeys.

Title: I Traveled Across Europe ‚Äî Then Something Unexpected Happened in Prague
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

Listen
Share
Travelling through Europe had always been a dream for me ‚Äî not as part of a typical group tour with strict itineraries, but as a slow, meandering journey where I experience different countries getting a feel for the life in this continent.
This was my third trip‚Ä¶ and towards the end of the trip I felt something very unexpected.
It was something that I‚Äôd never seen in travel vlogs or read in blogs that walk you through the adventures and experiences of Europe.
I was in Prague ‚Äî it was my last day of the trip. I was walking over the beautiful bridge that connected old town with the extravagant Prague castle. The atmosphere was very lively, people walking around joyfully with live music being played at every corner. The weather was pleasant too and I was surrounded by the best landscape of river, mountain, and the beautiful Prague castle.
And yet ‚Äî I wasn‚Äôt mind-blown.
I hate to admit it ‚Äî but it all felt‚Ä¶ normal. Not because the city was dull or unimpressive. On the contrary, Prague is one of the most beautiful places I have seen.
It was an amazing vibe, so much so that it made me feel guilty for not being surprised or mind blown by the ambience. An ambience that anyone would die to experience.
I realized this was happening to me because I had seen so many beautiful cities, wonderful architecture, and gorgeous landscapes that my brain had subconsciously normalized it.
My brain had adjusted itself to this new reality, and all the beautiful places had unknowingly become my new normal.
It was like eating your favorite ice cream every day only to find out that it doesn‚Äôt excite you anymore.
I learned something new that evening in Prague ‚Äî even the best things or the best places we see or experience in life cease to excite you or offer surprise spark after a point.
It stops being special.
I had always dreamed of seeing the Swiss Alps, climbing the Florence cathedral dome, watching the sunset from the Prague castle ‚Äî and all those things were truly amazing ‚Äî but now that I was on the right side of all those experiences ‚Äî everything else felt just normal.
In fact, when I look back at all achievements or special moments of my life ‚Äî they all had eventually subsided and became mundane. When I got my first job, or started living in my dream city, or when I first started dating ‚Äî all the feelings that excited me beyond imagination at first started to feel ordinary when they became reality.
Perhaps, the moment you accomplish your goals ‚Äî your brain normalizes it. Sparks begin to fade; you aren‚Äôt surprised or mind blown anymore and it feels just routine.
Think for yourself, the life that you are living now, in this exact moment, was a life that your younger self would‚Äôve dreamt of‚Ä¶ and yet it feels just another day today.
Having said that ‚Äî know that just because your brain normalizes something doesn‚Äôt mean it isn‚Äôt an achievement that you should stop being proud of. It simply means life has used that achievement as a conduit to move upward and you have outgrown yourself.
You now have bigger ambitions and bigger desires that excite you.
So ‚Äî don‚Äôt dismiss your efforts or take your achievements for granted just because it feels normal now.
The younger version of me ‚Äî the one who dreamt of travelling, doing everything from solo adventures to group outings ‚Äî would be in awe of everything I‚Äôve experienced today.

Title: Prague Reverb
Content:
Sign up
