Title: Seattle vs Prague
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
I lived in the greater Seattle area for three years. I‚Äôve lived in Prague for five months. Here‚Äôs my take on the wins and losses in both countries.
1Topic: SmokingWinner: Seattle
As a lifelong non-smoker, I define a country‚Äôs smoking success as having less of a smoking culture. Compared to the US, Prague has a huge smoking culture. According to data from the Czech National Cancer Control Programme, about 25% of Czechs smoke, compared to approximately 15% of Americans.
Anecdotally, I‚Äôve noticed much more smoking on the sidewalks, in parks, and in the outdoor sections of restaurants in Prague than in the US. Every time I walk through a smoke cloud in Prague, I long for the US.
2Topic: DogsWinner: Prague
If you‚Äôre a dog-lover, Prague has two really awesome parts of dog culture that make it better than the US:
3Topic: Dog PoopWinner: Seattle
Czechs don‚Äôt pick up dog poop. :( I almost had to stop picking up my dog‚Äôs poop in Prague because I physically could not find anywhere to buy poop bags and could not consistently find publicly-provided ones. For months, I lived off the supply I brought from the US, then finally restocked when I was on vacation in Asia.
But don‚Äôt take my word for it. A reply on a TripAdvisor forum went as far as to encourage people to not pick up dog poop, as it labeled you as a foreigner. And this poignant excerpt from the Czech Expats page, titled ‚ÄúPoo Fighters‚Äù (the Seattlite in me approves of the title), explains the issue even better:
There‚Äôs the issue of doggy do-do. However positively disposed you are towards our four-legged friends, no-one enjoys stepping in a steaming pile of poop. Yet despite all those green disposal bins supplied with free brown, erm, doggy bags, some owners persistently fail to clear up after their pets‚Ä¶ Matters have become so serious that Prague 7‚Äôs district council is considering DNA testing feces at the scene of the crime in order to track down the responsible pooches.
I don‚Äôt think I‚Äôve ever stepped in dog poop in the US. In Prague, I‚Äôve stepped in it more than half a dozen times. Get your shit together, Prague. Literally.
4Topic: Public TransportWinner: Prague
If you want reliable, dependable, and affordable public transport, Prague is an easy choice. On a normal weekday, if you miss your metro, the next one is only two minutes away. Two. Minutes. From this list of best global public transportation, Prague ranks within the top 25:
In the US, conversely, public transport is a nightmare of inconsistent times on incomplete routes. I can personally speak to the abhorrent public transportation Pittsburgh offered during my college years; with the minor experience I‚Äôve accumulated, I can also briefly speak to Seattle‚Äôs public transport. That said, with the exception of New York, none of them compares with any of the public transport systems I‚Äôve used in Europe. For the curious, Now This News covered the historical reasons why the US is transportationally behind the rest of the world (summary: we chose highways).
5Topic: Health CareWinner: Prague
I caught a lung infection within my first two months in Prague. I went to the doctor but didn‚Äôt have my work-supplied insurance card yet. They charged me without insurance for an emergency, unscheduled visit with a nurse practitioner. I approached the checkout desk post-appointment, waiting for the immense sans-insurance bill. As I stood, cringing, watching the lips of the receptionist read out my balance, seemingly in slow motion, it was‚Ä¶ $35. Without insurance.
In the US, my boyfriend had some blood tests done in a scheduled appointment and was charged $1,500 post-insurance. Prague obviously wins here.
It‚Äôs not just cost, however. It‚Äôs also coverage. In the Czech Republic, every citizen is by-default insured. In the US, over 10% of adults do not have health insurance. Health insurance for all is definitely a win.
You go, Czech Republic.
6Topic: Automatic Sliding DoorsWinner: Seattle
Sliding doors in the Czech Republic have two major issues:
In the US, sliding doors open in such a way that you just keep walking, and the doors will move to not impede your pace. Czech doors, in contrast, will open after you‚Äôve been standing in front of them for a few seconds. On my first day in Prague I tried to enter a mall, but the sliding doors weren‚Äôt sliding. I figured the mall was still closed. It wasn‚Äôt. I just didn‚Äôt wait long enough for the sliding doors to engage. I texted my American friend living in Denmark about it. She confirmed that European sliding doors just suck.
I only have anecdotal and social evidence to back up my claims, however, I know I‚Äôm not the only one to have noticed this. I don‚Äôt know this person, but based on their rant, I can tell we‚Äôre soulmates in another life:
2. The doors have different opening widths depending on the season
Czech sliding doors open less in winter. I get it, they save energy. However, this algorithm has a ton of problems. First, you get used to one opening width and then have to acclimate to another. This wouldn‚Äôt be a problem, except that you‚Äôre usually not paying much attention to the doors when walking through them. Suddenly ‚Äî SURPRISE. They unexpectedly open narrower than they used to and you walk into the door. I wish I were kidding, but the sliding glass doors at my work cracked in the winter, I presume for this very reason.
And second, the narrow width is a huge bottleneck. Luckily, waiting outside doors in the winter is one of my favorite pastimes. Oh wait, it‚Äôs not.
Get with it Prague.
7Topic: Drinking CultureWinner: Prague
US drinking law: No open alcohol on the streets, absolutely no open containers in cars, and .08 BAC to drive. And that .08 BAC is something a drunk person has to self-gauge. Ne dobry (that means ‚Äúnot good‚Äù in Czech).
Prague drinking law: Open alcohol containers are mostly legal, open containers in the car are fine as long as the driver doesn‚Äôt partake, and drivers must have 0 BAC. There‚Äôs no tolerance for drunk driving, or even buzzed driving, in the Czech Republic. üëç
The Prague drinking laws make Czech drinking culture less restrictive for people enjoying responsibly. Additionally, they‚Äôre not so strict that they ironically encourage more drinking, like in the US, where paper-bagging alcohol or hiding alcohol in a bottle of Gatorade is a common sight. And finally, the zero-tolerance rule for drivers makes drunk driving less prevalent in Europe.
In the US, alcohol is involved in 23% of traffic-related deaths. In the Czech Republic, that same statistic is 4%. And the Czech Republic is one of the worst offenders in the EU.
8Topic: ShoppingWinner: Seattle
You know what I miss about the US? Target. Need to find some obscure household item? Target has it. Target doesn‚Äôt have it? Amazon surely does.
What happens in the Czech Republic? Well, if you want to find that same obscure household item‚Ä¶ well, you can go to‚Ä¶ fuck it, I don‚Äôt know. There are no major shopping centers like Target or Walmart. Think you can turn to Amazon next? Nope, there‚Äôs no Amazon in the Czech Republic. Your only options are to use Germany‚Äôs Amazon service, or the Czech Republic‚Äôs Amazon equivalent, Alza.cz.
I miss you, US shopping. ‚ù§
9Topic: TechnologyWinner: Seattle
One of Prague‚Äôs charms is its rustic, classic look. The streets are still cobblestone, the buildings are still original. Apparently, Prague is so beautiful that Hitler himself was inspired to spare it. Consequently, it‚Äôs one of the few places in this part of Europe that wasn‚Äôt bombed in WWII, so it‚Äôs one rarity that preserved its vintage appearance.
Unfortunately, that old-school culture also makes Prague lag the rest of the world in adoption and prevalence of technology. Do you enjoy elevators? Get ready to use some slow, old, questionable elevators that you‚Äôre not sure will hold your weight. The one in my apartment building doesn‚Äôt even have up or down buttons ‚Äî just a call button. When my dog chewed up my laptop charging cord, I quickly found out I couldn‚Äôt get a replacement in the Czech Republic (luckily, my work had an extra lying around). When I lost my Fitbit charger, I was forced to order one from Amazon Germany.
This carries on to other parts of daily life. When I was apartment hunting, almost nobody accepted emails. You had to call, and calling meant you had to speak Czech. Welp.
Welcome to the shitshow that is the Czech technology scene. Missing you rn, America.
10Topic: Customer ServiceWinner: Seattle
Need help at a store? Czechs don‚Äôt give a fuck. Want a shopping cart? Gotta put in a coin to get one. Want a bag for your items? Gotta pay for that too. Need a restroom while shopping? Get ready to pay again.
Generally, Czech store representatives and systems are ruder, less-helpful, and more prohibitive than in the US. It‚Äôs even worse if they figure out you‚Äôre a foreigner.
Check out this poignant quote and related article with more formalized data on Czech customer service:
In the Czech Republic, a basic lack of understanding of the minimum level of courtesy required when dealing with the public seems all too widespread ‚Äî and it‚Äôs costing companies dearly. A survey by telecommunications firm Genesys estimates that Czech businesses lose 1.08 billion US dollars annually because of substandard customer service.
11Topic: Elderly CommunityWinner: Prague
Perhaps because of the prevalence of public transport and the de-emphasis of cars, elderly people are active and all over Prague. It‚Äôs really refreshing to see independent elderly people around the city, a rare sight in the US. If you want to stay active in your senior years, I‚Äôd prescribe Prague.
12Topic: BathroomsWinner: Prague
Do you love knowing who‚Äôs in the bathroom with you based on the shoes sticking out beneath the stalls? Making eye contact through the stall gap? Do you enjoy people hearing you poop? And hearing other people poop?
Europe has none of these things. Water closets are God‚Äôs gift to relieving yourself. They‚Äôre little, private, sealed, closed rooms where you can do your business discretely and in peace. Mmmmmm.
The only downside is that Europe has a bad habit of charging for bathrooms. But with bathrooms this delightful, I‚Äôll take it.
Topic: WaterWinner: Seattle
I ask for few things in life. One of them, however, is free, still, ice water without a lemon in it. Seattle gets this. Prague does not. Most Czech restaurants don‚Äôt offer free water, and when you ask for water, they offer you the option of still or sparkling. And when your paid-for, over-specified water does arrive, it usually includes a lemon. And no ice. Shame on you Prague.
(I realize that most of this is personal preference. Please indulge my rant)
And there you have it! What I love and don‚Äôt love about my two homes, Prague and Seattle. Did you come to the end of this article looking for me to call a winner? I‚Äôm sorry to disappoint. Both cities have a special place in my heart.
--
--

Title: GETTING A HAIRCUT IN PRAGUE: WHAT NOT TO DO.
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
GETTING MY HAIRCUT while traveling is something that I still can‚Äôt take in my stride. Because of this I now look like one of those Barber: What you want? memes. Here‚Äôs my easy step-by-step guide on how not to get a haircut in a foreign country. Haircuts, as they say, are 20:20.
There are two key factors you should aim for when truly trying to devastate your hairdo: laziness and language barriers. Thankfully, I achieved both.Laziness, over time, will allow your hair to look odd. It grows this way and that- always unevenly, of course. Eventually, it will evolve to a look bad enough that if you bump into someone you hadn‚Äôt seen in a while they feel obliged to ask ‚ÄúEverything okay man?‚Äù
By this stage you start to think ‚ÄòYou know what? A bad haircut probably wouldn‚Äôt be worse than this.‚Äô(*Note* If you reach this point, remind yourself: a bad haircut is, in fact, much worse).
This morning, I had that incorrect thought. It was time to get a haircut in Prague.
‚ÄòThe difference between a good haircut and a bad one is a couple of weeks‚Äô my Granny says. As an Irishman, I would never be seen to disagree with my grandmother. But, come to think about it: A travel blog is the safest place to dispute your 93-year old Granny‚Äôs opinion and get away with it.
That‚Äôs if I was to do it. Which I would not.
As mentioned, my hair was more than unruly. It was bordering on passers-by questioning my mental health. Too short to be long hair; too long to be considered short. I looked tragic.
I had 2 work meetings on Google Hangouts later that day. Not the phone ones in your PJs. Video ones where you need to appear compos mentis.It seemed as good a day as any to smarten up.
I researched some Prague barbers and found plenty. There was an American Expat website that offered some decent options. Weighing them all up, I decided it would be best to procrastinate.
I took a break from helpful research and watched YouTube videos on ‚ÄòHow To Cut Your Own Hair‚Äô instead. Almost all of them were imitating a David Beckham haircut of one time or other.
Could I do this myself? I had my own lightweight electric razor‚Ä¶
Could I ask my wife, perhaps? Remembering our hostile afternoon in Cape Cod after how I reacted to her previous attempt, I thought better of it. Back to Google.
It ultimately came down to discovering the barbers closest to Prague‚Äôs Old Town Square, where I am staying. I reviewed the reviews and set my sights on their sites. One, in particular, seemed slick.
The website and Facebook page gave a good first impression. It spoke to my need to think that I‚Äôm cool and stylish at 31. Even the translation for tutto barbuto- ‚Äòfully bearded‚Äô- was pretty badass.
Customers drank scotches and smoked shisha in the online pictures. Smoking Hookah isn‚Äôt my thing. But drinking scotch while getting a haircut would be great to tick off the bucket list. It was 10am.
My wife Rachael and I embarked on the 6-min journey by foot from the Old Town Square to Tutto Barbuto.
By Prague standards, it was mild although my toes were beginning to lose sensation.
Flecks of snow fell lazily on the streets, too few and far between to ever last.When we found Tutto Barbutto, it was dark and empty. For a moment, I thought it was closed.
Before turning to leave, I hurled a tentative ‚ÄòDobr√Ω den?‚Äô towards the back of the shop. A small woman, maybe 26, emerged immediately, greeting me in Czech.
-I‚Äôm sorry, but do you speak English?-No.
We were off to the perfect start.
We were at an impasse. She had been clear she didn‚Äôt speak English. I had zero Czech but 2 impending Google Hangouts. Not to mention, the 99 problems growing out of my head. I decided to push through in English.
-Are you open?
-Yes.
That was good enough for me. I removed my coat and scarf then sat into the barber‚Äôs chair.
The lady who was about to cut my hair had dark features and a Marilyn Monroe portrait on her inner arm. I produced my phone to show her the picture I had screen-shotted as inspiration for whoever cut my hair.
This screenshot technique always strikes me as awkward. You can‚Äôt show them a photo of somebody who is tooooo attractive or it feels as if your drawing comparisons between yourself and the male model staring back at them dreamily from your phone.
Even the act of providing a photo is something I steer clear from when home in Ireland. Doing anything outside what is seen as standard behavior could be met with the most withering critique an Irish person can give a compatriot:
‚ÄúHe‚Äôs getting notions about himself‚Äù.
Looking at the screenshot, she zoomed in.
‚ÄúVery fastidious,‚Äù I thought.
She could have been thinking ‚ÄúThis man has notions,‚Äù in Czech.
To reaffirm we were on the same page, I pointed to the side of my head- albeit, an overgrown one- and said ‚ÄúVery short‚Äù. Then I helpfully pointed to the top of my head and said ‚ÄúLong‚Äù.
I find myself in these lost in translation moments regularly. While in the midst of them, I hope that a sizable smile will fill the gaps and encourage my opposite number to give me the benefit of the doubt while I point at my head and say random words.
-Zero blade?-No, thanks. A one.
I‚Äôm sure I held up one finger and accompanied it with another oversmile.
After a quick wash, the razor purred and hairs began to drop. So long, old friends.
She was painstaking and focused, spending what seemed like 15 minutes on the sides alone. It looked terrific. Suddenly the phone rang and she went to retrieve it.
Rachael came over to the chair for a moment and we both talked about how good I looked before the hairdresser returned.
I‚Äôm a long term insomniac and the night before had been rough. I had laid awake from 3.30am-7 before giving up the ghost of sleep and getting up to work out. It was only 10.30 in the morning, but I‚Äôd already been awake 7 hours. My eyes were heavy.
And now that the adrenaline was wearing off since my hairdresser was so good, I wasn‚Äôt sure I would be able to stay awake in the warm barbershop.Snip.
She chopped about three inches from my hair in one fell swoop. She had clearly experienced my universal gesture of point-at-top-of-head-and-say-long though. Or had she? I waited to see.
Snip.
Snip-snip. Snipsnipsnip.
I looked in stunned silence waiting for her to stop. She didn‚Äôt.
While I knew I needed a serious cut, I had expected to leave with much more hair to brave the bitter Prague weather. That protective layer of hair now lay on the floor beneath me.
As I write this now, it seems so stupid. Why not just stop her? There was something that was making me give her the benefit of the doubt, though. I felt like she had a plan.
Turns out she really didn‚Äôt.
Rach had been on her phone for the last few hellacious minutes. In the mirror, I saw her look up.
‚ÄúKeith!‚Äù
I ignored her call, trying to look calm as if this was all my plan. The man with the plan.
‚ÄúKEITH‚Äù she called again, louder.
I looked at her in eyebrow-raised resignation. Edwina Scissorhands chopped on, oblivious
Rach jumped out of her seat and walked towards the blizzard of hair.
‚ÄúYou‚Äôve cut it too short!‚Äù
The hairdresser paused. After a moment she said:
‚ÄúWas damaged.‚Äù
‚ÄúIt‚Äôs fine,‚Äù I said to no one in particular in consummate Irishness.
And it was fine. Just about as fine as looking like an idiot can be. The strangest think about my Prague haircut was that, at the end, she shaved back my hairline a half-inch or so.
Image of google screenshot for Prague hairdresser and how it turned out.Can you spot the difference between my Prague haircut and the model?When she finished, it didn‚Äôt look so bad. I won‚Äôt claim I looked good but it could have been worse. Through a combo or blow-drying and hair-spraying, she made it seem like she hadn‚Äôt scalped me.
Stepping away from the scene of the massacre, that big broad smile from earlier was a little more difficult to muster. But muster it I did; long enough to pay the 569 Czech Koruna (about $23).
Then I did what any self-respected Irish person would do.I thanked her and left a tip.
If you liked this and want to read more of my travel stories/mishaps, visit my website, sowherewerewe.com
--
--
Thanks for reading! If you liked it, give it an ol‚Äô clap and then visit sowherewerewe.com for more.

Nestled in the heart of Europe, Prague stands as a testament to the seamless fusion of history, architecture, and culture. Its magnetic allure has made it a global sensation, drawing in millions of visitors each year. But what is it about Prague that makes it so popular worldwide?
In the heart of Europe lies Prague, a city that seems to have borrowed pieces of history from various centuries and woven them into its very streets. For those with an appreciation for architecture, Prague is nothing short of a living museum, where each building tells a story of a bygone era.
Gothic, Baroque, and Romanesque Harmony ‚Äî What makes Prague stand out is its remarkable blend of architectural styles. As you wander through its enchanting streets, you‚Äôll encounter a seamless fusion of Gothic, Baroque, and Romanesque designs. It‚Äôs like taking a stroll through time, where every turn unveils a different chapter in the city‚Äôs architectural evolution.

Listen

Prague
I had not heard a single negative thing about Prague before arriving ‚Äî most of the travelers I had encountered prior had preached about how amazing of a city it is. This had my expectations sky-high for the Czech city, which I hereby declare the Interstellar Mistake (Christopher Nolan, Matthew McConaughey, Hans Zimmer, reality-based space sci-fi‚Ä¶ how could it have not been the best film of all time?!) When I only get to visit a place for a few days, my entire perception of it is largely dependent on the weather while I‚Äôm there (Ireland is beautifully sunny and warm, in case you were unaware). Unfortunately for me, my visit to Prague was accompanied by clouds, rain, and cold weather.
That said, it still is architecturally a magnificent place, thanks partially to it not being blown up by war. After all the historically significant, gigantic, celebrated churches I‚Äôve seen over the past three months, the Gothic churches of Prague are far and away my favorite. The charred-looking stone and ridiculously intricate gold and black ornamentation stand out prominently above the other buildings of the city. The largest of these, St. Vitus Cathedral, sits in the middle of the Prague castle on the top of a hill overlooking the Vltava river. The castle itself is a pretty well protected peek into the past, with the palace, churches, shops, and residencies that once inhabited the space within the castle walls.
Another thing Prague does do well is public / street art. This is also most definitely in response to Soviet rule of the city. One particular space called the ‚ÄúLennon Wall‚Äù celebrates the freedom to write anything on a public wall without an authority covering it up. Every day, hundreds of people come by and paint their own drawings and words on the wall, which is now feet thicker due to so many coats of paint. Beyond this street art, there are many humorous statues with implied political meaning, such as giant bronze babies with barcodes instead of faces, and two men urinating in a pool shaped as the Czech Republic. I don‚Äôt exactly remember the point of that one, but it‚Äôs funny nonetheless. Hopefully one day I‚Äôll be able to return to Prague under clearer weather and lower expectations, and be able to thoroughly enjoy the beauty of the place.

Title: Prague: Fear and Beauty
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

For those who love to travel, live for travel, and always have a story to tell.

--
1
Listen
Share
The Czech capital guards its secrets.
We came late to Prague. By the time we made our way to the red-roofed city, the path to the east was already well-beaten by hordes of budget travelers and lairy British stag parties. An influx of foreign tourists has pushed Prague close to the top of the list of Europe‚Äôs most visited cities, with all the opportunities and problems that kind of popularity creates for the local residents.
But Prague is every bit as beautiful as it was back when it seemed so exotic, smiling shyly behind the Iron Curtain. The Haussmannian grandeur of the Old Town buildings invites comparison with Paris, but Parisiens would never allow their buildings to be painted like this. Bright yellow next to powder blue beside terracotta. And while tourists gape at the astronomical clock that jerks into life twenty-four times a day, the sun ‚Äî when it shines ‚Äî gilds the dark spires of the Church of Our Lady of Tyn and makes the old stones glow as brightly as the painted buildings.
The same force that makes a person wander the world pushes flowers from the ground to salute the distant sun. The artists of Prague don‚Äôt stop painting the old buildings just because they can no longer afford to own them. Among the graffiti of the Old Town, two themes recurred: the Golem, as played by Paul Wegener in the 1920 horror film he directed. And the simple phrase, in English: Life Is Beautiful.
Flowers bloom and die and never leave a mark, and for most of us, this beautiful life is the same.
Few of us shape history, like the dead kings in their cold tombs on the high hill where Prague‚Äôs castle stands. But that doesn‚Äôt keep us from trying. For an additional fee that‚Äôs as steep as the stairs, you can climb the tower of St Vitus Cathedral and look out across the river at Prague. And up there, in the teeth of the wind that rises from the Vltava, you can see the old stones scored with the initials of decades of visitors, the merged letters in a dozen languages forming the ridges and valleys of an insensate fingerprint.
Prague isn‚Äôt as cheap as it used to be when the first intrepid tourists arrived from the West after the fall of Communism. But it‚Äôs still an absolute steal compared to the likes of Paris or London or Barcelona. Two nights at the gorgeous five star Art Nouveau Palace cost 166 euros after tax. Dinner and drinks for two at a Michelin starred restaurant for 200. Prague still represents a great deal for a budget traveler and offers a chance to splash out on high-end experiences at a price you could never hope to pay in other European capitals.
Prague has other marks, too. Scars with gloomier origins than the vandalizing initials of bright and brutish tourists.
On the day we visited, a young woman was lighting a candle in front of the narrow window of the church basement. The stone is still pockmarked with holes, where Nazi bullets once struck sparks from the walls. Seven hundred and fifty soldiers launched attack after attack on the church, but couldn‚Äôt dislodge the men hiding inside.
After hours of fighting, the Germans brought in the fire brigade and ordered them to flood the basement. Not one of the Czech freedom fighters was taken alive. The mission cost them their lives and the lives of anyone connected to them. It also prompted Nazi massacres in villages entirely unconnected with the plot. But it was the only successful assassination of a high-ranking Nazi officer. The war would continue, of course, with or without Reinhard Heydrich, Hitler‚Äôs ‚Äòman with an iron heart.‚Äô But at the cost of their lives, Josef Gabcik, Jan Kubis, Adolf Opalka, Josef Bublik, Jaroslav Svarc, Josef Valcik, and Jan Hruby proved that despite their military prowess, even the highest-ranking officials of the Nazi government could be killed. And 70 years later, Czechs still honor the bravery of men willing to die for their country.
Some fights are worth having. And life is beautiful. So beautiful that sometimes it‚Äôs worth losing.
Prague feels like the kind of place with secrets. It‚Äôs still relatively new to modern mass tourism, having been shut off behind the Iron Curtain within my lifetime. You can see it in the bullet marks, or in the creepy statue of the Commendatore outside the theater where Mozart‚Äôs Don Giovanni premiered. You can see it in the frowning face of the ubiquitous Golem.
Stories make cities what they are, just as they do for people. We become the sum of what we experience, our cathedrals and our bullet holes. Our spires and basements. We may be the wealthiest and most fortunate group of people in human history, and yet so many of us are afraid. Afraid to lose what we have. Afraid to fail. Afraid of others who are themselves prisoners of fear, that makes them lash out and bite anyone they can reach. Fear lives at the heart of our culture, the magic word written down and stuffed into the hollow clay skull of the Golem to make it live.
Tyranny comes in many forms, and fear has always been one of its favorite weapons. Prisons without bars are the hardest to escape. I‚Äôm living proof that you can spend your whole life making what seems like the right decision and never get any closer to what you really want ‚Äî the raw experience of being alive. Inside each of us, an iron-hearted voice commands caution, and while we hoard worthless tokens and live in fear of losing, we miss the bright imperfect world sailing by.
And yet we all want to make our mark. That brief blaze of light across an immensity of darkness, to say in some way to the uncaring universe that we were here. This is mine, a few words held out into the world like writing on water, vanishing even in the act of creation. The rough wind whirls the ticket from my hand, and I carry on without it, lighter for the loss.
This story is published in Writers on the Run. If you‚Äôre interested in submitting your travel stories please visit our submission guidelines.

Title: Museum technology keynote ‚Äî words from ICOM 2022 Prague
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Presented at ICOM Prague. August 24, 2022. Because I don‚Äôt ever fully ‚Äòwrite‚Äô talks but instead assemble slides which I then talk ‚Äòaround‚Äô, what follows is a very slightly more verbose version. The images used in the presentation, of which some are included here, were generated using the ‚Äòof the moment‚Äô AI image synthesis tools Midjourney and DALL-E2, I have included the relevant prompts used in the image captions. I wanted to use those images as a means of hinting at some of what I didn‚Äôt talk about.
Hello. I changed jobs last week and so did my slides.
I‚Äôd like to acknowledge that these words were prepared on the unceded lands of the people of the Kulin Nation in Naarm (Melbourne). The ideas I will talk about are the result of working with many collaborators, and inspired by many other poeple. All knowledge is the result of generosity and intercultural exchange.
A huge thank you to ICOM, and the organising team in Prague especially Martina and Jiri. And also to the tech team here at the conference centre who were able to deal with my request to present on my own device from the stage. I know how hard this can be when you‚Äôve not set up your venue to make that possible.
I work at ACMI, Australia‚Äôs national museum of screen culture. I will give you a little bit of background because it will help contextualise some of what I say later. Because this is ICOM, let‚Äôs begin with our collection.
ACMI has a large collection of different types of objects and media. Our historical time-based media is stored on analogue and magnetic formats but our contemporary commissions arrive as digital files on digital storage formats ‚Äî hard drives, USB sticks. This used to be rare. It is now common. The range and diversity of our contemporary works continues to expand from linear to interactive, networked, and multiplayer games.
As you may also be aware, Melbourne also has an amazing videogame-making creative community. As a result we also collect modern videogames and because of the uncertainty and complexity in digital preservation, this is a collaborative effort with Powerhouse Museum (Sydney) and National Film and Sound Archive (Canberra). This approach to collecting contemporary software-based artworks is greatly assisted by this distributed collecting approach, which I believe will become necessary and standard practice across many types of museum.
Through this process we‚Äôve learned that digital objects are more fragile than their analogue ‚Äòoriginals‚Äô, and that both digital and digitised objects exist in systems that require reliable power, engineering, maintenance, ongoing software development. These are all challenging frontiers for museums.
Further, collecting modern materials and presenting them for contemporary audiences has forced us to rethink the documentation processes of the past. Our online collection documentation reveals to the public the bias in what has (and has not) been collected, and how the language used in historical documentation practices reflects the prejudices and social biases of its time.
We also make rich experiential exhibitions that take advantage of constantly improving projection and interactive technologies. ACMI is also a bit famous for The Lens. With the support of the Lens, ACMI wants to change the media we make and consume. We want to change the what, the how, and the why of cinema, of television, of games. The Lens is one in a range of technologies to foreground the visitors‚Äô agency in this. And the visitors‚Äô responsibility to ‚Äòtake the museum home with them‚Äô. We work with the seductiveness of the media forms to sow the seeds of a critical eye, ear and hand.
Things have changed.
The old ACMI used to be a place to come to see an exhibition or watch arthouse cinema. That was how we measured success. The new ACMI suceeds when it changes what you watch or make, and changes how you watch and make. And that change could occur anywhere ‚Äî hence our brand as a ‚Äòmultiplatform museum‚Äô. We are still figurng out how to best measure that.
ACMI‚Äôs mission and how we fulfil that mission has been transformed by harnessing the potential of new technologies.
As a quick aside, at ICOM, many people have asked me about ‚Äòthe metaverse‚Äô. Julian Oliver, now a well known contemporary artist (‚Äòcritical engineer‚Äô) along with Chad Chatterton, and Andrea Blundell ‚Äî built a real-time collaborative virtual world ‚Äî ACMIpark ‚Äî that reproduced ACMI and Federation Square online, and bridged the physical and the virtual.
This was before Second Life, before Facebook.That was twenty years ago.
These ideas that seem new are not new.
The rest of the talk is a gentle provocation.
In 1968, the Metropolitan Museum of Art held a conference on ‚Äòcomputers and museums‚Äô. It was very important, and like many things from the late 1960s, we still feel its resonance today. At that conference the University of Illinois presented the PLATO system [Programmed Logic for Automated Teaching Applications]. PLATO was originally developed for the Illiac I computer connected to 20 student terminals and was a key part of education technology research. In these images we glimpse the birth of user experience design for media technology in museums.
‚ÄúThe terminal must be simple to use, yet flexible enough to accommodate and display many types of information. It must provide enough depth and scope of information to challenge the visitor without confusing him. It must involve him in gathering information and answering questions without frustrating him.‚Äù
You can see on this user diagram the familiar ideas of story, question & answer, user comments, related objects that museum educators and designers still focus on today. These are some of the first terms we still see in design briefs for gallery interactive experiences, and online catalogues.
That was more than fifty years ago.
It was designed in an era before the arrival of colour television.
We still think like that today.
In 1994 I was at university. Both I and many others were excited by the arrival of the nascent public web. For those of us in Australia and NZ, the 1990s and early 2000s ignited a utopian dream of ‚Äòplanetary computation‚Äô and access to a ‚Äòglobal network‚Äô. Culturally too ‚Äî for us, distant and far awy ‚Äî it offered the mirage of an opportunity to destabilise the media power centres of Europe and North America.
The web could have gone in many directions. There was the cosmopolitan web, the web as an infinite library, the web as a playground. And of course the web as a shopping mall.
Museum websites were rare but the first that existed were courageous. Some museums collaborated with others to build ‚Äòknowledge portals‚Äô and in some countries, museums even provided internet access directly to communities that they worked with. Even though screen resolutions were tiny, museums were worried about the people ‚Äòstealing our thumbnail images‚Äô.
It was a short lived dream.
Back then it felt like digital technology promised a lot. We thought expansively about the opportunities and that early history of museums and the web is largely one of exploration and imagination.
Unfortunately we didn‚Äôt question the underlying logic or politics of the databases we were working with or building. That would come much later.
Nowadays, every museum has a website. Even the smallest. And they ‚Äòdo social media‚Äô even if its a job done by a volunteer. They don‚Äôt even need to do it well. Their web presence is just a communication of ‚Äòwe exist‚Äô ‚Äî like a sign on a motorway that cars zoom past barely noticing.
In 2008 the smartphone and mobile devices grew web access by billions of people. Suddenly half of the planet was connected ‚Äî we did not think of the consequences of such rapid change. More people, all at once, was great for the profits of technology companies, but not for much else. The debates around access to the internet changed to focus on the quality of that access.
The internet is now awash with digital content and museums flood the web with their digitised collections. As a result of the economics of web platforms, everything is tracked. In an attention economy, breadth wins over depth. More, more and more.
We have seen that flood of content change our politics, grow misinformation, grow fear, destabilise our societies. In the absence of shared narratives, communities will create their own narratives ‚Äî true, false, rumour or otherwise.
The companies that emerged as part of the Web 2.0 wave have merged and consolidated into a handful of closed, data leveraged platforms. Free-to-use platforms have monetised our attention, monetised our data.
It turns out that the Internet is not a place.
We need to stop thinking about it using metaphors of place. There is no ‚Äòthere‚Äô there.
The cloud is simply a server farm in a region of cheap real estate with manageable weather and reliable energy supply. Like ACMI‚Äôs digital collections it is fragile. More fragile than we think. During the recent UK heatwave, several of the server farms underpinning the UK cloud came under extreme heat stress impacting the performance of major digital platforms. We should expect this to worsen ‚Äî and more of the Global North will be exposed to the conditions that the Global South has existed as an everyday reality.
The internet is not a place. It is better thought of as a time machine, or a time sink.
So now what?
Through the pandemic I‚Äôve been running a mentoring scheme for arts and culture CEOs pairing them with digital practitioners. In this program we work through conceptual and strategic issues around technology and how it affects and creates opportunities across different artforms and practices. It aims at building competencies amongst senior arts leaders to help them navigate the potential of the future ‚Äî developing a both capabilites and critically, fostering a digital imagination.
It has not just been for museums but also for ‚Äòadjacent‚Äô arts institutions ‚Äî theatre, music, dance, cultural centres, performance venues. Through it, we have realised that we share many of the same challenges ‚Äî ageing infrastructure conceived of in the last decade of the 20th century; skills that are expensive and rare; and as a result of infrastructural and skills shortages, we have crimped our imaginations. We talk a lot about risk, and we talk about cybersecurity, machine learning, bias, we talk about accessibility and we talk about sharing services across domains.
At the heart of this is the question, what might institutions need to support the creative practices of the future ‚Äî for the more diverse audiences of the future?
Our conversations have shifted from digital marketing, the latest immersive spectacle, and back of house operations to tangible transformation ‚Äî21st century infrastructure, staff skills and an expanded creative imagination. And how that shift inevitably leads to new questions about institutional purpose.
How might our buildings adapt and be re-designed for an always-connected visitor? And even more importantly, how might we retain that visitor‚Äôs attention and focus whilst they are in our building?
How might we shift our focus from technologies of ‚Äòinformation and data‚Äô, to those of world-building, narrative, emotion and imagination?
How might we better collaborate across the arts and cultural sector?
But, and there is always a but.
The pandemic and its social effects has created a huge demand for quick ‚Äòsolutions‚Äô. Around the globe many institutions are in desperate situations ‚Äî lacking revenue, lacking State support, pressured by the demands of a rapidly changing social and cultural context.
This situation sets up a risky situation where museums and those in a desperate situtation are easy marks for questionable ‚Äòsolutions‚Äô. Just as museums are not neutral, neither are technologies. All technologies have a politics and all media technologies have a specific grain. Museums will be ineffective if we do not understand the nuance of that grain.
Networked digital technologies are not inherently democratic.
New web technologies are easily branded with the language and rhetoric of liberation. We have seen this recently in the rhetoric around so-called Web3. This language often hides extractive and anti-democratic intent.
Beware the term ‚Äòdecentralization‚Äô in this context.
In the technology discourse around Web3, ‚Äòdecentralization‚Äô can be a legitimate desire to unseat the powerful platforms that control much of the web as we experience it today.
But when coupled with ‚Äòblockchain‚Äô it is also easily co-opted into a series of ideologies that work against many of the ethics and purpose of our institutions. In this context ‚Äòdecentralization‚Äô undermines the very idea of institutions and in some cases, sees societies only a mass of individuals distrustful of each other, mediated by so-called ‚Äòsmart contracts‚Äô. In this context, ‚Äòdecentralization‚Äô can be code for unfettered libertiarian anarcho-capitalism.
Museums beware.
Beware, too, if you do not understand how the companies you work with expect to generate profit for their investors and shareholders. In modern technology industries, funded by venture capital, the way in which revenue is generated is often very opaque.
And remember the words of Kate Crawford and Vladen Joler in 2018, writing on the technologies behind the Amazon Echo, but applicable to contemporary digital services generally,
‚Äúeach small moment of convenience ‚Äî be it answering a question, turning on a light, or playing a song ‚Äî requires a vast planetary network, fueled by the extraction of non-renewable materials, labor, and data‚Äù
With that in mind, we need to be clear about what change we want our museums to make in our communities before we can appropriately choose the technologies that will help us realise this.
What does your museum actually want technology to do for it? Is it more than ‚Äúgreater efficiency‚Äù, more than ‚Äúnew revenue opportunities‚Äù, more than ‚Äúreaching younger audiences‚Äù?
Looking back to that conference of 1968 and its prescient but unacheived ideas, how might your museum imagine possibilities that were actually unimaginable half a century ago?
Who do you partner with to achieve this ethically, sustainably, and in the least extractive manner possible?
You need to be able to confidently answer these questions in a manner that speaks to your institution‚Äôs mission and purpose because every museum technologist with any experience will tell you‚Äú‚Ä¶ technology is expensive, difficult, needs a lot of maintenance, it will break, it will become obsolete, and your vendor will disappear‚Äù.
They are right.
Thank you to ICOM, the ICOM conference committee in Prague, Martina Lehmannov√°, Ji≈ô√≠ St√Ωblo, and everyone who has been so welcoming on this trip.
Some rights reserved

--
--
I‚Äôm currently the Director & CEO at ACMI (Australian Centre for the Moving Image) in Melbourne. Previously Cooper Hewitt (NYC) & Powerhouse Museum (Syd).

August 28, 2012.
I had just finished my dietetic internship in NYC at the hospital formerly known as Beth Israel Medical Center, now transitioned to Mount Sinai, and I felt a sense of freedom. Where better to reap the benefits of this long-lost feeling than wander around Eastern Europe, specifically Bohemia, specifically Prague?
I hopped on an ICE fast train from Leipzig, Germany to Prague. Back then I had no smartphone, and I used a paper map to guide my way through the winding European streets. I got around just fine, except for that one time I was lost in the rain at 2 am. I did eventually find my way back to the Hotel Sunflower.
One thing I pack with me while traveling is a notebook and pen to write down thoughts, ideas, things I would like to do and see; places to eat and drink. My weekend in Bohemia included a typical tourist visit to Prague Castle and the Staropramen Brewery, yet it also included some not-for-tourist places such as Tynska Bar & Books, and this other place I had read about that was known for its vegetarian food in the land of pork knuckle and dumplings. The Czech name of the restaurant is Lehka Hlava, which translates to Clear Head.
Perfect, I thought. The name called to me after my long-lost night. I needed to clear my head.
After I arrived and was taken to my table at the restaurant I noticed a table of four women near my table of one. They were laughing, and enjoying their food and wine. Seeing them made me miss my friends back home. I bounced back into the present and ordered a full meal complete with a starter, a main, and a dessert with one glass of wine.
Looking back all these years later I cannot remember exactly what I ordered, but I do remember that the meal I had that evening in Prague was the best meal I had while traveling Bohemia. I remember the bill was equivalent to about 12 US dollars, which has been embedded into my memory since I was a graduate student at NYU at the time‚Äî not rich in money, but rich in books.
Although I cannot recall exactly what I chose on the menu nor did I take any photos of it, I do know that my solo dining experience was welcomed, and the food was honestly delicious.
Now many years later I glance at the menu on my computer. It includes items such as pumpkin and ginger soup with orange juice, vegetable consomm√© with yeast dumplings, spaghetti with tempeh bacon and sauce of baked garlic, g√©rtaix ‚Äî cheese balls with cumin sticks, wasabi dressing, and balsamic reduction, Kimchi-potato pancake ‚Äî traditional Czech potato pancake with kimchi and spring onion, and hot raspberry crumble with mascarpone-ricotta cream.
The menu reflects the diversity of the chefs at Lehka Hlava, and each dish has a goal to both electrify and soothe the senses. I still think about this restaurant now and then. It pops into my mind as ‚Äúthose carefree days.‚Äù It was such a relaxing atmosphere and left me with a sense of, well, clarity. I left Prague happy and with lucidity. I did not get lost that night with my paper map.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt have a girlfriend, but I do know a woman who‚Äôd be mad at me for saying that.‚Äù
-Mitch
I decided on Prague next because Kevin had told me you can get wasted there for 5 bucks. That was enough for me. Kevin always knows the right move. Except for the time he jumped into the Chicago River, drunk as hell, to rescue a shoe. That was dumb. The Czech Republic had yet to switch over to the Euro, and as a result, the exchange rate with the dollar was about 4:1. In simple terms, everything in Prague was cheap compared to other European Union countries. Slovakia was also on the Koruna, but that will come later.
The only issue with Prague was the overnight, 14-hour train ride I needed to take to get there. But that‚Äôs what Tylenol PM is for, or Ambien if you have access. I figured I‚Äôd just zonk out then arrive in the daytime, rested and ready to go. So, I booked a bed in a 4-person room for the 20:00 train that night.
I had a while to kill yet, so I did my laundry and went to an internet caf√© to peruse hostels. I found one called, ‚ÄúHostel One Prague,‚Äù and booked it as soon as I saw pictures of a bar. Again, the stumble home just can‚Äôt be beat. It cost the equivalent of 4 Euros/night (about $6 USD at the time) and looked just weird enough for my taste. I was stoked.
When I got back to the train station at 7pm, I sat down in the corner of the massive waiting area to kill time, for what I thought would be 3 hours.
Let me stop for a second and say military time is some deceptive bullshit. Why is it even used at all? Do soldiers not understand am/pm clocks?
Anyway, I missed my train.
20:00 looks and feels like 10:00pm, I will die on that hill. Tell me I‚Äôm wrong. It‚Äôs an optical illusion.
The following train didn‚Äôt depart until eleven hundred hours the next morning (see how stupid that is?) and going back to either the hotel or the hostel was not an option. Those bridges were torched. So, I slept in the train station cuddling my backpack. It was just me and a few other people who also couldn‚Äôt tell time.
*
April 4, 2006
When I woke up the next morning, I had breakfast before hitting the train station booze shop. I bought whiskey and wine for the ride, and for when I‚Äòd arrive in Prague in the middle of the night. Never show up to a party empty handed. I also got a couple mini baguettes and a bunch of bananas to supplement. I didn‚Äôt want to take the chance of separating them.
The cabin was tinier than I expected, and my three roommates were already there, lying on their beds. The four of us tried to introduce ourselves, but we quickly realized none of us spoke the same language. One guy spoke Cantonese, one French, and the other, German. Names were even difficult, as they all involved different dialects. Communicating verbally was an impossibility. I feared the four of us were in for a silent ride.
After a short while, I pulled out a bottle of wine from my bag and opened it with a corkscrew, making a loud popping sound. Before taking a swig, I looked around the room to get everyone‚Äôs attention, but they were already looking in my direction, smiling and nodding. I motioned to the bottle and asked, ‚Äúeh?‚Äù. We all broke out in laughter.
I put my index finger up, the international sign for ‚Äúwait a minute,‚Äù and went to the bar car to grab four cups. I took some Adderall too, knowing that it was no longer going to be a Tylenol PM type of night. Drugs allow you to execute hairpin turns like an F1 driver.
Back in the cabin, I handed one to each guy before getting in my bed. One at a time, they stood and received their serving, like communion. After our first round, the bottle was finished, so I pulled out another. Then came the whiskey. Within two hours we were all good and drunk, telling stories in our own language without caring if we were understood by the others. The person standing had the floor, and the full attention of the other three. Miming (they love mimes in France, and we were still technically within the border), and facial expressions were all we needed.
When my turn came around, I regaled the guys of my time in Paris, acting out my shitting and vomiting fiasco from a few days prior. They were hysterical. We all were. It was beautiful; four guys from all over the world, getting on like lifelong friends, without even the benefit of language. I couldn‚Äôt have been more grateful for such a warm experience on a ride that otherwise would have been a lonely one, filled with dad thoughts.
The guys and I all had transfers to make, so we parted ways one at a time, hugging each other and exchanging emails as we said goodbye. I was the last to transfer, and when I did, around 1am, I got on the wrong train and ended up in the middle of nowhere, at the Praha-Veleslav√≠n station at 2:00am. It didn‚Äôt even look like city; the area was so desolate. I had absolutely no clue where I was, or where to go from there.
After 10 minutes of walking and smoking, I saw a couple driving down the street, approaching the stop sign where I was standing. I flagged them down, waving my arms like a lunatic. They stopped, as if they‚Äôd had this experience before. Unfortunately, they didn‚Äôt speak English. With miming now out of the question, all I could do was show them my map, and say the word ‚Äúhostel.‚Äù They nodded their heads and waved me into the car. If they weren‚Äôt so old I wouldn‚Äôt have gotten in. Have you ever seen an old serial killer? No, obviously not. As soon as they tried to snatch you, you could just rip their frail arms right off. It would be that easy. Now that we‚Äôre on the topic, I wonder how old the oldest serial killer was. Can‚Äôt be older than 50, right? I mean, it‚Äôs a young man‚Äôs game, all that trudgery.
After 10 minutes of driving, we stopped in a parking lot with a bunch of taxis and the couple motioned for me to get out. I thanked them by leaning forward and grabbing their shoulders. I for sure could have ripped their arms off. I wanted to thank them to show my appreciation, I just didn‚Äôt know how. To cover all my bases, I bowed, crossed my heart, blew them kisses, and curtsied. They laughed and went on their way. I still wonder what they were doing out so late. Or maybe it was the morning for them, and they were going to the Czech equivalent of a Denny‚Äôs. Old people keep weird hours.
The cabbie spoke to me in what I assumed was Czech for the entire 15-minute ride. He knew I had no clue what he was saying, but I think that‚Äôs what emboldened him. He was angry about something, probably politics. Only politics, or maybe a spouse, can get a person that mad. When he‚Äôd look back in the rear-view mirror, I‚Äôd shake my head up and down in agreement like, ‚Äútotally. I can‚Äôt believe that either. Those motherfuckers.‚Äù Nevercomment on someone‚Äôs politics, especially when they‚Äôre driving you around in the middle of the night. It‚Äôs best to just listen.
*
When I checked in, the manager told me people were still drinking in the ‚ÄúCave Bar‚Äù downstairs. It was an actual cave with stone walls and an echo, very cool. It looked like the Catacombs, minus the bones. If people were drinking that late, I knew I was in the right place.
The first person to introduce himself was an Irish lad named Simon.
I‚Äôve always hated the name Simon because it was my grandfather‚Äôs name, and because I‚Äôve never known a sane Simon. When I was a kid, I went to camp with a Simon who got expelled for torturing animals. And then there was the Simon I knew in Iowa whose party trick was chewing glass and swallowing it. Tons of deviant Simons are roaming the earth unchecked, and it worries me.
Simon was all of 5'7'‚Äô, 190 lbs., most of which was stored in his robust belly. He had on a punk-style outfit with a mohawk and piercings. He was in his late thirties but came off like a disgruntled teen. His manic energy was off-putting, but he did have a charm to him.
Simon: How the fuck are ya, ya cunt? I‚Äôm Simon. You need a drink.
Me: Jesus, man, nice to meet you too. I‚Äôm Sam.
Simon: I‚Äôm going to call you John McEnroe.
Me: Because I look like John McEnroe?
Simon: Because I said so.
Caroline: Ok, Simon. Let‚Äôs be nice.
Caroline was there from Australia, on ‚Äúholiday.‚Äù (The Australian government partially pays for their post-uni holidays, an act so anti-American it‚Äôs hard for me to even conceive. In America we don‚Äôt go on ‚Äúholiday‚Äù to explore other cultures, we ‚Äúvacation‚Äù in apocalyptic places like Galveston, TX). She was 24 years old but seemed older because of how confident and worldly she was. Her smile was more of a single-cheek, shy smirk, than an all-out smile. She had long brown hair and bangs that laid atop her eyebrows, and was dressed casually, in blue jeans and a V-neck sweater. Some may have seen her as overweight, but I didn‚Äôt. I thought she was pretty. She also had Simon wrapped around her finger, which was impressive. The moment he‚Äôd say something too crass she‚Äôd tell him to shut up, and he‚Äôd listen. He‚Äôd even apologize, which amazed me.
Simon: Sorry for calling Sam a cunt. He‚Äôs not a cunt. Happy, Caroline?
Simon was just there fucking off, avoiding his life in Dublin. I remember him mentioning a kid, but I didn‚Äôt ask any questions because I feared his answers. He and Caroline had just met the day prior, though it seemed like they went way back. The cave had a way of doing that. We drank beers and took shots until the remainder of the Jameson bottle I had was gone. I can usually spot a fellow speed freak, so I gave Simon a few Adderall to christen our new friendship. He swallowed them right away, against my advice.
Me: If you take them tonight, you won‚Äôt be able to sleep.
Simon: I know how speed works, ya fuck.
Caroline and I called it a night around 4:30 am, while Simon went for a stumble until the bars opened so he could extend his bender another day.
*
April 5, 2006
When I came down to the common area the next morning, breakfast had already been made, by Caroline. It was a simple spread of toast, eggs, sausage, and potatoes, but I could tell she knew how to cook. Turning raw potatoes into crispy ones without the use of a fryer is not easy. You need to remove some of the starch by first soaking or blanching them. She used the latter method and nailed it. Again, I‚Äôm looking at you, London. I was impressed the way she carried herself in the kitchen, and by her motherly sensibilities. She took on the role of ‚Äúhostel mom‚Äù naturally, making sure everyone had a homemade meal before embarking on the day. That really attracted me. (Freud would have another field day with me liking mom-types).
After breakfast, Caroline and I went on a walk to a nearby bookstore. The place was gigantic and had a line a block long.
Me: There must be a book signing.
Caroline: No, there‚Äôs a line because they only let a small amount of people in at a time. It‚Äôs so shoppers feel comfortable.
Me: Do you know what Black Friday is?
Caroline: No, but it sounds scary.
Me: It is. It‚Äôs the day of the year when middle class Americans wake up at 4:00am to fist fight over who gets to buy toys.
Caroline: How is this legal?
Me: It‚Äôs part of the fabric of our nation.
Inside the bookstore, we had nearly the whole place to ourselves. It felt like we were on one of those dates that only happen in movies, where a guy rents out a whole ice rink for a romantic skate. At one point, when she grabbed my hand and pulled me to her favorite section, I could have sworn we were dating.
*
When we got back to the Hostel, Simon was in the cave, drinking by himself, so we joined him.
Simon: How was the li-bary, ya fucks?
Me: (mockingly) I rented a good book. It‚Äôs called ‚ÄúWanking Guys Off in Alleys for Dummies,‚Äù by Simon‚Äôs mom.
Simon: Now that‚Äôs the Johnny Mac I like.
Me: We‚Äôre still doing this?
Caroline: We are, Johnny‚Ä¶ I‚Äôm the umpire so I have final say. You play tennis, you should know this.
Me: Fine, I‚Äôll be John McEnroe.
Simon: It wasn‚Äôt up for debate, cunt.
After a few rounds, we went to a bar down the street, one that Simon had been frequenting. The three of us shared a joint on the way. Simon, fittingly, would forget to pass it because he wouldn‚Äôt stop rambling on. I had to keep reminding him, which got old quick.
‚ÄúUh, hey buddy. Remember, weed burns even while you‚Äôre not hitting it. If it was your weed, I wouldn‚Äôt say anything. But, seeing as I paid for it, you should keep it moving.‚Äù
The bar was spectacular in its‚Äô simplicity. It reminded me of a hotel conference room, with its‚Äô white stucco walls, and foldable card tables. There was no TV. In fact, there was nothing in there at all. It was just a plain room with a tiny bar that housed the beer. No liquor was sold, just bottles of Czech beer.
When we entered there were 5 guys sitting at a table, all of them old as sand. They waved us over to join them. We pulled up seats, and they motioned to the bartender with three fingers in the air. The bartender, who must‚Äôve been 80 years old, walked the beers over to our table. Simon immediately opened his using his teeth, a truly unhinged act. We all clinked bottles, and from there on out we were old friends. Who needs language when you have drinks?
Those old men could drink, let me tell you. After 5 or 6 beers the bartender came over and placed an unmarked bottle filled with a clear liquid onto the table. I knew moonshine when I saw it, and that was it. We took shots out of tiny paper cups like you find in the dentist‚Äôs office until none of us could see straight. One of the old guys fell on the way to the bathroom. Caroline and I picked him up, while Simon and the others cackled. Apparently, that happened to him often.
We sang and danced to Czech music and acted like fools for hours. My face hurt from smiling. Our bill came out to about $5 USD. Kevin was right, obviously. I left way more than that.
Caroline and I held hands on the way back. I could tell she wanted me to kiss her, but the time wasn‚Äôt right. Simon was still there, leeching like Dave used to. Every time we got close, he‚Äôd scoff.
Simon: Ahh, fuck off you two.
Me: (sarcastically) Thank you, Simon. I really appreciate you doing this.
Simon: Ooohhh, he‚Äôs pissed. Don‚Äôt throw your racket at me, Johhny Mac.
When we got back, Caroline and I still wanted to hang out, so we told Simon we were going to bed. Caroline, in her motherly way, insisted Simon do so too. After she tucked him in, her and I went down to the cave bar, where we drank water and talked. Water is truly the key to pulling off alcohol and drug addiction. 2 gallons a day at least, if you want to stay limber.
Caroline: So why are you here by yourself, in Europe?
Me: Running from my feelings? Trying to become my own man? I‚Äôm not totally sure anymore. Since my dad died last year, I just can‚Äôt stop speeding, that‚Äôs all I know.
Caroline: I understand.
Me: Do you?
Caroline: My younger brother died in a car crash last year.
Me: So, you‚Äôre doing the same thing?
Caroline: Yeah. I keep telling myself that running away from something means you‚Äôre running towards something else, but lately it hasn‚Äôt been working. So, I came here to forget myself altogether.
Me: How‚Äôs that working?
Caroline: It‚Äôs not really. Grief is just a cunt.
Me: Same and same.
Caroline: How about we run together and if that makes it any better?
Me: I‚Äôd like that. Where to next?
Caroline: I hear Bratislava is nice.
Me: Where is that?
Caroline: It‚Äôs the capital of Slovakia. Have you ever seen the movie ‚ÄúHostel‚Äù?
Me: No.
Caroline: Good. Don‚Äôt watch it between now and tomorrow.
--
--

Title: Street Photography Locations in Prague: The National Theatre and Its Surroundings
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

The home of enthusiastic supporters of Fine Art Photography. We respect its history, admire its present form, and look forward to its future.

--
2
Listen
Share
From time to time, I try to improve my Lightroom catalog‚Äôs structure to better organize my photos ‚Äî and while going through my Prague photos, I started noticing patterns in the places I shoot. Sometimes, I go to certain areas on purpose because I know they‚Äôre great for photos (or I just want to explore something unfamiliar). Other times, I‚Äôm just wandering around without a plan and somehow end up at these familiar places. I realized there are certain locations where I feel more comfortable shooting and where I consistently come home with photos I‚Äôm proud of.
Also, I‚Äôve recently received multiple questions on Glass about the best street photography spots in Prague. So, after having lived in Prague and walked its streets for almost two years now (often with a camera in my bag or in my hand), I thought it might be helpful to write about some of these recommended spots.
If you‚Äôre visiting Prague, or even if you live here and are looking for good places for street photography, these might be useful for you too.
Let‚Äôs start with one of my favorites, a place that always seems to offer something new: the area around the National Theatre (aka N√°rodn√≠ divadlo).
The National Theatre is an impressive building with its grand, neo-classical design right on the banks of the river Vltava. What makes this spot truly stand out, though, is the building behind it: the New Stage (Nov√° sc√©na), or as the locals call it, ‚ÄúThe Ice Cube‚Äù. The New Stage couldn‚Äôt be more different ‚Äî it‚Äôs modernist (brutalist, to be exact), boxy, and covered in textured glass panels that bounce the light, sometimes in unexpected ways. The contrast between these two buildings, side by side, makes for some great photos, especially if you like playing with old vs. new themes.
But to be a bit clich√© here, the buildings are just half of the story. The real magic happens in the life around them. The narrow tram stop in front, with its old red Tatra T3s, is always busy (but not chaotic) with people lined up in a single row, waiting, boarding, or rushing to catch their ride. The open space around the theatre adds a sense of scale, while the narrow passages create more intimate scenes, perfect for experimenting with different compositions, perspectives, and leading lines.
The best time for shooting here is probably a sunny afternoon when the light creates deep shadows and bounces off the glass of the New Stage. This can add depth and contrast to the photos and highlight the theatre‚Äôs detailed, brown facade with a warm feel. This effect can be harder to catch in winter when the sun doesn‚Äôt rise high enough to be above the buildings. But I‚Äôve also been here on dark, rainy days, and the scene was equally interesting.
I won‚Äôt lie ‚Äî sometimes I feel like I might end up with the same shot over and over if I keep going back. But more often than not (and it surprises me!), that isn‚Äôt the case. I‚Äôve tried to figure out what keeps me coming back, and my best answer so far is the mix of the expected and unexpected. One day, you‚Äôll find people going about their usual routines; the next, there might be a street performer, skaters, or a temporary exhibition in the middle of the ‚Äúinner square.‚Äù The stage stays the same, but the act changes. I know, this might sound like a clich√© again ‚Äî what else would you expect in the center of a capital city? ‚Äî but I‚Äôve found most other areas of Prague more predictable. This balance of routine and surprise, old and new, makes the surroundings of N√°rodn√≠ Divadlo an almost endless source of inspiration. At least for me, and at least for now.
Oh, and I‚Äôve found myself growing more fond of these brutalist buildings. And Prague certainly has a few of them. Maybe that‚Äôs part of the reason, who knows!
I think the area around the National Theatre is like a small version of what makes Prague so special from a street photography perspective. It‚Äôs got history, modern architecture, and plenty of street life. If you‚Äôre looking for a spot that will spark new ideas for street photography, this is a good place to start ‚Äî maybe even the best.
Thanks for reading to the end! If you enjoyed this or have any thoughts, I‚Äôd appreciate your üëè claps and comments ‚Äî especially if you‚Äôve already taken photos here or are planning to visit Prague with a camera.
Small note:During my preparation, I came across an article mentioning that the Ice Cube will undergo renovations starting next summer, which are expected to last for several years. So, you might want to hurry up and visit before it starts!

Title: The Two Thakurs
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

Reading the stories and travelogues by the likes of Biswanath Ghosh and Mark Tully.

--
Listen
Share
Which part of Himachal are you from?I am actually not from Himachal, but from Madhya Pradesh.But you‚Äôre a Thakur?Yes, MP as well has Thakurs.
This is how my first interaction with most people at Himachal Pradesh (the northern state that hosts my workplace IIT Mandi) begins, people with last name Thakur being omnipresent here. However, perhaps the most famous Thakur was from West Bengal (a state in the East of India), and interestingly, he is known more commonly as a Tagore in India. At Prague ‚Äî the city of hundred spires ‚Äî though, my stay was booked at Thakurova ‚Äî the Thakur street ‚Äî and so I knew I would be welcome at Czechia.
My trip to Boston (recall Tryst with America?) had made me acquaintance with Prof. Jan Vitek‚Äôs group at Northeastern University. I met him again during ECOOP 2019 (recall Romance at London?) ‚Äî we knew we were working in similar areas ‚Äî so he suggested I visit his laboratory at Czech Technical University, where I would hopefully be able to formalize a working relationship. And thus the seed to a trip to Prague ‚Äî one of my most memorable trips ever ‚Äî was sown.
In general I would have been worried about the cold weather at Prague in January. However, having settled after the London trip at Mandi, in one of the coldest states of India, I wasn‚Äôt much excited (read worried) about the weather. This, however, also translated to not being prepared for the trip at all. My first teaching semester at IIT Mandi ended in December, and it was only after that, that I started planning a trip ‚Äî my longest abroad till date ‚Äî to Prague in January. Two things I was more thoughtful about, though, were (i) The Visa; and (ii) The Trip to Delhi ‚Äî you will get to know a very suspenseful story about both in Rendezvous with Athena. TLDR: The Visa was smooth, I travelled to Delhi a day before this time, and hence obtained a comfortable flight hopping for an hour at Sharjah (the place I knew from childhood for Cricket matches).
Prague is known to be a beautiful city, and a very welcoming one for tourists. I was supposed to stay 12 nights at a hostel-cum-hotel (wrongly known as a dorm) named Masaryk Colej. The second word indicates its association with the college CVUT (Czech Technical University, in English). Travel from the airport was quite comfortable: you buy an hourly ticket for public travel in Prague and can then take any bus, tram, or metro ‚Äî very convenient for those who don‚Äôt understand the currency or the local addresses. So I took a bus and a tram (Pristi zastavka) and reached the hotel. First surprise: I was provided with a map to find my room! And indeed, the map was damn useful ‚Äî you need to pass through a cobweb of rooms (smelling the varieties of food college guys keep cooking in there) to finally reach the corridor that forms the ‚Äúhotel‚Äù part of the huge building. I needed the map on quite a few occasions (specially when I decided to wander around the building trying to get a glimpse of the food).
I used to walk daily to the university, take the lift to the 13th floor (tried the stairs one day!), and come back in the evening. Pretty standard. So what I would do next, is to mainly discuss the interesting trips ‚Äî solo as well as group ‚Äî along with the classical places I visited, the people I met, and the heart-warming experiences that I got in the extremely cold weather (subzero on almost all days). Not to forget the funny stories surrounding the food!
This was the first time I was visiting a place that‚Äôs famous for its exotic food ‚Äî but almost all non-veg. The first day I located a Pizza outlet with vegetarian options, about 1.5 miles from my hotel. I had taken my warmest clothes, but God it was really difficult following Google Map as you need to take your gloves off (I got enlightened about touchscreen-enabled gloves much later). Being in Europe I knew I didn‚Äôt have to worry much about tips and the phrases for taking home versus dining-in as in the US (Europe and India have pretty much similar terminologies, owing to history). Breakfasts were taken care of by the hotel (with two kinds of cupcakes, orange juice, toast, and cheese forming the 365-day menu). Lunches (and some dinner outings on weekdays): I knew I would have enough expertise from the lab in sailing through the university canteen. However, things became adventurous when I decided to try the hotel restaurant for a dinner:
Me: ‚ÄúWhich all options in the menu are vegetarian?‚ÄùShe: [After the previous sentence being looped over 20 times]: ‚ÄúYes, please sit; we will bring you vegetarian.‚Äù
On table I get something that looks very muttonish. After making some noise the chef came out of the kitchen; he understood some English and told I could get a replacement without paying again.
Me: ‚ÄúWhich dish will you get for me?‚ÄùHe: ‚ÄúVegetarian.‚Äù
Finally I got some cauliflower (in its purest vegetarian, read raw, form) and some fried (read oil-soaked) potatoes. I ate about 30% from my plate, then boiled MTR Poha (puffed rice) carried from home in the hot water obtained from the geyser-that-actually-worked-only-in-the-morning, and knew this was the end of trying out my luck at the hotel (apart from breakfast). On the remaining days I mostly sticked to the long menu of a Chinese restaurant next door (147 dishes, 3 vegetarian), an occasional Pizza from the chilly-walk place, and my MTR Pohas cooked with the morning-only geyser.
However, one night we had a fine dinner at an Indian restaurant (where I again found that Indians have a much stronger digestive system, think spices); I tried some tasty soups with two new friends on a beautiful evening; and on the last day finally tried the national dish (which happens to be vegetarian) ‚Äî Fried cheese:
As indicated before, Prague is perhaps the city with the most convenient public transport: You can just install an app and charge it with your card for a day (not expensive at all), get a barcode that is your ticket, and travel as you want in any tram, bus, metro, or train. Moreover, the city is very-well covered ‚Äî you perhaps don‚Äôt need to walk more than a few hundred meters anywhere ‚Äî you will have nicely maintained, well-timed, clean-and-safe public transport available at the blink of an eye. I had listed down a large number of places to visit, and divided them into two days: Day 1 and Day 2, for the Saturday and the Sunday.
If you followed me in America, you know that the first thing on my list in a city that has a zoo, has to be a zoo. So Saturday began with visiting one of the best places hosting animals in the world: The Prague Zoo. Unlike the Zoo at Washington DC, at Prague you are welcomed with the star cast quite near to the entrance:
I spent nearly 3 hours at the zoo, walking about 8 kilometers inside, and ended with a team of as-tall-as-can-get Giraffes, and as-cute-as-can-get Penguins:
The next stop was The Old Town across Charles bridge (challenge: find the river in the lab-view above). Old Town has several attractions from the times Czechia was part of the Soviet Union, with several churches and castles at every turn. While the Prague Castle reminds one of Hogwarts, the Astronomical Clock attracts a huge crowd every hour for witnessing one of the many scientific marvels associated with the same (read more on Wikipedia):
Charles Bridge is a heritage on its own, with so many activities and picture-spots around that you can spend hours walking across and yet find something every time you cross! A beautiful view of the colorful city follows:
I finished traversing the Old Town by filling my bag at a shop full of candies (and forgetting the bag mid-way during my return journey)!
Having explored the crowded places the previous day, I decided to spend a solo Sunday climbing hills and exploring castles ‚Äî both being rare opportunities in a vibrant city. The day was cold and hazy, but I walked and walked like crazy.
Vysehrad is an old castle in a bit far-off location, and should be traveled in broad day-light, is what I was told. Though the far-off part was true, I found the place full of people craving for silent time amidst the hustle and bustle of the cheerful city. You could sit there for hours with a book in hand, appreciating the rare greenery in the coldest of months.
The last I went was The Petrin Hill ‚Äî reminiscent of the hikes I do around Mandi. I went up via a crowded rope-way and came down exploring solitary paths watching the city of hundred spires; as you descend, you realize every climb has its end, but the walk downhill doesn‚Äôt necessarily take you down.
If you ever visit Prague, do roam around the colorful streets, but take a moment walking up/down the Petrin Hill, sitting on that bench I couldn‚Äôt, and wondering ‚Äúwhat to eat next‚Äù :-)
I returned back via Warsaw; the trip was prepended with a day‚Äôs stay with an about-to-be-engaged friend at New Delhi, and appended with a trip to Kolkata ‚Äî a city where you drive ahead with both the legs on breaks (for preserving its classical past) ‚Äî to attend the engagement of the same (more about my old-and-gold friends some time later!).
The series had promised an article every few weeks: it started swiftly, but has been going on rather slow. For me, the year 2020 has been full of remembering (read missing) the travels from 2019, and avid readers are in for many more write-ups. For now, an assurance is to have a few more articles than those promised in the intro A Traveling Year, one of them being exclusively on the rather long airport stays and flight journeys (of course with feedback on the food) I have had in the travel-rich year! So keep reading, and stay on‚Ä¶
