November 22, or something like that.
Lovely cafe in which I do not know the name,next to another European clock towerand a bell that strikes upon the hourtick tick ticking away the seconds that make upEvy and I drinking lattes and eating cakes in a foreign place.
Wandering along the slippery cobblestone path, an indulgence, a tiresome dancebetween coffee and beer and long mornings sleeping withthe cold aircoming in through the window.
This place has decorative tiles, imperfect concrete walls supporting high ceilingsabstract paintings for the contemplation of the consumerthe ponderings of an American who can‚Äôt sit still obsessing over the future,reading Eckhart Tolle to cease the dwell.
Is it possible, to be all that I wish to beto live out the stories I tellin my mind, the visions of a lifeexisting in a raindrop of time.
Tis a compulsion to live almost exclusivelythrough memory and anticipation.

Title: Two perfect days in April: my book launches in Prague and the Netherlands
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
When the audience gets involved: events, interviews, videos, and book talk
In this article, I will cover two perfect days in April. 12 April: Book launch in Diemen, the Netherlands. 26 April: book launch in Prague.
It was the perfect day for my book launch; the cherry blossoms bloomed. Spring was palpable. The book signing took place at the local bookstore. We arranged coffee, cakes with the book cover on them, balloons, my lucky pencil, and of course, the books.
The local newspaper announced the signing. Read it here (it‚Äôs in Dutch). The article is about the book and my reason for writing it, my choice of leaving Amsterdam to move to Prague, traveling, writing in English, and daydreaming.
‚ÄúI knew early on that I didn‚Äôt want to stay in the place I grew up and knew well.I wanted to gain new impressions and reinvent myself.‚Äù ‚Äî Eline Vedder
Friends and family were there, and people I had not seen for eight years. They had read it in the newspaper. They bought the novel with them or brought it from the bookstore. I signed their copies and added a personal note. Something I knew they would like in the book, something that would resonate with them.
Strangers visited the store, too. Some passed the store and were curious. I told them about Nora‚Äôs story (the main character in Sitting Next to a Stranger) and my love for writing. We talked about books, traveling, self-publishing, creating art, and following your dreams.
Check the reel below:
Text continues
A post shared by @eline.vedder
How books surprise usWhen I started writing the book, I thought it was about meeting strangers and summarizing the lessons we learn from each other. The book surprised me when I wrote it. It turned out to be about strangers, but more so, about finding a connection, friendship, and love. About art, traveling, and stepping away from your protective upbringing. About getting into the beautiful world. About daring to leave. Your place, your relationship, your old self. It‚Äôs about removing the labels you put on yourself. The characters in the book taught me everything I needed to know about these topics.
I still have to get used to the idea that my book stands on people‚Äôs shelves. People will enter the world I wrote down and go on a journey with my characters. I‚Äôm curious to hear what the readers will pick up from the book. Which topics and lessons will stand out for them? What will they find in the story?
‚ÄúLike Nora, I used to go to the Museum Square and look at the Van Gogh Museum. I drew some of my first paintings there.‚Äù
‚ÄúMy son lives and works in Guatemala. I will give him Sitting Next to a Stranger once I finish.‚Äù
‚ÄúI am an anthropologist and have traveled through Mexico. Can‚Äôt wait to see how you fictionalized this country.‚Äù
Saturday 26th April. 16.00/4 pm. Prague ‚Äî I enter a calm garden in the city center. The sky is blue, and the weather is perfect after four days of rain. I place three journals on display. They are the original manuscript of my just-published novel, Sitting Next to a Stranger. I am setting up a small exhibition while I wait for my nerves to calm down and for the guests to arrive.
16.59/4.59 pm ‚Äî My friends Gabriele, Andrew, Miko, and Cortney transformed the garden into a magical place. They hang all the balloons and posters and put everything in the perfect spot. They tell me that it‚Äôs going to be fine.
‚ÄúIt will all go smoothly, you can enjoy your achievement,‚Äù they all say in their own words.
‚ÄúOK, I think you‚Äôre right,‚Äù I reply. My voice is quivering, and my eyes scan the garden. I realize how perfect it is, how grateful I am that we can make this day happen. How important it is to celebrate creative endeavors. The sun warms my face, and I start to believe it: I can do this, I‚Äôm the author. I know my novel, and I can answer every question. I trust my art and myself.
I run to the tables on the terrace. The people don‚Äôt know anything about this event. ‚ÄúHey,‚Äù I say. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm celebrating my book. We don‚Äôt know each other, but you are invited.‚Äù They wish me good luck and adjust their seats so they can see what we are about to start. We are about to start the most magical three hours. This event is all I dreamed of. I‚Äôm still flabbergasted that I pulled this off, but I have envisioned this for the last three years. Is this manifesting?
Text continues
‚ÄúI met you three years ago, when you told me you wanted to write a book. I‚Äôm so happy I can be part of this celebration.‚Äù
‚ÄúI love the cover, the title is catchy.‚Äù
‚ÄúI don‚Äôt read a lot, but my girlfriend does. She will love this book.‚Äù
‚ÄúI‚Äôm lost in life, I need to figure out what I want.‚Äù
I reply: ‚ÄúThis is the perfect moment for you to read this book. It won‚Äôt answer your question of where to go in your life, but it will make you gentle with yourself.‚Äù
‚ÄúI have been to Mexico too, I can‚Äôt wait to ‚Äòtravel‚Äô back to it.‚Äù
‚ÄúI need something lighthearted.‚Äù
‚ÄúI heard your interview, I want to read Nora‚Äôs story.‚Äù
You can find the full 36-minute Q&A on YouTube. Read the questions and my answers in my other Substack post.
My biggest takeaways from these events:
Writing is, first and foremost, something I do for myself. I want to spend my days thinking about scenes, characters, and books. I wrote this book because I had to; I wrote it for my 21-year-old self. The best mindspace was when I wasn‚Äôt even sure if I‚Äôd publish it.
Now, the audience is involved, and my book is out in the world. It‚Äôs there for you. Be surprised and have fun on this trip in Mexico and within yourself.
I‚Äôm always down for a book chat!
Thank you to everyone who showed up üíô‚ú®
üìöSitting Next to a Stranger is out now! Here on Amazon.
With Love,
Eline Vedder
www.elinevedderauthor.com

Title: 3 Days in Prague: The Best Way to Experience the City During a Short Visit.
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Moo Downtown, https://www.mooo-apartments.com/downtown/en/
Getting from the airport to the city centre is very simple; there is a bus (number 119) outside the terminal that takes you to the nearest Metro station (N√°dra≈æ√≠ Veleslav√≠n) from which you can ride the line six stops to the centre of the city. This can all be done on the same travel ticket which can be purchased at the bus stop using your bank card or Apple/Android Pay for a few pounds.
The city has a fantastic transport system comprising of retro and modern trams which always seem to be around when you need them; a cool and efficient Metro system fitted out with a Soviet-era feel; buses; and even a funicular railway line.
A single ticket can be used on all modes of transport, for the amount of time purchased.
Card or coins are accepted. Simply stamp your ticket when first entering the system.
The city also has a rising number of e-scooters and e-bikes which can be hired using the various apps on your phone.
The best way to get a bearing of the city is to start in its centre.
The Old Town Square is filled with grand architectural masterpieces, host to fancy restaurants, and free museums. The famous Astronomical Clock is located in the square and is the oldest clock in the world still in operation. The square is also host to two large and lofty churches ‚Äî the Church of Our Lady before T√Ωn, and St. Nicholas‚Äô Church. Be sure to look up and admire the ceiling frescos, and ask staff for the times of the next free choir performances!
A short walk from the Old Town Square is Wenceslas Square, a half-mile long, 14th-century street crowned with the Czech Republic‚Äôs National Museum, shops and hotels. The Metro line runs underneath the street enabling quick access to either end and transport beyond. The National Museum currently includes exhibitions on the city‚Äôs role in defying Nazi rule during WW2, a fabulous light show that adapts according to classical music, and an elaborate collection of natural history from angler-fish to grizzly bears. The building itself is a fantastic classical-style structure with a spectacular fountain and a commanding view of the street. Entry is not free but is under ¬£10.
North of the city centre is the Jewish Quarter comprised of six different locations to explore and learn about including an amazing 15th-century cemetery, multiple synagogues and museum displays narrating the Jewish story of Prague. Entry is not free, but under ¬£15 for full access.
Lunch: Bistro Monk, a laid-back eatery with an outdoor terrace, serving all-day breakfasts, pancakes & burgers.
Dinner: San Carlo Dittrichova, a small but characterful Italian restaurant with underground and outdoor seating (and very good pricing!)
Perhaps Prague‚Äôs most famous tourist spot is the 14th-century Charles Bridge which stretches over the Vltava river that runs through the city.
Crossing the bridge from the city centre will take you towards Prague Castle and its accompanying St. Vitus Cathedral which dominates the skyline. While you can walk to the castle, it is easier to get the tram since you have to walk up a long flight of steps to get to the top of the hill on which the castle resides. Entry is not free but low-priced, and this gives you access to the whole Cathedral and multiple rooms of the castle, as well as a fantastic old street made up of tightly packed houses which are host to shops, an armour museum, torture chambers and medieval rooms. There are multiple cafes to eat at around the castle complex, uniformed soldiers manning outposts for a great photo opportunity, and stunning city views from the beautiful green gardens.
For an exciting late afternoon, try renting a peddle or rowing boat from one of the small islands on the Vltava river. The island housing the ≈Ωof√≠n Palace is a popular spot to sit by the river in the evening or hire a boat. A map of the boating area is provided and a lifeboat watches over. The normal renting period is an hour and is not expensive with boats of varying sizes available. The experience is particularly mesmerising at sunset with the sky turning a deep blue as the buildings begin to be lit up by their mesmerising golden lights. Look out for the otters swimming around!
Dinner: Bistro ≈†pejle, a modern buffet-style restaurant that provides numerous small tapas-like dishes and lovely desserts. There is a very wide selection of drinks and the pricing system is based on the number of cocktail sticks on each dish.
The role played by Prague during WW2 is perhaps best remembered through Operation Anthropoid (1942). Start your day by visiting St Cyril and Methodius church crypt in which the brave men who fought against Nazi rule hid inside before facing a fateful stand-off in the crypt with Nazi soldiers. There is a new but small museum that documents the story of the brave men involved and Prague‚Äôs WW2 history. Access is free, but given the nature of the topic, it is a moving location to visit.
From the church, you can head directly across the river via the tram or on foot to the Funicular Railway near the √öjezd tram stop. Using the line is cheap and a ticket can be purchased which gives you 24hr access. The ride is short but exciting with a stop 3/4 of the way up and then at the very top. Once at the top, there are multiple cafes and places to visit including an observatory and gardens. The Petrin Lookout Tower is a must-visit for the best 360-degree view of the city. It is 63.5 metres tall and was built in 1891, resembling a miniature Eiffel Tower. Scale the tower for a small price via the spiral staircase. There is a cafe and restaurant at the base of the tower. Once done, return down the hill using the Funicular Railway.
A new addition to Prague is the temporary exhibition of Russian military vehicles destroyed by the Ukrainian army in 2022. Take the tram from the funicular railway to the North of Letna Park to visit the vehicles bringing the message of Ukraine‚Äôs defiance to the rest of Europe. From there you can walk through the large green park to the famous 75 ft functioning Prague Metronome which sits overlooking the river. It was erected in 1991 on the plinth left vacant by the 1963 demolition of an enormous monument to the former Soviet leader Joseph Stalin.
Dinner: Wine O‚ÄôClock Shop Prague, a fantastic dining experience where the food is cooked in front of you. The restaurant is small, so book in advance!
If you have time:
Museum of Communism
Franz Kafka ‚Äî Rotating Head
Prague Zoo
Prague Ghosts and Legends of Old Town Walking Tour

What‚Äôs the first thing after landing? It‚Äôs definitely searching how to go to the city.
From London and Stansted Airport, the airport express ticket is about 20 GBP (24 EUR). Then guess how much the airport express bus ticket in Prague costs? It is 100 CZK (4 EUR). It is ONLY one-sixth! My price made my trip have a good beginning.
The public transportation system in Prague is well designed. The tickets are on time bases (eg. 30 mins, 45 mins). With the ticket, you can access all public transport (except airport express), including trams, buses, and the metro. The ticket vending machine can be found at the metro station.
Besides the tourist spots, you also can find the historical atmosphere in the entire city. Every corner of the city shows its special stories. From the bridge, castles, to the stores, none of them let me down.
The beauty of the city shines especially during sunset. The sunshine covers the roofs and makes the city even more orange. My friend and I enjoyed the sunset view at the castle, which is on the hill. There is no word able to describe how stunning it was.
Prague is a special capital. The city is full of stories. For example, it is where the Defenestration of Prague happened, which leads to the Thirty Years‚Äô War. Now you can see how important a role Prague plays in history. If you are interested in European history, Prague definitely drives you crazy.
Same as in many touristy areas, the prices in the center of Prague are also ‚Äútouristy.‚Äù My friend and I, luckily, found a local caf√© with a cozy environment and affordable price. It is called Sladk√° Cesta Caff√©.
There are various cakes and pies. The price is about 80‚Äì100 CZK. According to my friend, who studies in Germany, some desserts are also common in Germany.
Chill time! Sitting in the caf√©, enjoying the desserts, and watching the passengers on the streets.
K√ºrt≈ëskal√°cs (Trdeln√≠k) ÁÖôÂõ™Âç∑
There are tremendous trdeln√≠k stores on the street. The price is about 70 CZK without ice cream and 130 CZK with ice cream.
The root of this word, trdlo, is the name of the wooden tool the cake ingredients are wrapped around during cooking.
In my opinion, ice cream is not necessary. Ice cream covers the flavor of the bread and makes the pastry too sweet. The crispy hot bread with spread is just right!
Prague Ham
Near the Old Town Square, some food stands sell Prague ham.
It is tasty and juicy, but it is not affordable. The price is based on the weight of the ham. I would suggest you have someone and share it together if you want to give it a try.
Different from other tourists, we are really looking forward to something natural and special.
We used to plan to visit Bohemian, which takes 2 hours by train from Prague, but it would make the schedule too tense. After discussion, we decided to go to a natural park called Diok√° ≈†√°rka in the countryside.
It is at the final station of tram no. 26. The entrance of the park is right next to the station. The park is easily accessible from the city. It takes about 30 mins by tram from the city center.
Unfortunately, it was not warm enough when we visited the park. There were rarely leaves. When the spring comes, the entire park is going to be amazing and really good for picnics.
There are several routes. You can walk by the river or go hiking. Trees, rivers, birds, and hills. The views can definitely purify your mind and help you stay away from annoying things.
Look at the picture below. Can you imagine how beautiful the park is going to be? Don‚Äôt miss the park when you visit Prague.
The international stamps (Z stamps) sold in Prague are the most beautiful I have ever seen!
The price for each international stamp is 45 CZK. Compared with other European countries, the price is relatively affordable.
BTW, the post office in Prague is also beautiful and spacious. If you want to send the postcards, find ƒåesk√° Po≈°ta near the train station.

Title: Writing and Programming from California to Prague
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

Stories from Pipedrive‚Äôs product, engineering, design, marketing, localization, and many other teams

--
Listen
Share
About three months ago, I decided to put my doctoral thesis in English on hold, sell most of my things and move from California to Prague to start my first job as a Junior Full Stack Developer at Pipedrive. This is a story about my journey and how I got to Pipedrive, Prague.
Since 2013 I have been pursuing a Ph.D. in English at the University of California Riverside, outside Los Angeles. In addition to teaching undergraduate film and literature classes, I spent several years working on a thesis project. My dissertation analyses the experimental art practices of a small group of twentieth-century American artists and writers.
In the summer of 2020, I committed myself to making a career change out of higher education. Without a specific job in mind, I knew that I needed work that would be intellectually challenging if I were to remain interested and motivated in the long run. I was also attracted to the flexibility that a career in tech could provide: finding software domains that match my interests, organizing my own schedule and remote job options. Beyond building an embarrassingly personal website in high school, I had no previous experience in IT. My initial plan was to take online courses and slowly develop my technical knowledge, but when I heard about a coding Bootcamp at my university, I decided to enroll.
My background in art criticism and education may not immediately make sense as a foundation for a career in software development. As I have learned more about programming, I came to find that humanities scholarship and web development actually have a lot in common. Both combine the creative with the logical. They are challenging endeavors that benefit from ongoing learning and continual revision. Over time, my awareness of the many intersections grew, along with my enthusiasm. Although I initially thought that my previous, non-technical experience would be irrelevant to development, I now realize that my background has provided me with a lot of important and valuable skills ‚Äî communication, critical thinking and research, to name a few ‚Äî that have helped me to get to where I am today.
Ultimately, while my work as a teacher and a researcher was very rewarding, I came to feel that the direct practicality and collaboration that is so fundamental to software development were missing from my daily work. In response to this feeling, in June 2020, I set a goal to devote 30‚Äì60 minutes a day towards learning web development. After doing some light internet browsing, I thought that computer science fundamentals would provide a strong foundation for learning programming, so I decided to start with a CS101 course on Udemy. In a way, the shift to fully remote university instruction gave me more freedom to balance my work with my new objective. When I heard about The Coding Bootcamp at my university, I felt that the structure of a curriculum and the community of students that the Bootcamp offered would be a good environment for me.
Because the class was entirely online, I learned to remotely collaborate on projects with teammates from the very beginning. The class was a six-month, part-time, full-stack web development class focusing on the fundamentals of HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Node and React. In addition to the essential languages of the web, we also learned some basics about databases and using git. The class met online three days a week for about three hours. Although it was roughly 10 hours of class time, we were expected to put in close to 15‚Äì20 weekly hours of work outside class meetings to practice our skills and solidify the concepts we covered.
During the week, we met twice in the evenings and we also had one class on Saturday mornings. The schedule was designed to accommodate people who were attending class while working full time. Because of my flexible work schedule, I was able to thrive with this schedule, but it was very demanding for many of my classmates with stricter work responsibilities. Every week, we had homework assignments related to our weekly topics, which we submitted by posting Github links. The teacher and teaching assistant encouraged us to keep our Github accounts active to establish professional visibility.
Every two months, we had to deliver a major group project. Of course, the opportunity to work on a larger project was rewarding in and of itself, but it was also a great chance to function within a self-organized team. For a final project, I worked with a team of three others to develop an inventory tracking application using React and MongoDB. One of our team members gathered specific information from her clients who worked in logistics about a major problem they faced: quick and easy access to inventory item locations in the warehouse. With this real-world use case, we each spent several hours a day over three weeks developing our application, ‚ÄúInHouse.‚Äù In addition to the supportive community, I think that this experience in building a full-stack web application with a team using the git version control system was one of the most valuable aspects of my Bootcamp experience.
Immediately after completing the Bootcamp, I was determined to maintain my momentum, so I began applying to jobs and talking to as many people in the industry as I possibly could. Setting up 30-minute chats on zoom ‚Äî what people sometimes call ‚Äúinformational interviewing‚Äù‚Äì was a great way to gather information about working in tech. I was able to ask people about their background, how they got into the field and what their workday is like in their current role. It was also a good chance to practice presenting myself and my interests in a low-stakes and supportive context.
At the same time, I continued to work on personal projects and jumped headfirst into LeetCode algorithm problems, something that was not a part of the core curriculum of the Bootcamp. I also continued to improve my personal website and started several projects to expand my portfolio. Probably one of the most difficult but important tasks for my website was making it mobile responsive!
I designed a landing page for a friend‚Äôs small business, which was a good chance to practice client requirements gathering, wireframing and Figma prototyping. I took part in an international hackathon called Hacktrix. Communicating with my partner and transcending a 12-hour time difference, together we built a simple news aggregator. The hackathon was another great collaboration experience and it gave me more practice in quickly developing an app that uses a third-party API service.
I also began helping a graduate student friend improve the structure of their excavation research database for their dissertation project in archaeology. That project was an opportunity to gather information about a particular problem while also learning how to effectively create an Entity Relationship Diagram using LucidChart. This technology helped me to visually plan out the structure of the database and the relationships between different tables.
Although I rarely completed (and certainly never sold) these projects, each of them helped me to learn new things while I continued to practice web development. They also enabled me to learn which aspects of development I enjoy more and where my (numerous, countless!) gaps in knowledge reside.
During my ongoing learning after graduating from the bootcamp, I became interested in Open Source communities. I started slowly by learning how to fork a repository and did some basic markdown housekeeping for a student-run resource called awesome4girls, which offers a curated list of events and projects in tech geared specifically for girls and women. My dive into the open-source community also brought me to AnitaB.org, a nonprofit organization working to improve inclusivity in tech. They have a number of student-friendly projects on Github and actively cultivate mentorship and contributions from new developers. Through this organization, I got my first experience setting up a more complicated local development environment on my computer.
I learned about Pipedrive during the research phase for one of my Bootcamp group projects. While trying to develop a project idea, I conducted some interviews with real estate professionals to gather information about their current software and look for potential opportunities to solve a problem. Armed with a relevant user story, I pitched a CRM project to track potential tenant leads and as a team we developed a modest, full-stack implementation. The research that I did for that project led me to Pipedrive as one of the top models for our small application.
When I first came across the job post for a Junior Developer position at Pipedrive, I was immediately struck by how entry-level-friendly the post was. It was clear that they really wanted a Junior Developer and that my inexperience was not some shortcoming that I had to justify or minimize. It was also clear that my professional development would be actively supported and that Pipedrive would be an ideal place to grow. There was no shortage of online information for me to access to familiarize myself with the company culture. I read several articles from this blog: one about our group product manager and another one on the onboarding process written by two junior engineers. I gained a lot of insight into the current topics, culture and people involved in the company from these publicly-accessible posts.
In the end, Pipedrive made it easy for me to make the big decision to accept the offer and move to Prague. I was honestly not expecting to pull off a complete career change one year after I started the Bootcamp. The accountability and community structures that the Bootcamp provided were definitely key factors of my success. While I was looking for my first software developer job, I noticed that a lot of online forums highlight (and bemoan) the low response rate in job applications. This is certainly a frustrating and complicated problem.
Still, in my case, I tried to not think about what I couldn‚Äôt control and focused on finding a balance between consistency, feedback processing and a strategic search. I found a company working on a product in an area that interested me and reached out to a Pipedrive recruiter directly on LinkedIn. But it was also important for me to maintain a healthy mindset, so I made sure to pace myself, exercise and spend time with friends. Resting and walking my dog Poppy were essential parts of the search!
I‚Äôm glad that my circuitous career route has led me here to Prague, and I hope that this story might offer some perspective for other potential Pipedrivers.
Here at Pipedrive‚Äôs Prague office, our Group Product Manager Michal Smetana has been organizing monthly meetups. During the fall this year we hosted an event on GraphQL at Scale with guest speakers and a live stream of the event. We have also had a meetup on Advanced Microservices. Check out our Pipedrive Talks Prague meetup group to see a list of all upcoming events and recordings from previous events. If you can‚Äôt make it in person you can join remotely!
We‚Äôre currently hiring for several different positions in several different countries/cities.

Title: It was hard to leave Prague
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
Member-only story
--
Share
I can mean this in the most basic way possible, of course. Stepping off the plane, I was an eighteen year old baby. Now, I‚Äôm twenty-one (and still a baby). I‚Äôve finished uni, gotten into a relationship, and made lifelong friends from people around the world. I‚Äôve lived in two different flats in Prague, with vastly different situations. My style has changed more times than I can count on my two hands.
But, as I was telling my mom, it feels like I‚Äôm leaving a friend. I never experienced Prague like the big packs of British guys coming for a stag do or the backpacking groups that are here for a long weekend before they bounce off somewhere else.
I don‚Äôt relate to the videos fawning over Duplex or the five story club of Karlovy Lazne. The Charles Bridge and Old Town Square became a route I would only walk through out of pure necessity, a scene I should‚Äôve never taken for granted.
The Prague that I know is the sun setting over ≈Ωi≈ækov on the rooftop of my friends‚Äô apartment, sharing a bottle of white wine, a pack of cigarettes, and some hummus from Albert.

Share
Jozef is a Slovakian living in Prague. Although he joined our team only half a year ago, it almost feels like he‚Äôs been here forever. He always has a plan, knows his way around all things design, and is the best man for any type of ideation. Jozef also hates discovering new places alone and apparently loves vodka.
What do you do?
I‚Äôm a product designer.
And I mean, what do you really do all day?
My days really differ according to which phase of a product we are working on. So, it can range from sketching user flows/stories, testing ideas, prototyping, working on visuals or preparing exports for dev guys ‚Äî very colorful.
What keeps you motivated?
People I am working with ‚Äòcause they‚Äôre really good at what they do, so I can learn from them and get inspired. And also our users. It‚Äôs really motivating and challenging to design something people like using.
What‚Äôs your song of the day?
I don‚Äôt have one. Recently, I started to love my spotify discover or some indie mixes.
What‚Äôs been the most recent life lesson?
I read few articles that the tech industry is about to change massively in the next decade. For me it means we should never stop exploring the unknown. For example, I seriously started to learn how to code but it‚Äôs going really slowly.
What are your all-time favourites? Any underrated or classic TV-shows, books, music you would like to share?
I really love the email digest and newsletters I receive. Just to mention few I rely on ‚Äî Sidebar, Medium digest, UX daily and so on. I also watch series on Netflix and cooking videos on Youtube. And last but not least I recently bought some books about typography and a few posters.
Describe the scariest moment of your life.
The scariest one was definitely when I had a car accident with my friends. It happened so quickly. The car was totally crushed but luckily nobody was seriously injured. Before the crash I loved speed and extreme sports. Since then I am totally the opposite. This kind of thing changes you forever.
What are the five things you‚Äôd take to a desert island?
A bottle, swiss knife, matches, vodka and some book about how to survive on a desert island.
What do you wish you had known 5 years ago?
That being yourself is just what matters the most.
One thing you really like about your job and another you don‚Äôt like that much?
I really like that I can be independent and at the same time responsible. It kind of makes me feel I‚Äôm working on my own thing which is very important to me. On the other hand, I don‚Äôt like being without the team from time to time. But we meet up in almost every 3 months, so it‚Äôs not that bad.
What‚Äôs your one big dream or life goal?
Being totally independent in terms of everything like money and schedule. Just waking up and doing what I want.
What are your most recent discoveries? Any tv-shows podcasts, blogs, books we should keep our eyes on?
Treehouse ‚Äî really cool site regarding how to learn code.
What are you really grateful of today?
That I woke up today.
The blog posts are a part of our ongoing campaign demonstrating the merits of gratitude. Join the campaign and check out other entries! üíö

Title: My Experience at EFSY Prague ‚Äì A Hidden Gem Worth Celebrating
Content:
Sign up

Sign up
Sign in

Tucked away in one of Prague‚Äôs quieter corners, EFSY feels like the kind of place you stumble upon once and never forget. I had been seeing it pop up on Instagram for a while ‚Äì always these dreamy shots of perfectly poached eggs, colorful lattes, and that minimal-but-cozy interior ‚Äì so I finally decided to check it out for myself. And honestly? I‚Äôm so glad I did.
When I walked in, the first thing I noticed was how peaceful the atmosphere felt. It‚Äôs bright, thoughtfully designed, and somehow manages to strike the perfect balance between modern and warm. You instantly get the sense that every detail ‚Äì from the playlist to the ceramic plates ‚Äì has been chosen with care.
On this visit, I ordered the Turkish eggs and the green salad with raspberries, and both dishes were genuinely memorable. The Turkish eggs were silky and flavorful, served with creamy yogurt, spicy chilli oil, and perfectly boiled eggs that just melted into everything. It was comforting, rich, and yet still light ‚Äì I loved every bite. As for the green salad, it totally surprised me. The raspberries added such a unique sweetness, and paired with the greens and light honey dressing AND PECANS, it felt super fresh and summery. It was one of those combinations that makes you think, ‚ÄúWhy haven‚Äôt I tried this before?‚Äù
What made the visit even more special was learning that EFSY is celebrating its very first birthday. It‚Äôs wild to think that this cozy little caf√© ‚Äì which already feels so established and beloved ‚Äì has only been open for a year. The owners launched EFSY with a clear vision: to create a space that goes beyond good coffee and food, and actually feels like a little escape. Over the past 12 months, it‚Äôs grown into a real community spot, where you can tell the regulars are part of the caf√©‚Äôs story too. I really respect how they‚Äôve stayed true to their values ‚Äì simplicity, quality, and creativity ‚Äì while still experimenting with their menu and aesthetic.
Even during their birthday, when the place was buzzing with energy and filled with more guests than usual, the service stayed warm and attentive. The staff made me feel welcome without ever being too much ‚Äì they seemed genuinely happy to share the space with everyone. That kind of hospitality makes a big difference, especially in a city where cafes can sometimes feel a bit rushed or transactional.
If you‚Äôre into food that feels both comforting and inspired, beautiful interiors, and supporting small local businesses with heart, EFSY is 100% worth a visit. Whether you‚Äôre going for brunch with friends, working solo with a matcha in hand, or just treating yourself to something nice ‚Äì you‚Äôll walk out feeling better than when you walked in. I know I did.
Happy birthday, EFSY ‚Äì here‚Äôs to many more!ü§ç

Title: 6 Inspiring Design Talks & Other Memories from a Web Conference in Prague
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

Notes and Stories about UI Design, UX Design and Other Related Topics.

--
Listen
Share
by Brett Mazoch, published in A Designer‚Äôs Thoughts
Business, creativeness and development met together under the same roof again in the historical Prague in Czech Republic. Enthusiastic speakers from Google, Microsoft, Slack and others shared their inspirational thoughts and ideas. Local startups and established tech companies showcased their work. Businessmen, designers and developers networked in a friendly and supportive atmosphere‚Ä¶ And three months ago I was lucky to experience all of this during the WebExpo conference (23‚Äì24th Sep 2016).
Since I still have in my mind great talks about designing systems in difficult places, Google‚Äôs agile design process or about meaningful animations in user interfaces, I would like to share my memories and thoughts from this great conference before the New Year arrives.
For those who haven‚Äôt heard about the conference yet: WebExpo started as a small meet up of people interested in the digital world and throughout the years it has turned into the largest tech conference in Central Europe. The sign of the quality are excited speakers from industry leading companies like the mentioned Google, Microsoft, Slack or several other as IBM, Adobe, MSD/Merck or InVision. On top of that, the conference takes place in a location which anyone can easily fall in love with because of its charming old architecture and delicious Czech beer ‚Äî the city of Prague.
I attended 12 talks and since in our software company ‚Äî Bluewire Technologies in Bristol (England) ‚Äî I am working as a UI Designer, my schedule was full of talks on design related topics. I‚Äôve realised that the talks I enjoyed the most were those in which the speakers shared their own personal experience and some good & bad real examples supported by their own testing or research.
The following 6 talks definitely met my internal criteria for the great performance. And, in addition to that, their content resonates with my current focus and interests. I enjoyed the ones mentioned below the most and I think you might do so as well, here we go:
Mark Boulton, Design Director at Monotype
MY TAKEAWAY‚Ä¶
When designing a system, start learning about your users, about who the users actually are. Creating simple design models based on the users study will help you in specific cases and situations with the answer to the question ‚ÄòHow should the solution look like?‚Äô. Also provide a framework to support creativity in others by giving them well-designed parameters to work within rather then trying to be a design police. And finally understand (and eventually modify) the workflow to establish a mandate for the system.
Mark has also published a FREE e-book, really worth reading, called Designing for the Web in which he describes his design process and basics about typography, colours and layout.
WATCH THE TALK‚Ä¶
Dana Cohen, Strategic UX Designer at Google Campus
MY TAKEAWAY‚Ä¶
A team of multidisciplinary experts, led by an experienced Design Master, can find and test a solution very quickly and effectively before even starting programming by following the agile Design Sprint methodology. You will end up with well-discussed decisions and tested prototypes which means that you can save your development resources. You will also involve stakeholders and other team members into a design phase very soon and that means a bigger connection and a better satisfaction with the final solution.
If you are thinking about introducing this design methodology in your project, then definitely have a look at the Google‚Äôs website The Design Sprint. There you can find a comprehensive guide, video examples and other learning sources.
WATCH THE TALK‚Ä¶
Tom Giannattasio, Director of Product at InVision
MY TAKEAWAY‚Ä¶
When thinking about incorporating animations into user interfaces, we should consider its purpose and actually have a good reason for incorporating them. We can think about these purposes for animations:
Explain ‚Äî aid a user‚Äôs understanding of the content,Acquaint ‚Äî aid a user‚Äôs understanding of the architecture,Change ‚Äî switch an element‚Äôs meaning or behaviour,Indicate ‚Äî clarify the current state or the changes to it,Convey ‚Äî build a sense of quality or character,Entertain ‚Äî lighten the mood or occupy the user,Delight ‚Äî surprise with clever craftsmanship,Engage ‚Äî make the user an active participant in the interface.
Have a look at Tom‚Äôs animated presentation with examples.
WATCH THE TALK‚Ä¶
Adrian Zumbrunnen, Freelance UX Engineer at Google
MY TAKEAWAY‚Ä¶
Aiming only for delight when designing animations is not enough. It is about creating meaningful interactions. Animate meaningfully and smartly. Don‚Äôt over animate your product. Focus more on smart motion and micro animations which do give gentle feedback and which explain, navigate and tell the story. Meaningful motion is about keeping your eyes on details.
WATCH THE TALK‚Ä¶
Jan Kvasniƒçka, UX designer
MY TAKEAWAY‚Ä¶
In a mobile era we should optimise our designs for different and small resolutions. The optimisation for phone devices definitely pays off and in the future the impact will be even more significant. When designing for small resolution environments, definitely follow good mobile design principles and patterns. But that design optimisation should be based more importantly on information gathered from user testing and the analysis of real users behaviour.
You can find a lot of screenshots with explanatory notes at Jan‚Äôs article Practical guide to the most common mistakes of mobile and responsive web design (written in Czech only).
WATCH THE TALK (in Czech only)‚Ä¶
Ivana J√≠lekov√°, User Researcher at MSD/Merck
MY TAKEAWAY‚Ä¶Thanks to a quick and informal user testing we can find important things in our products worth improving. And, surprisingly, even cheap and easy changes ‚Äî based on insights from a simple user testing ‚Äî can make the users‚Äô experience way, way much better. Don‚Äôt underestimate the user testing.
In the articles Unusability of Bitcoin ATM and Improvement of Bitcoin ATM (both written in Czech only) is available introduced user experience study with videos taken during the user testing of bitcoin ATM.
WATCH THE TALK (in Czech only)‚Ä¶
It was my very first time at the conference and I was captured by its digital vibe and really enjoyed this special event. I was walking from one talk to another with great interest in what I am about to hear, see and learn. And that is what I am always expecting from such a conference. If you are interested, you can watch all its talks on business, design and development topics at WebExpo Videos.
Thank you to promoters and speakers who prepared an entertaining mix of topics. I hope to see you next time WebExpo!
For more stories see ‚ñ∫ A Designer‚Äôs Thoughts.
Thank you for reading and Happy New Year 2017!
If you enjoyed the article, please clap below to help others find it.
Do you have any question or just an idea for sharing? Feel free to leave a comment below or share it on Twitter.
The article was written by B≈ôetislav ‚ÄúBrett‚Äù Mazoch while working as a designer in England. He moved there from the Czech Republic to follow his traveller‚Äôs dreams and work passion ‚Äî UI/UX Design and Front-end Development.
Visit his Portfolio ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ LinkedIn ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ Twitter ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ Instagram.

Title: Street Photography Locations in Prague: Hradƒçany (Castle District)
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

The home of enthusiastic supporters of Fine Art Photography. We respect its history, admire its present form, and look forward to its future.

--
1
Listen
Share
This is the second piece in my series on street photography locations in Prague, and today, I would like to write about Hradƒçany, the castle district. It‚Äôs a place that holds a special, personal kind of charm ‚Äî not just because of its history and beauty, but because it feels like home to me.
Living just a short, fifteen-minute walk away from the St. Vitus Cathedral, it‚Äôs usually the place where I go to reconnect with the city, camera in hand.
Also, my wife and I have a ritual related to this district: after any trip away from Prague, we head to a spot we simply call ‚ÄúThe Terrace‚Äù, a viewpoint at the intersection of Ke Hradu and Hradƒçansk√© N√°mƒõst√≠, and stand there for five quiet minutes, taking in the sweeping view of the city‚Äôs rooftops and towers and the distant hum of life below. On a quieter day, if there are fewer tourists in front of the Cathedral ‚Äî this area and the nearby Starbucks can get quite busy ‚Äî it‚Äôs a moment to arrive and feel grounded here.
Hradƒçany is a little different from what you might think of when someone talks about street photography. It‚Äôs not the kind of place where you‚Äôll find a bustling crowd or fleeting, dramatic moments.
It‚Äôs quieter here, slower. There aren‚Äôt many chances to catch the apex of a situation, that decisive moment of tension or drama that many associate with the genre. Some might argue this isn‚Äôt street photography at all, more like urban exploration or architectural photography ‚Äî and if you are lucky ‚Äî with a touch of life.
For me, street photography is about finding stories wherever you are, even in quieter moments (also, I am not taking this super-seriously). In Hradƒçany, the stories can be found in more subtle things: a man smoking while standing next to his old ≈†koda Felicia, street musicians waiting for their ride after a day‚Äôs performance, or a lone figure disappearing into a shadowy alley. (Small note here: maybe this slowness is not entirely true to the closest vicinity of the Cathedral, ‚Äúinside‚Äù the castle‚Äôs courtyards, or along Nerudova, which are always full of wandering tourists.)
The district‚Äôs slopes are a recurring theme in my images. The streets here rise and fall unpredictably, creating natural compositions that are both dynamic and harmonious. I often align the roads with the buildings in my shots to emphasize the incline. And, for reasons I can‚Äôt fully explain, most of my photos here end up in portrait orientation. It‚Äôs a pattern I just noticed when I walked through the photographs I took in this area. Perhaps it‚Äôs the verticality of the streets and facades, and because of the narrow streets, this feels more natural, as I can include more of the buildings and make the photos cleaner.
Outside the crowded heart of the castle complex, Hradƒçany feels almost untouched. Streets like Nov√Ω Svƒõt, ƒåern√≠nsk√°, and almost up to Poho≈ôelec, reveal a different side of the district, where life seems to unfold at its own pace. Some of the old houses here are waiting for renovation, their faded walls and crooked windows adding layers of texture and character. These are the streets where you can find children on their phones in front of an old church ‚Äî now a hotel, funnily enough ‚Äî and these quiet, everyday scenes are what I sometimes find compelling to photograph. It might not fit the usual mold of street photography, but it can still be satisfying.
In conclusion, Hradƒçany isn‚Äôt about fast-paced action or dramatic moments; it‚Äôs about the quiet interplay of people and place. The district invites you to slow down, pay attention, and appreciate the timeless vibe it has to offer. If you‚Äôre a photographer seeking calm, understated beauty, this might just be the perfect spot for you.
Thanks for reading to the end! If you enjoyed this or have any thoughts, I‚Äôd appreciate your üëè claps and comments ‚Äî see you in the next chapter!

Content:

Last night I flew back from my first live international conference. Being flown abroad to speak was an exciting milestone in my career! The first day the ~20 international speakers had breakfast at the hotel, went on a guided walking tour of Prague, lunch together out, and then met up with the ~50 local speakers plus the mentors, round table facilitators, and everyone else, for an icebreaker and dinner, followed by the first party where early attendees joined. It was a whirlwind. Then the conference began.
Main takeaway from my time with the international speakers ‚Äî we all feel a little ‚Äúfake it til you make it‚Äù. All making last minute adjustments to our slides and practicing one (or three) last time(s) in our hotel rooms. You might not guess that from the impression we give on stage, or on paper. Why is that important? It means no one should be afraid to apply to speak, too. It was a very humble group. From the most well-known to those speaking for the first time, 100% of the speakers were down to earth, friendly, and excited to be there.
Which led to a really interesting conversation over lunch between some of the international speakers and one of the conference organizers: why aren‚Äôt there more new faces and how do we change that?
Part of the problem is the built-in bias of speaker applications ‚Äî new voices didn‚Äôt apply. Women and minorities didn‚Äôt apply. That put the organizers in a pickle, who desperately wanted a more diverse lineup.
Then there was the part about some of the new-voice applications not being as good, which makes sense, these are people with less experience. The conference is only as good as its content and keeping a super high standard is critical for success.
We started brainstorming what we, the experienced speakers and conference organizers, could do to change that. How do we get more, better applications from inexperienced speakers? A whole bunch of ideas were thrown out and it was reassuring to hear that this is a common value for the people who are most empowered to make change. (I also suggested getting in touch with Button organizers because in my opinion they are trail blazers in getting DEI right. Will let the WebExpo organizers catch their breath before picking that back up where we left it :)
My talk didn‚Äôt go as well as I‚Äôd hoped. I‚Äôm a pretty harsh critic of myself so I‚Äôve spent a huge amount of energy analyzing why. My conclusions:
All in all, WebExpo was an amazing experience! Being on my own away from my family which is a very very very rare occurrence; being abroad which, other than the US, I haven‚Äôt done in years; the shear size of the conference and venue; being an invited international speaker. I‚Äôm sure I‚Äôll be processing for a while and what it means for the types of opportunities I want to take on next.

Content:

First of all, it‚Äôs so fantastic to have such industry-oriented ML conference around. Focusing on deliverable impact, but without irritating business content. Diving into comprehensible theory, but without overhyped papers. All is just set right. Moreover, it‚Äôs hard to imagine a better place for this than historical Rudolfinum building in the cultural heart of central Europe: Prague.
In this blog post, I‚Äôm sharing some of my notes from this conference.
Walking around the conference building and having talks with industry representatives, I noticed three basic prototypes of modern ML-driven industries:
The good part about these segments is that the people were authentic, so you could quickly decide how is it beneficial to keep the conversation.
Overall there were almost 50 talks and I haven‚Äôt watched all of them. I was convinced to attend only if there was a resonating company, person or an academy. The content and talk title doesn‚Äôt guarantee anything.
Anomaly detection talks use to provide a completely new way / paradigm of finding data inconsistencies. In this case, it was Quantum Mechanics, which partially triggered me since the proposed algorithm had only a single weak property in common with QM. As a former physicist, I have a particular dislike of self-anointed ‚Äúdiscoveries‚Äù, unclear analogies and buzzwording.
Apart from this, I have to admit, the algorithm itself for generating locally similar bitmaps is quite impressive. See here: https://github.com/mxgmn/WaveFunctionCollapse
Algebraic Topology, as a subfield of mathematics and space analysis, is inevitably emerging as a useful way of thinking while solving problems in multidimensional spaces. In this talk, Leland McInnes drafted the idea of using manifolds, functors and other fancy abstractions, leading to the UMAP algorithm: a string dimensionality reduction technique, similar to the famous t-SNE.
He also shared the presentation on Twitter so you can look by yourself:https://speakerdeck.com/lmcinnes/learning-topology-topological-methods-for-unsupervised-learning
Clearly the best story-telling talk of the conference. Starting with a market fit (although a controversial one), poor 1st model, continuing in augmentation and preprocessing, tuning and finishing with the representative output. That‚Äôs how the ML story should be told.
This one really surprised me. Fast-growing companies such as Spotify usually don‚Äôt speak a lot about their used technologies, techniques and best practices. They rather retain the hype and promise a lot. Not in this case.
Marc Romeyn from Spotify revealed quite a lot and it was stunning. However, it seemed to me the talk was shortened from an around 1h long one to the restricted 30 mins. It was not possible to keep up with the speaker‚Äôs flow and the content on slides.
For more info, I recommend to check out the Spotify‚Äôs official technology blog:https://labs.spotify.com
It‚Äôs interesting to find out there are modern artists using ML to investigate creativity.
A beautiful choice for the ending talk of the conference :)
AI gallery link: http://www.aiartonline.com/
That‚Äôs the main statement at the front of the MLprague‚Äôs page and cannot be more eloquent. Personally, I appreciate all the work done by organisers in order to fulfil this mission. However, I‚Äôm also going to point out a few drawbacks and I will help myself with other quotes from the webpage:
I can confirm this was true in most cases. Sometimes, I would appreciate more time invested in a preparation for speaker's talk and, surprisingly, less content. The most interesting lectures had much to say, but they were so rich that they would be better at half-speed.
Next, one of the key parameters for enjoying the talk is the perfect sound balance in the lecture room. This was not well set on the ground floor. Thus I was recommended many times to go upstairs and find a seat near the loudspeakers where the sound was much cleaner and without echoes.
Also, I heavily missed the Slido (Q&A platform) during the talks. Many on-point questions were unrevealed in the end. I think it was a reaction after last year's hates and jokes that appeared. This can be fixed by moderation.
Great initiative to offer local foods / standards, really. However the international kitchen has moved to a more healthy level, so constantly offering baguettes and no salads or fruits is not a good idea.
Nevertheless, it was a well-organised conference! I‚Äôm returning home to refresh and looking forward to the next year edition.
PS: If you are a student and don‚Äôt have money to pay for this conference, it is possible to go as a volunteer. And it‚Äôs absolutely feasible to do the work and enjoy the content besides. PM me or directly the organisers for more info :)
